column2: Ghaziabad extends vacation till Tuesday, but not Noida
column3: NOIDA/GHAZIABAD: Taking a cue from Delhi, which ordered a shutdown of all schools till Class VIII for one week (till July 8), the Ghaziabad administration has ordered the same for two days (till July2) in wake of the severe heatwave. Ghaziabad district magistrate Ritu Maheshwari has ordered an extention of the summer vacations of schools in the district. The schools, private and government, which were supposed to open on July 1 will now reopen on July 3. Meanwhile, Gautam Budh Nagar DM B N Singh has refrained from giving any such order. “The heatwave is definitely more than it should be in July, but I have not ordered a shutdown of schools in the district,” Singh told TOI. Besides, according to Singh, the Uttar Pradesh government has initiated a one-month ‘school chalo abhiyan’ (go-to-school campaign) across the state, and it will run from July 1 to 31 across all government schools. “Shutting down schools in such a scenario will lead to a derailment of the campaign,” he said. In Ghaziabad, government schools have been asked to continue with the campaign and also hold the pre-decided rally under the initiative on July 1.

column2: Ghaziabad: No power in Crossings, locals spend night on road
column3: GHAZIABAD: Some residents of the city had to bear with the deadly summer cocktail of soaring temperatures and long hours of power cuts on Saturday. The residents of GH-7 society in Crossings Republik were forced to spend the entire Saturday night on roads, parks and cars due to continuous power outage. The situation was aggravated after diesel generator sets of two towers (7 and 8) of the society malfunctioned. According to the residents, the power supply was interrupted by the electricity department in Crossings Republik from 11 pm on Saturday to 6.30 am on Sunday due to some local fault. They blamed the Crossings Infra Private Ltd (CIPL), a group of private developers who provide and maintain basic amenities in the township for a monthly payment, for its failure to provide power supply through DG sets. Vishal Tripathi, a resident, said, “There are 336 flats in towers 7 and 8 of the society, in which 1,400 people live. There was no power in the two towers for over four hours. There are several elderly people and children, who had a harrowing time on Saturday in this hot and humid weather. The CIPL is least interested to look into our problems. We kept making calls to the officials, but in vain.” Rohit Chaudhary, president of GH7, said, “The society does not have an estate manager for the past two months. The problem with the specific DG sets has been persisting for the past many years. We spoke to the CIPL’s senior officials, but no action was taken to rectify them.” Residents complained that a similar incident had taken place three weeks ago, yet DG set issue was not resolved. Kameshwar Prasad Pandey, deputy general manager (electricity), CIPL, denied the allegations that DG power supply was interrupted for four hours. “At present, DG sets are required to be switched on manually. So every time it takes around 15 minutes to start them. On Monday, we are going to replace them with automatic ones.”

column2: Pink letterboxes in Ghaziabad for schoolgirls
column3: GHAZIABAD: After pink jackets for anti-Romeo squads, Ghaziabad police have decided to install pink letterboxes in all private as well as government schools in the district, where girl students can drop anonymous complaints of harassment. Moreover, following Noida police, they are also planning to issue red cards to eve-teasers through anti-Romeo squads. SSP Upendra Kumar Agrawal said the department would study the initiative first before implementing it here. “It is a good initiative and there is no harm in implementing it. But before doing so we will study it,” the SSP said. As far as installation of letterboxes is concerned SP (City) Shlok Kumar said, “Every week school principals and the SHOs of the concerned area will open the letterboxes and go through the letters. Based on the complaints, an investigation would be done and remedial action would be taken accordingly.” Talking about the one-month special drive on girl security, SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun said “Every day each of the 16 police stations will conduct an awareness class where students would be apprised about safety measures. Special teams have been formed for this purpose.” The anti-Romeo squads, which have been reactivated in the district following the order of UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath, will don a distinctive pink jacket with florescent strips while conducting patrolling near schools, colleges and public places at specific times during the day. In the second inning, the squads will look more organised in its functioning as specific timings have been fixed for their working. Now, each of the 16 police stations of the district has a dedicated anti-Romeo squad headed by a sub-inspector. Other members include constables and head constables. Police are also ensuring the presence of at least one female cop in the squad. UP minister Suresh Kumar Khanna, who is in-charge of Ghaziabad, took a crime review meeting on Sunday. He urged cops to maintain discipline and behave politely with the public.

column2: Teen abducted, gang-raped in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: Just 24 hours after the horrific gang rape of a class VIII girl in a government school at Maholi in Sitapur, another gang rape of a minor girl was reported from Sadarpur area in the same district. A case has been registered against five persons. The teen told police that she was abducted and raped at gunpoint. The 13-year-old survivor told police that she had gone to attend nature’s call some distance away from her residence in the evening on Friday, June 27. “Two youths of another village came and pointed a pistol at me and took me to a secluded place where three others were present. They raped me in turns,” the survivor told police in her complaint. The accused dumped the traumatised survivor near her house in the wee hours of June 28 and fled, said police. A profusely bleeding survivor reached home and narrated her ordeal to her parents, but her family informed police on Sunday. Police said a case of gang rape has been registered against five persons and efforts are on to arrest them. Sitapur SP L R Kumar told TOI, “The survivor has said in her statement that she was gang-raped at gun point.” The preliminary medical reports of the survivor ruled out gang rape but a detailed report is awaited, he added.

column2: Cover expressway to Agra in less than 3 hours, get challaned
column3: LUCKNOW: To curb speeding that has turned Lucknow-Agra expressway into a death trap, commuters would be slapped with a challan if they cover the 302km distance in less than three hours. This was announced on Sunday by officials of UP Expressway Industrial Development Authority (UPEIDA), who set a speed limit of 100km/hour on the e-way. Chief executive officer, UPEIDA, Avanish Awasthi, said data collected at two toll plazas — one near Lucknow and another at Agra — will be collated to assess time taken by commuters to cover the distance between the twin toll plazas. “Errant vehicles will be photographed and an echallan sent to the police in Agra and Lucknow. The process has begun and 25 commuters have been fined, he said. Spiralling cases of accidents on the expressway have been attributed to speeding. Agra e-way prone to accidents Two days ago, seven people died when a double-decker private sleeper bus rammed a sand laden truck near Fatehabad on Agra-Lucknow expressway. On June 21, three persons, including a techie employed with a Noidabased firm were killled when their car rammed a cargo container parked on the side lane of the expressway. In May, another five people died and at least 30 injured near Devkhari village near Bangarmau police station. A bus carrying passengers from Delhi to Bihar overturned after hitting a tractor trolley.

column2: Where’s night patrol? Bullets fly near Durgapuri Metro station, 1 dead
column3: LUCKNOW: Cocking a snook at claims of stringent night patrolling, two assailants opened fire on two businessmen and looted Rs 2 lakh near Durgapuri Metro station in Alambagh on Sunday night. The victims, Manoj Bhattacharya (45) and Ashu Bajaj (48) were rushed to KGMU Trauma Centre, where the former was declared brought dead. “Around 10pm, Bhattacharya went to drop Bajaj, a dealer of digital wrist watches in Delhi, to Charbagh railway station on a two-wheeler. When the duo reached near Durgapuri Metro station, two bikeborne youths intercepted them and a verbal spat ensued. In a fit of rage, the man riding pillion opened fire on Bhattacharya and the bullet pierced his shoulder. Before Bajaj realised, several rounds were fired and one of the bullets also grazed past him,” said Sanjeev Sinha, circle officer, Alambagh. Assailants fled with cash bagBefore fleeing, the accused took away a bag stashed with Rs 2 lakh and clothes, Sinha said. Hearing gun shots, locals rushed to the spot and informed the police. Police took the injured to a hospital in Alambagh, where doctors referred them to KGMU trauma centre. IG Lucknow range SK Bhagat told TOI the motive of the murder is yet to the ascertained. “Prima facie it seems an argument took place between businessmen and killers over a monetary issue. But it is yet to be substantiated," he added.

column2: Stifled at home, Bihar boys take train to Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: Four boys, the youngest 9-year-old and eldest 12, ran away from their homes in Aurangabad, Bihar, on being scolded for remaining glued to the television and watching cricket world cup matches. The boys stole money from their homes and took a train to Lucknow. A team of city police, alerted about the boys boarding a train to Lucknow, found them having breakfast at a restaurant in Naka Hindola on Sunday. Naka SHO, Sujeet Dubey said the boys, residents of one colony, were watching the New Zealand-Australia match on June 25 when they were scolded by their parents. "Hurt by the scolding, they planned to leave their homes and go on a holiday alone. They went to railway station and boarded a train," added Dubey. Their parents got apprehensive when they couldn't find them and informed police which checked the CCTV footage at bus and railway stations. The railway station footage showed them boarding a Lucknow-bound train. Aurangabad police alerted Naka police which started looking around in parks and restaurants in Charbagh. "The boys said that they had chalked out a 15-day tour. They said they were never taken on outing and were not allowed to watch cricket," he said. "We thought of enjoying a ride in Metro train and being away for 15 days so that our parents realize and let us do what we want," said the eldest.

column2: Morning rain tames mercury, monsoon to hit Lucknow tomorrow
column3: LUCKNOW: The weather went on a roller-coaster ride on Sunday with heavy premonsoon showers bringing relief in the morning, but the blistering sun returning to torment citizens along with high humidity by noon. The good news is that hot and sultry days may finally be over, as the monsoon current that was stuck over Sultanpur-Lakhimpur Kheri, around 150km from the state capital, is inching closer to the city and may tiptoe in by Tuesday. State Met director JP Gupta said a low-pressure area over the Bay of Bengal was likely to intensify on Monday. “It will fuel moisture incursion into the atmosphere and propel the southwest monsoon lying dormant over Sultanpur-Lakhimpur Kheri. The current will cover some more parts of the state, including Lucknow, by Tuesday-Wednesday,” he said. Sporadic pre-monsoon rain began around 6.30am and continued till 8am, with downpour for around 30 minutes in between. The maximum temperature at 36.1°C stayed well below the oppressive mark, but relative humidity at 84% kicked up the the discomfort index (DI) to 34.1 degrees. In Met parlance, it is “severe” and “detrimental to health”. The DI at night was 21.1 degrees. No significant change in temperatures is expected on Monday. The maximum will hover around 37°C and minimum around 23°C degrees Celsius, although there are possibilities of another round of pre-monsoon showers, besides partly cloudy skies. Light to moderate rainfall is expected on Tuesday and Wednesday while widespread and heavy showers have been predicted for Thursday. Power pangs amid premonsoonshowers:The showers triggered marathon power cuts in areas like Husainganj, Charbagh, Lalbagh, Kaiserbagh, Wazirganj, Victoria Street, Shahmeena Road, Aishbagh, Mawwaiya, some parts of Gomtinagar, Aliganj, Purania and many adjoining areas. Lesa chief engineer Madhukar Verma said: “There was a power shutdown for few minutes in some areas, which was due to ongoing renovation work.”

column2: What’s vulgarity? Panel to find out yet to be formed
column3: LUCKNOW: Though the district administration on Saturday, reaffirmed its four-year old stand on “no-vulgarity in clothing or activity” inside Imambara premises to honour the religious sanctity of the historic Shia shrine, its promise to clerics and Shia community that a committee will be set up to hammer out decency norms still rings hollow. On June 26, 2015, after the 20-day stir led by Shia cleric Maulana Kalbe Jawaad, seeking a dress code at the Bada and Chhota Imambara among other demands, it was announced that a verbal agreement had been reached on forming an Imambara Committee. The panel was supposed to include senior Shia clerics, historians and members of the Awadh royal family to decide on do’s and don’ts inside the 235-year-old Imambara, including dress norms. But, after four years, no such committee was formed and the decency quotient remains fuzzy. Talking to TOI on Sunday, Maulana Kalbe Jawad, said, “IAS officer Navneet Sehgal and then district magistrate (DM) Raj Shekhar, had assured us that a committee will be formed. However, nothing was done. I was never consulted on any decision on the Imambaras. We demand that norms followed in Delhi’s Jama Masjid and Amritsar’s Golden Temple, where tourists are cover their heads and legs, should also be enforced at Imambaras, which are our live religious monuments.” However, the district magistrate, Kaushal Raj Sharma, said, while the committee is yet to be formed, necessary action is being taken. “Even without a committee, we have been doing the needful. We are aware of cleanliness and maintenance issues. And we keep getting letters and suggestions from people and we take note of them.” He also said, “It would be controversial to make such a committee since the Shia community has several clerics, many of whom hold opposing views. The monuments are a trust of the government and we are taking good care of them.” The district administration is currently in control of the Husainabad and Allied Trust (HAT) which was a Nawabi-era body formed to look into management of monuments in the Husainabad area.

column2: Dress code fuzzy: Day after DM’s order, confusion rules
column3: LUCKNOW: In the absence of any written order by district administration on the dress code and no clarity over the definition of ‘decency’, confusion prevailed among tourists visiting the Bada Imambara on Sunday. Some heated arguments between tourists and guides kept happening throughout the day with some returning home disappointed. The district administration later said that a final order on what is ‘decent’, will be issued in few days and put on boards at various spots in Imambara. Tourists arriving at Imambara were checked by Husainabad and Allied Trust (HAT) employees for inappropriate clothes. When the employees were asked to produce a written order, they failed to produce any. Guides at the main hall entrance which leads to shahnasheen (sanctum sanctorum), were seen handing out dupattas to tourists for covering their heads while entering the hall. Mubashir Ali, a worker, told TOI, “Heads are to be covered ever since an agitation was launched in 2015. But yesterday, we were been asked to be extra vigilant since the district administration’s meeting and the fact that action will be taken against employees if obscenity is reported anywhere in Imambara.” District magistrate, Kaushal Raj Sharma, who is also the ex-officio chairperson of HAT, said, “Everyone is expected to maintain decency while entering a mosque, temple or gurdwara, and the same is expected of tourists coming to Bada Imambara. The emotional religious value of Imambara cannot be overlooked, we have to find a balance.” “There is no dress code but tourists,both men andwomen, wearing shorts or skirts will be denied entry. Covering head is optional since we cannot enforce any orthodox rule to tick away tourists,” he added. (With inputs from Niba Mirza)

column2: Google Maps cracks Gudamba whodunit, widow's son arrested
column3: LUCKNOW: Phone history on Google Maps helped police nab 20-year-old Devendra Yadav on Sunday for killing his mother Prema Yadav at their Gudamba home on Friday allegedly because she refused to give him his share of property and also didn't approve of the fact that he wanted to marry his cousin. Prema, a widow and mother of seven, was found dead with a bullet wound in the head in their courtyard. The breakthrough came when police detained Devendra and found discrepancies in his words and actions. The youth had said he had no phone, but police found one on him. "The location alibis he offered didn't match with what was showing on his Google Maps history. On being grilled, he broke down and confessed to the crime. He led police to the murder weapon hidden in a hay stack," said Ghazipur CO Deepak Kumar Singh.

column2: UPPSC toppers & now top babus to face CBI quiz today
column3: LUCKNOW: CBI has summoned 110 successful candidates of 2011-15 provincial civil services exam and the additional private secretary test of 2010 to probe irregularities in recruitment. Many of those called for quizzing are UPPSC toppers, currently deputy collectors or posted at UP Secretariat. The investigating agency is probing discrepancies in exams conducted during the tenure of Akhilesh Yadav between April 1, 2012 and March 31, 2017. APS recruitment is the only exam which started during Mayawati’s stint as the notification was issued when she was CM, but the exam was held in 2016. CBI has sent summons through e-mail and post from its Delhi-based headquarters after a week-long investigation at UPPSC office in Allahabad. The probe team headed by additional superintendent of police Chandradeep will be questioning the officers from Monday. Also, UPPSC employees involved in recruitments from 2012 to 2017 and the complainants have also been summoned. They have been asked to carry documents to justify their claims and allegations. The candidates who successfully cleared the Combined State Upper Subordinate Examination-2015 or PCS-2015, PCS-2011, review officer/assistant review officer exam-2014 and Lower State Upper Subordinate Examination-2013 have been called for questioning. “We need clarifications on pattern of symbols used in answer scripts revealing identity of candidates and the moderation/scaling methodology adopted by UPPSC in the civil services test. They cannot be termed accused, but it’s expected truth will come out after questioning,” said an official. Sources said, the successful candidates are required to divulge income details before and after the exams, their contacts with commission officials, conversations on phone or any link with a political family. The CBI team took away three van loads of documents and answer scripts after investigation in the administrative and examination sections of the commission till Saturday late night. The probe agency has lodged an FIR against UPPSC officials on charges of irregularities in selection process of PCS-2015.

column2: Biodiversity parks along Ganga in 27 districts to battle pollution in lifeline
column3: LUCKNOW: Cleaning Ganga through phytoremediation is what the Yogi government has on its mind. It is a lowcost, solar energy-driven technique that uses plants to remove pollutants from water. To clean a river, the water must be channelled through boulders to filter it and then held up in retention ponds. These ponds have certain naturally growing plant species that help increase the level of dissolved oxygen in water. The government, following directives from National Green Tribunal, has preliminarily identified sites in at least 22 of the 27 districts through which the Ganga flows. Biodiversity parks complete with retention ponds will be developed at these sites, which are also likely to boast tourist attractions such as nature trails and butterfly parks. “The parks will be along the banks of Ganga,” said member-secretary, UP Pollution Control Board, Ashish Tiwari and added that retention ponds would be fenced off to thwart unwanted interference in phytoremediation. The state pollution watchdog is expected to submit a detailed project report (DPR) on biodiversity parks in all the 27 concerned districts by August. Before that and acting on NGT orders, the government will notify the floodplain area of Ganga by July 15. A floodplain is the maximum area that a river has flooded in 25 years. Though the river may not rise that high every year, demarcating it in a way marks the area that a river may engulf. The area also needs protection against squatters. The irrigation department and the Central Water Commission conducted a survey to demarcate Ganga’s floodplain in the state. Once the area is marked and notified, not only will it help remove encroachment but also define activities that will be illegal in the area. It may result in more space for biodiversity parks that are meant to generate awareness. The parks will be developed by the forest department. In several districts, the department has its own land. For instance in Moradabad, a deer park on the banks of Ramganga can be further developed into a biodiversity park.

column2: UP: BJP internal survey to track those who sabotaged party in LS polls
column3: LUCKNOW: While gearing up for the much-anticipated membership drive, BJP in Uttar Pradesh has begun an internal survey to identify and expel those who indulged in anti-party activity during the recently concluded Lok Sabha elections. The party bagged 62 seats against its target of 74, despite SPBSP forging a pre-poll alliance. The party brass sought a report from different districts to identify party functionaries — many of whom were denied tickets — who worked against party line to restrict BJP from winning more seats. The internal survey covers sitting BJP MLAs and MPs, who instead of doing their bit, tried to sabotage chances. BJP denied tickets to a number of sitting MPs in the run-up to Lok Sabha elections. Confirming the development, UP BJP vice-president JPS Rathore said reports have been sought from all districts. He said even after 2017 UP assembly elections, when BJP got an overwhelming mandate, the party expelled 87 members and issued notices to 303 party functionaries for not adhering to party norms. “It’s on the high command to take action,’’ said Rathore. The BJP versus BJP battle was being fought in over 12 constituencies where the party denied tickets to sitting MPs, who not only held demonstrations in their constituencies, but also wrote to the party high command. While two BJP MPs Ashul Varma from Hardoi, and Shyama Charan Gupta from Allahabad, joined SP after being denied tickets, Ashok Dohre joined Congress. BJP denied tickets to 16 sitting MPs and changed constituencies of four MPs. The MPs denied tickets include Satyapal Saini (Sambhal) , Nepal Singh (Rampur), Rajesh Diwakar (Hathras) , Chaudhary Babu Lal (Fatehpur Sikri) , Krishna Raj (Shahjahanpur), Anshul Varma (Hardoi), Anju Bala (Misrikh), Ashok Dohre (Etawah), M M Joshi (Kanpur), Uma Bharti (Jhansi) , Shyama Charan Gupta (Allahabad), Priyanka Rawat (Barabanki) , Savitri Bai Phule (Bahraich) , Rajesh Pandey (Kushinagar), Kalraj Misra (Deoria) and Bharat Singh (Ballia). The four MPs whose constituencies were changed include Maneka Gandhi (from Pilibhit to Sultanpur), Ram Shankar Katheria (from Agra to Etawah). Varun Gandhi (from Sultanpur to Pilibhit) and Virendra Singh Mast (from Bhadohi to Ballia).

column2: UP bypolls: Where the die is 'caste'
column3: LUCKNOW: The process to issue caste certificates to members of the 17 MBCs, which were included in the SC list, could not have come at a more appropriate time in Uttar Pradesh, though the issue was raised for the first time in 2005 and remained mired in controversy. The move is likely to give the BJP an edge in the upcoming assembly bypolls in 12 constituencies in the state in the wake of several MLAs getting elected to the Lok Sabha in the recent parliamentary elections, say political observers. The 17 OBC castes that have been included in the Scheduled Caste list are Nishad, Bind, Mallah, Kewat, Kashyap, Bhar, Dhivar, Batham, Machua, Prajapati, Rajbhar, Kahar, Kumhar, Dhimar, Manjhi, Turaha and Gaudia. A directive issued by the the UP administration says caste certificates will be issued after thorough verification, a move that could steal the opposition's thunder, especially of the SP and the BSP which have tried to sympathise with these 17 Most Backward Classes (MBC) in the past by attempting to bring them in the SC bracket. These MBC groups constitute nearly 13 per cent of the total backward population in the caste-politics dominated state and can make or mar the electoral prospects of a party or candidate. The missive was sent to all divisional commissioners and district magistrates by Principal Secretary Manoj Singh instructing them to comply with a 2017 Allahabad High Court order which said caste certificates being issued to people belonging to these 17 categories will be that of Scheduled Caste "subject to outcome of an ongoing writ petition". The district officials have been asked to start the process of issuing caste certificates to these most backward castes that have been included in the SC list by the Yogi Adityanath government. The Adityanath government had been trying to put the 17 other backward castes in the SC list for a long time. The reason given was that these castes figured very low on the social and economic indices. Being in the other backward class category had not improved their standard of living and the objective was to bring them under the SC list. A senior official explained that the direct advantage of putting them in the SC category will entitle them to reservation quota and other benefits announced by the government from time to time. Earlier, then SP and BSP governments too had made efforts in this regard, but did not succeed. It was in 2005 that the issue was raised for the first time when the then Mulayam Singh Yadav government had issued an order to this effect. It was seen as the SP stalwart's ploy to win over the 17 MBCs who felt left out and neglected in the backward quota as the pie went to the creamy layer of the dominant Yadav, Kurmi and Lodhis in government schemes and programmes, as well as admission in educational institutions. But, the order ran into rough weather when the high court stayed it following which the proposal was sent to the Centre. Two years later, when Mayawati came to power, she rejected the proposal but later wrote to the Centre extending her support. The Akhilesh Yadav government revived the move again in December 2016 and the proposal was cleared by the state cabinet ahead of the UP Assembly elections. A formal request to include these 17 castes was sent to the Centre, but the matter somehow got stuck with the Union Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment. While hearing a Public Interest Litigation moved by Gorakhpur-based Dr Bhim Rao Ambedkar Granthalaya Evam Jan Kalyan, which fights for SC rights, challenging the government decision, the court had made it clear that any caste certificate issued will be subject to the outcome of the writ petition. Scheduled Caste groups apprehend that the move of the Adityanath government might dent their quota as the new entrants would consume their share if their reservation limit was not expanded.

column2: ‘Was beaten black & blue, cop crushed my fingers with boot’
column3: LUCKNOW: He still can’t stand stable and starts shuddering on being asked to recall the nightmare he faced in a police station lock-up. Manish Kumar (14) is unable to walk, and is currently admitted in the orthopaedics ward of Civil hospital. The boy was picked by the police while probing an erickshaw theft. He had taken that e-rickshaw on rent and earned his livelihood from it. However, it got stolen and the owner lodged a complaint with the police which made boy a suspect. His father, Ram Kumar, a labourer, mother Shanti Devi and elder brother Ashish Kumar are by his side, the sibling seething in anger against police highhandedness. Manish says, “Police took metoPGI policestation put me in lock-up and beated me black and blue. The two-hour torture will torment me whole life.” “On June 27, around 6pm, there was a knock on the door. My mother opened it and saw cops standing. She came inside and told me that they had come to inquire. As soon as I went outside, they pushed me into a jeep and took me away,” he said. One policeman came and told me to confess that I had stolen an e-rickshaw. He returned after 20 minutes and asked me, but I refused,” he added. “Then it started. Three cops came inside the lock-up, pushed me and then kept hitting me in my leg with a stick for over 20 minutes and posed the same question again. When I again answered in a ‘no’, a cop crushed my fingers with his boots and thrashed me brutally,” said Manish and he started weeping again. Shanti intervened, “I prostrated before the SHO of SGPGI police station and pleaded him to release my innocentson.” “The police released me around 8pm,” added Manish.

column2: MBCs happy with quota move, SCs feel it will eat into their pie
column3: LUCKNOW: The most backward castes (MBCs) in Uttar Pradesh, who have been looking at an uncertain future, are now happy to have found a place in the Scheduled Caste category. On Friday, the UP government decided to include 17 categories of MBCs, which comprise nearly 14 per cent of MBCs, under the Scheduled Caste umbrella following a 2017 Allahabad high court order. Various commissions and committees, over the last 50 years, have recommended to the state government that there were certain most backward castes which were being denied the fruits of reservation, hence necessitating a quota-within-quota policy for their focussed development and uplift. However, government in the past have not dared to do this, fearing a backlash. “This is a historic decision as there are a number of castes in the MBC category which are living in an inferior socio-economic condition as compared to SCs. The Yogi government’s decision will end their exploitation,” said SPS Baghel, who was dairy development minister before being elected as an MP in the recent general elections. Dharambir Prajapati, chairman of the Maati Kala Board, said that the decision would revolutionise the socio-economic lives of the MBCs as they had been struggling since decades to get settled. “In the wake of technological advances and introduction of plastic products, lakhs of potters from the Kumhar caste have been rendered idle as earthen pots were discarded and replaced with plastic and paper products,” said Prajapati. BJP vice-president Prashant Pal also welcomed the government’s decision by saying that no government had ever looked into the problems of castes in the backward categories which were dependent on their occupations like fishing, boating, pottery and other such livelihoods that are being hit by modern techonology. Contrary to this enthusiasm and jubilation in the MBC camp, mood in the SC category is of anger and resentment, as it fears that reservation for them would be shared by more people within that limit. Bhawan Nath Paswan, national president of Dr Ambedkar Rashtriya Ekta Manch and vice-president of the SC, Backward and Minorities Employees Federation’, warned that it would be opposed until the quota for the SCs was not expanded. RK Chaudhary, a Congress leader and formerly a BSP stalwart, said that unless the reservation limit for SCs was increased to 32 per cent, the move will hit the SC population.

column2: Drunk men thrash BJP youth leader
column3: KANPUR: Divisional secretary of Bharatiya Janata Party Yuva Morcha (BJPYM), Prashant Sharma, was brutally assaulted by group of drunk men when he tried to make their video from his mobile phone while they were drinking at a public place and troubling people in Naubasta area of Kanpur on late Saturday night. The incident occurred when Prashant, who runs a medical store, tried to shoot the video of one Chunnu, an auto driver and his aides, who were allegedly consuming liquor in public and causing trouble to the passersby. As soon as Chunnu saw Prashant filming his and his aides activities, he attacked him with sticks and iron rods. Sharma then used his mobile phone to call police to his rescue, but they also snatched his mobile phone and broke it. The attackers fled the spot after people started to gather there. The locals then alerted police who took the injured to a hospital. "An FIR has been lodged and searches are underway to arrest the accused. The victim's medical examination has been conducted," said police.

column2: It feels good to hear that now people are also raising their voice for the men: Bidita Bag
column3: Actress Bidita Bag, who shot to fame with the film Babumoshai Bandookbaaz, was in Lucknow, recently. Here for personal commitments, Bidita talks about why #Mentoo movement is necessary, about being choosy regarding roles, her obsession with Lakhnavi chikan and more. Bidita visited a local chikan shop on her recent visit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Bidita visited a local chikan shop on her recent visit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Having been to Lucknow several times, Bidita has a special liking not only for the local food but also for Lakhnavi chikan. Reminiscing about how she fell in love with the traditional embroidery style from Lucknow, she shares, "The first chikan sari I ever saw was my mother’s as a kid. Since then I have been in love with Lakhnavi chikan." "Later, when I stepped into the fashion industry, I came to know that several big designers buy chikan fabric from Lucknow. And after little modifications or say styling, they label it and sell it as their own. I found that very interesting and always thought of coming to Lucknow and buying chikan. Babumoshai Bandookbaaz gave me that opportunity and I remember buying a yellow sari and wearing the same sari I had gone to meet the then CM of UP," adds Bidita. Since then, the T for Taj Mahal actress has developed an obsession for buying chikan clothes whenever she is in Lucknow. She says, "Uske baad se toh jo mujhe chikan ke kapde khareedne ki latt lagi hai, ki ek almirah poora ussi se bhara hua hai. Kuch 8-10 white saris ke alaava mere pass saare pastel shades hain. Jab bhi Lucknow aati hoon, dekhti hoon kuchh naya style mil raha hai chikan mein. So every time I come here my budget for chikan clothes has been going up." A popular actress in Bengali cinema, Bidita has been doing meaningful roles and has been selective about offers coming her way. "I have a very simple logic when it comes to choosing roles, the films which I would not like to go and watch, I am not going to do such films even if I get more money for it. Mann nahi maanta." "I prefer doing content-driven films. That’s why I choose subjects which are interesting, but then not everything is in our hands, sometimes subject bhi hamein chunte hain," she says. Having been vocal about the #Metoo movement, Bidita, who has been part of the fashion industry also, comes out in full support of the #Mentoo movement too. "While there is no doubt about the efficacy of the #Metoo movement, as it has happened with most females in India, from a 6 month-child to a 100-year-old lady, at some point or the other. But I think #Mentoo is also necessary because men are also victims of fake rape cases, harassment and even their friends laugh at them when they reveal to them, 'ki yaar ladki tere saath aisa kar sakti hai, tujhe toh enjoy karna chahiya tha'. So ladke hi ladkon ko seriously nahi lete. I know many such boys, especially in fashion industry, where they face so much exploitation. Uske baare mein toh kai ladke baat bhi nahi karte hain. But aisa hota hai, film industry mein bhi hota hai and corporates mein bhi. It feels good to hear that now people are also raising their voice for the men. Main apne ko feminist nahi, manist kehti hoon kyunki mujhe lagta hai ki jab ladkiyon ke liye ladke awaaza uthane lagenge and vice versa hoga, tabhi gender equality possible hai," says Bidita as she signs off.

column2: Book land grabbers, send them to jail: DM to officials
column3: KANPUR: The district administration on Monday directed the officials to lodge FIRs against those grabbing government land and send them to jail. Addressing a review meeting, district magistrate (DM) Vijay Vishwas Pant told the officials to launch a comprehensive campaign against big land sharks, free government land from their possession and sent them to jail. He also asked the officials of various government departments to prepare a list of illegal possessions on their lands and take action against the encroachers. In a specific direction to KDA officials, the DM asked them to fence the land which was cleared from encroachers and lodge FIR against habitual trespassers and encroachers. Pant also directed lodging of FIRs against those who had prepared forged documents and sold government land. The DM said he had received several complaints of illegal possession on Awas Vikas land. When Awas Vikas officials told him that there were no such incidents, the DM constituted a committee headed by additional district magistrate (finance & revenue) to look into the matter. The DM also ordered stern action against those illegally occupying government graze-yards, ponds, chak road, barren land and gram samaj land. He directed the ADM (finance & revenue) to prepare a list in a couple of days depicting how much land was to be vacated from land grabbers and what action would be taken. Besides SSP Anant Deo, CDO Akshay Tripathi, ADM (finance & revenue) Virendra Pathak, SDMs of Sadar, Bilhaur, Narval and officials of irrigation department, KDA and Awas Vikas were present in the meeting. Meanwhile, over seven kilograms of prohibited polythene was seized by official teams on Monday and a penalty of Rs 8,000 was realized. The district administration had launched an anti-polythene campaign in the city last month and set up as many as 32 teams to conduct raids.

column2: As Delhi University dreams fade, many mull skipping one year
column3: LUCKNOW: Stuti Sharma scored a commendable 94% in her Class XII boards and is yet unlikely to make it to any reputable college under Delhi University (DU), which released its first list with high cutoffs on Thursday. Stuti, who wants to study political science, now regrets not taking admission to St Xavier’s College, Kolkata. “The DU cutoffs are not only higher than last year, but were also declared late. Admissions at most prominent institutes in other parts of the country are already over. This leaves me with no choice. I have to either settle for an average college or skip a year,” she rued. The teenager is not alone in her predicament. Several other students who did not have a Plan B up their sleeves are finding themselves in the lurch, given DU’s high cutoffs especially in humanities and commerce subjects. Most are inclined to skip a year. “I was confident of making it to the first list because last year, a student with 95% had secured a political science berth in a good college. This time, however, DU has increased cutoffs in the subject by 2% on an average,” said Abhijit Sharma, who scored 95% in Class XII and is now keeping fingers crossed for the second and third cutoffs lists. Since DU released its list very late and after declaration of engineering and medical exam results, Mudit Agnihotri was hopeful that the cutoffs would dip. The high ceiling, particularly for Hindu College and Hansraj College, has left him shattered. “It will be a great disappointment if I don’t get into DU. I’ve got all my hopes pinned on the second list. Else, I may have to drop out this year,” said Mudit who scored 93.75% and wants to pursue physics honours. Adarsh Maurya is no less disappointed. “All my plans have fallen through. The first cutoffs list is a big blow to my ambition of becoming a writer. The cutoffs for English are extremely high. I won’t be able to study in any prestigious DU college,” said Adarsh who got 93.25% in Class XII. Economics aspirant Manasvi Chauhan has failed to clear the cutoffs at Kirori Mal College by 1%. The teenager who scored 96% in Class XII says she has little expectations from the second cutoffs list either. “I am looking at opportunities abroad. If I find none, I may skip the year.”

column2: Why ordinary BA from Delhi University is a huge hit in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: Harleen Singh could not clear the Delhi University cutoffs for honours in economics and English, the subjects of her choice. She has settled for an ordinary BA course at Shri Guru Tegh Bahadur Khalsa College only to fulfil her dream of studying in the North Campus. “I am no Alice, but that campus is my wonderland. I’ve always wanted to study there,” said the 18-year-old who scored 91.5% in her Class XII boards. This year, the highest cutoff for the BA programme is 98.75%, set by Lady Sri Ram College for Women, while the lowest is 72% at Bhagini Nivedita College. “With 91.5% in my best four subjects, admission to a North Campus college seemed a wishful thought. Nevertheless, I cleared the first cutoffs for Khalsa college’s BA programme comprising economics and mathematics. Since the cutoffs for ordinary BA is low compared to other courses, it is the most preferred course of many students who want to live the DU dream,” she said. Harleen isn’t the only one who has made a tough choice. Many youngsters have opted for pass programmes rather than honours course just to bag a berth in DU. Suryanshi Bharadwaj couldn’t control her excitement as she spoke to TOI about getting into Miranda House-University College for Women. “I always wanted to be part of the institution. I had applied for political science honours. But, since the cutoff is very high, I am enrolling in a BA programme with hindi and political science. Miranda House has been securing top ranks in the National Institutional Ranking Framework for three years,” said the student who scored 90% and wants to crack civil services.

column2: Dates out: UP Board exams from February 18
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh Secondary Education Board on Monday released the detailed schedule for class 10 and 12 board examinations. This was the first occasion when the UP Board released the board schedule on the first day of the new academic session. As per the schedule released by UP deputy CM Dinesh Sharma, board examinations will begin on February 18 next year. More than 55 lakh candidates will appear in these examinations. While class 10 exams will last for 12 days and end on March 3, class 12 exams will continue for 15 days, with the last paper scheduled on March 6. The examinations will be held in two shifts — 8am to 11.15am and from 2pm to 5.15pm Deputy CM Sharma, who is also the state secondary education minister, told reporters: “The answer copies will be evaluated from March 15 to March 25. The number of the evaluators will be increased at every examination centre so that results are declared between April 20 and 25.” In 2019, board examinations had begun on February 7. On Monday, Sharma also released the academic calendar of classes 9 to 12 of UP Board schools to regularize the 2019-20 session of the secondary schools in the state. The month-wise academic calendar will be followed by all schools so that there is uniformity in syllabus, examinations, results and academic activities.

column2: Dig a pit to get free sapling for plantation drive
column3: LUCKNOW: ‘No pit, no plant’ will be one of the base rules to ensure probity in state government’s plantation drive this year as it plans to distribute 15 crore saplings free of cost to farmers, MNREGA job card holders and beneficiaries of various central government schemes like Saubhagya, PMAY, Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana and Ujjwala Yojana among others. The government scheme beneficiaries will have to plant at least five trees each. Each state nursery sapling costs minimum Rs 7, hence giving away 15 crore saplings free will cost around Rs 105 crore to the state exchequer. Since it involves huge expenditure, the departments that distribute saplings will ensure fairness and set accountability by recording sapling given free. Besides, the beneficiaries will have to dig pits and produce a document signed by an officer certifying the same to collect free saplings. This year, UP has set the most ambitious plantation target ever — planting 22 crore trees in 2019-20. Inaugurating Van Mahotsav, a week-long annual plantation drive from July 1 to July 7 at Kukrail reserve forest on Monday, forest minister Dara Singh Chauhan said 22 crore trees will be planted on August 15. Out of 22 crore trees, forest department will plant seven crore on forest land, while remaining 15 crore will be planted by 23 other departments collectively. The trees planted during Van Mahotsav will be over and above the 22 crore target. Rural development department has been assigned plantation of 10 crore saplings. Gram Rozgar Sewaks, who are appointed on contract by government at Gram Panchayat level for smooth implementation of MNREGA, will work as ‘tree guardian’ to oversee plantation drive and monitor the growth and survival of trees for a year. Panchayats and urban local bodies will be geo-tagged to check status of plantation. Yogi government has been setting ambitious targets as it aims to increase state’s green cover from 9.1% to 15%. In 2018, 11.2 crore trees were planted against six crore in 2017.

column2: BJP leader joins Mayawati, terms government order on OBCs in SC list ‘unconstitutional’
column3: LUCKNOW: Soon after BSP supremo Mayawati slammed the Uttar Pradesh government on Monday for including 17 OBCs in Scheduled Caste category, terming it unconstitutional and demanding its withdrawal, a senior BJP leader also criticized the step saying it should have been done after getting a ‘recommendation’ of SC/ST commission. Ex-chairman of SC/ST commission and former Rajya Sabha MP, Bizay Sonkar Shastri, who is BJP spokesperson, said that the move by Yogi Adityanath government is against the Constitution. “Many Dalit leaders within BJP are not happy with this decision. I don’t want to comment beyond this,” Shastri said, while speaking to TOI on phone from Delhi. Shastri’s statement came hours after Mayawati attacked state government’s step saying it intended to cheat OBCs and SCs ahead of UP bypolls for 12 assembly seats. No state government can include any caste in SC list as under Article 341 of Indian Constitution, only Centre can do so, she said. “The state government knows this very well and hence its intention is exposed. These castes will neither get 27% OBC reservation nor of SC. They would rather be considered in general category,” she said, adding that the government knew that similar orders in past had been quashed by high court. Last week, UP government had added 17 castes, including Kashyap, Mallah, Kumhar, Rajbhar, Prajapati and others, in Scheduled Castes list. “My party had protested a similar order passed by previous Samajwadi Party regime. In 2007, when we were in power, we had written to Congress-led UPA government at Centre demanding increase in quota for SCs before including the 17 OBC castes in SC category,” she said. “I had also raised this demand in parliament, but neither the UPA government nor NDA intend to ensure that both OBC and SC people get benefited,” Mayawati said. She alleged that the order was issued for political gains with an eye on bypolls for 12 seats. “I appeal government not to cheat OBCs and take back the order which is unconstitutional. At the same time, Centre should follow due procedure to put the 17 OBC castes in SC category and increase SC quota in the same ratio so that the existing beneficiaries do not suffer any problem,” she added.

column2: Uttar Pradesh adds 16 lakh entrepreneurs to GST regime as collection soars
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh has registered 19.28% growth over last year’s collection in the goods and services tax (GST). The state’s GST collection for 2018-19 financial year stands at Rs 70,060 crore. Also, as many as 16.5 lakh new businessmen have become part of the GST regime in UP since 2017. These disclosures were made by the UP GST office at the commemoration of two years of indirect tax’s implementation by the NDA government. The event in Lucknow was presided by chief minister Yogi Adityanath, finance minister Rajesh Aggarwal, Lucknow zone principal chief commissioner (GST) Rajeev Tandon, and joint commissioner (GST) Vivek Jain. “The fact that GST collections are on the rise indicates that the tax base is widening gradually with stablity along with measures, such as e-way bills and people are also readily paying their arrears,” said Aggarwal. Both Jain and Tandon hailed GST as goods and “simplified” tax. The officials said that more than 200 commodities have seen a significant drop in GST, but their sales in both rural and urban areas have increased by more than 46 %, thereby adding to overall tax collection. The commodities range from four-wheelers, electronic goods to hospitality industry as well as aviation. In 2017-18, UP’s GST collection stood at 58,738 crore, while in 2016-17 it was Rs 51,819 crore. At least four times in the last financial year, the GST collections in UP were a touch short of Rs 7,000 crore. On the occasion, Yogi said his government’s target for GST would be Rs 1 lakh crore while also insisting that his government was trying to bargain hard with retailers and new entrepreneurs to use softwares to subscribe to GST regime. Since December 2018, the UP government, on recommendation of GST Lucknow zone, has made introduction of RFID (Radio Frequency Identification Tag) electronic tag mandatory on heavy vehicles carrying goods, thereby restricting tax fraud but at the same time facilitating ease of business.

column2: Gomtinagar gangs pull off a hat-trick
column3: LUCKNOW: Empty homes in Gomtinagar have become soft targets of burglar gangs who are taking full advantage of owners being either on vacation or business trips and police being lax as ever. Unidentified persons went on a break-in spree in the small hours of Monday, targeting three flats — one of them possibly owned by a DSP-rank officer — at Greenwood Apartments and taking the total number of burglaries in the posh city neighbourhood to nine in a little over a month. However, they were unable to bag a huge booty. According to preliminary investigation, the gang scaled the around 8ft boundary wall of the apartment complex while guards kept vigil at the gates, removed corridor bulbs in one of the six towers and broke into a flat on the second floor and two more on the fifth floor. All were empty with their owners away for either work or pleasure. While other residents did not hear any startling noise, a CCTV camera on the ground floor caught two persons in shorts and T-shirts entering the building around 3am. “We suspect they are the gang or at least part of the gang,” said SP, North, Sukirti Madhav. Flat 205, neighbours said, belongs to DSP Rama Shankar who has rented it out to one Akash Shukla, a native of Basti. Since Shukla also stays here occasionally, the burglars apparently did not find much to steal. At 501, owned by retired executive engineer of UP Housing Board Ramakant, the gang was again unlucky. “They rummaged through the wardrobe and at best took away Rs 5,000 in cash from the pocket of my trousers,” Ramakant told TOI. His wife and he were away visiting a relative at Rajajipuram. “When I reached home this morning, I found the burglars had broken the door open perhaps becasue they could not pick the lock,” he added. Flat 508 is owned by one Rajiv Ranjan who along with his family is away in Jamshedpur, Jharkhand. Police are trying to ascertain the losses. Ramakant has lodged a complaint while we are waiting for the others to do so, said a policeman.

column2: ‘My daughter’s dead; her killer is still out there’
column3: LUCKNOW: What is more painful for a father than losing his dear girl whom he allowed to leave hometown for higher education? It is perhaps watching her killer roam scot-free while police take a nap. On June 11, final-year dental science student Priya Singh (25) was found dead at her residence in Nilmatha under Cantonment thana, a mark around her neck and circumstantial evidence pushing the needle of suspicion towards murder than suicide. A day later, her father Prakash Singh — a civil engineer in Bihar — lodged an FIR against one Prakash Chandra Arya, a guy who wanted to marry Priya. Three weeks down the line, her bereaved parents claim police are sitting on the case. “No effort has been made to secure a non-bailable warrant against the accused, let alone track him down. We believe he is in New Delhi, where he was last seen withdrawing money from an ATM some two-three days after my daughter was killed,” the father told TOI. Singh said they were more than willing to co-operate in the investigations. “I have shared every bit of information possible. I have visited the Cantonment police station several times in these few weeks and waited there for hours at a stretch to meet the investigation officer. I have met senior police officers too. All I get is empty promises,” he said. While the exhausted father wants police to at least issue a lookout notice against Arya without delay, grieving mother Renu has hardly stayed away from her prayer room. “I have lost faith in police. I am praying to God so that the person who did this to my child is not spared,”Priya’s mother told TOI between sobs and sniffles.

column2: Grisly June: Lucknow witnessed a crime every three hours
column3: LUCKNOW: A businessman enjoying a family vacation returned home to Gomtinagar to find footprints in blood all over his house and valuables missing. A woman in Chinhat took a bullet because her husband thought she nagged him too much over his fetish for felony. And, two Mahanagar women had their gold turned into pebbles in minutes by men who said they were cops. These cases form only the tip of an iceberg of crimes that the city witnessed in June. If police files are anything to go by, as many as 236 cases of murder, burglary, rape, snatching, con and more have taken place in Lucknow in a month, which effectively means the state capital witnessed a crime every three hours and at least eight every day. Between June 1and 30, there have been eight murders, three shootings, six rapes, 45 cases of snatching, 22 burglaries and 21 incidents of con to mock police claims of routine city patrolling and their ambitious Jaagte Raho campaign to prevent crimes in the dead of night. Not just instances of physical violence, cyber crooks too have taken police for a ride with 78 cases registered in less than 30 days. Gomtinagar burglars score a hat-trickEmpty homes in Gomtinagar have become soft targets of burglar gangs who are taking full advantage of owners being either on vacation or business trips and police being lax as ever. Unidentified persons went on a break-in spree in the small hours of Monday, targeting three flats — one of them possibly owned by a DSP-rank officer — at Greenwood Apartments and taking the total number of burglaries in the posh city neighbourhood to nine in a little over a month. However, they were unable to bag a huge booty. TimesViewEvery loot or murder in the city is followed by a promise of improved policing. The administration should realise that such lip service can hardly be useful in arresting the rise of crime in the city. The police department should launch concrete steps like monitoring roads with a network of CCTV cameras to check crime. The move has yielded useful results in countries which use surveillance footage to keep a tab on criminals.Between June 1 and 30, there have been eight murders, three shootings, six rapes, 45 cases of snatching, 22 burglaries and 21 incidents of con to mock police claims of routine city patrolling and their ambitious Jaagte Raho campaign to prevent crimes in the dead of night. Not just instances of physical violence, cyber crooks too have taken police for a ride with 78 cases registered in less than 30 days.The men in uniform have been able to crack only around 28 of the 236 crimes, victims have been crying hoarse over lax patrolling and a handicapped surveillance mechanism, thanks to missing, substandard or defunct CCTV cameras. Anxious citizens mull private securityAlmost convinced that police can no longer protect the city, some enterprising residents like Khurramnagar jeweller Santosh Singh have decided to hire private security. “I was robbed of cash and jewellery worth over a lakh on June 23 on my way home to Jankipuram. Despite being a prime location, there were no UP 100 patrol vehicles. I am looking for private guards,” he told TOI. Shikha Tiwari of Mahanagar who was robbed of her gold chain and bangles at gunpoint near the Cantonment CO’s office at noon on June 3 said she was advising friends and family members to not wear or carry valuables when commuting alone. “The city has become unsafe and police are doing precious little (to curb crimes). It is up to us to stay safe,” she said. Lucknow SSP Kalanidhi Naithani made an attempt to defend his forces. “Most of the serious cases have been solved. Also, vulnerable areas (where cons and loots take place) have been identified. These areas will be geo-tagged for better patrolling by UP 100 vehicles,” he said.

column2: Lucknow zoo tickets to cost you 30% more
column3: LUCKNOW: A trip to Lucknow Zoo will now cost you more. The Lucknow Zoo Consultative Committee decided to increase entry charges and the price of toy train tickets by over 30%. The new prices would effective Monday onwards and the zoo administration’s decision comes after a gap of six years. The package ticket, which includes entry charges and a ride on the toy train, will cost Rs 100 for adults (anyone above 12 years); and Rs 50 for children aged between five years and 12 years. If you decide to skip the train ride, an entry ticket for adults will cost Rs 80 and Rs 40 for children. The price of other tickets would remain unchanged. Director of the zoo RK Singh said, “The decision to increase the ticket price was taken to supplement Lucknow Zoo’s earnings, which pays salaries, allowances and pension benefits to employees.”

column2: Private hospital sends body home, dead man wakes up
column3: LUCKNOW: Preparations for last rites of 20-year-old Furqan were complete at his residence in C Block, Indiranagar. Relatives and neighbours were waiting for Furqan’s body to arrive from the private hospital where he was admitted on June 21 after an accident, and was declared dead by doctors on Monday. Sobs could be heard when the ambulance arrived, but in a shocking development that looked like straight out of a movie scene, Furqan’s body showed movement while being taken out. As family members, relatives and several mourners had seen the movement, the glum atmosphere soon turned into one of bewilderment. Last rites were put aside and Furqan was rushed to Dr Ram Manohar Lohia Combined hospital where he was found to be alive and was immediately put on oxygen support. He was, however, referred to another hospital due to unavailability of ventilator. Furqan was later admitted to a private medical facility in Indira Nagar. Narrating their ordeal, Furqan’s elder brother, Mohd Irfan told reporters that after an accident on Sultapur road on June 21, Furqan had been undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Niralanagar. “The hospital put him on ventilator and started charging us huge fees. We spaid Rs 7 lakh and when we informed the hospital that we had run out of money, they declared Furqan dead on Monday,” Irfan claimed. “When we took the body home, a family member noticed that he was breathing. Others standing there also saw limb movement. We then rushed him to RML hospital immediately where doctors put him on oxygen support,” he added. Patient on ventilator: DocChief medical officer (CMO) of Lucknow, Dr Narendra Agarwal said, “We have taken cognizance of the incident and the matter will be thoroughly probed.” The doctor who is treating Furqan at the private medical facility, Dr Ashok Nirala told TOI, “The patient is in critical condition but definitely not brain dead. He has pulse, blood pressure and his reflexes are working. He has been put on ventilator support.” Read this story in Bengali

column2: AKTU professor caught taking cash in sting operation
column3: LUCKNOW: An associate professor of Dr APJ Kalam Technical University (AKTU) was suspended on Monday after he was allegedly caught redhanded accepting cash from a PhD aspirant. Prof Rajiv Kumar Singh, a faculty member in electronics engineering department of AKTU’s Institute of Engineering and Technology (IET) and associate dean of PG and Research Centre, allegedly sought Rs 1.50 lakh from Kanpur resident Deepak Kumar, who was seeking admission in a PhD programme. In a statement, the university said a probe found Singh prima facie guilty of accepting cash. The university said the accused was not associated with the entrance test, hence question of influencing results did not arise. However, the statement added that it appears the accused would have taken cash even if the candidate had got admission by way of merit. A sting operation was carried out on Saturday, a day before the entrance test for PhD, when the candidate called up vice-chancellor professor Vinay Kumar Pathak and informed him that professor Singh was demanding cash for admission. 2-member varsity team laid the trapThe VC immediately asked dean, undergraduate studies and entrepreneurship, Vineet Kansal and university spokesperson Asheesh Mishra to verify the complaint. The two-member team asked the candidate to meet the professor with the money. The meeting was set up near a hospital in Jankipuram around 9pm on Saturday. Mishra and Kansal followed the candidate from a safe distance. Prof Singh turned up at the spot around 9.30pm. “As soon as we saw Prof Singh taking the envelope containing cash, we caught him,” said Mishra. He said: “The teacher first offered a clarification that he was only talking to the candidate but when we told him that we saw everything, he handed over the envelope to us. He, however, denied the charges when we took him to the VC.” When TOI contacted Prof Singh, he politely refused to comment.
