Prof Singh turned up at the spot around 9.30pm. “As soon as we saw Prof Singh taking the envelope containing cash, we caught him,” said Mishra. He said: “The teacher first offered a clarification that he was only talking to the candidate but when we told him that we saw everything, he handed over the envelope to us. He, however, denied the charges when we took him to the VC.” When TOI contacted Prof Singh, he politely refused to comment.

column2: Gorakhpur MP Ravi Kishan croons 1961 song in Lok Sabha, seeks Bhojpuri as official language
column3: LUCKNOW: Debutant Gorakhpur parliamentarian Ravindra Shyamnarayan, better known by his celluloid moniker Ravi Kishan, on Monday broke into an impromptu gig in the Lok Sabha as he sang a portion of song from the first-ever Bhojpuri film to build a case for the inclusion of the language as one of the scheduled languages of India.“He Ganga maiya tohe piyari chadhaibo, saiyaan se kari de milanava haay raam” he sang from the 1961 film even as the speaker requested him to continue his plea without singing the song. The movie He Ganga Maiya Tohe Piyari Chadhaibo was the first ever Bhojpuri film to be made and screened in India starring noted actor Nazir Hussain. It was made on request of then President Rajendra Prasad. “The entire Bhojpuri speaking community is thankful to the prime minister for putting thrust on the backward areas of UP. From trains to airports to hospitals to, my request to PM is now that the same community has only another hope from him. Which is to see the language getting included in the 8th schedule,” said Kishan. Kishan was roped in by the BJP in 2017 to swing Purvanchali assembly constituencies in saffron party's favour during the Assembly elections and later made a candidate this year in Lok Sabha polls from UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath's home turf Gorakhpur. His victory is significant as BJP had lost the Gorakhpur bypoll for the first time in five decades last year to Samajwadi Party but the Bhojpuri cinestar secured a win for the party by a margin of three-lakh votes in a high decibel campaign that saw BJP president Amit Shah, Union minister Smriti Irani campaigning for him. 22 languages part of 8th scheduleAs of now, 22 languages are part of the 8th schedule which includes Hindi. Till 2018, requests for 42 more regional languages were lying before the Union home ministry which deals with their budget allocated to official language department under MHA at Rs 75.45 crore. Apart from Gorakhpur, BJP and its allies scripted a huge electoral success in more than a dozen Purvanchal regions of Mirzapur, Varanasi, Bhadohi, Deoria, Ballia, Kushinagar, Domariyaganj Sant Kabir Nagar and so on. In Nepal and Fiji, Bhojpuri has been a recognised language for long.

column2: Rs 9,300 crore cane dues pending in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: Despite CM Yogi Adityanath’s directions to millers to clear all cane dues by June-end, an outstanding of over Rs 9,300 crores is still pending, as per data of cane development department.In fact, some mills have not paid even half of the dues for current season. Data accessed by TOI shows that mills owned by Bajaj group alone have an outstanding of over Rs 3,000 crores. The group has paid only 38% of dues. Similarly, Mawana and Modi groups, both owning two mills each, have an outstanding of Rs 500 crores each. While Mawana has paid 45% dues, Modi sugar mills paid barely 25%. 33,000 crores in current crushing season, over Rs 23,000 crores have been paid. While state-owned sugar corporation mill paid Rs 135 crores (74.61%), the cooperative sugar mills cleared Rs 2,443 crores (84.66%). The private millers are faltering, having paid 68% of total and having to clear over Rs 9,000 crores. UP cane minister Suresh Rana said that the department has ensured full payment for previous crushing years. “We hope to clear the remaining dues by end of August,” he told TOI. “We cleared nearly Rs 70,000 crores, which includes cane dues of last five years during SP regime. It is the highest amount paid in a year,” Rana said. Yadu mills, owned by former SP leader D P Yadav, have paid only 11% of dues and nearly Rs 150 crores are due. Simbhaoli sugar mill is faltering on payment of Rs 645 crores and has paid only 20% till date. The aggregate data shows that against over Rs An office-bearer of UP Sugar Mills’ Association said that millers are facing multiple problems. “The state advisory price (SAP) of Rs 325 per quintal is high. We have been demanding increase in price of molasses,” he said.

column2: Clues elude cops in trader’s murder near Durgapuri
column3: LUCKNOW: A day after a trader was shot dead and Rs 2 lakh looted from him by four bikeborne assailants in Durgapuri, police were groping in the dark on Monday in the absence of any clue, including CCTV footage of the incident. The lone eyewitness, who was with the businessman at the time of the incident and was also looted, did tell the police that there were four miscreants but could not provide any further clue as he suffered injuries in the head after being hit by the looters. Police said the incident occurred at around 9.50pm on Sunday when Manoj Bhattacharya (50), a businessman dealing in tobacco products, was going to drop his business associate Ashu Bajaj (48) on a scooter to Charbagh railway station. They were intercepted by four miscreants on two bikes near Durgapuri Metro station. One of the miscreants fired at Bhattacharya and also hit Bajaj with the butt of the pistol. The other miscreant snatched Bajaj’s bag which contained the cash and the two fled. Bhattacharya was referred to KGMU Trauma Centre where he was declared brought dead by doctors. “Locals have told us that the miscreants fled towards Mawaiya. There were no CCTV cameras around so we have no clue about their identity or the vehicles used. Bhattacharya’s family has ruled out personal enmity for motive,” said CO (Alambagh) Sanjeev Kumar Sinha. Mano (26), son of the deceased, said, “Bajaj visits Lucknow every Sunday to collect money from customers and stays in the hotel above our shop. On Sunday, he met my father after collecting money around 9.15pm and asked him to drop him at the railway station. There could have beenover Rs 5 lakh in the bag.”

column2: Lucknow: 26 years after dad’s murder, man kills for revenge
column3: LUCKNOW: A man was arrested on Monday for hacking a 60-year-old man to death to exact revenge for his dead father, who was killed 26 years ago. Police said the accused Kalyan Singh murdered the victim Sunderlal with a sickle around 9pm on Sunday, while the latter was sitting at a tea shop in a Gosainganj village. Sunderlal was rushed to a community health centre, but was declared brought dead. The accused and the victims were labourers by profession. Police said Sundarlal had killed the accused’s father Ram Swaroop in 1993, when Kalyan was a child. Though Sunderlal had gone to prison for the crime, but was released on bail after a few months. The 26-year-old accused told the police that he had wanted to avenge his father’s death by murdering Sunderlal. Station house officer (Gosaiganj) Vijay Kumar Singh said, “We came to know about Kalyan’s whereabouts and arrested him later near a highway restaurant on Sultanpur Road.”

column2: Fake cops’ dupe 60-year-old in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: Two unidentified men conned an elderly woman by posing as policemen and convinced her into handing over her gold bangles, chain and a ring to them in Aliganj on Monday. Police said Madiaon resident Vimla Mishra (60) was accosted by the two accused near Purania Crossing. Introducing themselves as cops, they asked Mishra to take off her jewellery as it wasn’t safe to wear it in wake of the rising crime. They asked her to put the ornaments in a piece of paper, wrapped them and handed the package to her. When Mishra checked the package at home, she found the jewellery replaced by glass bangles. SHO (Aliganj) Farid Ahmad said a complaint was registered and police were checking CCTV footage of the road for more clues.

column2: Locals take the lead at plantation drive in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: A group of women in tandem with International Inner Wheel Club came together to save the environment and groundwater by planting over 100 trees in village Ataur of Ghaziabad on Monday. This group has decided to undertake more projects of the nearby villages where they will provide better basic facilities like water, pucca houses, community hall, and others. They also want to help girls get better education by teaching them different courses. The plantation drive was attended by Diksha Bhandari, the district forest officer, along with Ranbir Singh, the village head of Ataur. Others present included Kalu of Mohanpur, Pramod Kumar of Shamsher village, Madhu Nagpal, Abha Gupta, Seema Khaitan, Sunanda Sawhney, Sanyam Guglani and Dr. Anshu Dagur. International Inner Wheel is one of the largest women organisations started in 1924. The club has more than one lakh members across the world in 103 countries.

column2: Kanpurites turned neta at this do
column3: Elections may be long over but politics is still ruling the minds of Kanpurites. ML Agarwal and his wife Rama hosted an election theme party for their friends, recently. Organised at a banquet in the city, the guests following the theme came dressed as politicians. The male brigade chose to be dressed in kurtapyjama whereas the fairer sex sported Gandhi topi for completing their neta wali look. (L) Ajay Garg and Karuna Garg (R) Kriti, Keshav and Kashish (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Ajay Garg and Karuna Garg (R) Kriti, Keshav and Kashish (BCCL/ IB Singh) Rajeev Anand, came sporting a turban and an orderly escorted him with an umbrella. The guests were divided into four parties which were named on famous companies. It was fun time for the guests when the members started canvassing for their respective parties. (L) Mamta and Dabbu Mishra (R) Nitin Gupta and Kanchan Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Mamta and Dabbu Mishra (R) Nitin Gupta and Kanchan Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh) Going by the theme, the venue was also decorated as a polling center. A polling booth was installed so that the guests could get their selfies clicked. Jai Kumar Singh Jaiki, Minister of State for Jail and Public Service Management, also attended the party along with wife Sushila Singh. (L) ML Agarwal (R) Raju Dubey, Jai Kumar Singh and Vivek Singh (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) ML Agarwal (R) Raju Dubey, Jai Kumar Singh and Vivek Singh (BCCL/ IB Singh) Later, Sumit Agarwal entertained the guests with his soulful singing. Also present were Riya Agarwal, Kanchan Gupta, SK Bajaj Raju Dubey and Ajay Garg. SK Bajaj, Raju Dubey and Ajay Garg (BCCL/ IB Singh) SK Bajaj, Raju Dubey and Ajay Garg (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Rishabh Singh and Khushboo Singh (R) Riya Agarwal (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Rishabh Singh and Khushboo Singh (R) Riya Agarwal (BCCL/ IB Singh)

column2: Lucknow: Monsoon makes debut with light spell, yet to pick pace
column3: LUCKNOW: The wait for monsoon finally ended as the weather phenomenon entered the city, though on a quieter note, on Tuesday. Only few spells of light rain were received on day one, but the weatherman said the intensity will increase from Thursday and heavy rains are expected to lash city on Saturday. Tuesday morning was hot and humid, but clouds began to appear around afternoon. Intermittent showers were recorded during the day. Total 15mm rainfall was recorded till the night.  The maximum temperature, which was hovering over 40 degrees till Sunday, dropped to 37.3 degrees Celsius on Tuesday, while the minimum temperature dropped to 26.3 degrees Celsius. Though relative humidity soared to 90% during the day following rains, drop in temperature and a soothing breeze made weather pleasant in the evening. State Met director JP Gupta said a low pressure area that developed over the Bay of Bengal on Sunday fuelled monsoon advancement into the city. A cyclonic circulation is also hovering over Chhattisgarh and adjoining areas of Jharkhand. Together, these systems have created favourable conditions for further advancement of the monsoon that is now expected to cover entire state by Friday.Weather office has predicted light to moderate rainfall on Wednesday and Thursday and it will pick pace from Friday. Widespread heavy rains are expected on Saturday. City needs ample rains in July to make up for the rain deficit in June. The normal date of monsoon arrival in the state is June 15 and for city it’s June 15. However, this year it has arrived late.

column2: Lucknow: Trader shot at in Charbagh, commuters scurry for cover
column3: LUCKNOW: In a daring shooting incident in the crowded Charbagh railway station area on Tuesday, the second within three days, two bike-borne armed miscreants opened fire at a businessman in board daylight and escaped unchallenged, sparking panic in the area. Virendra Thakur (40), a property dealer and transporter, was waiting outside Charbagh railway station to meet an acquaintance who had called him. Thakur, a resident of Nilmatha, Cantonment, was standing on roadside when two men came on a bike, fired three shots at him and sped away. Thakur was hit in his waist and right thigh, while the third bullet missed. The sudden firing triggered panic with people running for cover. No one tried to stop or chase the miscreants. Government Railway Police (GRP) and Railway Protection Force (RPF) personnel arrived in minutes and rushed Thakur to Balrampur hospital. Thakur, who was conscious, called his wife telling her to reach hospital with some money. He was later referred to KGMU Trauma Centre. RPF constable, R K Singh said two miscreants came on a black sports bike and the pillion rider, wearing a red cap, fired thrice at Thakur and they zipped away. Ashwani Prajapati, an eyewitness told police that Thakur was booking an autorickshaw for two women when he was shot at The women, however, did not stop and hurried off on foot. Thakur’s wife, Priyanka Singh (37), said that she had gone to bank with him when he got a call. “He told me to wait in bank and left saying he had to meet somebody and will be back soon,” she said. GRP inspector, Somveer Singh said, “We will record the statement of Thakur once he is declared fit for it by the doctors. We are checking, collecting and scanning CCTV footage from the area to identify the miscreants. Prima facie, it appears .315 bore firearm was used in the crime.” On Sunday, a businessman was shot dead by bike-borne miscreants who also looted Rs 3 lakh from him near Durgapuri Metro station in Charbagh area.

column2: New SSP to take charge of Ghaziabad from today
column3: GHAZIABAD: SSP Upendra Kumar Agarwal, who was promoted to the post of DIG in January this year, has been transferred to Saharanpur range. Sudhir Kumar Singh (56), who was serving as Muzaffarnagar SSP, will now take the charge of Ghaziabad. Singh, a 2009-batch IPS officer, had served as circle officer (CO) in Ghaziabad between 1994 and 1997. Singh would take the charge of Ghaziabad SSP from Tuesday night. Talking to TOI, Singh said, “It’s been over 20 years when I served in Ghaziabad and the district has evolved drastically over the years. My priorities will be the same as those of the state government.” “I will look into the current issues and formulate strategies accordingly. At present, a month-long campaign on woman safety is going on and it would be implemented effectively. Safety of women will be one of the main priorities for me,” Singh added. During his three years tenure in Ghaziabad in the past, Singh had served as CO Dadri, CO City (II) and CO border. While Agarwal was appointed Ghaziabad police chief in November 2018, Singh had taken the charge of Muzaffarnagar SSP in September 2018. Just two months after his appointment, Agarwal was promoted to the rank of DIG. Apart from Agarwal and Singh, 20 more IPS officers have been transferred by the state government.

column2: Executive held hostage by cabbie for 3 hours, robbed of cash & jewellery
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 43-year-old executive of an auto component manufacturing company was allegedly robbed of Rs 1.15 lakh and a gold ring by a cab driver and three of his accomplices after he took the taxi from Ghaziabad railway station for his Greater Noida residence late on Sunday night. Manish Kumar Jha, the safety head of Spark Minda in Rewari, was allegedly held hostage at gunpoint for three hours and thrashed by his co-riders, forcing him to reveal his ATM card pin. Later the four withdrew Rs 1 lakh from his account. They also snatched his wallet containing Rs 15,000, mobile phone charger, earphone, and new clothes and some fruits he had bought, before dumping him near a school in Vijay Nagar in the early hours of Monday. Santosh Kumar Jha, his younger brother, told TOI that Manish was returning from Patna on Sunday. “Seemanchal Express was supposed to reach Ghaziabad around 9.30 pm but it was delayed by three hours. After getting down from the train, he took a cab from outside, but missed noticing a person sitting inside,” he said. “As soon as he boarded the cab, the driver stepped on the gas pedal. Within no time, the person sitting next to the driver pointed a gun at him. A little later, two other persons boarded the vehicle and made my brother sit in the middle. They had guns and knives and started beating my brother. He was forced to part with his debit cards and the passwords. They mainly hit him on his hands and knees,” Santosh added. The ordeal continued for over three hours. Around 3.30am, Manish was thrown out of the vehicle near Jindal Public School. In a badly bruised condition, he sought help from a passerby who told him to wait for the police patrolling vehicle. After covering a considerable distance on foot, Manish finally spotted a police patrolling bike and narrated the crime to cops. Based on his complaint, an FIR under IPC 392 (robbery) was lodged at Vijay Nagar police station. SP (city) Shlok Kumar said teams have been formed to investigate the case. “Noida police have also been informed as money was withdrawn from Noida ATMs as well,” he said. Similar crimes were reported in Ghaziabad in March this year too. A 30-year-old dentist was robbed by four persons in an auto-rickshaw, including the vehicle driver, while she was returning from her clinic in Vaishali. She was thrashed and kept inside the moving vehicle for around 45 minutes. They had gagged her mouth after blindfolding her and tying her hands and legs with ropes.

column2: Road institute has a plan to decongest 14 junctions
column3: GHAZIABAD: Poor design and lack of a proper enforcement mechanism are causing confusion and chaos, especially during the peak hours, at the city’s major traffic intersections, a report submitted by Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) to Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) said. The report studies 14 major intersections in the city, including GDA Old Bus Stand, Choudhary Mode, Indirapuram SRS Cinemas and Kanawani intersections. “Prior to implementation of Integrated Traffic Management System, we asked CRRI for a report to make necessary amendments to decongest roads,” said Kanchan Verma, vice chairperson, GDA. “The intersections are poorly designed, allowing on-street parking and stopping and standing at the corners. Wrong-lane driving and encroachments have worsened the problem,” said a CRRI official. “We had employed yardsticks like traffic, topographic and pedestrian surveys at each of the 14 intersections,” added the official. The GDA Old Bus Stand intersection, said the report, has excess open paved area at all corners which encourages private vehicles, vendors, autos and cycles to park to wait for passengers and for boarding and alighting of passengers in an unsafe manner. It often results in traffic congestion too. “We’ve proposed improving the intersection by providing traffic circulation plan for access to parking facilities under the flyover,” said the official. “Traffic control and safety measures in the form of road signs, marking, delineations and speed tables have also been proposed,” added the official. The report also highlighted the problem areas at the Choudhary mod intersection, which is located in the busy market area on GT Road. It said the presence of Chaudhary Cinema and a temple at the intersection was compounding the traffic woes. “We have proposed a separation at the junction and have also suggested strong traffic enforcement,” said the official. The report said a small rotary at Indirapuram SRS cinema intersection at the centre of Indirapuram on Kala Pather Road leading to Delhi-Meerut Expressway, is ineffective as traffic is flowing in all directions. The GDA’s new chief architect and town planner Asheesh Shivpuri said, “Before going about implementing the CRRI’s plan, we would like to discuss its proposals with a committee and only after that will we be in a position to say what can be implemented,” said Shivpuri.

column2: Lucknow: Police boast 1,000km daily patrol, residents sceptical
column3: LUCKNOW: If police are to be believed, they patrol 1,000km a day either in vans or on bikes. But, residents — particularly victims of snatching, burglary and street con — beg to differ. Gomtinagar resident Sandeep Agarwal, whose house was burgled of Rs 5.5 lakh worth of valuables on June 30, said he had hardly seen cops patrolling the area. In Indiranagar, Smita Pandey who was conned by men posing as cops said she didn’t remember the last time she had seen a UP 100 vehicle in her neighbourhood. Akash Deep, whose cafe on Nawal Kishore Road in Hazratganj was targeted on June 25 amid police’s debut ‘Jaagte Raho’ campaign, is planning to hire private security guards. “Burglars don’t fear police anymore. Moreover, patrolling is hardly done,” said. Rekha Shah, a resident of Rajajipuram, was robbed of her gold while she was learning how to ride a two-wheeler from her husband. The incident took place in front of Talkatora police outpost on June 8. Shah says no cops were present at the outpost while UP 100 patrol was conspicuous by its absence. The month of June alone saw 236 crimes, including murders and rapes. In other words, nearly eight crimes took place every day, the most vulnerable areas being Hazratganj, Vibhuti Khand, Gomtinagar, Indiranagar, Mahanagar and Aliganj. Circle officer, Gomtinagar, Avnishwar Chandra Srivastava claimed they had “studied the pattern of crime” and accordingly, charted out a patrol plan. “You will see the difference this month,” he said. The UP 100 in-charge of Lucknow ASP Sarvesh Mishra said patrolling had increased, especially during night. Big police station areas have been given two four-wheelers and smaller thanas one. “The SHO concerned maps out the areas for patrolling by PRVs (police response vehicles). If he feels any specific area is witnessing more crimes, he can accordingly change the roster. On an average, 10km is covered by a vehicle. It increases when there is a spurt in crime in a certain area. On an average, the van fleet covers 730km daily. As many as 55 bikes cover another 275km area a day,” Mishra added. Officials at UP 100 said the whole of Lucknow district had 73 four-wheelers and 55 two-wheelers, mostly for patrolling in urban areas. They also said around 10,000 calls were received at UP 100 in June and all were attended to.

column2: Write in capital letters, KGMU tells doctors
column3: LUCKNOW: Doctors at King George’s Medical University (KGMU) will have to write prescriptions in capital letters from August 1. The university has taken the decision following complaints that its prescriptions are often illegible and patients find it difficult to procure medicines. There have also been instances when pharmacies have handed wrong medicines to patients because they too couldn’t decipher what was actually prescribed. “The circular has been issued to all the departments in accordance with the Medical Council of India guidelines,” said KGMU medical superintendent Dr BK Ojha. Patients in general welcomed the move. Some also recalled how wrong pills had done them or at least threatened to do them more harm than good. Bharti of Khadra, an ENT patient, said a pharmacy misread her prescription a week ago. “They gave me a pill to cure an ear infection, but it induced vomiting. Later, a doctor at a private hospital said the pharmacy had given me a wrong pill because they confused a spelling,” she said. Narendra Kumar (25) of Barabanki, who was escorting a cancer patient on Tuesday, told TOI that a medical store outside KGMU sent him back to the doctor twice for clarifications. Aliganj resident Shikha Pandey said recently, a doctor of general medicine had prescribed her a pill for blood pressure, but no pharmacist or chemist could read what it was. “I had to go back to KGMU and request the doctor to rewrite the prescription more clearly,” she added. Atul Singh, a resident of Balaganj who visited the urology OPD on Tuesday, said he had to hop from one private clinic to another to get some pathological tests done. “I simply wanted to avoid the rush at KGMU. But, no lab outside could read what tests were prescribed. So, here I am, waiting for my turn at KGMU.” A section of doctors also supported the decision. Dr Suryakant, head of respiratory medicine at KGMU, pointed out that there were many drugs with similar names. “Pharmacies are likely to confuse among these and give a wrong pill to a patient. The move can remedy the problem.” Dr Rakesh Kumar, head of paediatrics preventive dentistry, said: “Along with the brand name in capital letters, I think, the generic name should also be written. I have asked doctors in my department to follow this rule.” Another doctor had a sense of humour. “If we start practising (writing in capital letters) from now, it may become a habit in a month,” quipped Dr Shally Awasthi of the department of paediatrics.

column2: UP: Teenager raped & forcibly given abortion pill, dies
column3: KANPUR: A teenage girl died allegedly after consuming abortion pill administered by her neighbour under Chhibramau Kotwali police jurisdiction in Kannauj district on Monday. The accused and his family members are absconding. They have been booked under relevant sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC) following a complaint lodged by the girl’s parents. Inspector Chhibramau Kotwali Balram Mishra said as per the complaint, the girl had been sexually exploited several times by the youth, who resides in her neighbourhood. “When the youth learnt that the girl had become pregnant, he allegedly started forcing her to undergo an abortion. On Monday, on the pretext of an outing, he took her to Kamalganj area and compelled her to consume a pill that would abort her foetus. Soon after consuming the pill, the girl’s condition deteriorated and she collapsed. The youth abandoned her near Kamalganj crossing and fled. The girl was spotted by locals who informed her parents and she was rushed to a nearby hospital where she died during treatment. The body has been sent for postmortem examination,” he added. Police said a case under sections 313 (forcible abortion) and 314 (causing death with abortion) has been registered against the youth and three other members of his family, who are absconding.

column2: UP to shrink cabinet berths to 27 for seamless working
column3: LUCKNOW: The much-awaited reorganization of government departments in UP kicked off on Tuesday when the state cabinet headed by CM Yogi Adityanath took up recommendations of the six-member committee set up by state government for merger of departments of similar nature. The reorganization is likely to reduce the number of existing 99 departments to almost half. The committee has sought the shrinking of the 86 cabinet berths to just 27. State government spokesperson Sidharth Nath Singh told reporters that cabinet reviewed the recommendations of committee that was set up on suggestions of Niti Aayog for better coordination and transparency in functioning. “Final decision was not taken but the cabinet was of view that state departments should correspond with those at Centre,” Singh added. “A final blue print for reorganization is being prepared and would be put up for cabinet approval soon. The Centre has formed new departments, like water conservation. Accordingly, the state government will have to set up a department for fast, smooth functioning in coordination with Centre,” he added. The committee, which was set up on January 3, 2018, and almost took a one-and-half year following marathon meetings, has also said that 17 departments of UP will remain untouched and not be merged. These 17 departments which will not be merged with any department are sugar industry and cane development, cooperative, public works department (PWD), transport, housing and urban development, prisons, election, food and civil supplies, health and famiy welfare, food safety and drug administration, secretariat, parliamentary affairs, Vidhan Parishad, chief minister's office and labour. The reports have made suggestions for bigger merges for key departments like finance, tourism and general administration. Tourism will be merged with languages and religious work of Uttar Pradesh. Finance will now be expanded to have two more departments -- Banking and institutional finance. Civil aviation will be merged with protocol (VIP duties on ministers’ movements) and estate department that deals with government assets. General administration will be merged with national integration, UP reintegration, Public service Management. Also, social welfare will expand into OBC welfare, divyang empowerment and servicemen welfare. A team of Niti Aayog officials had visited the state in May 2017 and recommended the amalgamation of similar departments, following which, a joint working group headed by Singh was constituted. “The Niti Aayog had given a road map and suggested actions needed for speedy development of UP. It included reorganization of departments for better functioning. The motto was minimum government and maximum governance,” he said. The reorganization would result in reduction of departments that could have political ramifications as the number of ministers will have to be reduced or portfolios distributed. For instance, while energy department is with Shrikant Sharma, the department of additional sources of energy is headed by Brijesh Pathak, who also holds the law portfolio. Significantly, Alok Kumar holds the dual charge of principal secretary, energy & additional sources of energy. The cabinet also considered how departments being largely funded by Centre, would be merged. For instance, the rural engineering and rural electrification departments are being completely funded by Centre. “How would their funds be utilized and completion certificates issued will have to be decided. It is a long haul process,” said a senior official.

column2: Defaulting on tax? Time to face the music, literally
column3: LUCKNOW: How does one recover tax from brazen defaulters? ‘Band baja ke’ if it’s a civic body with a sense of humour. The Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) on Tuesday literally made an evasive hotelier dance to its tunes by unleashing a band of musicians on him outside his house on Sapru Marg. The five-member band drummed up a cackling crowd by announcing the defaulter’s name and pending property tax, and within 15 flat minutes, the hotel had coughed up Rs 33 lakh that it hadn’t paid in 1.5 years. Buoyed by the speedy recovery of tax, the civic authorities now plan the same treatment for other defaulters. The LMC has an annual tax target of Rs 350 crore from 5.48 lakh households and commercial establishments. But, it has been able to recover only Rs 178 crore in 2018 and Rs 170 crore in 2017. According to LMC officials, the hotelier who was named and shamed on Tuesday had been warned several times in the past, but he never paid heed. “So, we decided to adopt a policy originally put to practice by Pune Municipal Corporation,” said LMC zonal in-charge 1 Narendra Verma. As the band played and a loudspeaker boomed around 2.30pm, curious neighbours and amused passers-by started gathering near the hotelier’s home. The manager gave us a cheque of Rs 33 lakh, the pending tax. We will continue this strategy against other big defaulters,” Verma added. The message, it seems, has reached everyone loud and clear. Pankaj Shukla, an onlooker, said: “It was an entertaining sight for us, but embarrassing for the defaulter. I am going to clear all my dues ASAP.”

column2: No deluge, but Lucknow already waterlogged
column3: LUCKNOW: The first rainfall of monsoon exposed the laxity of Lucknow municipal corporation (LMC) as showers that lasted from 30 minutes to around two hours in various areas led to the same old problem — heavy waterlogging — proving that the civic body failed to get choked drains cleaned clean even thought the deadline was extended to June 30. An hour’s rainfall in Hazratganj led to ankle-deep waterlogging in the area. “The road in front of my house was waterlogged for two hours. I could not take out my vehicle and had to wade through to the market,” said Nitesh Verma, a resident. Similar complaints poured from Mahanagar. Jayant Mushran, a resident of Sector-B, said, “Just half an hour of showers caused waterlogging in front of my house.” As the drains overflowed at Parivartan Chowk, Daliganj, Lalbagh, Narhi and Kaiserbagh, pedestrians had to walk in the centre of the roads as the sides were inundated. “Dirty water was flowing on footpaths in Kaiserbagh, so we had to walk in the middle of the road,” said Tanuja Singh, a commuter. Waterlogged roads also resulted in jams from Hazratganj to Charbagh. “I am stuck in jam for last 45 minutes, it is the same story in every monsoon,” said Bhuvan Srivastava. A tree fell on Vidhan Sabha marg and slowed down traffic. “We called LMC, but no one picked, so we are removing the tree ourself,” said Rahul Dhawan. “We have already given orders to private agencies to clean all drains, which were not done properly. We have taken strict action against lax agencies by black-listing them,” said an LMC official.

column2: Lucknow airport revises parking fees to end queue chaos
column3: LUCKNOW: Parking a four-wheeler for less than 30 minutes at Chaudhary Charan Singh International Airport in Amausi will now cost 50% less than earlier, but there’s a catch. A minute more will leave a motorist poor by Rs 85 if the vehicle is a hatchback or a sedan and by Rs 100 if it is an SUV. These fee slabs were introduced from Tuesday to ease traffic congestion on the airport premises and also warns of a penalty of Rs 150 if vehicles are found parked in unauthorised areas. While there will no longer be a provision for tokens for those who come to pick or drop passengers, a halt of more than three minutes in the terminal area will invite the usual parking fee. Earlier, parking at Amausi airport was managed by private agencies hired through tenders. Many avoided the designated parking lot to dodge the fee, which led to long queues of vehicles in front of the terminal gates. To avoid the chaos, the Airports Authority of India (AAI) has revised parking fees and regulations. The charge of parking a four-wheeler, which was earlier Rs 60, will now be Rs 30 for 30 minutes. The same for a two-wheeler has been slashed to Rs 10 from Rs 20. However, an overstay for even a minute more will cost a car Rs 85, an SUV Rs 100 and a two-wheeler Rs 20. The rate will last for the next two hours after which the fee will increase by Rs 20/hour for four-wheelers and Rs 10/hour for two-wheelers Since complaints of haphazard parking were common, the AAI has also raised the penalty by five times of the minimum parking fee. In other words, any vehicle standing in a no-parking zone will have to cough up Rs 150 (four-wheeler) or Rs 50 (two-wheeler) for the first 30 minutes after which the vehicle will likely be towed away. Airport director AK Sharma said they were hiring staff to man the parking lots for two-wheelers, four-wheelers and other heavy vehicles at both the domestic and international terminals. “Also, a team will be deputed to keep vigil against unauthorised parking,” he added.

column2: Suspended steno opens fire, panic grips health directorate
column3: LUCKNOW: Panic gripped Health Directorate premises in Kaiserbagh on Tuesday afternoon after a suspended stenographer of the department opened fire on an administrative officer. The employees caught the accused and handed him over to the police, who booked him for attempt to murder. Police said the accused, Srinivas Srivastava, is a native of Kushinagar and worked as a steno at the office of additional director, health and family welfare in Gorakhpur. He was suspended recently on charges of dereliction of duty and had come to Lucknow on Tuesday to meet senior departmental officials to get his suspension revoked. According to an FIR lodged at Wazirganj police station by the administrative officer of the directorate, Shashank Sharma, it was around 1.30pm when Srivastava stopped him and insisted on hearing his case. However, Sharma told him to go to the director, administration. “At this, Srivastava caught me by collar, took out a pistol and fired at me twice. I ducked in time and was saved,” he said. Others in the office reacted swiftly and overpowered Srivastava, who continued to threaten Sharma. “We then somehow managed to push him out of the room and locked the door. The guards standing outside caught him and later handed over to the police,” Sharma mentioned in the FIR. SP (West) Vikas Chandra Tripathi said that a licenced pistol and six bullets of .32 bore were recovered from the accused. “We are investigating the case and scanning CCTV footage and talking to the eye-witnesses about how he managed to take the gun inside. Srivastava has told us that he fired in the air and not at Sharma.”

column2: Random boring stifles water table, Lucknow and suburbs face subsidence
column3: LUCKNOW: The capital district is losing around 1,100 million litres of groundwater reserve every day owing to indiscriminate boring, which is also causing irreparable damage to the aquifer. Scientists have warned that if the problem is not tackled urgently, land subsidence was likely in parts of the city in eight to 10 years from now. An aquifer is an underground layer of water-bearing permeable rock, rock fractures or unconsolidated materials (gravel/sand/silt) from which groundwater can be extracted. According to a study conducted by hydrogeologist RS Sinha on groundwater status across urban centres in the Ganga basin, groundwater in the city and its suburbs is depleting at the rate of 1,100 million litres a day while recharge through rainwater covers only 5% of this total extraction. If the trend continues, water in the first acquifer out of three will be exhausted, leaving a vacuum below the surface and raising the threat of subsidence, warns the study that was recently presented at a Lucknow University conference. Sinha, also convener of Water Action Group, maintained that there were three distinguishable aquifer groups — each separated by 5-10 metres of clay — below Lucknow’s surface. The first is at a depth of 67-155 metres, the second between 155 metres and 327 metres and the third is found between 327 metres and 542 metres. The first aquifer, the expert reiterated, was under “tremendous threat”. Cracks in Kakori warning sign of land subsidenceThe study corroborates another research done by a group led by BB Trivedi, retired scientist of Central Ground Water Board (CGWB). In 2009, the team had warned that if groundwater depletion continued, several areas like Narhi, Charbagh, Rajajipuram and Gomtinagar would face land subsidence between 2024 and 2026. The study had been conducted after 250-metre-long cracks surfaced in Dullu Khera and Vader Khera, two villages in Kakori, in 2007. Lucknow University geology professor Dhruvsen Singh, who probed the Kakori subsidence and has been working on rivers and lakes in the Ganga plains, said groundwater was accumulated in porous and permeable sediment and rocks. An impervious layer of clay acts like a seal. “When water is indiscriminately extracted, it leaves behind vacuum in sediment and rocks. The clay becomes dry and develops cracks. Simultaneously, the vacuum increases the compactness of sediment and clay. They contract when pressure is generated on the surface due to heavy rainfall or movement of heavy objects, leading to land subsidence,” he explained. Singh offered an analogy to elaborate further. “Think of a rasgulla filled with sugar syrup. If you squeeze it too hard, it never regains its original shape. Loss of syrup makes it collapse. The same happens when groundwater is badly exploited without recharging aquifers,” he said.

column2: Rainy Happy Streets for Lucknow!
column3: Even rains couldn’t stop people from participating in the Happy Streets held on Sunday at Chatori Gali in Gomti Nagar. People turned up in large numbers to participate in an array of activities like the yoga, dance, aerobics, gymnastics, jogging, etc. Emcee Shadab (in black) with the crowd (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Emcee Shadab (in black) with the crowd (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) An initiative by The Times of India and Navbharat Times, Happy Streets started with city folk doing some warm-up exercises under the showers. People of all ages indulged in various athletic activities. “It’s a pleasant morning and Happy Streets is an amazing initiative to bring city folk together and enjoy time away from gadgets,” said Dhruv, an entrepreneur. A group of about 15-20 people were seen running, doing push-ups and just enjoying the lovely weather. “The weather is so awesome today. In fact main toh apna rain coat bhi laya hoon to have fun even when it rains,” said an excited Ritesh, a collegian. (L) Apurva Nigam, Swati and Shivangi Nautiyal (R) Dr Gaurav Gupta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Apurva Nigam, Swati and Shivangi Nautiyal (R) Dr Gaurav Gupta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Emcee Shadab introduced the crowd to yoga teacher Mohit, who then helped people across age groups indulge in power yoga. On one side of the street, students were spotted doing Taekwondo stunts. UNDER MY UMBRELLA (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) UNDER MY UMBRELLA (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Yoga was followed by an aerobics session headed by Satendra. Despite the rain people were seen enjoying the fitness activities planned for them. “Happy Streets is the perfect way to rediscover the simple pleasures of enjoying just about any thing, irrespective of how old or young you are,” said Jennifer, a newlywed. — Yashi Agarwal Even rains couldn’t stop these youngsters from doing Taekwondo (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Even rains couldn’t stop these youngsters from doing Taekwondo (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Fitness was on everyone’s mind at Happy Streets (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Fitness was on everyone’s mind at Happy Streets (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: Key documents gutted in PICUP blaze, CM Yogi Adityanath orders probe
column3: LUCKNOW: Many important files, computers and furniture were gutted in a major fire that broke out in the finance department of Pradeshiya Industrial & Investment Corporation of Uttar Pradesh Limited (PICUP) Bhawan in Vibhuti Khand of Gomtinagar on Wednesday evening. The fire broke out on the second floor of the building. Nine fire tenders struggled for over two hours to douse the flames. The fire was reportedly caused by a short-circuit in a computer. Since key files were gutted in the fire, chief minister Yogi Adityanath has ordered a probe to determine the cause of the incident and damages, besides fixing the responsibility. A 3-member committee comprising ADG Lucknow zone, special secretary industry and additional MD UPSIDA PK Pandey and chief fire officer will probe all the aspects and submit its report in two days. According to police, the fire broke out at 7.15pm. Two employees and a guard present on the second floor intially tried to douse the fire and then informed the police and the fire department. By the time fire tenders arrived the flames had spread to the third floor. Chief fire officer VK Singh said, "Except the finance department, all other offices in the building had shut for the day when the fire broke out. We are trying to verify the claims of the employees that fire was caused by a short-circuit. Though fire safety systems were installed in the building, it needs to be probed whether they were functional." Manoj Gupta, deputy manager in the finance department, was present in the building at the time of the incident. He told TOI: "I saw smoke coming out of the chamber of the manager's personal staff at 7.15 pm. Before I could alert the guard, flames started leaping out of the chamber. I, along with my colleague Narendra Kureel and a guard tried to control it through fire extinguishers but in vain. We then informed the police and the fire department and rushed out of the building." Kureel claimed that police and firefighters came 30 minutes after being informed.

column2: Lucknow: Defunct CCTV cameras give crooks a free run
column3: LUCKNOW: An unidentified man looted Rs 1.25 crore from a cash van in Gole Market in 2016, but police are clueless till date because the surveillance camera near the scene of crime was defunct. Killer of businessman Manoj Bhattacharya are still roaming scot-free because the spot near Durgapuri Metro station where he was shot has no CCTV cameras. While most capital cities in India have foolproof electronic surveillance to curb crime, lack of planning and co-ordination between civic authorities and police has left Lucknow vulnerable. The city has over 220 big and small traffic intersections, but only 70 are technically covered by CCTV cameras. Of the 280 cameras installed at these crossings, 44 at 10 major intersections are missing. The "blind zones" include Durgapuri, Charbagh, Station Road, IT College, Badshah Nagar, Bhootnath Market, HAL crossing, Sector-25 Indiranagar and Telibagh. "The cameras at 70 crossings were installed under the modern control room project of Lucknow police between 2015 and 2016. It was supposed to cover the entire city, but the plan changed in 2017 when the responsibility of city surveillance was passed on to Lucknow Municipal Corporation under the Smart City project. The latter is underway," said Sarvesh Mishra, ASP, police control room. Regarding the missing cameras at 10 crossings, Mishra said: "They were removed during construction work by civic agencies, but were not put back together after completion of work." SK Jain, project manager for Smart City, added that they would cover 110 crossings in the city with CCTV cameras and the process was underway. Residents remained sceptical with cases of con, burglary, snatching and shooting being the order of the day. Gomtinagar, the soft target of break-in gangs, is not covered by surveillance cameras, they pointed out. Anil Kumar, who lives at Rapti Apartments in Gomtinagar extension, said not just his residential complex, many others in the area had witnessed a spate of burglaries. "Had CCTV cameras been installed here, police could have at least identified some of the gangs," said Kumar whose flat was targeted on June 15.

column2: Charbagh shooting has Bihar underbelly
column3: LUCKNOW: In a shocking twist to the Charbagh shooting case, police found on Wednesday that the victim, Virendra Thakur (45) was not a property dealer and transporter as he had claimed, but a gangster from Bettiah district of Bihar and was facing several criminal cases, including murder. Thakur had shifted base to Lucknow in 2013 following threat to his life from rival gangs and was living in Nilmatha, Cantonment under an assumed name. Police officials suspect that the attempt on his life was a result of his old gang rivalry or revenge executed in a planned manner through ‘honey trap’. Thakur had suffered two bullet injuries when he was shot at by two unidentified bike-borne miscreants in a sensational daylight shooting on the crowded main road in Charbagh on Tuesday. He had told police that an acquaintance had called him for meeting. Police investigation, however, revealed that his real name was Gorakh Thakur and that 17 criminal cases are registered against him in Bettiah and West Champaran districts of Bihar. SP Government Railway Police, Lucknow division, Saumitra Yadav said, “During questioning, Thakur’s wife Priyanka Singh told us that they hail from Bettiah district in Bihar. When we called Bettiah police, the officials there revealed his criminal history to us and also that his real name was Gorakh, not Virendra. The criminal cases against him are of murder, attempt to murder, arms act, narcotics, extortion and liquor smuggling among others.” “Thakur was running a gang in Bihar, but when gang rivalries escalated and the threat to his life increased, he shifted to Lucknow with his wife and three sons and started living in Nilmatha where his sister lived with her husband, a subedar in army. He changed his first name and projected himself as a property dealer and businessman, but still continued his extortion and smuggling business in the two Bihar districts with the help of his gang. He had been arrested by Bihar Police in various cases and had been to jail several times and was out on bail,” added Yadav. Thakur had sustained bullet injuries on his back and right thigh. He is currently under treatment at KGMU Trauma Centre and his condition is said to be stable.

column2: Kanpur: Dad shoots teen twice in the head
column3: KANPUR: In a suspected case of honour killing, a retired IAF personnel shot dead his 17-year-old daughter in Etawah late Tuesday night for having an affair with a local youth. He was arrested on Wednesday after the victim's maternal uncle Sunil Kumar filed an FIR at Friends Colony police station. Police said the accused, Udayveer Yadav, a resident of Sainik Colony, pumped two bullets into his daughter Soni's head. "Prima facie, it appears that Yadav was angry with his daughter, a student of class XII, for having an affair with a youth despite his objections," the police said . "The accused confessed that he killed his daughter Soni for honour. He had shot her twice from a close range," said ASP (Etawah) Ram Yash.

column2: Ghaziabad: Out for walk, teen ‘abducted, raped by three at gunpoint’
column3: GHAZIABAD: An 18-year-old woman who had gone to a park near her house for an evening walk with her six-year-old sister was allegedly abducted and raped at gunpoint by three youths, including two minors, inside a dilapidated building in Indirapuram. Two of the accused have been detained for questioning, police said. The woman’s father has alleged that the crime took place on June 27 but the police made them run from pillar to post to get an FIR registered. Cops, however, said the woman’s family had earlier reported molestation and on that basis, an FIR under relevant sections was already registered at Indirapuram police station on Tuesday. In the complaint, the woman’s father has alleged that following a power cut in the area on the evening of June 27, his eldest daughter along with her six-year-old sister had gone to a nearby park for a walk. Around 6.30 pm, the three youths, who were lurking in the park, blocked her way, took her to a nearby building and raped her at gunpoint. “My younger daughter witnessed the crime and rushed home to alert her mother. At that time, I was at work. My wife went to the spot and found my daughter lying in an unconscious state. She even grabbed one of the accused from behind, but he managed to flee,” he said. “Later in the evening, we went to the local police post to lodge a complaint. The cops present there took our complaint, but did not register an FIR,” he claimed. It was only after the Ghaziabad SSP’s invention that cops swung into action, he said. Police, however, claimed on the initial complaint of the girl’s family, an FIR under IPC sections 354A (sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment) and 354B (assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe) was registered at Indirapuram police station on Tuesday. Abhay Khand police post in-charge Prahlad Singh, who is investigating the case, said two of the accused, including a minor, has been detained for questioning. “The third one, who is also a minor, is on run,” he said.

column2: One in every 10 pregnant teens is from Uttar Pradesh: Survey
column3: LUCKNOW: Every tenth teenage pregnancy reported in India is of a girl from Uttar Pradesh and the maximum number of these cases are happening in Bahraich district of the state. Experts at a conference in the city on Wednesday extrapolated data from the National Family Health Survey (NHFS-4) and 2011 Census to claim that India is estimated to have around 44.67 lakh teenage pregnancies every year. Of this, over 4 lakh cases are from UP alone, they said. Jointly organised by Society for Advancement of Village Economy (SAVE) and World Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (WASME), the conference said 20 districts accounted for 49% of the state’s total teenage pregnancies. “The burden on UP is huge, which calls for a public movement. We need to go door to door and include education department/private schools to spread awareness against teenage pregnancy, which sometimes is a result of child marriage. It is illegal, but still happens in the name of customs and religion. It leads to complications for both the young mother and the child,” state health minister Sidharth Nath Singh said at the conference. Executive director, Population Foundation of India, Poonam Muttreja said child marriage in UP stood at 21%, as per NFHS data. Of this, 4% end up with teenage pregnancies. In fact, 23% of girls in UP in the age group of 15-19 years end up with a child because they do not have access to contraception,” she added. Secretary of SAVE Sampa Banerjee pointed out that early marriage and consequent teenage pregnancy posed a high risk to the demographic divide of UP. “Awareness campaigns and easy access to reproductive health education and services have the potential to save adolescent girls, which will in turn save economic burden,” she observed.

column2: LMC music campaign collects Rs 65 lakh tax dues
column3: LUCKNOW: The Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) on Wednesday continued its face-the-music campaign outside houses of property tax defaulters and collected around Rs 7.8 lakh from six. At the same time, to avoid the embarrassment, three persons visited the Lucknow Municipal Corporation office in Lalbagh and paid a cumulative amount of Rs 58 lakh. As many as 3.78 lakh houses and commercial establishments owe the Lucknow Municipal Corporation a total of Rs 158 crore. When the evasive owners didn't pay up despite reminders, the civic authorities decided to shame them by unleashing a band of musicians in front of their homes. The amusing sight had pulled a crowd on Tuesday and prompted a hotelier to pay his dues that were pending for a year and a half. An LMC official said, "So far, we have collected around Rs 87 lakh through the campaign. We will continue the crackdown against big defaulters on our list."

column2: Hit by car in Kavi Nagar, cyclist dies
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 33-year-old man succumbed to his injuries after a car rammed into his bicycle in Kavi Nagar area on Tuesday night. Police are trying to identify the accused and the car with the help of CCTV footage collected from the area. “Dharmendra was a resident of Sanjay Nagar. His father informed us that he had gone to meet a relative in Shastri Nagar on Tuesday evening,” an officer said. The accident happened around 11.45pm when Dharmendra was returning home. “The car hit Dharmendra’s bicycle near Hapur Chungi. A patrolling van noticed him and rushed him to a hospital in Sanjay Nagar, where he died during treatment,” an officer said. An FIR has been registered against the accused under IPC sections for rash driving and causing death due to negligence at Kavi Nagar police station.

column2: Housing scheme files missing, GDA to probe
column3: GHAZIABAD: Suspecting foul play, Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) vice-chairperson Kanchan Verma has ordered an inquiry into missing property files relating to its two housing schemes — Madhuban Bapudham and Indirapuram. The missing files came to light when records of the two housing schemes were being scanned for the online property-tagging software that has recently been introduced by the GDA. “Ever since we introduced online property tagging software in the GDA, we have been working on uploading all files related to property, which so far was manually preserved,” said Verma. “The process involves scanning all property files and getting it uploaded in the system. But during the course of scanning, it was found that many files of the Madhuban Bapudham scheme were either found to be missing or duplicate files were placed in the record books,” added Verma. “This raises suspicion as there are chances it could have been deliberate to benefit some buyers, so an inquiry under GDA’s additional secretary has been ordered.” Under the Madhuban Bapudham housing scheme alone, there are over 5,000 property files which are stacked in GDA’s strong room. “In a digital world, the very aim to bring all of GDA’s over 1.5 lakh properties, which are interspersed across 27 of its housing schemes, online is to enable access to property-related details like size, location, building plan and dues at the click of button,” Verma said. The GDA has, on a pilot basis, taken up the Madhuban Bapudham scheme first. The online tagging will cover all its properties.

column2: Uttar Pradesh government retires 200 tainted officials, more on radar
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government has compulsorily retired more than 200 officials across 72 government departments and is contemplating harsh punishment against 400 others in pursuance of its zero tolerance policy towards corruption and non-performance. At least 51 employees of state home department and 36 of revenue department have been forcibly retired. Similarly, eight officials of basic education, seven of dairy and six of cane development departments have met the same fate. Besides, five employees each of urban development and excise departments and three of khadi and village development board were also handed over retirement letters, said officials. Also, non-performing and tainted employees above 50 years of age are on the radar. This comes two weeks after the CM took a similar step to forcefully retire corrupt and lax police officers who were above the age of 50, as per an order made public by then UP Police ADG (establishment) Piyush Anand. Plan to stop promotion of tainted employeesAll state departments have been asked to prepare a list of officials facing corruption. They too would be sent packing,” said state government spokesperson Shrikant Sharma. The government is also contemplating to stop promotion of tainted employees, who are less than 50 years of age. “Inquiry against them would also be expedited,” he said. Sources said around 170 employees of energy department are likely to face the music and their promotions would be stalled. Likewise, 26 officials of basic education and 25 of panchayati raj departments are in the cross-hairs. According to an estimate, the Yogi Adityanath government has initiated inquiry against 400 employees. “No one involved in corruption will be spared,” Sharma said. Under fundamental rule 56 of state government, the competent authority at any time can serve a three-month notice to an official above 55 years of age and send him on compulsory retirement. The fresh order by government has hit the power department most, with 169 of its employees being bracketed as fit to receive punishment for graft or “adverse” job entry in the department. None of them though would be voluntarily retiring “They are free to move court. The move came after brainstorming and discussions with top IAS, legislators and members of various agencies,” said government official. Non-performing employees came under the radar soon after state government’s decision to get rid of officials who were given extension after retirement by the Akhilesh Yadav government.

column2: A midnight musical treat for Lucknowites
column3: A cafe in town organized a live Indie music performance by a band named Zubaan recently. The interesting part about this event was that the performance was held at midnight. "The reason why I thought of organising this event at midnight is because not everyone is free in the evening for such events. So it was an experiment which thankfully was successful!" shared Bhoopesh Rai, organiser of the event. (L) Nuria (R) Priyanka Sarkar and RP Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Nuria (R) Priyanka Sarkar and RP Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  The band comprised three artists playing different instruments. While Kanishk Sinha and Raghvendra Kumar played Cajon-tabla and Mohan Veena, respectively, the lead singer Kavish Seth played his own invented instrument called Noori. (L) Ali Hamid Zaidi (R) Anuradha and Rashmi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Ali Hamid Zaidi (R) Anuradha and Rashmi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) The highlight of the event was the Kathak performance by Nuria, who came all the way from Spain. The combination of Kathak and live Indie music was something that was loved by everyone who attended it. (L) Arun and Bhawna (R) Farah Rizvi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Arun and Bhawna (R) Farah Rizvi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Cricketer RP Singh was also spotted enjoying the performance over hukkah and snacks. Accompanying Singh was Priyanka Sarkar. Also present at the event were Ujjwal Seth, Ajay Jain and Ali Hamid Zaidi, among others. — Saad Abbasi (L) Bhoopesh Rai (R) Meesum Ammar Rizvi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Bhoopesh Rai (R) Meesum Ammar Rizvi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Madhulika Singh and Supriya Handa (R) Ritu Agarwal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Madhulika Singh and Supriya Handa (R) Ritu Agarwal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Nitika and Amal (R) Abhinav Chhabra (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Nitika and Amal (R) Abhinav Chhabra (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Ujjwal Seth and Saad Warsi (R) Ajay Jain (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Ujjwal Seth and Saad Warsi (R) Ajay Jain (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: A play on hardships of Kashmiri Pandits staged in Lucknow
column3: A play titled 'Khamoshi Sili Sili' was staged at the Bhartendu Natya Akademi, recently. The play was a translation of the famous play Fiddler on the Roof by Joseph Stein. It was adapted by Asif Ali, while Suresh Sharma directed the play. The National School of Drama-based artists performed in a way that everyone present was glued to their seats. A scene from the play Khamoshi Sili Sili (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) A scene from the play Khamoshi Sili Sili (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The play revolved around communal pressures in Kashmir, intolerance and the hardships faced by the Kashmiri Pandits. Some of the characters including Prithvinath, Nonika, Didda and Sheen, were dramatized by Shanawaz Khan, Anamika Sager, Bornali Borah and Sakshi Sharma for the stage. (L) Dr Anil Rastogi (R) Madhvi Srivastava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Dr Anil Rastogi (R) Madhvi Srivastava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The audience outnumbered the capacity of the auditorium and most of them witnessed the play standing. "Such a sensitive topic was handled brilliantly by the director. I was overwhelmed to watch the actors act in different situations," said Anisha. — Saad Abbasi (L) Prateek and Faisal (R) Sukumar Tudu (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Prateek and Faisal (R) Sukumar Tudu (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shobha Jagdish (R) Shubham Tiwari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shobha Jagdish (R) Shubham Tiwari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Surya Mohan Kulshreshtha (R) Swati Rawat and Kavita Srivastava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Surya Mohan Kulshreshtha (R) Swati Rawat and Kavita Srivastava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: Got a plaint against errant officials? Dial UP CM helpline
column3: LUCKNOW: Continuing his government’s recent anti-graft policies, chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Thursday launched a 24-hour toll free helpline for people to register complaints and air grievances against errant government officers from anywhere in the state. The CM helpline 1076 will be dealt by staff of Yogi’s office. This came a day after the government said that it had voluntarily retired 201 inefficient officials — either due to corruption taint or having crossed 50 years of age — from 72 departments, while also announced to mete out harsh punishment to 417 officials from the departments including home, revenue, finance and power. Yogi said the helpline was an addition to the existing Integrated Grievance Redressal System (IGRS) known as Jansunwai portal, that deals with complaints on website. “The new system was on a testing mode for the past one year. I was delighted to see the response of people from far away corners sharing their complaints and redressal through IGRS. Now we have introduced 1076 helpline for round-the-clock monitoring of complaints and providing them personal contact,” CM told a gathering at Lok Bhawan here. Yogi said the helpline would also work as a self-monitoring mechanism on governments officers’ availability, attendance and their work performance. “I will attach the ACRs (annual confidential reports) of officers and their attendance based on this helpline. It will be a 360 degrees mechanism. That will monitor the government performance as well,” he said “After registration of a complaint, its follow-up will be done within 3-4 days to make sure that it is redressed,” the CM said. He, however, warned of action against those sending fake complaints and raising false alarms against honest officers. Yogi shared that the helpline has generated direct employment for 500 officials, who would work in the call centre. He also warned of action against the officials of the department concerned in case the complaints are not addressed.

column2: Excise department churning to break mafia nexus
column3: LUCKNOW: The state excise department has decided to transfer lower-rung officials who have been holding on to their posts for a long time. Sources said this was done to break the nexus between unscrupulous excise department officials and the liquor mafia. This comes a day after the department announced that NSA will be slapped on those supplying adulterated liquor in the state. In the recent hooch tragedy that claimed the lives of about a dozen people in Barabanki last month, six officials — including an inspector rank officer of the excise department — were placed under suspension for their alleged involvement in the sale of spurious liquor. Allegations of manipulation in postings and extended stay by officers in one position had come to light during a review meeting by chief minister Yogi Adityanath. There are nearly 1,300 district-level excise officers rung in the state and many, according to sources, have managed to stay in one position for a long period. Principal secretary (excise) Sanjay Bhoosreddy told TOI that a warning was issued on Thursday to lower-rung officers to abstain from seeking stay on new postings under the premise of family compulsions. This would be deemed “misconduct” and “disciplinary action may follow,” he added. The new transfer and posting policy of the state government holds that no official can stay in a district beyond three years and in a division beyond seven years, said Bhoosreddy. “But a number of officials have been under the scanner for staying on in one district for five to 10 years. These officers have been identified and action will be taken against them,” said Bhoosreddy.

column2: Haj quota up, but applications dip
column3: LUCKNOW: There has been a steep decline in the number of haj applications from Uttar Pradesh this year despite 20% increase in the state’s quota. The applications are down by 20%, shows the data of State Haj Committee. In 2018, as many as 43,100 pilgrims had applied for 29,053 haj seats from UP. Of them, 31,679 pilgrims had finally boarded the flights to Mecca after clearance of waiting lists and adjustments of seats from other states. This year, UP has 32,237 seats after the Central Haj Committee added 20% seats to the state’s kitty. But so far, State Haj Committee has received just 34,384 applications — a 20% drop as compared to applications received last year. However, given the low number of applications, all applicants have been selected for the pilgrimage. Taking last minute cancellations into consideration, it is expected that 32,100 pilgrims from UP will board the haj flights to Saudi Arabia this year. State Haj Committee authorities said this was the first occasion when applications have dipped. Though they did not cite any reason for the drop, sources attribute it to scrapping of haj subsidy by the central government. “There is a drop in the number of applications but we are yet to analyse the reasons,” said secretary, State Haj Committee, Rahul Gupta. The first batch of haj pilgrims flew out of Delhi on Wednesday. Haj pilgrims will leave from Lucknow embarkation point on July 21 and from Varanasi on July 29.

column2: Cabinet rejig, bypolls on Nadda’s mind
column3: LUCKNOW: BJP working president JP Nadda will arrive in Lucknow on Friday for a meeting of the high-powered core committee headed by him. Nadda will review preparations for the party’s membership drive and upcoming bypolls for 12 UP assembly seats. The committee also includes chief minister Yogi Adityanath, UP BJP chief Mahendra Nath Pandey and UP BJP organisational secretary Sunil Bansal. Party sources said that Nadda has sought names of prospective candidates for the forthcoming byelection. The visit also comes amid speculations of cabinet expansion and state unit reorganisation.

column2: Charbagh shooting: Bihar gang war over contracts?
column3: LUCKNOW: The name of a Bihar-based criminal Vinay Sharma, currently lodged in Buxar jail, surfaced on Thursday during probe in Charbagh shooting in which gangster Gorakh Thakur was shot at by two bike-borne assailants in rivalry for railway contracts. Thakur told police that Vinay could be behind the attack. GRP Charbagh SHO Somveer Singh said, “The assailants could have come from Bihar. Gorakh has told us that he has old rivalry with Vinay Sharma and several shootouts took place between their gangs.” Police identified the assailants in CCTV footage on the basis of the account of Railway Protection Force (RPF) constable R K Singh. The CCTV footage shows that the entire episode ended within four minutes. Gorakh arrived at 1.06pm and assailants escaped at 1.10pm after shooting at the target. One of them also dropped the helmet he was holding in his hand. Officials are taking help of Bihar police to identify the shooters. TOI also contacted senior police officials of West Champaran district in Bihar where majority of criminal cases against Gorakh are registered. SSP Jayant Kant said that Gorakh was a rival of Vinay Sharma and had been involved in railway contracts in the district. “Besides handling his business in Bihar, we have learnt that Thakur was also getting into illegal mining business in UP,” he said.

column2: Legally tasty? Food vans to stay on Lucknow roads
column3: LUCKNOW: Fast food vans may soon legally operate in the city. A proposal to lift a ban, imposed on these vehicles in December last year, will be tabled at the house meeting of Lucknow Municipal Corporation on July 7. According to a survey done by the civic body, there are around 500 food wagons illegally operating in prominent areas such as Gomitnagar, Mahanagar, Jankipuram, Aliganj, Aashiana, Charbagh, Vikasnagar, Hazratganj and Munshipulia. The decision to ban these vans was taken because their haphazard parking in public places and on busy roads led to frequent traffic bottlenecks. However, the directive was never implemented in letter and spirit. As a result, while there was no respite from congestion of arteries, the LMC also suffered financial losses to the tune of Rs 90 lakh in terms of licence fee. Now, the civic body has asked the in-charge of all eight city zones to identify ideal spots where food vans can operate without disrupting traffic. If the proposal gets a nod at the house meeting, all food trucks will be licensed and zonal officials will then carry out their registration, besides allotting them specific spots. The LMC, in association with the Food and Drug Administration, will also periodically check the quality of food being served from these vans. If the quality is found to be bad, the registration will immediately be cancelled. Municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi said, “We are in process of framing laws for food vans and the proposal will be tabled in front of the house. A policy will be framed to regularise food vans (if the proposal is cleared).”

column2: Defaulter thrashes LMC’s band-baja tax recovery team
column3: LUCKNOW: The face-the-music campaign of LMC to recover pending property tax boomeranged on Thursday when a rogue defaulter in Sarojininagar roughed up an official and his driver on being denied more time to cough up dues. While an FIR has been lodged at Sarojininagar thana, LMC staff have threatened to boycott work from Friday if police failed to take appropriate action against the accused. The LMC band-baja recovery team, led by tax superintendent Dhirendra Singh and in-charge of Zone 5 Sanjay Bharti, went to collect Rs 70 lakh from the owner of a commercial complex in Gauri Market. As the band drummed up the name-shaming drive, the owner came out of the building and tried to negotiate with LMC officials. The FIR says he sought more time. When the team refused the same, he mobilised neighbouring shopkeepers and allegedly started beating up tax superintendent Singh and his driver Gangaram. When Singh tried to call police, the accused allegedly snatched his phone and broke it. The unexpected belligerence prompted the LMC team to beat a hasty retreat. The injured were taken to hospital and discharged after first aid. Sarojininagar SHO Pramod Kumar Singh said the accused trader had been charged with assault and using force to deter a public servant from discharging duty. “The LMC officials were sent for medical examination. Necessary action will be taken against the accused,” the officer added.

column2: ED attaches 4 plots, flat of Gomti riverfront engineers
column3: LUCKNOW: The enforcement directorate (ED) on Thursday attached immovable properties of three engineers of irrigation department involved in Gomti riverfront development project. The properties include one plot of superintending engineer Roop Singh Yadav in Noida, a residential flat of chief engineer S N Sharma in Ghaziabad and three plots of assistant engineer Anil Yadav in Gomtinagar, Madiaon and Adilnagar, having total value of Rs 1 crore, said ED officials. The attachment of properties was done under the provisions of Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA), 2002. "During investigation, searches were carried out and incriminating documents mentioning amount and manner of payment of bribes to engineers Roop Singh Yadav, Anil Yadav and S N Sharma, were seized," an ED official said. Irrigation engineers used wives as financial frontsED officials revealed that the accused engineers had used the financial profiles of their wives to channelize, place, layer and project illegally earned money in the voluntary Undisclosed Income Declaration Scheme, 2016 of the Government of India. Further investigation is in progress and more properties may be attached and the three be prosecuted for involvement in money laundering. Earlier, taking cognisance of CBI FIR, ED had in March 2018 filed a criminal case under Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) in Rs 1,500 crore Gomti riverfront project scam. CBI had started probe after the Yogi Adityanath government in Uttar Pradesh had ordered an inquiry into the project and filed FIR against then chief engineers Gulesh Chandra, S N Sharma, Qazim Ali, then superintending engineers Mangal Yadav, Akhil Raman, Kamaleshwar Singh, Roop Singh Yadav and executive engineer Surendra Yadav. Gulesh Chandra, Mangal Yadav, Akhil Raman and Roop Singh Yadav have since retired. The government had first constituted a committee under retired Allahabad High Court judge Alok Kumar Singh, which found irregularities in the project, following which Gomtinagar police registered a case on June 19. The government subsequently sought a CBI probe and the premier agency took over the investigation on November 24, 2017. Rs 1,500-crore project involved construction of a rubber dam to maintain its water level, a stadium, amphitheatre for 2,000 people, cycle and jogging tracks, a play area for children and a musical fountain. It was inaugurated in November 2016 by then chief minister Akhilesh Yadav.
