It was inaugurated in November 2016 by then chief minister Akhilesh Yadav.

column2: Uttar Pradesh government to move HC against Mukhtar Ansari's acquittal
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government on Thursday evening said that it would file an appeal in the high court against the Delhi's CBI special court order acquitting mafia and BSP MLA Mukhtar Ansari, his brother and BSP MP Afzaal Ansari and other accused in the murder of BJP MLA Krishnanand Rai. Rai, an MLA from Mohammadabad seat in Ghazipur, was shot dead in 2005 along with six aides. A state government spokesperson said the CM has taken cognizance of the verdict. The government will examine the judgement and file appeal in the high court, he added. The accused were acquitted due to lack of evidence. Special Judge Arun Bhardwaj, who considered various aspects of the case, including whether there was an enmity between Ansaris and Rai, held that when a contestant loses Assembly elections, "it will not result in enmity of such nature and enormity that he will think of murdering his opponent who defeated him". Rai's wife Alka Rai, who had pleaded for a CBI probe, had also hinted at moving the high court. Alka is MLA from Mohammadabad assembly seat in Ghazipur. Besides Ansari brothers, others acquitted in the case are Sanjeev Maheshwari, Eijazul Haq (brother-in-law of Ansaris), Rakesh Pandey, Ramu Mallah, Mansoor Ansari and Munna Bajrangi. Bajrangi, a dreaded criminal in UP, was killed inside Baghpat jail last year.

column2: Debts tribunal summons MLA son of Gorakhpur 'bahubali'
column3: LUCKNOW: Debt recovery tribunal (DRT) in Delhi has summoned BSP MLA Vinay Shankar Tiwari on a complaint by a consortium of banks, citing non-performing assets (NPAs) alleging fraud by Tiwari's firm Gangotri Enterprises Ltd to the tune of Rs 1,129 crore. The Chillupar MLA is the son of veteran Gorakhpur strongman Hari Shankar Tiwari. A consortium of banks led by Bank of India and including Canara Bank, Oriental Bank of Commerce, Corporation Bank, IDBI, Axis Bank and Central Bank of India had approached DRT for the recovery of loans. Contacted by TOI on phone, Vinay Shankar refused comment on the summons or the bank loan recovery process. The DRT on July 1 issued a public notice against Tiwari and 33 others including his father, brother Bhishm Shankar Tiwari, wife Reeta Tiwari, son Kandarp, daughter Vartika and several management officials and director of Gangotri and its off-shoot companies - Royal Empire Marketing and Kandarp Hotels Pvt Ltd. "For the satisfaction of this court, the DRT feels that it is not appropriate to send this notice to you in a normal way, hence by way of this advertisement notice, we are informing that you have to be present on July 6, 2019, at 10.30 am," the DRT notice, published in the state's vernacular dailies, said. The banks have told DRT that the borrowing company Gangotri and its officials, with dishonest intention of causing wrongful loss and "wrongful gains to themselves" have fraudulently committed acts of misappropriation, criminal breach of trust by diverting bank's funds for purposes other than what loans were granted for. The banks also told DRT the declaration of fraud was reported to RBI and Central Repository of Information on Large Credits. The banks have also approached RBI to request a 'look out circular' (LOC) against company's director, guarantors and promoters, saying it is necessary "to prevent any possibility of economic offender leaving the country." Gangotri was formed in 1991. Vinay and Reeta are the second-largest shareholders in Gangotri.

column2: Yogi government retires 200 tainted officials, 400 more on radar
column3: LUCKNOW: The Yogi Adityanath government in UP on Wednesday said that in pursuance of its 'zero tolerance' policy against corruption, it has given compulsory retirement to over 200 tainted officials and employees in the past two years while more than 400 others are under the scanner for 'exemplary punishment'. The move has been initiated on the basis of a report of a screening committee formed in July 2017, soon after the BJP government came to power and Yogi ordered to identify officials and employees who have crossed 50 years of age and are involved in graft cases. "The government has given forced retirement to 201 state employees. Many more are on the radar," UP minister and government spokesperson Shrikant Sharma said, adding that 417 others are being watched and could get 'exemplary punishment'. Sharma said all departments have been asked to prepare a list of officials facing corruption charges. "They too would be sent packing," he added. Among those who have been given forced retirement, 51 are from the home department, 36 from revenue, eight from basic education, seven from dairy development and six from cane development. Besides, five employees each of urban development and excise departments and three of Khadi and village development board were also handed over retirement letters, said officials sources. The government is also contemplating to stop promotion of tainted employees who are less than 50 years of age. "At the same time, inquiry against them would be expedited," Sharma said. Among those on the list for 'exemplary punishment', 170 employees are from energy department, 26 from basic education and 25 from panchayati raj. While the list of corrupt officials was ready, the action was fast-tracked when, around 10 days ago, Yogi started taking review meetings in Lucknow, Varanasi, Gorakhpur, Azamgarh, Saharanpur and Moradabad about progress on various central and state government schemes. During these review meetings, he directed various district administrations to take quick action against officers identified as 'corrupt'. A senior official told TOI that service records of employees and officials, mainly those who are 50 years or above, are being checked for making the list. "The officers and employees are being screened not only as per their service entries but also their reputation in department," said a senior IAS officer.

column2: HC judge who wrote to PM denied farewell
column3: LUCKNOW: Justice Rangnath Pandey of Allahabad high court —who, according to a news report, had alleged “favouritism, nepotism and casteism” in appointment of judges in a letter to PM Modi —was not given a customary farewell when he retired on Thursday. Senior registrar of Lucknow bench of Allahabad HC withdrew the July 1 notice about the farewell, known as full court reference in legal parlance. It has been a tradition of the HC to extend a farewell reference to a retiring judge and the court administration had on July 1 issued a notice, informing Oudh Bar Association, the advocate general and the additional solicitor general about the ceremony. In a fresh order, senior registrar Manvendra Singh said, “Due to unforeseen circumstances, the July 1 notice on full court reference (farewell) is withdrawn.”

column2: Narrow escape for 6 families as flats in Vaishali catch fire
column3: GHAZIABAD: Six families, including those of a Prasar Bharati private secretary and a chartered accountant, had a narrow escape early on Thursday after their flats in Vaishali were engulfed in a fire caused by a short-circuit in a transformer nearby. Residents said they had seen sparks coming out of the transformer on Wednesday evening too, but the electricity department officials who had come there did not take their complaint too seriously. They allegedly doused the sparks with sand and left. The six flats that were damaged are built on two back-to-back plots (263 and 293), while the 630 KVA transformer is installed within metres of the two buildings. P Chandrashekhar (53), a private secretary in Prasar Bharati, said he and his wife were sleeping in their first-floor flat (B1 263) when they heard a loud noise around 12.45am and saw flames leaping towards their house. “Had there been a little delay in coming out of the house, we would not have survived. The blaze was quite intense and had spread to the drawing room in no time. Fortunately, it was only my wife and I who were in the house. My daughter is on a trip to Singapore to attend an academic seminar. We somehow managed to come out of the flat and run downstairs,” Chandrashekhar told TOI. Vijay Prakash Singh, a chartered accountant who lives on the second floor of the same building with his wife and two young sons, accused the fire department of responding late. “Initially, they sent a fire tender having a capacity of just 200-300 litres of water. It was insufficient to douse the flames. Maximum damage had already been done by the time bigger ones came to our rescue,” he added. It was the first-floor flat of Rajiv Shahi, who works with a finance company, on the second plot that bore the maximum brunt. Almost all household items inside his flat were burnt to ashes. The other flats that were damaged in the fire are owned a GST inspector, and a manager with an automobile company. Pashchimanchal Vidyut Vitaran Nigam Limited (PVVNL) sub-divisional officer Shashank Shukla said the blaze could have started because of dry leaves on the roof of the building, where the transformer is installed. “I will prepare a report and submit it to the electricity department. We are with the victims and would try to provide them monetary relief as well,” he added. On the issue of delayed response, chief fire officer Sunil Kumar Singh said fire tenders were busy attending to two other incidents. “Earlier, we were informed about the fire in the transformer only. Other fire tenders were immediately rushed to the spot after we came to know the exact magnitude of the blaze,” he added.

column2: Ghaziabad civic body plans two pipes for kitchen, sewer water
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) is working on a plan to ensure judicious use of kitchen and sewer water in the city. It is in the process of formulating guidelines for housing societies which will be later incorporated in its building bylaws. “Waste water has been categorised into two heads — grey and black water. While grey refers to kitchen waste water, black refers to waste water from toilets,” said Asheesh Shivpuri, chief architect and town planner, GDA. “We have proposed that all future group housing societies lay two separate pipelines connected to each household through which kitchen (grey water) and sewer (black water) will be channelised,” he said. “Kitchen water, which does not require much treatment, will be stored in an underground reservoir especially built for the purpose. Residents can easily use it for watering lawns and washing their cars,” added Shivpuri. “Toilet or sewer water will be channelised into the nearest STP (sewage treatment plant) through a network of pipelines. After treatment, it will be used for watering the city’s parks and at construction sites,” he said. The GDA hopes to limit groundwater extraction which has wreaked havoc with the city’s table. As per the UP groundwater department, the average depletion in Ghaziabad in the last five years, from 2013 to 2018, has been recorded at 4.35 metres. There are at least 12 spots out of total 38 measured in the city table that have gone dry in this period.

column2: Three youths arrested for stealing SUV
column3: GHAZIABAD: Three youths, including a sales official with an automobile showroom and a BBA graduate, were arrested on Wednesday for allegedly robbing an SUV last year from Link road area. Police said the accused committed thefts to lead a lavish lifestyle. The trio had apparently removed the original number plate of the vehicle after stealing it. Police said they had stolen the SUV for their personal use. However, for the past few months, it was parked at a shop for repairing. The arrested persons have been identified as Neeraj, a resident of Nandgram, Prince from Sadiq Nagar, and Shanky Tyagi fom Balaji Enclave in Govindpuram. Besides the stolen SUV, two country-made pistols and a knife were also recovered from their possession. They were arrested from Sanjay Geeta Chowk around 11.45pm on Wednesday. Police said Neeraj and Shanky had stolen the SUV and a Honda WR- V in October last year. Prince’s role was limited to conduct recce and identify targets. Expalining the youths modus operandi, police said they would target people in secluded areas and flee with their valuables at gunpoint. Prince had a criminal history and was arrested two months ago for conducting robbery in a wedding function. He had recently come out of jail. Circle officer 2 (city) Atish Kumar Singh said, “All the accused are from well-to-do families, but they aspired to lead a luxurious life which turned them into criminals. Neeraj worked as the sales executive with Maruti company during day time, but became a robber when he got free. Prince is a BBA graduate and his family runs a tent business. Shanky was doing an apprenticeship with Shriram Pistons. His father works with a private firm in Noida.”

column2: Lucknowites enjoy this fashionable evening
column3: A get-together of businessmen and entrepreneurs was recently organised in the city. The much awaited part of the event was the fashion show organised during the latter part of the evening. The models exhibited ethnic as well as western attire. The members of the club enjoyed snacks with cocktails and danced at the end of the event. — Saad Abbasi (L) Aarti Vaid (R) Eesha and Kunal Punjabi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Aarti Vaid (R) Eesha and Kunal Punjabi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Arjun Singh (R) Sumit and Raghav (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Arjun Singh (R) Sumit and Raghav (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Astha Mathur (C) Mansi Bajaj (R) Monisha (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Astha Mathur (C) Mansi Bajaj (R) Monisha (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Nitin Mohan (R) Vikas and Shachi Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Nitin Mohan (R) Vikas and Shachi Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Prakhar Tandon (C) Ratika Rastogi (R) Supreet Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Prakhar Tandon (C) Ratika Rastogi (R) Supreet Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: Lucknow Municipal Corporation likely to miss ODF deadline
column3: With more than five lakh houses in Lucknow district yet to be covered under open defecation free (ODF) scheme, Lucknow Municipal Corporation may miss the extended deadline of October 2 due to slow rate of toilet construction. To meet the target, the corporation needs to build 8,000 toilets daily. But, at present, it’s building only 1,200 toilets every day. Out of the total target of constructing 17 lakh toilets in Lucknow, LMC has built around 12 lakh toilets since April 2017. Initially, the deadline was October 2, 2018. But as many districts are behind the target, the central government on Friday extended the deadline till October 2, 2019. An official of Lucknow Municipal Corporation claimed that they will will double the pace of work to meet October 2 deadline. He said LMC has hired 11 private companies to build toilets.

column2: 30 IAS transferred, Kumbh boss gets plum postings
column3: LUCKNOW: In a major reshuffle, UP government on Friday transferred 30 IAS officers, including social welfare director, CM secretary and PWD special secretary. Last week, social welfare department had stirred a row after it issued an order to include 17 MBC categories in UP in SC list, while quoting a 2017 interim order by Allahabad High Court on Akhilesh government’s pre-poll announcement on these castes. However, the order was later termed illegal by the Centre. On Friday, the government left the social welfare director post vacant. Incumbent director Jagdish Prasad has been sent to SIDCO (State construction and infrastructure development corporation) as director. In other transfers, the government elevated director (information) Shishir Singh as special secretary, culture and Hindi publicity director. Singh had played a crucial role along with principal secretary, information and publicity, Awanish Awasthi in coordinating, highlighting and promoting government’s key programmes. Chief minister’s secretary Manish Chauhan, a 2000 batch IAS, has been sent to sugarcane department as commissioner. PWD special secretary Rahul Pandey has been made vice-chairman of Varanasi development authority. Several IAS officers, who had been awaiting posting orders, were accommodated in Friday transfers. Vikas Gothwal, a 2003 batch IAS, has been made urban development secretary. The government also rewarded Vijay Kiran Anand, who was Kumbh Mela affairs in-charge — a post specially created during the fair — with a plum posting with multiple portfolios as special secretary (basic education), state Sarv Shiksha Abhiyan director and director midday meal programme. Anand, a 2009 batch IAS, comes from Karnataka. Isha Duhan, a 2014 batch IAS, will take charge in Meerut as chief development officer and has been shifted from Bulandhshahr where she was working in the same capacity. Akash Deep, 2005 batch IAS and mission director, Swachh Bharat Mission (Rural), has been brought to finance department as special secretary.

column2: ED attaches Rs 89 lakh assets of ex-Noida chief engineer
column3: LUCKNOW/NEW DELHI: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) on Friday attached assets worth Rs 89 lakh of the former chief engineer of Noida, Greater Noida and Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority Yadav Singh in a money laundering case, taking the total attachment in the case to more than Rs 21 crore. The former chief engineer is being investigated under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) for illegally allotting work to contractors which resulted in undue advantage of Rs 19.92 crore to NKG Infrastructure Ltd, JSP Constructions Pvt Ltd and Tirupati Construction Company. Singh was suspended in 2015. Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) had registered an FIR against him in July 2015. The agency later filed a chargesheet against Singh and his family members, revealing accumulation of disproportionate assets to the tune of about Rs 24 crore — 513% more than his known source of income — on the basis of which the ED had started the probe. In another case filed by the agency, the probe found Singh’s wife, Kusum Lata, had acquired disproportionate assets from the proceeds Singh received by awarding illegal contracts. “Investigation found that Kusum Lata along with her sister-in-law Vidhya Devi formed a trust named PGP Trust to project proceeds of crime as untainted money. Donations by cheque were deposited in the account of PGP Trust and equivalent amount in cash was returned in lieu of donations received,” the ED had claimed in a chargesheet. The agency had earlier attached properties of PGP Charitable Trust of Singh in which his wife was one of the trustees. The assets attached on Friday include residential and commercial properties, besides agricultural land and bank accounts. Explaining the modus operandi, ED officials said that during investigation it was revealed that funds related to income from illegal earning/unexplained sources were routed to the trust under control of Singh in the guise of corpus donations. The same fund was routed to the bank accounts of his family members in guise of sale proceeds of properties and the same was used for purchasing further commercial/residential properties at Delhi and Noida and maintaining bank balances to the tune of Rs 89 lakh.

column2: Jobless and suspicious of wife, man wipes out family before killing self
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 37-year-old man allegedly killed his wife with a hammer and poisoned his three kids to death before committing suicide in Masuri early on Friday. The alleged murders come barely six days after a former official of a pharmaceutical company reportedly killed his wife and two children and hanged himself from the ceiling fan of their house in Gurgaon. Officers in Ghaziabad police said Pradeep had been unemployed for the past one and a half years and had turned alcoholic over time. His wife Sangeeta (32) worked as a nurse at AIIMS’s National Drug Dependence Treatment Centre here, and the couple had three daughters — Mansavi (8), Yashasvi (5) and Ojasvi (3). They lived with Pradeep’s father Feru Valmiki, who retired as a master chief petty officer in the Indian Navy, mother Sheela and sister Reena in a single-storey house in New Shatabadipuram. Police have recovered a six-page suicide note purportedly written by Pradeep, suspecting his wife of being involved in an illicit relationship. The letter also vividly mentions the way the woman and the three girls were murdered. Quoting the “suicide note”, SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh said Pradeep first hit his wife on the head multiple times with a hammer and then forced the three daughters to drink poison. He wrapped their mouths and heads with a four-inch-wide black tape to ensure they did not blurt out the poison. Pradeep, too, wrapped his head with the same tape and drank poison. Police said when they entered the room, the bodies of Pradeep and his three daughters were found on the bed while Sangeeta lay on the floor. She was being rushed to a nearby government hospital as she was found breathing feebly, but died on the way. Ironically, the black adhesive tape used by Pradeep to wrap the faces of his wife and daughters was actually brought home by Sangeeta. It is used for containing violent patients undergoing treatment at hospitals. It was Pradeep’s sister Reena who first spotted the bodies. Reena told police she woke up around 4.30am and saw Pradeep lying on the sofa. Asked why he was not in the bedroom, Pradeep went inside but did not say anything. A little later, Reena heard cries of the three children and knocked on the door, but Pradeep asked her to go back saying he was just talking to them. Finding something amiss, Reena woke up her elderly parents and alerted neighbours. When she peeped inside the bedroom through a glass above the door, she saw the bodies lying on the bed. The police control room was informed around 5.40am. SSP Singh reached the house along with a team of senior officials. The bodies were sent for autopsy. Relatives said Pradeep would often accuse his wife of having an affair and had claimed that his daughters had been conceived through IVF. He was jobless for around a year and a half and would often come home drunk, which led to frequent quarrels with his wife. On Thursday too, Pradeep and Sangeeta had fought over delay in paying the electricity bill. A commerce graduate, Pradeep had taken admission in a foundation course offered by the Institute of Cost Accountants of India, but left it in the middle. A relative said Pradeep had told him he had landed a job in a private company and would join work in a few days. According to the man’s cousin, Ravindra Kumar, Pradeep and Sangeeta had met 12 years ago while working at a private hospital in Patparganj and fell in love. Pradeep worked there as a storekeeper while Sangeeta was a nurse. Sangeeta was originally from Ranchi, while Pradeep’s hometown was in Meerut’s Aghera village. “Pradeep doted on his three daughters and it was quite shocking to see the way he killed them. We had spoken on Thursday evening and he told me he would like to see me on Friday,” Ravindra said. On a complaint by Pradeep’s father Feru Valmiki, an FIR against his son was registered under IPC sections 302 (murder), 306 (abetment of suicide) and 307 (attempt to murder) at Masuri police station.

column2: Kanpur: Woman, grandson shot in home
column3: KANPUR: A 70-year-old woman and her 12-year-old grandson were shot dead by unidentified men at their house in Sanigwan area of Chakeri on late Friday. The victims were identified as Shanti Devi and Sujal Gupta. The victims screamed for help to alert neighbours in vain. "The motive behind the double murder could not be ascertained. We are questioning Vinod Gupta, their relative, who was the first to spot the gory killings. The assailants probably used 315 bore fire to execute the killings. The accused shot them from point blank range," said SP east Raj Kumar Agarwal. A case of murder has been registered.

column2: JP Nadda sets membership goal before crucial bypolls
column3: LUCKNOW: On his maiden visit to Lucknow after becoming BJP working president, JP Nadda on Friday held a marathon meeting at party headquarters with senior party members — a day before the launch of a mega party membership drive by PM Narendra Modi in Varanasi on Saturday. The membership drive is being billed as a big event by the party ahead of bypolls on 12 UP assembly seats. BJP is seeing the event to build upon the momentum gathered after Lok Sabha results for 2022 UP polls, which many feel could be a direct fight between BJP and BSP, which increased its Lok Sabha tally from zero to 10. BSP supremo Mayawati has snapped ties with the Samajwadi Party and announced to contest bypolls and future polls independently. BJP will launch a missed call service to enroll new members. On Friday, Nadda, BJP national secretary (organisation) Shiv Prasad, chief minister Yogi Adityanath, BJP UP in-charge Sunil Bansal, Union minister and state BJP chief Mahendra Nath Pandey and deputy CMs Keshav Prasad Maurya and Dinesh Sharma went into a closed-door meeting with district general secretaries. The party discussed the success of pre-poll programmes such as Mera parivar BJP parivar, Mera booth sabse mazboot, Kamal Jyoti as well as restructuring of community-wise morchas and sabhas from booth to top level. “At present BJP has 1.8 crore members in UP and our intention is to register 20% rise in membership,” Nadda told party workers. The party also delegated membership drive work for July 6 to all ministers. Senior state leaders Vidyasagar Sonkar, Ashok Kataria, Salil Bishnoi, Vijay Bahadur Pathak were present in the meeting, but the presence of former Union minister Kalraj Mishra led to speculation if he would be appointed as UP BJP president or a governor. Mishra, though said that such decisions are taken by the organisation. “I am happy to be part of the meeting today. I was invited by senior leaders. I met Sunil Bansal. Decision on my role would be decided by the organisation only,” he told TOI. UP minister Swatantra Dev is also a front-runner for state BJP president’s post.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Sepoy mutiny guns, utensils found in well
column3: KANPUR: Decades-old weapons, including six guns, two bronze utensils, a pot and a pitcher, were discovered from a village well in Banda district. Cleaning of village well under ‘Talab-Kuan Jiyao Abhiyan’ was underway in Mahokhar village under Dehat Kotwali police station for the past few days when the rare items were recovered. The villagers tried to connect the rusted guns and bronze utensils to the 1857 mutiny when Indians had revolted against the rule of the British East India Company. “It seems that a warrior class used to live in this region in the past, said a villager. “About five days ago, while cleaning a well under the project ‘Talab-Kuan Jiyao Abhiyan’, a labourer Devnath, came across a rusted gun. Next day, he again found five rusted guns besides few tools and a bronze pot and a pitcher. He and the fellow labourers immediately informed the village head Ram Sajeevan Verma, who in turn alerted the district and police authorities following which a police team of Dehat Kotwali police station took all the discovered ancient firearms and utensils in its possession”, said Circle Officer Rajiv Pratap Singh. But, one cannot rely on mere speculations, and these iron weapons and utensils need to get authenticated by historians and archaeologists, he added. Head of Makohar village Ram Sajeevan Verma said, “I tried to gather information about the connection of our village to the 1857 mutiny, but have failed to get any clue. We demand proper excavation at the site by the state government.”

column2: Headmaster assaulted in Sachendi area
column3: KANPUR: A man allegedly assaulted headmaster of a Government Basic Primary School in Sachendi area after he resisted the former’s attempt to molest fellow female teachers. Following a complaint made by school headmaster Rauf, police have launched an investigation in this regard. The incident took place on Thursday at Raikepur village under Sachendi police station when a villager Manoj Yadav, after being scolded by school headmaster Rauf, allegedly barged into the school and assaulted him with a belt. “As Manoj used to stalk women teachers, the headmaster warned him to mend ways. This infuriated Manoj and he attacked the headmaster with a belt,” said station house officer Sachendi Raghvendra Singh. Subsequently, the headmaster gave a complaint against Manoj in this regard, the SHO added. “After preliminary investigations, we are in the process of registering an FIR under relevant sections of IPC while separate teams have been formed to nab the alleged molester, who is on run”, the SHO further said.

column2: Funds from petrol and diesel cess to make UP zoom on highways
column3: LUCKNOW: The increase of Re 1 in additional excise duty and road cess each on petrol and diesel per litre have raised the hopes of the state government for getting more funds for the construction and strengthening of roads. UP has one of the longest road networks in the country. Officials in the public works department (PWD) said that the increase in fuel cess was certainly going to benefit the state road network, essentially in villages to boost rural economy of the state. "The increase in cess on fuel would contribute to the funds dedicated for road infrastructure and would benefit all states including UP," said principal secretary PWD Nitin Ramesh Gokaran. Officials said that an increase in funds could be utilized for strengthening roads connecting villages with district headquarters. According to PWD records, UP has more than 2.4 lakh km of roads. Of these, around 8,500 km is that of national highways, around 7,000 km of state highways, nearly 7,300 km of main district roads, around 50,000 km of other district roads and over 1.6 lakh km of rural roads. Except for national highways, maintenance of all other kinds of roads is done by the state government. Officials said that the funds pooled in from petrol and diesel costs would be utilized for maintenance of all kinds of roads. The funds might also be utilised for making roads pothole-free, officials said. In 2018-19, the state government had identified over 44,000 km of roads to be made pothole-free, PWD records show. For the financial year 2019-20, the state government would be carrying out road work for around 65,000 km at a cost of around Rs 3,500 crore. This includes 42,000 km of special repair work at a cost of Rs 294 crore, 16,500 km of newly constructed roads at a cost of Rs 2,186 crore and special maintenance of 6,500 km of road at a cost of over Rs 1,000 crore.

column2: UP asked for AIIMS in west, IIT in Bundelkhand, got nothing
column3: An AIIMS in western UP, an IIT in Bundelkhand and an IIM in east UP, Rs 2,300 crore for Namami Gange project and more funds for the defence corridor and many more items had figured in the state’s wish list presented ahead of the Union Budget. But, the first Budget of NDA-II has not included any of these. Uttar Pradesh finance minister Rajesh Agarwal, while attending an all-India meeting of finance ministers in Delhi chaired by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, had placed the state’s wish list. The state was especially looking forward to the Budget following the Niti Aayog’s report that showed UP slipping in its health services in the last three years and made recommendations for speedy improvement in this sector. Probably with this at the back of its mind, the state had demanded at least one more AIIMS. However, there has been no mention of it in the budget. Demand for another IIT in Bundelkhand by the UP government came on the back of the concern to develop this industrially backward region facing repeated drought in the past few years, lacking basic amenities like electricity and water. Also, while the Yogi government has been working overtime to prepare DPRs for Metros in Kanpur, Meerut and Agra, the Budget has not made any allocation to give them a push. As for the proposed defence corridor in Bundelkhand, Sitharaman had taken keen interest as Union defence minister but her Budget did not mention it. In his speech during the pre-Budget session, Agarwal had emphasised that since UP has maximum population and the highest number of backward and aspirational districts, the Centre should intervene to assist the state in improving its socio-economic condition. Agarwal had said that the state had certain geographical constraints as it is landlocked and lacked in mineral wealth. He also asked for subsidies and concessions for the sugar industry and initiatives for agriculture startups for rural youth. “I cannot comment on the lack of announcements for specific projects, but I am confident that once the details of the Budget are clear, UP would turn out to be a big beneficiary,” Agarwal told TOI.

column2: Birthday celebrations get happening in Kanpur
column3: It was a special day for Paritosh and wife Khushboo Awasthi as they celebrated the first birthday of their son Vihaan, recently. Organised at a banquet hall in Kanpur, the party was themed Jungle Safari. The venue was beautifully decorated with cut-outs of cartoon elephants, zebras, lions and monkeys. Decoration with green, yellow and orange balloons also added more to the décor. (L) Anna and Monty (C) Anurag Pandey (R) Arlene Barlow (BCCL/ AS Rathor) (L) Anna and Monty (C) Anurag Pandey (R) Arlene Barlow (BCCL/ AS Rathor) The event was attended by close friends and family members of the couple. Jitendra and Sadhana Sharma turned up early at the do and were soon joined by Punit Tripathi and Ankur Bajpai. Vihaan’s grandparents RA Awasthi and Jayanti were also seen socializing with the guests. (L) Astha and Rekha (R) Deeksha Pandey (BCCL/ AS Rathor) (L) Astha and Rekha (R) Deeksha Pandey (BCCL/ AS Rathor) Soon after the cake was cut, the DJ played Bollywood remixes that made the guests get on the dance floor. We spotted Ruchi Awasthi, Ashutosh Awasthi, Shubhankar, Devasheesh Bajpai, Vikas, Vibha and Deeksha Pandey dancing on songs like Dilbar and Jabra Fan. (L) Dhirendra and Rashmi (R) Dr Sharad and Poonam Mittal (BCCL/ AS Rathor) (L) Dhirendra and Rashmi (R) Dr Sharad and Poonam Mittal (BCCL/ AS Rathor) Also present were Dr VK Tandon, Kitty Tandon, Sakshi Agarwal, Poorvi Agarwal, Mary, Freddy Barlow, Astha Tiwari and Rekha Tiwari. (L) Jitendra and Sadhana Sharma (R) Pooja Pandey (BCCL/ AS Rathor) (L) Jitendra and Sadhana Sharma (R) Pooja Pandey (BCCL/ AS Rathor) (L) Sakshi and Poorvi Agarwal (R) Dr Sharad and Poonam Mittal (BCCL/ AS Rathor) (L) Sakshi and Poorvi Agarwal (R) Dr Sharad and Poonam Mittal (BCCL/ AS Rathor)

column2: Duty on CCTV cameras may deal blow to e-surveillance
column3: LUCKNOW: The proposal to increase customs duty on CCTV cam eras and digital video recorders (DVRs) is threatening to burn a hole in the pocket of city residents who are already grappling with a rise in incidents of burglary and theft. Dealers say the surveillance system business in the city is annually worth around Rs 5 crore. On an average, over 3,000 CCTV cameras, along with items like DVRs, monitors, hard discs and cables needed to operate them, are sold. Around 90% buyers go for basic models costing between Rs 3,000 and Rs 20,000. These are made in India and the customs duty hike will have no impact on them. However, accessories required to run these cameras are mostly imported ones. Hence, their cost will increase, resulting in an additional financial burden of around Rs 500-2,000 per item. On the other hand, 10% buyers, mostly government and private establishments like apartments, banks and malls, opt for artificial intelligence-based high-end CCTV cameras imported from the US and Japan. They cost between Rs 90,000 and Rs 5 lakh each. “The demand for surveillance systems increased at a rate of 10% till 2018. However, this year, we have seen an increase of 25% because more people are becoming aware of personal security amid a spurt in burglaries. The camera is a cheaper option for them in comparison to employing security guards,” said Anil Kumar Srivastava, a dealer in Nishatganj. A dealer of high-end CCTV cameras, Aniket Juneja said after the spate of burglaries in Gomtinagar, not just apartment residents, but also restaurants and shops were installing surveillance systems. “This year alone, we have supplied around 150 AI-based CCTV cameras.” Usman Rizvi — a leading provider of security solutions — said in two years, the cost of hiring private security guards had increased by four times, as a result more people were buying surveillance cameras.

column2: Corporators wait for LMC funds
column3: LUCKNOW: The LMC budget proposal plans to boost development, but street lightning, laying of water and sewage pipes and interlocking of inner streets in various wards of the city are pending because it has not released around Rs 45 crore of corporator development funds due since March. The city has 110 wards and each corporator gets Rs 95 lakh per annum for development work. The first instalment of Rs 45 lakh each is released in March and the second of Rs 50 lakh each in September. It is July and corporators are yet to receive the first instalment. While major development work such as construction of main roads, laying of sewage and water pipes, lighting up streets, garbage collection and cleaning of drains is carried out by the LMC workforce, the funds allotted to corporators are mostly used to resolve small, but crucial issues. Many corporators use their funds for construction or repair of inner roads, cementing drains, pavement interlocking, maintenance of parks and repair of streetlights. Such tasks are piling up in various wards. At various wards under Mahanagar, residents complained of potholed road that have not been fixed in two years. Chandan Tripathi, a resident of Sector H, said: “We face problem of waterlogging every monsoon. We have complained to our local corporator, but he says he has not received funds from LMC.” Residents of Indiranagar complained of poor sewerage. Sector 12 resident Tarun Jaiswal said, “Sewers were laid in 2009, but the quantity of sewage has increased in 10 years. So, all the dirty water overflows and floods roads.” Daliganj corporator Mukesh Shukla conceded that development work was pending owing to lack of funds. Shukla said he and other corporators had decided to raise the issue at the LMC house meeting on Sunday. Additional municipal commissioner Amit Singh claimed they had not received funds from the government. “As soon as we get it, we shall release the first instalment.”

column2: Megabucks to make Lucknow cleaner & smarter
column3: LUCKNOW: The LMC has allocated over 40% of its 2019-20 budget for 4‘S’ — Smart City, Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, sewer and sadak (road). And, all this without levying any new taxes or increasing existing ones. The annual budget, proposing Rs 2,012 crore expenditure, will be tabled at the house meeting on Sunday for approval. It is 12% or Rs 241 crore more than that of last fiscal’s Rs 1,771 expenditure. Of the total expenses proposed, Rs 1,708 is for development work. This includes Rs 300 crore for Smart City projects, Rs 230 for Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, Rs 220 crore under AMRUT scheme for laying sewer/water pipelines and Rs 110 crore for road construction and repairs. Other expenditure include Rs 10 crore for cleaning drains, Rs 14 crore for streetlights and Rs 7 crore for maintenance of parks, besides Rs 90 crore as development funds for corporators of all the 110 wards. In comparison to last year, the maximum increase in budget has been for AMRUT — from Rs 116 crore in 2018-19 to Rs 220 crore in 2019-20 —followed by road repairs, from Rs 90 crore to Rs 110 crore. While 75% of the revenue for the expenses will come as grants from central and state governments for various projects as well as allocation by 14th Finance Commission, the LMC will generate Rs 600 crore through its own resources like house tax and auction of parking lots and advertising slots. Several other important decision on proposals like providing civic services to Gomtinagar and Jankipuram extensions, and regularising of food vans will also be tabled for approval.

column2: Special police ops, projects yet to see the light of day
column3: LUCKNOW: Three special operations and plans announced by Lucknow police in the past two years to check crime are gathering dust in files. The most promising among them was Operation Prahar, announced after the murder of a cash van guard near Raj Bhavan in August 2018. Likewise, after back-to-back dacoities in January-February 2018, it was said that a comprehensive criminal database would be prepared. The third proposal was to train police like ATS so that hostage situations could be tackled well. Under Operation Prahar, police were supposed to reach the crime scene in 2-3 minutes and immediately issue an alert to all police stations to set up road blockades, intensify patrolling and barricade borders to stop the accused from fleeing Lucknow. Since the announcement was made, 15 murders, 20 shootings and six loots have taken place, but cops have failed to respond as proposed. In the latest incident on June 30, businessman Manoj Bhattacharya was shot dead near Charbagh station. Police took 15 minutes to respond. Similarly, in Thakurganj, when tent house owner Chhotu Lodhi was shot dead on May 18, police arrived 10 minutes late. In February 2018, then Lucknow SSP Deepak Kumar had proposed a comprehensive computer database of criminals with fingerprints, photographs, area of operation and their sympathisers after 14 dacoities took place in the district within a month.  However, police have not been able to create such a database till date. Had it been in place, it would have helped them crack burglaries that have taken place in the past month and is suspected to be the handiwork of one gang. While no hostage crisis has taken place so far, the fact that the third proposal wasn’t implemented means police are likely to have a tough time if there’s one.

column2: Banker, varsity accountant in ED net for SUV fleets, 7-star holidays
column3: LUCKNOW: A former bank manager and the accountant of an agriculture institute – a deemed university — landed in the Enforcement Directorate (ED) dragnet after they booked by police for fraudulently withdrawing over Rs 24 crore from its bank account by misusing their positions. The bank manager and institute accountant came on police radar when they went on a spree purchasing a fleet of high end SUVs, flats and for holidaying at seven-star hotels, which was grossly disproportionate to their known sources of income. Kamal Ahsan, manager of a private bank, in connivance with the university accountant, Rajesh Kumar withdrew over Rs 24 crore from the institution’s account in the bank from 2013 to 2016 by misusing their positions, said ED officials. Initially, in March 2017, police registered a case in connection with inexplicable withdrawals from the bank account of the university. The case was transferred to ED in October 2017. ED officials told TOI on Saturday that around 11 more staffers of the institute are under the scanner for conniving in the crime. “We have attached assets of the accused, which includes 17 immovable properties worth around Rs. 3.18 crore, mutual fund investments of around Rs 85 lakh and around Rs 58 lakhs lying in bank accounts of both accused, their family members, friends, and relatives. More searches will be carried out in the coming weeks,” said a senior ED official. The official said that the scam came to notice when colleagues of Ahsan noticed him coming to office in a high-end car while the co-workers of Kumar also reported his using a high-end SUV. Both also went on holidays and stayed at seven-star hotels. The respective authorities carried out internal probes and then informed police. Ahsan and Kumar used to withdraw money from the university’s accounts. They fabricated bank statements to hide the cash withdrawals and submitted them to the university.

column2: Uttar Pradesh government posts 560 cops to check power theft
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government on Saturday ordered posting of 560 policemen in UP Power Corporation Limited on a deputation period of two years with the aim of curbing high line losses that are denting its revenue. Following the order, 10 inspectors, 190 sub-inspectors and 360 constables would be posted at police check posts dedicated to take up power theft cases. Soon after coming to power, the Yogi government had decided to create a police check post in every district to handle power theft cases. “The deployment of police will help in checking power theft,” said principal secretary, energy, Alok Kumar. The move, sources said, was necessitated by incidents of power employees being attacked during anti-power theft drives. A week earlier, energy minister Shrikant Sharma had ordered snapping of power connections of consumers having electricity load of 5Kw and above with unpaid electricity bills for two months. The decision to create dedicated police units to check power theft was initially taken in Akhilesh Yadav government but the move did not take off and was kept pending in the cabinet.

column2: CBI raids sacked I-T commissioner’s house, former office
column3: NEW DELHI: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) registered an FIR under sections of cheating and forgery against sacked income tax commissioner S K Srivastava and conducted a raid at his house in Noida while probing allegations that the senior IRS officer backdated orders on I-T appeals to show that he had settled the cases before June 10 when was compulsorily retired. The search operation, which started on Friday morning and continued till Saturday, took place at 13 locations in Delhi, Noida and Ghaziabad, including at Srivastava’s Pandara Road residence, his former office in Noida and, also, at the boutique his wife runs in Vasant Kunj. It is alleged that Srivastava who was serving as commissioner, income tax (appeals), Noida passed 104 backdated orders in June, 2019. While he compulsorily retired on June 10, 2019, these orders were uploaded on the income tax business application (ITBA) between June 11 and June 13 using the RSA token to log into what is a secure system. The orders were shown to have been dispatched on June 7, 2019, i.e. three days before he was sacked, whereas they had , in fact, been sent on June 14, 2019. Moreover, 13 of the “ backdated” orders concerned cases which did not fall under Srivastava’s jurisdiction. The CBI has recovered jewellery worth Rs 2.47 crore, Rs 16.44 lakh in cash, watches approximately valued at Rs 10 lakh from his residence, sources said. Bank deposits to the tune of Rs 1.30 crore in the name of Srivastava and his family members were also found during the raid. Additionally, the agency recovered documents related to two immovable assets and a bank locker during the raid, sources added. The CBI also carried out searches at the residence of Amar Das whose services were used by the officer to write orders, two chartered accountants Anil Prahlad Kumar and K P Garg in Ghaziabad and Nehru Place, Delhi.

column2: Lucknow: Rain to rein in heat over weekend too
column3: LUCKNOW: Cloudy sky and intermittent light to moderate rains forced the mercury to remain below 30 degrees Celsius, keeping weather pleasant all day on Saturday. Similar conditions are expected on Sunday and Monday. It started drizzling on Friday night and continued at regular intervals till morning. Partly cloudy sky and a few spells of rains were also recorded during the day. As a result, maximum temperature dropped to 29.3 degrees Celsius, six degrees below normal, and 24.9 degrees Celsius, a degree below normal, in the night. High relative humidity, between 88% and 100%, did not cause discomfort because of moderate winds and low temperature.  Total 50mm mm rainfall was recorded in 24 hours from 5.30pm on Friday. State Met officials said rainfall would continue on Sunday and Monday.

column2: Flats with imported tiles, bath fittings to cost up to Rs 5 lakh more in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: High-end apartments and row houses in the city are set to become more expensive with the decision of the finance minister to impose 5% customs duty on imported tiles, marble, metal fittings, furniture and windows. The impact will mean escalation in the cost of around 2,800 high-end flats and bungalows under construction in the city. According to experts, these imported items are generally used in high-end houses costing more than Rs 50 lakh. Buyers of these properties prefer luxury fittings and furniture. The cost of imported tiles, marbles, furniture, windows and bathroom fittings is around 40% of the total cost of the house, depending on the quantity and quality of the products used. The overall cost of such under-construction houses can now go up by up to Rs 5 lakh. Prakhar Khanna, a government employee, said, “My 4BHK house is under construction in Gomtinagar Extension. I was planning to get Italian marble flooring in my house. However, now I have decided to drop the idea because imposition of customs duty will increase the prices, taking them beyond my budget.”Businessman Jatin Krishna said, “My family and I were planning to purchase imported furniture, but won’t be able to now as the increase in taxes has taken the price out of my reach." According to officials of Lucknow Development Authority, more than 1,200 highend flats being constructed by it will be affected by the decision. Flats with total area of 1,200 sq ft or above made for higher income group (HIG) buyers will now see an increase in price. Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Lucknow Chapter) told TOI that as many as four big private projects coming up in Chinhat and Matiyari and on Dewa Road and Sitapur Road with around 1,600 flats in them will see a 5% increase in the principle amount. The budget of underconstruction government and private buildings to be used as offices or for other commercial purpose would also go up, experts said.

column2: Ghaziabad: Woman missing, dad alleges torture by her in-laws
column3: GHAZIABAD: The father of a 23-year-old woman has lodged a police complaint alleging that his daughter has been missing since Saturday morning because of alleged torture by her parents-in-law. There was speculation that the woman, Komal Talan, might have committed suicide by jumping into the Hindon canal in Indirapuram as her car was found parked nearby. However, divers did not find her body despite hours of search. Later on Saturday evening, Komal’s father Anil Talan lodged the missing person’s complaint. Talan alleged that Komal, who was married to Delhi resident Abhishek, was being harassed over dowry. “We have found a note in Komal’s car that says she was being tortured by her parents-in-law over dowry,” said Talan, an office-bearer in the Bharati Kisan Union. “My wife called on Komal’s number around 5pm but it was switched off. Around 8.30pm, we received a call from her mother-in-law who informed that Komal had left home in the morning and hadn’t returned,” he added. Seeing an abandoned car near the canal, a cop passing by enquired about its details and informed Komal’s father. “Initially, we suspected that the woman may have committed suicide by jumping into the canal. But her body could not be traced. We spoke to her father, questioned her in-laws and lodged a missing person’s complaint,” said Shlok Kumar, SP (city). “The woman’s father has levelled allegations that her parents-in-law could be behind her disappearance,” he added. “However, it is a matter of investigation whether she has gone on her own or there is any foul play. For that, we need to trace her first,” said Kumar, adding that teams were looking for the woman in various other parts of the region.

column2: Trans-Hindon towns among worst hit as water table rings alarm bells
column3: GHAZIABAD: The trans-Hindon areas of Ghaziabad, places like Kaushambi, Vaishali and Indirapuram that have turned into addresses of choice for new settlers in NCR, are among the most exploited for groundwater, government data shows. The water table’s cumulative fall in the six years from 2013-2018, for which data is available, is 4.26 metres, but since the depth of the water table is an average of data recorded across the district, the number masks the sharp fall in some urban areas where it has fallen below 30 metres. Piezometer readings in urban areas of Ghaziabad also showed that of 38 spots where the Uttar Pradesh groundwater department measured the water table, 11 spots have gone dry. This means the water table has plummeted so much that it did not register in piezometer readings. Makanpur in Indirapuram is one of these spots. The others are Krishi Beej Bhandar (Kaushambi), Zila Ganna Adhikarai (Surya Nagar), Bhovapur, Hindon Motel (Patel Nagar), Civil Lines, Lajpat Nagar (Sahibabad), Sikandarpur and Police Lines. The water table has plunged below 30 metres at Vaishali, Maharajpur, Prahladgarhi, Jhandapur, CIPL (Sanjay Nagar), CGO complex (Hapur Road), government nursery (Kavinagar), Dundahera and Pasunda. In Vijay Nagar, it has fallen below 40 metres. Environmentalists say the responsibility for this lay squarely with government agencies, which have allowed rapid and large-scale urban activity in the city over the last few decades. Today, for instance, the Indirapuram-Vaishali-Vasundhara cluster, developed through housing schemes and licences, is a thickly populated one. Sushil Raghav, a city-based environmentalist, said, “The Central Ground Water Authority (CGWA) in 1998 had declared the municipal area of Ghaziabad a ‘notified area’, which means extraction of groundwater was banned for all purposes except drinking. Despite that, there is large-scale, illegal extraction of groundwater by various authorities, industries, residential and commercial complexes.” Raghav claimed he had copies of no-objection certificates to show that seven major industries cumulatively extract 1 crore litres of groundwater per day. “The numbers would be much higher if we calculate permission given to all industries,” added Raghav, pointing out that the NOCs are conditional and the industries have been asked to replenish groundwater in the same ratio at which they extract. “While some industries have been asked to adopt lakes and ponds to recharge groundwater, some are bound to take up harvesting but there is no mechanism to know whether they are following the conditions laid down or not,” he said. RB Kaushik, engineer (CGWA) said no new NOCs have been issued to any industry. “We have only renewed old NOCs and have not issued any new NOC,” Kaushik said. Raghav also claimed 2,403 hectares of waterbody area in Ghaziabad has been encroached on, making way for buildings and other infrastructure projects. The administration said steps have been taken to rejuvenate lakes and waterbodies. “In the recent past, we have freed close to 700 ponds and waterbodies of encroachments, which includes 133 in Ghaziabad, 469 in Modi Nagar and 101 in Loni tehsils,” said a district administration official. Though rainwater harvesting is mandatory for all group housing societies, monitoring remains an area of concern. “From time to time, we carry out inspections,” said VK Singh, officer on special duty with the GDA, which has administrative control of places like Indirapuram and Raj Nagar Extension. “We are also in the process of fine-tuning laws in which toilet and kitchen water will be compulsory used after treating it. This way, we hope to limit dependency on groundwater to a large extent,” added Singh.

column2: Protest after 2nd theft in society with 80 guards
column3: GHAZIABAD: Residents of Panchsheel Primrose in Kavi Nagar staged a protest on Saturday against a rise in thefts and burglaries in the area after a flat in the society was broken into and goods worth Rs 2.5 lakh stolen. This was the second case to be reported in the past two weeks. Residents alleged that despite the presence of 80 guards, such cases were being reported inside the society periodically. They staged a protest against local police and the builder alleging that no progress had been made in another theft case reported two weeks ago. The burglary, which triggered the protest, came to light after its owner, retired central government employee Gopal Krishna Gupta, returned home on Saturday. The flat had been closed for a long time as Gupta and his wife had gone to Pune and Chennai to visit their children. When they reached home and unlocked the door, they found the flat ransacked and cash and goods worth Rs 2.5 lakh missing. It is suspected that the burglars entered the house through the balcony. Another burglary was reported in the society on June 21. Residents claimed that the burglars had a similar modus operandi in that case. On Saturday, the protesters put a lock on the builder’s office in the morning, which was removed in the evening, though the protest went on till late in the evening. Anuradha Sharma, a resident, said, “We have been raising the issue of safety and security with the developer for a long time now, but no concrete steps have been taken from their side so far. Moreover, the society does not have a resident welfare association as yet.” SHO (Kavi Nagar) Raj Kumar Sharma met the residents and assured them of proper action in the case. Sharma said police patrolling would be conducted inside the society as well. “CCTV footage has been collected to identify the culprits in both the cases,” he said.

column2: GDA plans to set up homes for birds in housing societies
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) has come up with a plan to install towers in housing societies that will have wooden boxes for birds to build nests inside them. The idea was flagged after a GDA official went on a tour to Bikaner and found similar structures there. The GDA plans to name the societies having such towers “bird flats”. “Ours is a generation that has grown up in small towns and villages, where we are used to seeing birds on out premises,” said the GDA official. “But in big cities, which are dotted with highrises, birds are hardly seen making nests in closed enclosures. In some way, we are also responsible for the loss of their habitats,” he added. A few weeks ago, the official made a proposal to build bird towers before the GDA vice-chairperson, who agreed to the idea. “The plan is to install a 12ft iron tower at a vantage location inside a housing society, preferably in green and shady areas,” said Kanchan Verma, the GDA vice-chairperson. “We will place small wooden boxes around the towers where we hope birds will build their nests,” she added. The vice-chairperson said each tower could house 100-120 wooden compartments for birds to build nests. The GDA plans to implement the idea with help from the RWAs. “It would take around Rs 40,000 to build a tower housing the wooden boxes. I think RWAs can afford to spend that much. If they can’t, the GDA will pitch in. We will, however, have to work out the modalities,” the official said. Environmentalists, however, are not sure if the GDA’s idea would take wing. “The area for a bird flat needs to be chosen carefully. It has to be shady and protected from rain and sun. Finding such a spot in every housing society will be a challenge,” said Ruchin Verma, a city-based environmentalist. “Also, we need to be very specific about the size of the wooden boxes. They should be able to accommodate birds of every size,” added Mehra. As example, Mehra said house sparrows and bulbul would need smaller wooden houses, while pigeons, rock cat bird, mynah and parrots may need bigger nests. “The idea at the very face of it looks good, but the GDA would need to talk to experts before going about this plan.” said Mehra.

column2: Ayushmann’s Bala wraps up with a sweet celebration in Lucknow
column3: Ayushmann Khurrana and Yami Gautam wrapped up shooting of Amar Kaushik’s Bala in Lucknowon Saturday, and the cast shared pictures and videos of the celebrations on their social media handles. The team, along with leads Ayushmann Khurrana and Yami Gautam, shot scenes at the Residency in Lucknow the whole day and in the evening they cut a two-kg cake to celebrate the successful completion of the film. The cake that was especially made for the occasion (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  The cake that was especially made for the occasion (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) ("And it’s a wrap for #Bala. A film which will question the superficial definition of beauty in an entertaining way. Thank you #DineshVijan Amar Kaushik Bhumi Pednekar Yami Gautam #AbhishekBanerjee Jaaved Jaaferi and the entire cast and crew. This is going to be special. Nov 2019 🙏🏻" Wrote Ayushmann of the film and the occasion on his Facebook and Instaqgram, posting a pic of the cake)  The film went on floors in Kanpur in the first week of June and after shooting there for a couple of weeks, Kaushik moved to Lucknow to shoot the rest of the film. In Lucknow the cast was also joined by Bhumi Pednekar and Javed Jaffrey. Sporting a clean shaven look, Ayushmann and Yami cut the cake with director Amar Kaushik along with the other members of the team. Kaushik thanked his crew and the security persons who helped in shooting the film and said, “It was a tough schedule.” Further adding, Amar said, “Shuru mein sab bahut tough tha. Lag raha tha sab kaise hoga, kahan hoga because itni garmi thi. Especially in Kanpur, but still aap logon ki madad se, all went off so well.”Ayushmann also thanked the team and said “I loved shooting in Lucknow again. And you guys have been a great team!. Thank you all of you.” He then hugged the team and the security personnel and also got selfies clicked with them. Yami expressed her gratitude to the team and in a Bhojouri accent said, “Bahute badhiya experience ke liye apka bahute-bahute dhanyawad. Thank you so much for the best team.” A few days ago, we caught Ayushmann dressed as a dulha, sitting on a ghodi shooting for a baraat scene in Lucknow (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  A few days ago, we caught Ayushmann dressed as a dulha, sitting on a ghodi shooting for a baraat scene in Lucknow (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Ayushmann, who is playing a man with premature balding in the film uploaded a series of videos on his Instagram, where the entire crew can be seen celebrating the occasion by dancing and cutting a cake. In one of the videos, the crew can be seen shaking a leg to the Badhaai Ho’s Morni Banke where Ayushmann was seen teaching the signature step to the team. In the second one, the actor along with the entire team including director and Yami are seen cutting a cake to celebrate the last day of the movie. “It’s a wrap for Bala,” he captioned the videos. Yami also shared a picture from the sets of the film where everyone can be seen pouncing on the cake. “This expression is literally what we felt in every moment spent on this set...with this team... Bala, (sic)” she captioned the picture. After this movie, Ayushmann will continue shooting in the city for Shoojit Sircar’s Gulabo Sitabo along with Amitabh Bachchan and Bhumi will start shooting Pati, Patni Aur Woh with Ananya Pandey and Kartik Aryan.
