column2: 17% of Indian cities and towns face water shortage; TN tops list
column3: NEW DELHI: About 17% notified cities and towns in India face water shortage, according to a list prepared by the central government. Among the states, Tamil Nadu has maximum number of such urban areas followed by Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh. All the four municipal areas in Delhi including the posh NDMC zone have been included in the list of 756 “water stressed” urban areas out of total 4,378 which are governed by municipal bodies. All urban areas surrounding the national capital such as Ghaziabad, Noida and Faridabad have been facing similar shortage. According to the list, two smaller northern states - Punjab and Haryana - have high number of municipal areas where water availability is less which officials said could be due to falling water table because of increased extraction of ground water for irrigation. While in Punjab 82 municipal areas (nearly half of all notified urban areas) face water shortage, in Haryana their number is 52 out of total 86 notified urban areas. The housing and urban affairs ministry has come out with the names of cities and towns on the lines of Jal Shakti ministry, which has identified 255 districts and 1,597 blocks as water stressed. The urban affairs ministry has also prepared a plan to undertake intensive campaign and undertake activities for water conservation, recycle and reuse of grey water. Unlike in rural areas where central government teams have started visiting the designated districts, in this case, the Centre has asked states and urban local bodies (ULBs) to carry out focused activities in two phases; July 1 to September 15 and October 1 to November 30. It has circulated a template for effective monitoring of the activities and performance on implementation of rainwater harvesting, rejuvenation of water bodies, reuse of treated waste water and plantation. “The progress needs to be monitored on a real-time basis to ascertain the progress of ULBs and gaps therein in each of the thrust areas under Jal Shakti Abhiyan,” the urban affairs ministry has said. It has also asked all urban local bodies to set up a cell for effective monitoring of rainwater harvesting and revival of at least one water body in their respective areas. The “Rainwater Harvesting Cell” will monitor the extent of groundwater extraction and groundwater aquifer recharge. Moreover, they will have to display the information at prominent locations for public awareness The ministry has asked ULBs to ensure all new building permissions must have rainwater harvesting structures incorporated as per building by-laws and its compliance should be checked before issuing occupancy-cum-completion certificate.

column2: Maharajganj SDM shunted out by Yogi Adityanath for lax work
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday ordered transfer of Maharajganj’s SDM Sadar, Satyam Mishra, for dereliction of duty and non-performance. Maharajganj comes under Gorakhpur division. This was the first action ordered by the CM after holding a review of works done at the divisional level. The removal of SDM in Gorakhpur division is significant since it’s Yogi’s political backyard and he has represented Gorakhpur for five consecutive terms in Lok Sabha. Presiding over a review meeting of Gorakhpur division — which comprises Kushinagar, Deoria and Maharajganj — to assess the progress of development works, Yogi bluntly said that officials would not be retained if they failed to deliver on the priorities set by the state government. “The state government has adopted a zero tolerance policy towards corruption and dereliction of duty,” he told officials. Two Padrauna power engineers removedThe CM has also sought explanation from Deoria chief medical officer Dr Dhirendra Kumar, CMO Kushinagar Dr Haricharan Singh and CMO Maharajganj Kshama Shankar Pandey over their alleged laxity in performing duties. Yogi also ordered removal of two executive engineers of the power department in Padrauna — Hansraj Kaushal and AH Khan. Padrauna, which comes under Gorakhpur division, has reported frequent power outages and recurrent line losses resulting in revenue losses to the power department. Later while holding a review meeting in Gorakhpur, Yogi ordered suspension of three power engineers, including executive engineer AK Singh, Sub-divisional officer Pratush Balab and Junior engineer Arun Chaudharry for irregularities in underground cabling works under integrated Power Development Scheme. Recently, the CM had ordered forced retirement of 200 employees and action against over 400 employees after reviewing works in various state departments.

column2: Cloud cover and showers likely for next 2-3 days in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: The weatherman has predicted similar conditions for next two-three days. The city continued to receive intermittent light to moderate rainfall keeping the mercury below 30 degrees on Sunday too. Most parts of the city remained under the cloud cover keeping the weather pleasant all day on Sunday. The maximum and the minimum temperatures were recorded 34.3 and 26.6 degree Celsius with relative humidity as high as 100%. Outskirt areas like Amausi received moderate rainfall while other areas like Indiranagar, Gomtinagar and Jankipuram received light rainfall. A total of 49.2 mm rainfall was recorded at Amausi which was around 12 MM more in comparison with Saturday. Similar weather conditions are expected on Monday with the maximum and the minimum temperatures to be 34 and 25 degree Celsius respectively. “There will be no significant change in temperatures it would be a degree more or less in the coming days. The city is likely to receive rain for the coming 3 to 4 days,” state met director JP Gupta. According to Lucknow University Climate monitoring station director Prof Dhruv Sen Singh, “Humidity levels will remain high throughout the week but it will not cause discomfort due to winds and intermittent rain.” He said the low pressure of Bay of Bengal which was a reason behind delayed monsoon in Lucknow and adjoining areas have now changed to high pressure and so the city and the nearby areas are likely to receive rain for rain.

column2: Bonded labour: Freedom for two girls after 14 years
column3: LUCKNOW: Fourteen years after four girls from Jharkhand were allegedly “sold off” to an illegal maid hiring agency in Delhi, two of them have been rescued in the city. The girls, who are now in their 20s, had been working as bonded labourers in two separate houses here for the past 14 years. The third girl had escaped from a house in 2011, while the fourth girl is missing. This unfolded when the mother of the fourth girl lodged a missing complaint with a Delhi-based NGO. The duo was rescued by the state women and child welfare department’s women distress cell — Aapki Sakhi Asha Jyoti Kendra — from two homes in Aliganj and Rajajipuram on Friday and Saturday, respectively . The girls were working in the homes of a doctor and retired government official, both of whom are relatives. The girls, natives of Simko in Jharkhand’s west Singhum district, were sold off to Delhi based agency in 2005. The agency then sold them to the four families in Lucknow. Investigations have revealed that the girls were not paid a single penny by the families in the past 14 years. “The four girls are around 24-year-old now. They were taken to Delhi by a man on the pretext of providing job, but were instead sold off to a maid hiring agency. The girls were ‘bought’ by a big family of seven siblings in Lucknow,” said in-charge, Asha Jyoti Kendra, Archana Singh. “The family member who took these girls from the agency, had given a fake Delhi address and had kept the girls in Lucknow instead,” she added. One of the girls escaped in 2011 and married a man of her choice in Lucknow and is based here. She provided vital information when we approached her, said Singh. Last year, mother of the third Jharkhand girl, who is missing, approached a Delhi-based NGO seeking held to trace her daughter. “The mother met us with a representative of the same maid hiring agency. The representative told us that girls were in Lucknow. We then approached the Lucknow Police on May 25, but they refused to lodge our complaint,” said Renu Toora, who heads the Delhi-based NGO. “Since the police were not helpful, we went to the Child Welfare Committee. But since the girls are not minors, the CWC asked Asha Jyoti Kendra to intervene in the matter,” Toora added. In a joint rescue operation with the help of the girl who had escaped from her employer’s home earlier, the other two girls were located. “Even when we were searching for them, the family members kept misguiding us and denied having employed any of the girls. They cooked up stories, but we finally got hold of the girls,” said Archana Singh.

column2: Ghaziabad: After torture video, son says he won’t evict parents
column3: GHAZIABAD: The son of an elderly couple, who had allegedly threatened to throw them out of their house in DLF Ankur Vihar, has now decided to leave the flat himself along with his wife following a meeting with administrative officials. Police and the district magistrate intervened after a video surfaced showing the elderly couple from Loni urging the administration to save them from their “greedy son and daughter-in-law”. On Sunday, the married son gave a written statement that he and his wife would vacate the house within 10 days. District magistrate Ritu Maheshwari and Ghaziabad police shared the incident on Twitter. In the two-minute video, the elderly couple man said he and his wife were 68-year-old and suffered from heart ailments and arthritis. He alleged that their “greedy son” was forcing him to vacate the house which is in his wife’s name.   Sub-divisional magistrate Prashant Tiwari said, “We had come to know about the video on Saturday night. I along with CO (Loni) and other officers went to the complainant’s house in DLF Ankur Vihar on Sunday and spoke to them. It was mutually decided that the son would vacate the house within 10 days.”

column2: Dowry ‘suicide’: Woman’s body not found in Hindon canal
column3: GHAZIABAD: The body of a woman, whose father had lodged a missing person’s complaint alleging she had fled torture at the hands of her parents-in-law, could not be traced in the Hindon canal despite a daylong search by an NDRF team. There had been speculation that Komal Talan (23) might have jumped into the canal as her car was parked nearby. Her father Anil Talan, a Delhi resident, had alleged that Komal’s in-laws had been torturing her over dowry. Police now suspect that the woman might not have jumped into the canal at all, but fled. On a complaint by Komal’s father, an FIR has been registered under IPC sections 498A (domestic violence) and 365 (kidnapping or abducting with intent secretly and wrongfully to confine person) against her in-laws at Indirapuram police station. “We found a note in Komal’s car that says she was being tortured by her parents-in-law over dowry,” her father Anil Talan had said. Talan is an offcer-bearer in the Bhartia Kisan Union.

column2: Airport, Charbagh inundated again: Rain washes away LMC’s tall claims
column3: LUCKNOW: Sunday afternoon rain caused inconvenience to travellers from the city as it led to heavy waterlogging at Amausi airport and Charbagh railway stations. The 100-metre stretch from the entrance area till domestic terminal of Amausi airport turned into a pond after the downpour. As a result, travellers were forced to take a longer route from the international terminal side to reach the domestic terminal. Passengers coming to Charbagh station, too, found it difficult to reach the platforms. Abhinav, who had to board a train to Gorakhpur, struggled to reach the platform with his luggage. But despite the effort, he missed the train. On the other hand, the entire premises of Charbagh railway station and Lucknow junction was logged after the heavy rainfall. Many passengers carried the luggage bags on their head as they crossed the waterlogged road outside the station. Some elderly passengers too missed their trains as they couldn't cross the stretch with their luggage and waited for help. Tarun Juneja suffered a leg injury as he slipped on the waterlogged stretch.

column2: Owner enters Crossings flat lying locked for a year, finds it occupied
column3: GHAZIABAD: Sunil Yadav’s flat in Crossings Republik had been lying locked for the past one year. The Delhi resident thought of giving it out on rent and even contacted a property dealer recently. On Sunday, when he visited the flat to check if the electricity and water connections needed repairs, he found his furnished house occupied. An inquiry revealed Yadav’s flat in Panchsheel Wellington had been given out on rent by a woman named Megha Tyagi, who had got a duplicate key made.  Megha was not the property dealer Yadav had contacted recently. “The flat had been lying vacant ever since my shifted to stay with us in Delhi. Recently, I decided to give out the flat on rent and contacted a property dealer in Crossings Republik. We have even finalised a deal with family,” said Yadav, a deputy manager with a private firm. Yadav (37), who lives in Delhi’s Mayur Vihar Phase 1, seldom visits his flat in Crossings Republik. On June 30, however, he visited the flat to check if the fans and lights were working fine and sign the agreement with the family to whom he had agreed to give out the house on rent. “To my utter surprise, when I opened the door, I found eight to nine bags lying in a room. The family with whom I had struck a deal said the bags did not belong to them. I opened the bags and found a resume and a phone number on it,” Yadav said. The private firm manager called on the number on the resume and the person who picked up the call said he and his two friends had taken the house on rent a week ago. They said they had paid a month’s rent and a security amount to Megha, who had asked them to shift to the flat from July 1. When Yadav spoke to Megha, she blamed one Sumit for giving them the duplicate key. “I don’t know who else have lived in this flat. The maintenance office should have looked into it as no tenant can live in the society without its permission,” Yadav said. Police sources said flat owners should check on their property at regular intervals as there have been instances earlier of houses being rented out or even sold in the absence of inspections. Yadav has filed a police complaint, but an FIR was yet to be registered till late on Sunday evening. Rahul Sharma, the maintenance manager at Panchsheel Wellington, said no permission had been given to the three youths to stay in Yadav’s flat. “There is no signature of any maintenance official on the tenants’ approval letter. The complainant should take up the matter with the property dealer and find how he/she got the key,” he said.

column2: Man bangs wife’s head against wall, kills her
column3: GHAZIABAD: A man in his late 30s was arrested on Sunday for allegedly killing his wife by banging her head several times on a wall in their house in Mirza Garden Colony of Loni on Saturday evening. Police said the accused, Raeesuddin, was in an inebriated condition when he committed the murder. Raeesuddin, a daily wager, had married Shamshadi (30) a year back after giving divorce to his first wife. He has three children aged between two and eight years. According to the police, Raeesuddin was an alcoholic and it led to frequent fights between the couple. A similar argument had ensued on Saturday evening after Raeesuddin came home drunk, but in a fit of rage, Raeesuddin banged Shamshadi’s head multiple times on the wall and then fled after she fell unconscious. Police said that the children were playing outside the house when Shamshadi was killed. When they came home and found their mother lying in a pool of blood, they informed their neighbours, who in turn informed the police. A police team arrived soon, along with circle officer of Loni, Raj Kumar Pandey, and SHO Sanjay Kumar Pandey. The police sent the body for an autopsy. “The accused has been booked for murder and was arrested on Sunday. We are trying to ascertain the exact reason which resulted in such a heinous crime,” said the SHO.

column2: Rain turns posh locales, hospitals into cesspool
column3: LUCKNOW: Afternoon rain on Sunday led to ankle deep waterlogging in several parts of the city, including government hospitals, posing hardships to people. Residents of Hazratganj, Lalbagh, Aashiana, Thakurganj, Chowk, Hussainganj, Nishatganj and Daliganj had to struggle with overflowing drains and filth which had entered their homes. Roads remained partially submerged in many areas, hitting the vehicular traffic badly. Waterlogging was also reported from Aashiana near Apollo hospital. At King George Medical University (KGMU), Balrampur hospital and Civil hospital, patients and their attendants had to face problem as water continued to seep through roofs in waiting areas. Puddles were formed at Trauma centre and surgery and anatomy departments at KGMU and at Balrampur and Civil hospital's emergency and OPD gates.  An attendant Gyanvati, whose relative was admitted to KGMU trauma centre, said, "Waiting area has leakage from the roof." At Civil hospital, a resident of Aliganj Ramnaresh said, "Doctors directed us to keep off from wards for being in dirty clothes. But we were helpless as waterlogging and mud was all over the hospital."

column2: Snag disrupts Metro near Indiranagar station
column3: LUCKNOW: Metro rail service was hit by intermittent disruptions between Indiranagar and Munshipulia stations on Sunday afternoon. Its ripple effects were felt at other Metro stations too. The disruptions lasted for 30 minutes - from 3.15pm to 3.45pm. Lucknow Metro Rail Corporation officials said that following a strong wind a flex banner got entangled in the overhead line of 25,000 volts near Polytechnic Crossing, leading to disruption in the movement of Metro rail. However, passengers complained of discomfort during the journey. Ashutosh Gupta, who was onboard a Metro, said the train suddenly stopped around 3.20pm. Parul Rastogi (45), who was riding in a Metro from Badshahnagar to Munshipulia for the first time, told TOI: "The train came to a screeching halt. The ACs stopped working and the train remained stranded for about five minutes." "A flex from a hoarding got entangled in the overhead line around 2.30pm. "Till the time flex was removed, Metro was stopped on the down line stretch - From Munshipulia to Charbagh. The trains from the down line were tracked on the up line, leading to stoppages of 2 minutes while changing of tracks," LMRC PRO Pushpa Bellani told TOI. She claimed that announcements in this regard were made inside trains.

column2: Runway lights on the blink, trigger trauma for flyers
column3: LUCKNOW: Dysfunctional runway lights at Amausi airport triggered trauma for more than 100 flyers after a Lucknow-bound IndiGo flight was diverted back to Delhi and another IndiGo flight from Mumbai was kept airborne for over 30 minutes before touchdown on Saturday night. The situation remained erratic at Amausi on Sunday too, when a 7am Delhi-Lucknow Indigo flight was left hovering for 15 minutes before getting the ATC nod to land. Around 10.30 pm on Saturday, runway lights went on the blink due to rainwater seepage. This was confirmed by Air Traffic Control (ATC) officials after inspection of the airstrip at 10.35 pm. The Delhi-Lucknow 6E528 IndiGo airlines which was scheduled to arrive at 11 pm at Amausi with 100 passengers onboard was informed about the defunct lights on the airstrip and was sent back to Delhi. Around 10.45 pm, the technical team arrived to fix the issue. While repair of runway lights was underway, ATC received another alert about arrival of the Mumbai-Lucknow 6E6446 IndiGo airlines, which was already running an hour behind schedule. The pilot of Mumbai-Lucknow flight was told not to land before the ATC nod. The plane hovered over the airstrip for over 30 minutes before touching down. Passengers onboard the Delhi-Lucknow flight said, they faced inconvenience, missed their schedules and were traumatized, while those aboard the Mumbai-Lucknow flight spoke about a scare in the sky. Gunjan Kapoor, a passenger on the Delhi-Lucknow IndiGo flight, said, "I was flying down to Lucknow due to an emergency. My aunt was in hospital and my elderly uncle was alone at home. I was angry when the diversion announced. I felt as if I was being barred from meeting my family. I am ashamed of the fragile air traffic system in the country." Atif Rabbani, a Dubai resident, came via Delhi to Lucknow to attend an engagement ceremony said, "We were shifted to another flight which arrived in morning. I missed the ring ceremony." Officer on special duty, Airport Authority of India (AAI), Sanjay K Narayan said, the glitch was due to a water leak in the underground cables. The airstrip was opened in an hour on Saturday night and it took 45 minutes on Sunday morning to restore air traffic."

column2: 'Can't believe we're free, can't wait to reunite with families'
column3: LUCKNOW: "I want to collect my clothes and belongings from the home where I was working and then return to my own home with my father," said Sonali (name changed), even as tears rolled down her cheeks as she sat in the first floor room of Aashiana-based Asha Jyoti Kendra. A day after being rescued, Sonali had been reunited with her father after 14 years. The thought of being free is yet to sink in for Sonali who lost her childhood and teenage years inside the four walls of a house in Lucknow. Sonali was 10-year-old when she was taken away to Delhi and then sent to Lucknow as a full-time maid. "I recognised my papa instantly. We both hugged each other and cried a lot," the girl shared. "My dad looks old now. I asked him ' papa aap itne buddhey kaise ho gaye (papa, how come you have grown so old). Papa said that my mother and siblings are waiting for me to reach home," Sonali said, adding we cannot wait to reunite with our families. Rima (name changed), the other girl who has been rescued, said, "We were paid no money in all these years. We asked our employers about our parents and families, but they only told us there were no addresses to locate them. We never met or heard from our families in the past 14 years," said Rima. Rima now wants all her dues to be cleared by the family that kept her captive. Like Sonali, she is eager to reunite with her family in Jharkhand. Rima's father has also come to Lucknow along with Sonali's father. Asked how the girls reached Delhi, Sonali said, "We had been talking to a man in Jharkhand and had not told our parents about him. He used to tell us about Delhi and how big and colourful it was. He told us that we would get work in Delhi and get paid as well. So one day, we went to a village fair where the man met us and took us to Delhi. But nothing happened like he had told us. We were instead sent to Lucknow soon and had been working here since."

column2: 45-day wait for LMC facility for Gomtinagar Extension
column3: LUCKNOW: Gomtinagar Extension and Jankipuram suburb on Sunday, officially came under the jurisdiction of Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC), which will now provide civic amenities to 12.5 lakh residents of these twin areas. However, they will have to wait for another 45 days for LMC to provide basic facilities. Earlier, civic governance of these areas was controlled by zila panchayats and the decision to bring them under the LMC umbrella was taken at a House meeting on Sunday. The facilities will include door-to-door garbage collection, cleaning of drains, installing dustbins, repair and sweeping of roads and trapping stray cattle. Officials had promised to kick-start services in seven days, but now the civic body has sought 45 days to arrange sanitary workers, dustbins and compactors. The big move to expand LMC limits was taken after receiving hundreds of complaints from residents of these two areas on poor sanitation and dilapidated infra.Once LMC starts services, residents of Gomtinagar and Jankipuram Extensions will have to pay a user fee. Transfer of property papers from zila panchayat to LMC is expected to begin from this month and the process would be completed by December. Municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi said, "The user charge will be fixed soon. While, Eco-green will be responsible for door-to-door garbage collection, two private agencies will be hired by LMC to clean drains, sweep roads and install dustbins." Other projects like regularising food trucks, reducing registration fee of vendors and installing an idol of Subhash Chandra Bose at Jhandewala Park also got approval at the house meeting.

column2: KGMU board decision on Kothari's stay today
column3: LUCKNOW: King George's Medical University's (KGMU) medical board would decide if loan defaulter and Rotomac Pens Limited owner Vikram Kothari needs to undergo further treatment at the hospital or not on Monday. The stationary czar has been undergoing treatment in a private ward at KGMU since the past two months. Kothari has been accused of defaulting on loans of up to Rs 3,695 crore by five government banks. "The medical board was to meet on July 3, but the patient was taken to SGPGI by a team of CBI officials for health check-ups. We will now decide if he needs further treatment or not," said KGMU's chief medical superintendent Prof SN Sankhwar. Sankhwar said that Kothari has been admitted to the university's physical medicine and rehabilitation department (PMR) after he complained of pain in his joints. "He had uncontrolled blood sugar, which had been causing the pain. His condition is better now and the board would take the final decision on Monday," he said.

column2: Speeding car smashes into bike in Gomtinagar, 35-year-old killed
column3: LUCKNOW: In another hit-and-run incident, a 35-year-old canteen owner of high court was killed, while his employee suffered critical injuries in Gomtinagar on Sunday night. The canteen owner was identified as Shanker Sonkar and his employee as Kamlesh Chauhan. According to police, around 10 pm, Shanker along with Kamlesh was going towards Hazratganj on a motorcycle when they were hit by a car on a flyover in Ujariaon locality. Persons driving the car did not bother to extend any help to the accident victims and sped away from the spot. Later, passersby alerted the police and the injured were rushed to Lohia hospital where doctors declared Sonkar as brought dead. Chauhan was under supervision of doctors when last reports came in. Talking to TOI, Chauhan said that for about half-an-hour cops of Vibhutikhand and Gomtinagar remined busy in deciding their area of jurisdiction and nobody cared to extend any help to Sonkar who was bleeding profusely.  He added that Sonkar was managing a canteen at the new high court in Vibhutikhand. When TOI contacted SHO Vibhutikhand, he said that no accident had taken place in his area, while SHO Gomtinagar said the accident spot came under Vibhutikhand police.

column2: Two prisoners escape from prison, one run over by train
column3: KANPUR: Two prisoners escaped from Etawah district jail by scaling the boundary wall on early Sunday. However, one of them was run over while trying to board a train. Ramanand (45) and Chandra Prakash (40), who were serving life sentences in separate cases, escaped from the jail around 2am. They used bamboo sticks, tree branches, bedsheets and ropes to scale the prison walls. Both were lodged in barrack 5 of the jail. Ramanand, a native of Auraiya, was run over while trying to hurriedly board a train near Etawah railway station, said DIG prisons (Kanpur) BP Tripathi and added that a hunt was on for Chandra Prakash, who belongs to Etawah. Police are also scanning CCTV cameras to gather clues about the fugitive. Tripathi said that a probe has been ordered into the incident and action would be taken against jail officials found guilty. Ramanand, a murder convict, was lodged in Etawah district jail since August 2007. He had escaped from the jail in February 2008 from Etawah district jail but was nabbed in June 2008. Their escape was detected when deputy jailor Jagdish Prasad went on a routine inspection around 3,15am. He alerted the jail staff and a massive search was launched. A police team has been sent to Chandra Prakash's native village, Mahanpur in Ekdil area of Etawah. Ramanand's severed body parts have been sent for postmortem, police said. Senior district officials inspected the jail premises and reviewed the security measures after the jail break.

column2: Sex racket angle in Sitapur rape being probed, says SP
column3: LUCKNOW: The main accused in the Sitapur school gang rape and torment case, a 25-year-old female teacher, was detained along with her two co-accused brothers from Maholi thana area in the presence of the SP on Sunday. "The three are being interrogated by a police team comprising an ASP-rank officer, a circle officer and the SHO (Maholi). I am personally monitoring the case," SP LR Kumar told TOI. Addressing a joint news conference with the DM in Sitapur, SP LR Kumar said police had searched the homes of the accused and scanned their phones, but did not find evidence to confirm that the girl was drugged or that whatever happened was filmed. On whether other schoolgirls were put through the same ordeal as alleged, the SP said, "We spoke to other girls in the school and village, but have so far found nothing to indicate there were more victims. Investigations are on to look into all allegations." The promptness in police action comes within a day of this newspaper publishing a report on the possibility of a drugs and sex ring operating in the school for two years, based on the statement recorded by the 15-year-old gang rape survivor before a magistrate on July 2 under Section 164, CrPC. "We are looking into the aspect of videos and images as alleged. So far, we have not found any other victim (who was drugged and raped as alleged by the girl in her statement)," the SP said, adding that they had applied for compensation for the survivor from a designated fund as per rules. Of the five accused, one Ghanshyam (20) was arrested on Thursday. He is a cousin of the said teacher. The fifth youth, also her cousin, is on the run while the teacher and her brothers were being grilled till the time of filing this report. Advocate Arun Kumar Pandey, who practises in Sitapur civil court and is fighting the case on behalf of the girl, said if arrests were not made by Monday morning, they would fax an application to the DGP and also upload the same on the CM's grievance redress portal. "The Maholi SHO has been intimidating the girl and her family. He is trying to dilute the charges against the accused. We want him removed or shifting of the case to any of the other 24 police stations. A formal application will be made to CM and DGP tomorrow (Monday)," Pandey told TOI.

column2: UP CM Yogi Adityanath orders probe into bus accident
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Monday ordered a probe into the bus accident on the Yamuna Expressway. Twenty-nine people were killed and 18 injured after a state-run bus skidded off the Yamuna Expressway and fell into a large drain in Uttar Pradesh on Monday, officials said. "An inquiry by a committee comprising Transport Commissioner, Divisional Commissioner and IG, Agra, has been ordered by CM Adityanath to investigate the incident in 24 hours," Additional Chief Secretary, Information, Awanish Awasthi said. The committee will report on the cause of the accident and also recommend measures to avoid such incidents in the future, he said.

column2: Kanpur tanneries to reopen, with riders
column3: KANPUR: The leather industry in Kanpur hailed the state government’s move to reopen tanneries, but urged the government to fast-track work on setting up effluent treatment plants to check pollution. Most tannery owners are concerned about survival of their units due to the rider on restricted production. “Government and UPPCB must consider the break-even line of production or industry would sink,” said Asad Iraqi, owner of a tannery. Talking to TOI, Iraqi said every infrastructure has a minimum production quotient and the unit would collapse if this is not maintained. UPPCB officials will have to raise the minimum production limit while imposing conditions, said Iraqi. Echoing this view, Mukhaturl Amin, former chairman of the council for leather export said the government should expedite work on ETP and complete it at the earliest so that the industry can operate in full capacity. The completion of ETP would help tanneries maintain industry parameters and check level of pollutants in effluents at the same time. He said the state government has displayed positivity, but limiting production would shackle the industry, said Amin. Dr Firoz Alam, general secretary, Small Tannery Association said, restrictions imposed on tanneries were to reduce production by 50% and reduce infrastructure accordingly. He suggested installation of CCTVs in units to check production and infrastructure limits at the units. The pollution control board should first allow the tannery to run and then issue notice on additional infrastructure, he said. However, he claimed reduced production and infrastructure would damage the industry. Gulam Mohiuddin, another member of leather industry, said seven-month hibernation period had damaged the industry and the reduced production limits would be of no help to the industry to recover loss. The government should expedite work on ETP, he said.

column2: UP ATS arrests couple in Bhopal, probes Naxal link
column3: LUCKNOW: A middle-aged couple from Jaunpur in Uttar Pradesh was arrested from posh Shahpura locality in Bhopal on Monday on charges of concealing their identity. The Anti-Terrorist squad, which picked up the couple from the MP capital, suspect they were in touch with a Naxalite outfit. Investigators claim the couple had figured in a 2018 video of a meeting with the guerrillas. The Intelligence Bureau is in possession of the footage of this meeting, where revival of a Naxalite outfit in UP was being discussed. After arresting the couple, sleuths searched two locations in Deoria and one in Kanpur after the inmates were found to be in touch with the arrested couple. During the searches, sleuths claim to have recovered documents and correspondence with listed Naxalite outfits. Those arrested in Bhopal were Manish Srivastava and his wife Varsha, who were putting up as tenants for last two years. They were unemployed, but regularly paid rent and could not provide any convincing explanation for residing in Bhopal since 2017. Investigators also recovered Rs 1.25 lakh from their possession along with Maoist literature. “We stumbled upon correspondence between the couple and the banned guerrilla groups,” said ADG ATS Asim Arun. He said investigators were yet to establish a direct link between the couple and Naxalite outfits, so they have been booked for concealing identity. Relevant sections of IPC will be added once their Naxalite links are established, he said. Some others linked with the couple were also detained by the Special Task Force of UP Police for their links with Maoist groups in Nepal in 2010.

Investigators claim the couple had figured in a 2018 video of a meeting with the guerrillas. The Intelligence Bureau is in possession of the footage of this meeting, where revival of a Naxalite outfit in UP was being discussed. column2: Shift case out of Sitapur: Girl’s father to ADG
column3: LUCKNOW: In an application faxed to ADG (Lucknow zone) on Monday, the father of the 15-year-old Sitapur student who was allegedly sedated, gang-raped and filmed on her school campus has sought transfer of the case outside the district, stressing that local police were pressuring them to “reach a compromise” with the accused. Since ADG (Lucknow) exercises jurisdiction over Sitapur, the letter faxed to 05222235399 also urges him to provide security to the survivor and her family who are allegedly facing threats from the SHO of Maholi thana and the accused — a female teacher of the government school, her two brothers and two cousins, one of whom has been arrested. “We are being threatened. My daughter was once quizzed in front of the accused. We don’t think the case can be fairly and impartially investigated here (Sitapur). We want the case to be shifted outside the district so that my daughter gets justice,” the father of the girl reiterated while speaking to TOI on Monday. The student, who was 13 years old when her alleged ordeal began two years ago, had recorded her statement before a judicial magistrate on July 2 under Section 164 of the CrPC. She has claimed she is not the only victim in the case and that other schoolgirls were similarly targeted. While police arrested one of the accused named in the FIR on July 4, they have not taken action against the others. A joint news conference, convened by DM Akhilesh Tiwari and SP LR Kumar on Sunday, summarised that the investigations so far had not substantiated the allegations of use of drugs to rape the student and making of video clips. In the letter to ADG (Lucknow zone), the father of the girl has once again demanded arrest of the all the others — the 25-year-old prime accused teacher and three youths — named in the FIR lodged under Sections 376-D (gang rape), 328 (use of intoxicating substance with the intent to cause hurt) and 504 (criminal intimidation). The plea to ADG also mentions that Maholi police were pressuring the family to get the FIR “expunged”. “Police and administration are trying to dilute the charges without a thorough probe. My daughter’s blood tests were not done to check if she was drugged. They are trying to give a gang rape case a different spin. Sarasar na insaafi hai (This is grave injustice),” the father said.

column2: Water table shrinks, gallons of rainwater go down drain
column3: LUCKNOW: Over 6,500 million litres of rainwater go waste in the city every year because the housing watchdog has not been able to enforce a government order that makes harvesting structures mandatory for residential buildings with a rooftop area of more than 200sqm. According to Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) records, 5.48 lakh households have come up after 2004. All have a rooftop area of 200sqm or more, but few harvest the 900mm rainfall the city receives annually. “As per calculations by the UP Ground Water Department (UPGWD), a house with 200sqm rooftop can recharge groundwater with 118 million litres in a year. If all the 5.48 lakh households have harvesting facilities, 6,545 million litres of rainwater can be used to recharge groundwater,” said RS Sinha, senior hydrologist and former deputy director of UPGWD. The order, originally issued in 2001, had directed housing boards to ensure buildings with 1,000sqm rooftops or more had facility for rainwater harvesting. The order was modified in 2003 and 2006. In 2017, the rooftop parameter was reduced to 200sqm after a survey by the Central Ground Water Board revealed that groundwater in nearly two-thirds of the state was declining at a fast pace. The onus of implementing the order in the city is on Lucknow Development Authority (LDA). Monsoon entered Lucknow last week and if LDA officials are to be believed, around 50,000 households in the city have rainwater harvesting. But, officials are not aware if all are functional. Even if 50,000 is deducted from the total number, as many as 4.98 lakh houses do not harvest rainwater. This, UPGWD calculations show, results in 6,543 million litres of rainwater being wasted. LDA chief engineer Indushekhar Singh said he had no idea why the order was not followed since 2001. “But after I joined in 2017, I ensured its implementation. We approve only those building plans that have provision for rainwater harvesting. We take Rs 1.5 lakh as security money, which is refunded after inspection to verify the facility has been installed,” he said. Senior hydrologist Anupam said apart from spreading mass awareness, there should be a mechanism to enforce the order on buildings and houses built after 2001. He also said at present, around 4 lakh million litres of groundwater are being pumped out yearly and if the situation remains the same, the city might face water shortage like Chennai in coming years. Sinha, who now runs Groundwater Action Group, a body of water conservationists, summed it up best. “Rainwater harvesting projects cost Rs 7,000-10,000—a nominal price to pay considering the gravity of the situation.”

column2: Speeding behind every third road accident in Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: Speeding tops the list of reasons behind road accidents in Uttar Pradesh, according to an assessment of data of the ministry of road transport and highways. The data also reveal that one in three road accidents in the state happens because the speed limit is breached. In 14,276 out of 38,783 crashes that took place in UP in 2017, drivers violated speed norms. ‘Driving on the wrong side’ accounted for 12% of accidents on highways. ‘Drunken driving’ was the culprit in another 8% accidents. And, ‘use of mobile phones while driving’ led to loss of vehicular control that led to accidents in yet another 8% cases. “The death of 29 persons on Greater Noida expressway is not just one incident. There is no dearth of data to prove that there’s an urgent need to improve enforcement on our highways,” said Piyush Tewari, CEO, Savelife Foundation, a nonprofit that works for the cause of road safety. Tewari maintained that there was also need to address the issue of road engineering on an urgent basis. “Most of our highways are missing crash barriers and other infrastructure measures that can prevent an accident from becoming fatal. This is pandemic and needs to be addressed at policy and ground levels,” he added. The report also noted that the percentage share of UP in total road accidents across India is the fourth highest at 8.3%. Also, UP ranks first in terms of the number of road casualties at 13.6%. The most unfortunate thing is that over 53% of deceased are below 35 years. Road safety crusader Ashutosh Soti said while law enforcement was essential to check these “preventable deaths”, encouraging people to follow traffic rules was equally important. “If people follow rules, accidents may be prevented to a great extent,” he stressed.

column2: 40% head & tail collisions: Yamuna Expressway data shows 1 death every 4 days
column3: LUCKNOW: The deathtrap Yamuna Expressway spanning 165km has recorded 5,706 accidents till May 2019, according to UP Traffic Directorate data. Number crunching pegs the accident rate at one in every four days, since the first crash on August 9, 2012 — days after its inauguration. Data compiled by Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority (YEIDA) between Jan 1, 2016 and May 2019, shows 1,176 accidents (40%) were triggered by head-and-tail collision, which includes stranded and moving vehicles. And at least 474 accidents were caused by speeding and another 1,228 from miscellaneous factors. The death toll in this period stands at 462 with 4,907 people suffering injuries. Data also shows the accident rate dipping by 45% to 659 in this period and 236 casualties being recorded this year till May. The highest number of accidents — 1,219 — took place in 2016 while the lowest of 659 was recorded in 2018. Senior YEIDA officials told TOI that on recommendations of Supreme Court, a road safety audit on the 165km stretch was conducted by IIT-Delhi team, but no black spots were found. Officials also claimed that prima facie it shows accidents on this stretch were caused by errant drivers.

column2: Driver dozed off or picked max speed in 5 min
column3: LUCKNOW: The Janrath bus that crashed into a divider on the Yamuna expressway and plunged into a drain early Monday was fitted with a speed-limiting device (SLD) that allows maximum acceleration of 80 kmph. But if a 60-tonne bus picks up maximum speed in a five-minute span, it could spin out of control. Senior UPSRTC officials who are probing the accident say this is what could have happened as the expressway parapet had tyre marks. “The bus first jumped onto the parapet, hit an iron rod below and then plunged into the gorge,” said a senior official. The driver, Kripashankar Chaudhary, was not familiar with the route and finally came on track after passengers pointed out that he was on wrong course, said sources. He was engaged for the trip to accommodate a huge rush of examinees who came to Lucknow earlier in the day, said senior UPSRTC officials. The accident site is the intersection point of the Yamuna and Agra expressways. No CCTV cameras are in place and it’s difficult to track the bus’ trajectory before the crash, said an official. Principal secretary, transport, Aradhana Shukla, said, “The driver had come for night duty and was scheduled to drive a bus to Ghazipur, but there were not enough passengers on the route. So, he was told to go to Delhi. This is a routine reshuffle.” The driver, who also died in the accident, had joined UPSRTC in 2005. He was transferred to Awadh depot (Lucknow region) two years ago. Since January, he had driven buses for over 23,000 km. Also, he resumed duty after three-day rest, said sources. “His eyesight was good and he had no health issues. We are investigating if he had consumed alcohol,” said an UPSRTC official. Based on survivors’ account, the driver dozed off before the tragedy. “The accident site is hardly 5km ahead of the toll plaza and it was just a 5-minute drive from the plaza. How the driver could have suddenly dozed off is tough to imagine,” said the official. The accident’s impact can be gauged from the fact that the two front wheels came off on the expressway and the chassis and body fell into the gorge.The bus was comparatively new as it was inducted into the fleet in 2017. It was thoroughly checked and maintained before the journey. The driver had no history of accidents and operated the same bus on several occasions.

column2: 29 dead as bus falls through gap between e-way flyovers
column3: AGRA: In the worst-ever crash on the Yamuna Expressway, 29 people were killed and 23 others injured when an Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) bus plunged 40 feet into a drain between two flyovers after breaking through the safety railing on the high-speed stretch near Agra early on Monday. The two-tiered AC sleeper bus, known as Jan Rath seva, was cruising at a high speed when it crashed at 4.05am at Etmadpur, 4km from Agra, near Milestone 161 of the expressway. It fell upside down into a drain called Jharna Nullah, which had about six-eight feet of water. “Prima facie, it appears that the driver fell asleep at the wheel. The bus was speeding, which caused it to jump off the flyover's railing,” Agra district magistrate N G Ravi Kumar said. So far this year, 135 people have died in 302 accidents on the Yamuna Expressway. The toll is higher than all of last year, when 111 lives were lost on the stretch, as per figures released by Union road transport minister Nitin Gadkari on Monday. The driver, identified as Kripa Shankar Chaudhary, was among those killed. Senior superintendent of police Babloo Kumar said, “Twenty-nine passengers, including a 2.5-year-old kid and 20-year-old woman, were killed in the accident. Another 23 were injured. They are being provided treatment.” The bus with 52 passengers and two crew members was heading to Delhi’s Anand Vihar ISBT from Lucknow’s Alambagh depot. Agra police confirmed the identities of all 29 dead, who hailed from Lucknow (11), Ghaziabad (2), Delhi (2), Gorakhpur (2), Basti (2), Rae Bareli (3), Pune (1), Bhojpur, Bihar (1), Gonda (1), Kurukshetra (1), Barabanki (1), Mirzapur (1) and one from an unidentified district. The Yamuna Expressway is one of the most modern roads in the country but the high-speed stretch is also notorious for its fatal crashes. A total of 944 deaths have been reported on the expressway since it was commissioned in August 2012. Major (retired) Manish Singh, in-charge coordinator of the expressway, said, “It seems the driver of the speeding bus fell asleep at the wheel. The bus crashed through the reinforced concrete railing and dropped 40 feet to the drain through the gap between two flyovers.” “Since our team was at Milestone 165 where a truck driver was killed around 12.30am in a hit-and-run accident, we moved our entire machinery, including cranes, ambulances and rescue team to the accident site within minutes and the rescue operation was started,” Singh said. Dilip Shrivastav, a 35-year-old resident of Eldeco II in Lucknow who was heading to Delhi to attend an official meeting, said, “I don’t know how the bus plunged into the nullah. All of us were trying to escape from the mangled vehicle. We were saved by the rescue team of expressway.” “It was the last bus for Delhi from the Alambagh depot in Lucknow. All seats were occupied. I was sleeping at the time of the accident when I heard a loud thud. When I opened my eyes next, I found myself in hospital,” said another passenger Sham Ahmad, 28, from Amethi. Two boys who were running along the road in preparation for recruitment in the armed forces told reporters that they saw the bus fall and rushed to join the rescue. Nihal Singh, who was in a field answering the call of nature, added that he was the first to see the accident. Other villagers, too, joined in to do whatever possible, losing no time to help save those injured. The victims were quickly taken to hospitals. However, the operation to pull out the bus, whose roof had ripped off as it fell, from the drain, took several hours. Two excavators and a crane were deployed. Expressing grief over the tragedy, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath announced an ex-gratia of Rs 5 lakh to the kin of the passengers killed in the accident. He also ordered that an investigating committee, comprising the transport commissioner, divisional commissioner and IG (Agra range), be set up to probe the accident and submit it report to the state government. On his instructions, deputy CM Dinesh Sharma and state transport minister Swatantra Dev Singh rushed to Agra and met the injured in hospitals. Deputy CM Sharma said, “It's an unfortunate accident. The medical expenses of all the victims will be borne by the state government. The transport commissioner, divisional commissioner and IG (Agra range) will submit a detailed report of the bus accident to UP government to ascertain the cause of accident.”

column2: UP CM for cattle transport permits to curb lynchings
column3: LUCKNOW: After a spate of lynchings by self-styled cow vigilantes sent shock waves across the country, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath directed the Gau Seva Aayog to issue certificates to those transporting cows to prevent recurrence of such crimes. He said the Aayog should be responsible for the security of those legally transporting cows. Addressing a meeting of Gau Seva Aayog on Monday, Yogi said, issuing certificates should not open avenues for cow smuggling and the Aayog should carry out regular inspection of gaushalas. He said a farmer with two cows will be given Rs 30 per day by the government for each cow to purchase fodder. The programme will be launched as a pilot project in Bundelkhand.

column2: Lucknow: Kids skip school, cook up story of kidnapping
column3: LUCKNOW: Fearing punishment from parents for skipping school, two children aged 13 and 11 cooked up a story about being kidnapped on Monday.  The panicked parents informed the police which mobilised teams to hunt the kidnappers in Saadatganj before finding that the story was false.  The 13-year-old student of a private school told his parents that he and his 11-year-old friend were going to school around 7.30am when a miscreant in a car called them towards him.  "The man pulled us inside the car which had five men who blindfolded us. Near Thakurganj, my friend broke the glass of the car with a bottle and shouted 'Bachao Bachao'. We then escaped," said the boy.  SHO Saadatganj Mahesh Pal Singh said, "After the information around 1pm, we scanned CCTV footage but neither the children nor the car were captured in any frame. There was no broken glass at the spot they claimed. When inquired, the children were unable to justify the claims. The 11-year-old then confessed that since they were late and had not completed homework, they went to a park and cooked up the story. We counselled them no not repeat such an act."

column2: No end to blood spill on deathtrap Yamuna expressway
column3: LUCKNOW: The Janrath bus that crashed into a divider on the Yamuna expressway and plunged into a drain early Monday was fitted with a speed-limiting device (SLD) that allows maximum acceleration of 80 kmph. But if a 60-tonne bus picks up maximum speed in a five-minute span, it could spin out of control. Senior UPSRTC officials who are probing the accident say this is what could have happened as the expressway parapet had tyre marks. “The bus first jumped onto the parapet, hit an iron rod below and then plunged into the gorge,” said a senior official. The driver, Kripashankar Chaudhary, was not familiar with the route and finally came on track after passengers pointed out that he was on wrong course, said sources. He was engaged for the trip to accommodate a huge rush of examinees who came to Lucknow earlier in the day, said senior UPSRTC officials. The accident site is the intersection point of the Yamuna and Agra expressways. No CCTV cameras are in place and it’s difficult to track the bus’ trajectory before the crash, said an official. Principal secretary, transport, Aradhana Shukla, said, “The driver had come for night duty and was scheduled to drive a bus to Ghazipur, but there were not enough passengers on the route. So, he was told to go to Delhi. This is a routine reshuffle.” The driver, who also died in the accident, had joined UPSRTC in 2005. He was transferred to Awadh depot (Lucknow region) two years ago. Since January, he had driven buses for over 23,000 km. Also, he resumed duty after three-day rest, said sources. “His eyesight was good and he had no health issues. We are investigating if he had consumed alcohol,” said an UPSRTC official. Based on survivors’ account, the driver dozed off before the tragedy. “The accident site is hardly 5km ahead of the toll plaza and it was just a 5-minute drive from the plaza. How the driver could have suddenly dozed off is tough to imagine,” said the official. The accident’s impact can be gauged from the fact that the two front wheels came off on the expressway and the chassis and body fell into the gorge.The bus was comparatively new as it was inducted into the fleet in 2017. It was thoroughly checked and maintained before the journey. The driver had no history of accidents and operated the same bus on several occasions.

column2: PM scheme flats: GDA to ask govt for Rs 2,000 crore
column3: GHAZIABAD: A target set by the UP government to build 36,000 flats under the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY) by 2021 will require the Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) to spend at least Rs 2,400 crore, which the development agency says is “very difficult” given the paucity of funds it is facing. “The cost of each flat under the PM scheme is Rs 4.5 lakh, of which the Centre will contribute Rs 1.5 lakh, UP government Rs 1 lakh and the remaining amount will have to be borne by the beneficiary. But we have seen that the actual cost of building one house comes to around Rs 15 lakh, which includes cost of construction and the land. This raises the difference amount for the GDA,” said a senior official at the development agency. He added that the GDA would need 60 acres for constructing the flats. “By a rough estimate, the GDA will have to bear Rs 2,400 from its kitty to meet the target of building 36,000 flats under PMAY. This looks very difficult, given the financial health that the development agency is in. We desperately need financial help from the state government,” he added. The UP government wants the GDA to use its infrastructure fund and the share that it gets from the sale of properties to build the houses. “The funds collected from these sources are meant for GDA’s own projects. If they are used for PMAY, we will be left with little or no money for other projects,” the official said. “We will raise these concerns with the state government in a meeting later and will seek funds from them for PMAY. We can also rely on private developers for taking up more construction of flats,” he added. According to the break-up, the target set for the GDA is 13,500 affordable houses in 2018-19; 18,000 units in 2019-20 and 4,500 more for 2020-21. So far, no flats under PMAY have been completed. The places where the GDA is planning to construct affordable houses are Koyal Enclave, where 1,800 units will come up. In Pratap Vihar, the target is 1,910 units; 1,441 in Masuri; 528 in Newari; 532 in Dasna; and 856 in Maduban-Bapudham.

column2: Robbers in masks target soft drinks godown
column3: GHAZIABAD: Three masked men barged into a godown of soft drinks in Ghaziabad’s Vijay Nagar area on Sunday night and allegedly fled with Rs 4.25 lakh cash and six mobile phones after holding seven people, including the owner, hostage at gunpoint. The owner of the godown, Sanjeev Chaudhary, was present inside along with his cousin Rajiv Chaudhary, a customer and a few staff members when the miscreants barged in at 8.10pm. The godown is located in Vijay Nagar’s South Side E block. Police said when Sanjeev tried to resist the robbery, the miscreants even hit him with the butt of a gun that they were carrying. Later, they locked him up along with other people inside the godown while they were fleeing the spot. Sanjeev told police that as they had hidden two mobile phones, which the robbers could not spot, they managed to call the police control room and get help. “They took Rs 3.5 lakh cash that was kept inside the counter and Rs 65,000 from the customer that was present with us,” Sanjeev told police. On the basis of the complaint, an FIR was registered against the three unknown persons under Section 394 (robbery) of the IPC at Vijay Nagar police station on Monday.

column2: Rainwater harvesting in Ghaziabad societies to be checked
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) will soon carry out on-spot inspections in all group housing societies, industrial and institutional units in the city to ascertain the level of compliance regarding rainwater harvesting and tree plantations. It is mandatory for developers and RWAs to adhere to clauses in the building by-laws related to rainwater harvesting and compulsory plantation. Non-adherence to them may elicit punitive measures from GDA. “From 2012 till now, the GDA has issued completion certificates to 798 housing societies and others in which it had been made mandatory to install rainwater harvesting measures, ahead of monsoon and in view of critical ground water table in the city we will carry out on spot verification to find out level of adherence,” said Kanchan Verma, vice chairperson, GDA. GDA’s enforcement wing has also been asked to check adherence to tree plantation clauses. “Depending on the plot area of group housing societies, industrial and institutional units in the city, there is a set of rules that includes compulsory planation,” said Asheesh Shivpuri, chief architect and town planner, GDA. According to building by-laws, in a plot area up to 200 sq m, plantation of two trees at a distance of 10 metres is compulsory. “In Industrial areas located in polluted zones, 15% of their total area should be densely planted and up to 1 hectares, it is mandatory to plant 125 trees,” added Shivpuri. “In group housing societies, a tree per 2.5 persons needs to be planted in societies’ open and green areas,” added Shivpuri. Even though there is a well-defined law on rainwater harvesting and compulsory plantation, environmentalists point out to large scale violation of the law. “You will hardly find any society that has really adhered to the mandatory plantation clause,” said Ruchin Mehra, a city based environmentalist.

column2: 18-year-old dies as scooter hits truck on Hindon flyover
column3: GHAZIABAD: An 18-year-old boy died after he rammed his scooter into a stationary tractor trolley on Hindon Elevated road on Monday afternoon, police said. The victim, coming from a wholesale chicken market in Delhi's Gazipur, was headed home in Masuri’s Nahal village when he met with the accident at 1.30 pm, they said. Onlookers said the boy was speeding and could not see the parked vehicle. The impact of the collision was such that the boy, Faizan, smashed his head although he was wearing a locally-made helmet. The accident area is under Sahibabad police station’s jurisdiction, the cops said. Arun, the tractor owner, informed that he was going home in Nandgram after buying fodder but the vehicle broke down on the road. “While awaiting help, I heard a loud bang. I saw the accident. The boy apparently died on the spot," he said. Soon after the mishap, a huge crowd gathered around the spot and the police control room (PCR) was called. By the time police reached the spot, a trail of vehicles had formed on Delhi to Ghaziabad side of the elevated road. Altogether, traffic remained disrupted on the road for about 40 minutes. The body was sent for post-mortem and the family of the deceased was informed about the mishap. The police said that an FIR would be registered in the case. Since the road’s opening in March last year, several fatal accidents have taken place and speeding has been found to be one of the major reasons for such mishaps.

column2: Driver dozed off or went to max speed in 5 mins?
column3: LUCKNOW: The Janrath bus that crashed into a divider on the Yamuna Expressway and plunged into a drain early Monday was fitted with a speed-limiting device that allows maximum acceleration of 80 kmph. But if a 60-tonne bus picks up maximum speed in a five-minute span, it could spin out of control. Senior UPSRTC officials who are probing the accident say this is what could have happened as the expressway parapet had tyre marks. "The bus first jumped onto the parapet, hit an iron rod below and then plunged into the gorge," said a senior official.  The driver, Kripashankar Chaudhary, was not familiar with the route and finally came on track after passengers pointed out that he was on wrong course, said sources. He was engaged for the trip to accommodate a huge rush of examinees who came to Lucknow earlier in the day, said senior UPSRTC officials. The accident site is the intersection point of the Yamuna and Agra expressways. No CCTV cameras are in place and it's difficult to track the bus' trajectory before the crash, said an official. Principal secretary, transport, Aradhana Shukla, said, "The driver had come for night duty and was scheduled to drive a bus to Ghazipur, but there were not enough passengers on the route. So, he was told to go to Delhi. This is a routine reshuffle."  The driver, who also died in the accident, had joined UPSRTC in 2005. He was transferred to Awadh depot (Lucknow region) two years ago. "The accident site is hardly 5km ahead of the toll plaza and it was just a 5-minute drive from the plaza. How the driver could have suddenly dozed off is tough to imagine," said the official.  The accident's impact can be gauged from the fact that the two front wheels came off and the chassis and body fell into the gorge. The bus was comparatively new as it was inducted into the fleet in 2017. The driver had no history of accidents.

column2: Why roads share blame for India’s deadly bus accidents
column3: NEW DELHI: June 21, 2019: 44 people die as a bus skids off the road in Kullu while navigating a sharp bend. There were no crash barriers at the site and the road was in a bad condition.July 1, 2018: An overloaded private bus going from Pauri to Nainital in Uttarakhand falls into a gorge, killing 48. A few of the wounded later said the driver was trying to avoid a massive pothole on the road when he lost control of the vehicle.January 19, 2017: A bus packed with little kids on their way to school in Etah hits a truck, leaving 18 schoolchildren dead. It takes days for some of the survivors to recover from the trauma and get back to class.Accidents on Indian roads that kill thousands of passengers have been occurring with alarming regularity. Sample these numbers: Over 11,000 people have died in bus accidents every year in the country, according to official data from 2015 to 2017. In 2017, UP alone recorded 1,406 such deaths while 1,684 perished in the state in accidents involving buses in 2018. Many of these occurred on the “super fast” Yamuna Expressway — Delhi’s seamless link to Agra — and the site of Monday’s deadly incident in which a UPSRTC bus cruising at about 100 kmph dived into a drain. In fact, the killer stretch has recorded 5,507 road accidents and 944 deaths since it opened to traffic in August 2012. In most cases, it is easy to blame the driver. He is, after all, the one behind the wheel. But could the road itself be a problem? Or enforcement of rules? Yes, say experts. The primary focus of accident causation has been narrowing down on unsafe driver behaviour — speeding, fatigue and alcohol use. As a standard measure, police file an FIR against the driver, and the “investigation” often ends there. But the issue with this approach is that it doesn’t take into account several factors that contribute to crashes, road geometrics being one. People gather at the site where officials take out the bus from a drain after it met with an accident and claimed 29 lives at Yamuna Expressway in Agra on July 8, 2019. (ANI Photo)In 2018, the Institute of Road Traffic Education (IRTE), a non-profit, conducted a probe into a bus accident in Kangra (Himachal Pradesh) where 24 children had died and found that the driver was not the only one to blame. “He was guilty of wrongful driving but the road environment — which includes road engineering and signage — did not meet required standards for safe operation,” road safety expert Rohit Baluja, who headed the investigation, told TOI. A probe by the state police into a bus accident that killed 60 in Kondagattu in Telengana in 2018 came up with similar findings. Krishna Prasad T, Telangana’s DGP in charge of road safety, said, “The primary reason was overloading. But we also found that the gradient of the road was too steep and there were chances that brakes wouldn’t work. There were poorly designed speedbreakers that could contribute to the driver losing control.” The engineering defects of this stretch have since been corrected, he said. Baluja added that instead of focusing completely on driver behaviour, it is faulty roads that need to be repaired. “Take hilly roads, for example. There are too many sharp bends. Potholes and boulders cover half the road but are not removed in time. Traffic control devices such as signage are usually missing and there is absolutely no enforcement of speed. We don’t investigate crashes and fix responsibility.” Prasanna Patwardhan, CMD of Purple Buses, which has a fleet of over 3,000, said, “I fail to understand why accident-prone spots have only warning signage year after year when the actual need is to fix them.” Seven students injured after a schools bus rolled down a hill in Lower Khalini area of Shimla on July 1, 2019. Locals are rescuing the students. (ANI Photo)Policy-makers remain tight-lipped on much needed reforms. Experts have been demanding mandatory scientific investigation of fatal accidents like those in Germany, UK and the US. While section 135 of the Motor Vehicles Act talks about the need to frame a mechanism for investigation of accident cases, most states have no such system in place. Union road transport and highways minister Nitin Gadkari has admitted that causes of road accidents could range from faulty engineering of vehicles and roads to drunk driving and people obtaining driving licence without being properly trained. In 2018, the government had announced Rs 11,000 crore to fix black spots —places where most accidents occur — across the country. But this is unlikely to be enough. India — a signatory to the Brasilia Declaration, has pledged to cut road accidents and fatalities by half by 2020 — will need major reforms to achieve its target. Fatigue management could be a good start. So is getting rid of incentives and market pressures that encourage drivers to get behind the wheel while exhausted. In some cases, drivers do with as little as four hours of sleep. The law doesn’t make it mandatory to have a reserve driver in buses. Major (retired) Manish Singh, incharge coordinator of Yamuna Expressway, one of the deadliest stretches in India, said drivers dozing was a recurring factor. The driver involved in Monday’s accident is also suspected to have fallen asleep at the wheel. “In a previous accident case, we found that the actual driver was resting due to exhaustion while another person had been driving the bus -- at full speed.” Lucknow UPSRTC regional manager P K Bose said that the corporation has taken measures to fight fatigue in drivers such as distributing thermos to them so that they could sip tea and stay alert. “We have also provided two drivers on buses operating on long routes,” he added. (With inputs from Deepak Lavania)

column2: Journey home turns tragic for Ghaziabad couple, Noida clerk
column3: GHAZIABAD: An elderly couple from Ghaziabad and a UPSRTC clerk returning to Noida after meeting his family were among the passengers of the ill-fated Jan Rath bus that met with an accident in Agra early on Monday. While 65-year-old Satya Prakash Sharma from Chiranjiv Vihar in Ghaziabad died on the spot, his 57-year-old wife Manju survived. Neighbours said the Sharmas had left Ghaziabad four days ago and were returning from Lucknow on Monday when the bus fell into a drain on Yamuna Expressway near Agra's Etmadpur. Manju suffered fractures on her legs, besides injuries on the head and back. Satya Prakash had retired from the marketing department of a liquor company a few years ago but was still associated with it. Rajnish Srivastav, the Sharmas' tenant, said, "Uncle (Satya) was quite good at his job, so the company had been still using his services. For this, he would frequently go to various towns on official tours. However, this time around, the aunt (Manju) also went with him." He added that they had planned to visit Varanasi as well during the trip. The couple's two sons, Ranjan and Khushal, rushed to Agra after the accident. While Ranjan, who is a business analyst with a Noida-based firm, lives with the couple, Khushal lives with his family in Noida. At least 29 people were killed and 23 others injured when a passenger bus fell into a drain on the Yamuna Expressway on Monday morning. Initial probe revealed that the mishap occurred after the driver of the bus, which was travelling from Lucknow to Delhi, dozed off at the wheel. The bus, after hitting the divider, fell into a 40-foot-deep gap between two flyovers on the expressway near Milestone 161 under Etmadpur police jurisdiction of Agra district at around 4.15am. Manoj Kumar, a 32-year-old clerk with the Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC), also died in the accident. He was posted in the Noida regional office of the UPSRTC as a booking clerk and was returning home after meeting his family in Lucknow over the weekend. "He had gone to Lucknow over the weekend and was supposed to join work on Monday. When he didn't turn up by 10am, some of his friends panicked and contacted his family. By then, we had already heard about the accident on the expressway," said Anurag Yadav, assistant regional manager at the Morna bus depot. The family informed that Manoj had left home around 11pm on Sunday to catch a bus for Noida. He had last spoken to his family after boarding at night and had said that he would speak to them in the morning. Two persons from the Morna depot were immediately sent to the accident site and the body was identified around noon. Manoj's body was taken to his home in Lucknow. Manoj had married about eight months ago and would visit his family during long weekends. He was appointed by the UP roadways in 2009 against his father's position, who had died of an illness while working for roadways. Manoj was promoted three years later in 2012. "He was the sole breadwinner of his family and had been married less than a year ago. Several roadways employees and friends have reached Lucknow to be with the family," Yadav said. Initial probe revealed that the mishap occurred after the driver of the bus, which was travelling from Lucknow to Delhi, dozed off at the wheel. The bus, after hitting the divider, fell into a 40-foot-deep gap between two flyovers on the expressway near Milestone 161 under Etmadpur police jurisdiction of Agra district at around 4.15am. Manoj Kumar, a 32-year-old clerk with the Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC), also died in the accident. He was posted in the Noida regional office of the UPSRTC as a booking clerk and was returning home after meeting his family in Lucknow over the weekend. "He had gone to Lucknow over the weekend and was supposed to join work on Monday. When he didn't turn up by 10am, some of his friends panicked and contacted his family. By then, we had already heard about the accident on the expressway," said Anurag Yadav, assistant regional manager at the Morna bus depot. The family informed that Manoj had left home around 11pm on Sunday to catch a bus for Noida. He had last spoken to his family after boarding at night and had said that he would speak to them in the morning. Two persons from the Morna depot were immediately sent to the accident site and the body was identified around noon. Manoj's body was taken to his home in Lucknow. Manoj had married about eight months ago and would visit his family during long weekends. He was appointed by the UP roadways in 2009 against his father's position, who had died of an illness while working for roadways. Manoj was promoted three years later in 2012. "He was the sole breadwinner of his family and had been married less than a year ago. Several roadways employees and friends have reached Lucknow to be with the family," Yadav said.

column2: Journey home turns tragic for Ghaziabad couple, Noida clerk
column3: GHAZIABAD: An elderly couple from Ghaziabad and a UPSRTC clerk returning to Noida after meeting his family were among the passengers of the ill-fated Jan Rath bus that met with an accident in Agra early on Monday. While 65-year-old Satya Prakash Sharma from Chiranjiv Vihar in Ghaziabad died on the spot, his 57-year-old wife Manju survived. Neighbours said the Sharmas had left Ghaziabad four days ago and were returning from Lucknow on Monday when the bus fell into a drain on Yamuna Expressway near Agra's Etmadpur. Manju suffered fractures on her legs, besides injuries on the head and back. Satya Prakash had retired from the marketing department of a liquor company a few years ago but was still associated with it. Rajnish Srivastav, the Sharmas' tenant, said, "Uncle (Satya) was quite good at his job, so the company had been still using his services. For this, he would frequently go to various towns on official tours. However, this time around, the aunt (Manju) also went with him." He added that they had planned to visit Varanasi as well during the trip. The couple's two sons, Ranjan and Khushal, rushed to Agra after the accident. While Ranjan, who is a business analyst with a Noida-based firm, lives with the couple, Khushal lives with his family in Noida. At least 29 people were killed and 23 others injured when a passenger bus fell into a drain on the Yamuna Expressway on Monday morning. Initial probe revealed that the mishap occurred after the driver of the bus, which was travelling from Lucknow to Delhi, dozed off at the wheel. "He had gone to Lucknow over the weekend and was supposed to join work on Monday. When he didn't turn up by 10am, some of his friends panicked and contacted his family. By then, we had already heard about the accident on the expressway," said Anurag Yadav, assistant regional manager at the Morna bus depot. The family informed that Manoj had left home around 11pm on Sunday to catch a bus for Noida. He had last spoken to his family after boarding at night and had said that he would speak to them in the morning. Two persons from the Morna depot were immediately sent to the accident site and the body was identified around noon. Manoj's body was taken to his home in Lucknow. Manoj had married about eight months ago and would visit his family during long weekends. He was appointed by the UP roadways in 2009 against his father's position, who had died of an illness while working for roadways. Manoj was promoted three years later in 2012. "He was the sole breadwinner of his family and had been married less than a year ago. Several roadways employees and friends have reached Lucknow to be with the family," Yadav said.
