column2: Super 30’s recognition can help me open a school in UP: Anand Kumar
column3: One of modern India’s most-talked-about teachers, Anand Kumar was in the city on Monday to promote the film based on his life. We caught up with teacher-mentor at a local school post his interaction with the students there. In his interaction with LT, Kumar talked about his feelings on the release of his biopic and how this Lucknow visit is special for him. Having been to Lucknow several times in the past, the educationist felt this visit was special for him. He shared, "I have been to Lucknow many times before to select students, aur yahan baar-baar aana acchha lagta hai. But this time it is special because I recently got the news that Lucknow is among the two cities with maximum advance bookings for our film. So, I feel very happy and connected to the city this time." Anand feels happy that Hrithik Roshan is reprising his character in the film Super 30 (BCCL) Anand feels happy that Hrithik Roshan is reprising his character in the film Super 30 (BCCL) Ask the Patna-based mathematician how does it feel when his biopic 'Super 30' is going to be shown on the silver screen and he was quick to respond, "It feels very good! Earlier, when we used to come to Lucknow to screen students for our coaching, we used to do a conference at Sharma ki chai ki dukaan. And now today we are sitting at a prominent school in the city. No doubt your popularity increases and people start recognizing you. But the best thing is that you also start getting association of more and more people who want to carry forward your vision and do good work for the underprivileged students. And gradually our reach is going to expand." He further added, "I had wanted to open a school in UP. In fact, I had submitted the whole plan to the concerned officials, but the government changed in the meanwhile and things couldn’t materialise. Now, I am hoping that the film’s recognition would help me to open a school in UP. If the Uttar Pradesh government gives its support, I would like to open the school in Noida, because it is centrally located and more and more students can reach there from around the country. The admission in the school will not be on the basis of merit and not on religion, caste or class." Anand Kumar gave some tips to the students at the school on how to crack difficult math equations (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Anand Kumar gave some tips to the students at the school on how to crack difficult math equations (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Anand is also elated that Hrithik Roshan is playing his character on screen. "People would say he looks like a Britisher or a Greek God and you look like a villager. But he has encapsulated my character on screen perfectly. The amount of curiosity Hrithik showed in the film earlier and later the amount of hard work he put in for the film, I think he was the right choice for the film. For one whole year he kept preparing for the role. I mean, his dedication was so much that he first gave up gyming to fit into the character. He used to copy my Bihari-Hindi accent. He used to make my videos and then would watch it over and over again for the dialect and mannerism. Just like me, once when our meeting got over, he forgot to wear his slippers as he came down of this flat to see me off," said Kumar, while talking about his ‘hero’.  Earlier in the day, while interacting with the students, Anand Kumar gave them a glimpse into his past and the passion with which he has helped shape the future of several students. "A proper strategy, planned preparation and a skilled team can deliver astonishing results. This is the formula which has worked for me and it applies equally to everyone. Today, the world is looking at us with hopeful eyes, which not only augurs well for the country but for the world. We need to make India stronger. If we can contribute even the slightest bit in realizing this dream, we would have made our life and education meaningful," he said. He also motivated students for a brighter future, "As you step into the professional world after studies, you must remember that the potential for learning is never exhausted. Education is a life-long process, I hope that your studies would have inspired you to seek knowledge at every stage in your careers," he added.

column2: Nostalgia grips these pass-outs in Lucknow
column3: A reunion party on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the 1994 batch of a well-known college was recently organised by the students. Held at a hotel in the city, the reunion saw people coming from different parts of the country to meet their long lost friends. (L) Anuj Khandelwal and Debashish Majumdar (R) Aparna Ratlani (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Anuj Khandelwal and Debashish Majumdar (R) Aparna Ratlani (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Sudeep Saxena, one of the organisers of the do, said, “This is our annual event and we have been organising this reunion for the last five years. But this one is special.” He added, “This is the 25th year of our batch. Many of us are meeting after 6-7 years. But there are two friends who are meeting each other after 25 years; can you believe it! People have come from Mumbai, Delhi, Bangalore, Hyderabad, Jaipur and other places to join the reunion ceremony.” (L) Mayurika Singh (R) Neeraj Mehrotra and Rosy Srivastava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Mayurika Singh (R) Neeraj Mehrotra and Rosy Srivastava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Discussion related to school time memories could be overheard in every nook and corner of the venue. In fact, while talking to each other, Tanushree Biswas and Mayurika Singh, were overheard saying that their bond of friendship is still the same though they were meeting after 25 years. (L) Nupur Shukla and Tanushree Biswas (R) Rachna Mishra (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Nupur Shukla and Tanushree Biswas (R) Rachna Mishra (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Salil Chaturvedi, who came all the way from Mumbai, said “I am meeting these friends after a long time. I used to go with many of them on a rickshaw together to school.” The event concluded with everyone cutting a cake. — Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui (L) Rajat Mehrotra and Anshul Rastogi (R) Sudeep Saxena (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Rajat Mehrotra and Anshul Rastogi (R) Sudeep Saxena (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: Age is just a number for these actors in Lucknow!
column3: A play titled 'Vibhaas' was recently staged at Sangeet Natal Akademi. Directed by theatre veteran Padma Shri Prof Raj Bisaria, the play that was staged on three consecutive days and witnessed a full house each day. (L) Atul and Anant Chaturvedi (R) Diya Badgel (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Atul and Anant Chaturvedi (R) Diya Badgel (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Based on Russian playwright Aleksei Arbuzov's play Old World, it was adapted in Hindi by Rakesh Veda. Theatre veterans Dr Anil Rastogi and Shobhana Jagdish were cast in the lead roles as Arvind Bhardwaj and Rita. The chemistry between the duo on stage was electrifying. Shobhana, who was back on stage after a long time, surprised the audience with her singing skills during the play while Anil's dance moves on English numbers was a scene that everyone enjoyed thoroughly. The plot of the play revolved around two characters who are lonely in their respective lives. While Anil played the role of the psychiatrist who lost his wife, Shobhana essayed the role of his patient. Interestingly, love blooms between the two and a special chemistry is seen on stage. (L) Dr Rashmi Chaturvedi and Prof Kumkum Dhar (R) Jayant Krishna and Beena Krishna (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Dr Rashmi Chaturvedi and Prof Kumkum Dhar (R) Jayant Krishna and Beena Krishna (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Actors Prafulla Tripathi and Somya Chawla also played key roles in the play. "It is very rare that we get to see love stories on older generation couples on stage these days. The plot and the versatility of the actors was just amazing," said Himanshu Patel, present among the audience. — Saad Abbasi (L) Dr Shobha Bajpai and Vinita Mishra (R) Gopal Sinha (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Dr Shobha Bajpai and Vinita Mishra (R) Gopal Sinha (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Kiran Raj Bisaria (R) Pradeep Kapoor and Rakesh Pandey (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Kiran Raj Bisaria (R) Pradeep Kapoor and Rakesh Pandey (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Naheed and Justice Shabihul Hasnain (R) Amit Mukherjee (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Naheed and Justice Shabihul Hasnain (R) Amit Mukherjee (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Prof Raj Bisaria (R) Veena and Major SC Mathur (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Prof Raj Bisaria (R) Veena and Major SC Mathur (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

column2: CBI conducts raids at 110 locations in 19 states
column3: NEW DELHI: In yet another mammoth operation, the CBI conducted raids at 110 locations in 19 states and Union Territories as part of its investigations into 33 cases which the agency registered recently. The cases concern offences of corruption, arms smuggling and criminal misconduct, officials said. This was the second large operation in a week. Last Tuesday, the CBI had carried out countrywide raids against alleged loan defaulters after several banks registered FIRs with the agency. Searches were conducted in Lucknow and some places in the NCR in connection with the sugar mills disinvestment scam which allegedly took place during Mayawati's tenure as Uttar Pradesh chief minister. The agency searched the premises of former IAS officers Netram and Vinay Priya Dhune and sons of former MLC Iqbal Singh — Wajid Ali and Mohammed Javed — in this case. Netram was Mayawati’s secretary at the time. The CBI had registered an FIR and six preliminary enquiries in this case in April. Another FIR was lodged against former Haryana CM Bhupinder Singh Hooda and searches were conducted at the office of Krrish Builders in Jasola in south-east Delhi in this case. In Kanpur, the CBI searched the premises of K A Duggal, the then CMD of BICL, and company secretary K V Vajpayee in a case of alleged irregularities in the tendering process during the sale of BICL properties. Searches were also conducted in the case of a missing youth from Rajasthan and disbursal of 13 housing loans worth Rs 3 crore by an SBI branch manager in Haridwar. Another raid was in connection with a cheating case where a Mumbai-based businessman, Ramesh Chaurasaia, was sold 980 acres of land for Rs 11.5 crore in Chhindwara district of Madhya Pradesh on the basis of forged government seals and stamp papers. The CBI took over the investigation on the order of the Madhya Pradesh high court. Searches were conducted at six places in Jabalpur, Baitul and Indore. The CBI recovered an original MoU signed between the parties apart from some receipts and property-related documents and bank passbooks. In J&K, searches were conducted at private gun houses in Udhampur, Srinagar and 11 places in Jammu in connection with two cases regarding irregularities in issuing of gun licences. Raids and searches at premises owned directly and indirectly by corporate lobbyist Deepak Talwar, an accused in the aviation scam, were also taken up. The raids were carried out across Delhi, Mumbai, Chandigarh, Jammu, Srinagar, Pune, Jaipur, Goa, Raipur, Hyderabad, Madurai, Kolkata, Rourkela, Ranchi, Bokaro, Lucknow, Kanpur and other locations in UP, Uttarakhand, Odisha, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Bihar.

column2: Mumbai touts hoarding tatkal tickets of city
column3: LUCKNOW: The RPF may have nabbed 40 railway touts over the past month, but bonafide passengers are still unable to book tatkal tickets from Lucknow. Many have alleged that the tickets are vanishing within minutes of the online and offline tatkal windows opening. For instance, on Tuesday, the tatkal quota lapsed in three minutes flat. Raman Mishra, who came to Charbagh early to book a ticket for Gorakhpur and was only second in queue, was shocked when he got a tatkal ticket that was 12 on the waiting list. Rishikesh Saxena, a resident of New Hyderabad, had logged on to the railway website at 10am sharp to book a Wednesday ticket to Mumbai. All he got was 10th position on the waiting list. RPF officers blamed touts in Mumbai, Pune and Delhi who had associates in Lucknow. “Touts there are buying tatkal tickets in bulk and sending them by air or road to Lucknow, where it is sold at a premium. For example, Lucknow-Mumbai confirmed tickets have an additional price tag of Rs 1,000 for AC-II, Rs 600 for AC-II and Rs 300 for sleeper coach,” said an officer. Two touts arrested recently from Lucknow and one from Gonda, along with 111 confirmed tatkal tickets, had confessed to their links in other cities. “They said tickets were booked on their behalf by their aides in Mumbai. Orders are placed through texts,” said senior divisional security commissioner, North Eastern Railway, Amit Prakash Mishra.

column2: Snag-hit Saudi flight lands in Amausi after seven hours
column3: LUCKNOW: The Jeddah-Lucknow flight (Saudi Airlines SV 890) developed a snag soon after take-off and made an emergency landing in Jeddah on Tuesday, triggering trauma for more than 200 flyers who landed at Amausi seven hours behind schedule. The delay caused inconvenience to passengers at Lucknow too as the return flight to Jeddah was delayed further. Spokesperson for Saudi Airlines, Nitin Dey, said, the flight took off from King Abdul Aziz Airport in Jeddah at around 11.50 am and after 50 minutes, the pilot reported a technical fault to Air Traffic Controller (ATC). The flight was allowed to make an emergency landing in Jeddah and an alert was sounded to Amausi airport. The passengers were shifted to another aircraft of Saudi Airlines, which touched down in Lucknow around 11 pm. And the return flight to Jeddah departed from Lucknow after midnight. Talking to TOI, stranded passengers at Amausi airport, said, they had to wait for nine hours before boarding the Jeddah flight. And the kin of flyers from Jeddah waiting at Amausi, complained of lack of seating arrangements.

column2: Centre will fund 28 cities with million plus population Rs 10 crore each to clean up air
column3: NEW DELHI: Extending initial financial support to cities under its National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), the Centre has started funding 102 cities with 28 cities with million plus population among them, including Mumbai, Kanpur, Lucknow, Chandigarh, Varanasi, Bengaluru, Kolkara, Hyderabad and Patna, getting Rs 10 crore each for capacity building activities. “Eighty of these 102 non-attainment cities have already prepared their city-centric action plans. The Centre is funding them so that these identified cities can take pollution abatement measures on the ground,” said Union environment minister Prakash Javadekar. Overall cost of air pollution abatement measures in 102 cities will, however, be much more than what the Centre will provide. An official explained that such financial assistance is in addition to what are being done, worth thousands of crores of rupees, in different sectors (transport, highways, forests and renewable among others) across the country to reduce carbon emission. The non-attainment cities, listed for multiple actions under NCAP, are those which did not meet the ambient air quality standard during 2011-15. The 28 million plus cities, identified for funding of higher amount, are those which had reported high pollution level - more than 90 micrograms per cubic metre (ug/m3) of PM10 (particulate matter). The other cities in this group include Raipur, Vijaywada, Surat, Bhopal, Gwalior, Jaipur, Jodhpur, Kota, Bhubaneswar, Agra, Allahabad, Nagpur and Pune among others. Among remaining 74 non-attainment cities, the ones having population of 5 to 10 lakhs will get Rs 20 lakh each while the cities with population of less than 5 lakh will get Rs 10 lakh each as an initial amount. “This financial year, the ministry has got an additional amount of Rs 460 crore with introduction of a separate head - Control of Pollution - under the budget,” said Javadekar while sharing budgetary provisions of his ministry in 2019-20. He noted that the ministry was allocated Rs 3,175 crore for 2019-20 as compared to Rs 2,683 crore in last fiscal - an increase of 16%. Javadekar said, “The budget 2019-20 has declared the intention of making ‘Earth Green and Sky Blue’. This will be achieved through more afforestation and making cities pollution free”. The Centre had launched the pan-India air pollution abatement scheme for 102 cities by formally unveiling details of its pollution reduction target and strategies in January. It had set a mid-term (five-year) target to reduce air pollution by 20-30% by 2024, taking 2017 as base year. The ‘control of pollution’ has been conceptualised to provide financial assistance to pollution control boards, funding to NCAP and other schemes such as National Water Monitoring Programme and National Ambient Noise Monitoring Network among others. Besides building capacities for air pollution abatement measures, the cities will also use the fund for source apportionment study, tree plantation, procuring water sprinklers and mechanical street sweepers, creating construction and demolition waste management facilities and public awareness.

column2: Delhi’s Gone Girl: Woman stages suicide to get husband arrested
column3: GHAZIABAD: “Have you arrested my husband?” When police finally got to the woman curled up under a blanket in a two-tier AC coach of Coimbatore Express at Bangalore City railway station late on July 8 (Monday), this was her only question. “Tell me, has my husband been sent to jail?” Komal Talan, the woman on the Bengaluru train, was 22 when Gillian Flynn’s page-turner, Gone Girl, first arrived at bookstores, and 24 when it was released, two years later, as one of the most anticipated movies of 2014. At 29, she could say she owns the title. Komal, a trainee manager with an insurance company on Barakhamba Road, disappeared on July 5 from her in-laws’ house in Delhi’s Pandav Nagar. A day later, her white Scorpio was found parked under the Hindon elevated road in Ghaziabad with a note saying she was “going away”, and accusing her husband and in-laws of torturing her over dowry since her wedding on April 20, 2018. The note and the car, parked right next to the Hindon canal, suggested she had committed suicide. Fake ID, new number and 4 cities: Cops finally bring back ‘Gone Girl’Divers were called to look for a body. Later, the National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) scoured the length of the canal, whose waters are still and mostly shallow. But this wasn’t the presumed last cry of anguish from a woman driven to despair. It actually was the final piece in months of planning by a woman who had channelled all her rage into quietly planning revenge against her husband for all the torture he had allegedly inflicted, a plot line straight from the pages of Flynn’s novel. For the first 24 hours of her disappearance, as divers searched the canal and police briefed news reporters on a possible suicide, the plot proceeded exactly as Komal had laid out. Her father, a Bharatiya Kisan Union member, filed a police complaint and a case was registered against her husband Abhishek Chaudhary, a bank executive, and her in-laws, at Indirapuram police station on Saturday night. They were charged with domestic violence and kidnapping under provisions of the Dowry Prohibition Act. Police also detained Abhishek for questioning as Komal’s parents accused him of murdering her and throwing her body into the canal. This was the second FIR filed in two days — the first was a missing person’s complaint filed at Barakhamba Road police station on July 5, the same night she disappeared. Just as Komal had thought it would be: it did look like she had driven all the way to Hindon Canal from Pandav Nagar in east Delhi, and jumped. She had left home for office in the morning and never returned — her last location was Sahibabad, 6.45pm — and her SUV wasn’t found till the next morning. It gave Komal time. She switched off her phone, went to Anand Vihar, and took an overnight bus to Jaipur. From there, she bought air tickets for Mumbai. She used the name Kamakshi, an identity she had created through forged documents and a possibly forged Aadhaar card (still being probed). Her note, which she left in the SUV, had been discovered by then. And while divers looked for her body in the Ghaziabad canal on July 7, Komal sat back in the economy class of an airplane that cruised towards India’s west coast. On landing in Mumbai, Komal checked into a hotel and booked a berth, again as Kamakshi, on Coimbatore Express. She boarded the train from Kurla that night. She had no particular destination. All she wanted to do was stay away long enough for Abhishek to go to jail. But her plan was eventually blown by electronic surveillance. Komal, police said, was in touch with some friends using a different number. That’s how she was eventually tracked. SP (city) Shlok Kumar said, “She had deliberately parked her car near the canal so that police and her family assumed she had committed suicide. Her motive was to see her husband behind bars. She remained on the move to avoid detection and did not speak to her parents either. She also hid her real identity to buy tickets.” Kumar said police got an inkling of Komal’s plan when they spoke to some of her close friends. They soon discovered the number she was using and her new identity, Kamakshi. Investigators also found she had withdrawn her entire July salary, probably to fund her getaway. “She would have returned home after all the money she was carrying was exhausted,” said a police officer who was part of the investigation. A police team was formed to find her. It missed her train narrowly in Pune and eventually tasted success at Bangalore. A cousin of Komal accompanied the police team to identify her. Komal’s father Anil Talan claimed he had given Rs 41 lakh in cash and an Audi car as dowry to Abhishek, whose father Dharmendra Kumar is a sub-inspector in Delhi Police. Talan also alleged Abhishek’s family was demanding another Rs 21 lakh for starting a business for him. The Talans are based in Greater Noida. “We had not spoken to Komal on Friday and on Saturday evening. Dharmendra called me and informed me about the car being parked near Hindon canal and that Komal was nowhere to be found,” the FIR lodged by Anil Talan read. Talking to reporters after being brought to Ghaziabad on Tuesday, Komal alleged her fatherin-law abused her from the first day of marriage and would tell her he was the boss of the house and she couldn’t do anything without his permission. Asked about her getaway, she said, “I did not think much while leaving from here (Hindon canal). I did not know my destination. I did whatever came to my mind. The only thing which was clear was that I would never go back to my husband’s house. Even if my family asked me to go back for the sake of their social status, I would have not listened to them.” Police said charges of kidnapping would be removed from the FIR against Komal’s husband but the other sections would remain. Abhishek was arrested on Tuesday night, after Komal’s return, and will be produced before a magistrate on Wednesday. In that, her plan to see her husband behind bars has worked.

column2: With robot hands, IIT-K profs bring joy to paralytics
column3: KANPUR: Taking calibrated steps inside the centre for mechatronics at IIT-Kanpur, professors Ashish Dutta and KS Venkatesh can hardly contain their excitement on Chandrayaan-2 launch mission scheduled for July 15. The six-wheeled robot, Pragyan, that will land on lunar surface after it’s sent aboard GSLV-MKIII by Isro from Sriharikota, has two subsystems — structured light-based map generation and motion planning — built by the IIT-K duo. But, the two professors have another reason for delight: they have ventured into world’s first robot exoskeleton hand for rehabilitation of stroke patients and finished its trials. Their latest device is a two-finger robotic hand (exoskeleton) that uses four bar mechanism and has four degrees of freedom (DOF). The exoskeleton can be worn by a patient on his hand. It uses brain signals, with the help of brain computer interface (BCI) worn on head, and helps paralytic patients open and close the motion of their thumb, index and middle fingers for physical practice. The exoskeleton is driven by AtMEGA 300 Mhz micro-controller and powered by a battery. The professors say that the device will cost around Rs 15,000. “It’s a proud moment and double joy for us while we recall the algorithm, which we made for lunar mission Chandrayaan to help the rover move safely between one point and another, known as path planning or motion. The structured light is like a scanning laser that will survey the surface of the moon, will take pictures and generate 3D maps and path planning. This will ensure four aspects — take minimum energy (20-50 watts) on 10 MHz processor, safe route, prevent rover from toppling over and finally, avoid obstacles in its route. Now, our next mission is completing large-scale clinical trials of exoskeleton in India and the UK,” said Dutta, who is coordinator of Centre for Mechantronics. For exoskeleton, the duo has teamed up with UK-based Ulster University and its professor Girijesh Prasad, who belongs to Gorakhpur. The device has sensors, which monitor the fingertip pressure applied by the patient. If the patient is able to close or move his finger, the device passively follows the motion. If he does not, then the device actively forces the finger to close, while taking directions from BCI using EEG signals. As far as design of the device is concerned, the exoskeleton’s degrees of freedom movement is based on human finger motion while manipulating a coin in hands. The joints on the device consist of four bars to give a human motion. The design and development of an exoskeleton robot for human hand support and rehabilitation is a Rs 55-lakh MHRD project, sanctioned in 2018, led by its department of science and technology and British Council in the UK. The research has been published in leading journals, including Journal of Neuroscience Methods, Biomedical and Health Informatics, Haptics and Engineering in Medical and Biology Society.

column2: WhatsApp honeytrap behind shooting near Charbagh station
column3: LUCKNOW: An engineering graduate from Bihar who was promised a railway contract worth crores in that state worked in sync with two women to honeytrap a history-sheeter over WhatsApp and target the latter near Lucknow Junction on July 2, GRP officers said on Tuesday. Gorakh, alias Virendra Thakur, sustained two bullet wounds in the Narkatiyaganj firing and is recuperating at a Delhi hospital. The student in his 20s, a native of Bettiah district in Bihar, is on the run. The two women were nabbed in Kolkata and are being brought to Lucknow via train. "Prima facie, it appears that the July 2 shooter is a diploma-holder in engineering and was promised a contract in Bettiah. Thakur had also applied for the tender worth several crores. We have succeeded in identifying the women who honey-trapped Thakur. The exact sequence of events will be known once these women are brought to Lucknow," said SP, GRP Lucknow, Saumitra Yadav Sources privy to the probe told TOI that Thakur had a criminal past. He is named in as many as 25 cases, including loot, kidnapping and attempted murder. He has been convicted in a few other cases. "For a long time, Thakur was on the hit list of his rival gang. It is a war of supremacy. The gang roped in two women to honey-trap him over WhatsApp. On the other hand, the engineering graduate was also fielded," a source said. A day before the assault, the women convinced Thakur to meet them at a hotel. The man was smart enough to not fall for the bait and changed the meeting venue first to Charbagh Metro and later near Lucknow Junction, where he was attacked. SP Yadav claimed they had almost cracked the case. "We need to grill the women for more details on their accomplices," he said. On July 2, Thakur was shot twice - once on the waist and then on the leg. He had remained tight-lipped on why he was attacked. Later, cops quizzed his wife in Neelmath and got a lead. It turned out that Thakur had received a call from someone while he was going to the bank with his wife. He dropped her at the bank and left for the station, saying he will pick her up in a couple of hours. His phone records helped police trace the women in Bengal.

column2: Seven lions for Uttar Pradesh, with love from Gujarat
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh is preparing to greet seven lions from Gujarat, instead of eight initially planned, at Etawah Safari Park and chief minister Yogi Adityanath’s showpiece Gorakhpur zoo. A team of two vets that visited Junagarh zoo and thoroughly examined the big cats found one female to be suffering from neurological issues. The others, including two males, have received a medical clean chit and their health certificates have reached the state government. “We are expecting seven lions, five of them females, from Junagarh zoo very soon,” said director of Etawah safari VK Singh. The extra precaution of getting the lions medically examined in their parent state before bringing them to UP stemmed from the embarrassment the erstwhile Akhilesh Yadav government had faced after five out of the 10 lions brought from Gujarat between 2013 and 2015 under an animal exchange programme died between 2014 and 2016. The big cats had contracted the canine distemper virus, which attacks the respiratory, gastrointestinal and nervous systems in domestic and wild animals. This time, the big cats from Junagarh are a gift from the Vijay Rupani government, which passed on their custody to UP on June 11. The safari has since been sanitised against the contagion, courtesy a vaccine provided by San Diego zoo, US. The big cats were initially set to reach Etawah by May 22, but the blistering heat forced the forest department to postpone the plan. The decision for medical check-up further delayed their arrival. Now, the lions are likely to reach UP by the end of July. Four safari keepers have been to Junagarh zoo twice to spend time with the lions to understand their behaviour, habits and needs. The lions will be quarantined for 21 days at the safari before being shifted to their new home, the Gorakhpur zoo, which is likely be ready for them only by November. The fact that the zoo can house only three lions indicates that the rest may stay back in Etawah.

column2: Kanpur: Medico, 19, ends life due to exam stress
column3: JHANSI: A 19-year-old student of MBBS first year in Jhansi Medical College ended her life by jumping from the fifth floor of the under-construction super-speciality wing of the college on Tuesday morning.  Mannya Tiwari, from Kanpur, was reportedly reeling under stress due to ongoing semester examinations. According to college authorities, she called up her mother around 5.30am and said that her previous exam had gone badly. Her mother consoled her saying she could reappear for it. Mannya reportedly replied that she would not take the exam again and was going to jump from the building and disconnected the phone. Her mother immediately alerted the hostel warden, who along with a guard rushed to save Mannya. However, by that time, she had jumped from the building.  By afternoon, her parents arrived in college and informed the authorities about the phone call. Her father Ashish Tiwari, a professor at IIT-Kanpur, said that Mannya was their only child and was a brilliant student. She had cleared both medical and IIT entrance exams in the first attempt but had opted for medical. Dr NS Senger, former principal of the medical college, said the incident was shocking and that Mannya was a promising student.

column2: Selfie is the new sign-in for teachers in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: The selfie obsession may have triggered a debate on whether the social media fad is a bane or a boon, but it’s turned out to be a clinical tool to enforce discipline in education in the Uttar Pradesh hinterland. District education authorities in Barabanki, UP have hit upon an innovative idea to smash the network of ghost teachers and rampant absenteeism in class with a diktat to its 7,500 teachers — send your selfie before starting class or lose a day’s salary. Besides the selfie-attendance meter, other disciplinary measures have been enforced. Teachers found surfing social media sites during school hours will also lose pay. The new mechanism to ensure punctuality has triggered panic. Teachers, particularly women, are now hurriedly completing morning chores, catching public transport to rush to school. And their first job is to shoot a selfie before their classroom and post it on the Basic Shiksha Adhikari (BSA) webpage to mark their attendance. Their mission needs to be completed by 8am sharp with BSA putting in place an automated system to verify selfies. So far, 700 teachers have lost pay in two months after the system was implemented and schools reopened after summer vacation in Barabanki. Primary education had been crippled in the state due to chronic absenteeism by teachers in primary and upper primary schools and ghost teachers on pay rolls. Education department officials have caught several primary teachers not taking classes in remote areas and hiring a local man to teach on their behalf for cut money. Also, some unscrupulous teachers don’t report to schools at all and manage their attendance and pocket their salaries in connivance with clerical staff. Talking to TOI, basic shiksha adhikari V P Singh said, the entire process of receiving and verifying selfies is being strictly implemented on directions of the chief minister and basic education minister. “Teachers have been specifically told if they don’t post their selfies by 8 am, they would lose their a day’s pay,” said Singh. But teachers feel the diktat is “tortuous”. “Traffic jams, unavailability of public transport in rural areas and poor Internet connectivity are posing a hurdle in uploading selfies on time. I lost a day’s salary because my tempo got stuck in a jam at the railway crossing,” said a woman teacher of a primary school in Ram Nagar in Barabanki district. One of her colleagues said, “District authorities are not ready to accept that Internet on mobiles fluctuate and this delays uploading of selfies. Net speed is so slow in rural areas and sometimes selfies can’t be posted at all. And we end up losing a day’s pay.” Talking to TOI, Barabanki’s basic shiksha adhikari VP Singh, said there’s enough buffer time to teachers, but selfies have to be posted by 8am. Also, teacher teachers can surf Facebook, Twitter or Whatsapp during school hours, he said.

column2: Bus accident graph up in Uttar Pradesh, dips in India
column3: LUCKNOW: The frequency of bus accidents may have dipped across India in the last decade, but Uttar Pradesh is the only state where the graph has shot up, according to data by Union ministry of road transport and highways. The state also clocked a rise in fatal accidents involving government buses. The number of accidents in 2006 stood at 1,894 and in 2016, it rose to 2,853. The data of the following year showed a spurt by 100 cases. The trend can be attributed to a population boom, augmentation in fleet, rise in bus frequency and more routes getting nationalised where government buses were allowed to ply, said a UPSRTC official. "Improved road conditions are also a reason, so is faulty road engineering. Three years ago, after a bus crashed into a crossing in Bareilly, we rectified the engineering error. The road was designed in a way that it was impossible for the driver to see what lies beyond the crossing," said a senior official of UP Road Safety Cell. Also, smooth roads spur speed. At least 60% bus accidents in last few years have taken place on expressways and highways. An expressway is a completely different driving experience and low traffic density makes the driver go off-guard easily as monotony sets in, said the official. "When we analyse causes, we do it under three parameters-mechanical failure, human error and the driver on the other side who triggered it," said an official. Going by this clause, there couldn't be a common thread linking accidents. Drivers' associations, on the other hand, say a skewed bus-crew ratio could be the reason. Initially, the ratio was 1:8.5, which means at least eight people, including the driver and the conductor, are required to operate a bus. In the last 10 years the ratio has dipped to 1:7. On a long journey (1,000km both directions), a bus should have two drivers, but rules are bent due to staff crunch.

column2: Ghaziabad murders and suicide: Woman’s lover arrested
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 22-year-old man, who was in a relationship with a nurse whose husband killed her following repeated quarrels over the illicit affair, was arrested on Monday. Police said Kapil Pippal, who is from Agra, was involved in a relationship with Sangeeta for the past two years. Sangeeta’s husband Pradeep, who was unemployed for over a year and had turned an alcoholic over time, had allegedly killed her with a hammer, poisoned her three daughters and committed suicide at their home in Masuri last week. In a six-page note purportedly written by Pradeep, he had mentioned Sangeeta’s affair with Kapil. “Sangeeta had met Kapil in Gaur Mall two years ago. Since then, they had been involved in this relationship. She had even helped him get a job at NDDTC. The duo would meet in a house in Govindpuram that Sangeeta had rented for Kapil,” SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun said. Sangeeta, who worked as a nurse at an AIIMS centre in Ghaziabad, would even give Kapil Rs 10,000 every month. Around a year ago, she had got him shifted to their own house in New Shatabadipuram as a tenant, but Kapil had to vacate the room in two months because of opposition from Pradeep. Police said the woman was even ready to sell the house, which she had bought with a loan, to live with Kapil. This led to frequent quarrels between Pradeep and Sangeeta. According to Jadaun, Kapil had described to his interrogators the entire sequence of events. He has been booked under Section 306 (abetment to suicide) of the IPC. Police said Pradeep would come home drunk and fight with his wife over her affair with Kapil. He would not sleep in the bedroom, but on a sofa in the drawing room.

column2: CBI books ex-SP mantri, four IAS officers in mining cases
column3: LUCKNOW: The CBI probe into the 2013-17 UP mining lease renewal controversy widened after the agency on Wednesday registered two separate cases of criminal conspiracy, forgery and corruption against four IAS officers and Gayatri Prajapati, a minister under the Samajwadi Party government. The CBI probe had begun on the directions of Allahabad high court over the irregularities in e-tendering procedures, renewal of existing leases and fresh leases during 2012-17. According to one FIR, the then UP principal secretary (geology and mining) Jiwesh Nandan, a 1985-batch IAS officer; then special secretary (geology and mining) Santosh Kumar (1995-batch IAS) and then Fatehpur district magistrate Abhay Singh (2007-batch IAS), had allegedly colluded with Prajapti to favour two businessmen by granting licence to mine land in 2014 despite several objections on pending dues and environmental clearances between 2010-12. Both businessmen — Shiv Singh and Sukhraj — belong to Fatehpur. While Shiv Singh had Rs 6.2 lakh in government dues outstanding against him following his renewal application in 2009 March and a curt reply of “not maintainable” by then Fatehpur DM in 2010, the next DM Abhay Singh allegedly overturned the decision in 2012 and granted him licence to carry on mining in 100-acre land in Korrakanak village of Fatehpur on January 10, 2014, for a three-year period, the CBI has alleged. Similarly, Abhay also allegedly overturned the February 2014 decision of the principal secretary (geology and mining) Chandra Prakash to not issue state mining lease to another businessman Sukhraj for 90-acre land in village Korakkana in Fatehpur. Abhay, allegedly, colluded with Prajapati to order renewal for a three-year period. The CBI has said that Abhay Singh also renewed Sukhraj’s second mining site in village Guruwal in Fatehpur. The CBI on Wednesday said that it has recovered Rs 45 lakh from Abhay, a charge which he denied. In the second FIR, the CBI has found that then DM Fatehpur Dr Vivek (2009-batch IAS) had allegedly renewed licences for two businessmen Phool Badan Nishad and Sharda Yadav despite objections by the Allahabad high court. While Nishad was granted licence for a 28-acre site at Kotwa in Ratanpura and 20-acre site Sabwat-Ahirwa road in Deoria, Yadav was granted a licence for 22-acre site on Kushinagar Deoria road. The CBI said that Vivek hatched a conspiracy with three other UP officials - then ADM, Deoria, Devi Sharan, mining clerk Hansraj and mining officer Vijay Maurya.

column2: Driver held with drugs convicted, gets 10-year jail term
column3: KANPUR: Additional district and sessions judge (VIII), Sundar Lal, on Wednesday convicted accused Kanhaiya Kumar Rai under Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPSA) Act, 1985 for keeping charas and sentenced him to ten years rigorous imprisonment along with a fine of Rs one lakh. According to the case file, Kanhaiya was a driver of oil tanker. A special team of central excise department seized around 102 kg of charas from his possession. According to the case file, the central excise department, Lucknow, received information on February 8, 2010 that a huge quantity of charas was being brought from Nepal to Kanpur by a LPG tanker. The central excise department constituted a team and deputed it at Kanpur-Agra national highway. At around 10 pm, the team spotted a LPG gas tanker at Bhauti, and asked the driver to stop the tanker. The team searched the driver’s cabin and seized 102 kg of charas kept in a box behind the driver’s seat. Driver Kanhaiya Kumar, resident of Begusarai village in Bihar and Jitendra Kumar Jha of Begusarai district were arrested by the team. The value of the seized narcotic was around Rs 30.60 lakh. . On the quantum of sentence, the prosecution demanded maximum punishment to the accused while the defence counsel requested the court to take a lenient view as the accused had no criminal history, is a young man of 30 years, and the only earning member of his family.

column2: Denied security, Sitapur teen forced to leave own village
column3: LUCKNOW: Unabated threats allegedly from the accused and also an inspector-rank officer have prompted the father of the Sitapur school gang rape survivor to shift her to an undisclosed location in the town away from their native village under Maholi thana. Four members of the family, including two children aged three and seven, who are still living in the village are allegedly being intimidated routinely so that the FIR is withdrawn while action on a plea for police security faxed to ADG (Lucknow zone) on July 8 is pending. The family has also appealed on the CM’s Jansunwai portal. Speaking to TOI on Wednesday, the father said the armed accused were roaming near their village home. “I am here with my eldest daughter for the past few days. My elderly mother, wife and two children are living in fear back in the village. The accused are armed with tamanchas (countrymade pistols). They are loitering near our home. The Maholi SHO is constantly pressuring us to reach a compromise with the accused,” he said over phone. On June 27, the 15-year-old student of a government school had lodged a complaint against a female teacher and four youths, accusing them of sedating her for two years, raping her and blackmailing her with threats of making video clips of the act viral. In his faxed petitition to the ADG, the father of the girl had sought transfer of the case outside the district and protection for his family. “ The survivor and are family are afraid to stay in their village because of threats from the accused and Maholi SHO... We urge you for better security and justice,” the plea to the ADG stated. The ADG is on leave. IG (Lucknow range) is holding additional charge. His office said they had received no such application from the family yet.

column2: CBI, ED zeroing in on ‘scams’ in SP, BSP regimes
column3: LUCKNOW: Law-enforcing agencies – CBI and ED — have expanded their footprints in Uttar Pradesh, with the proverbial sword dangling over many who allegedly had a role in scams in the BSP and SP governments. While the infamous National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) case during BSP regime took its toll with a minister in the Mayawati government, Babu Singh Kushwaha, still languishing in jail and a senior IAS officer, Pradip Shukla, now retired, out on bail, sources in CBI revealed that the “magnitude of embezzlement in the corruption-ridden sale of 21 sugar mills of the state government” was no less than the NRHM case.” In one of the 21 sugar mills near Bareilly, the plant machinery, mill compound spread over 400 acres was sold at a meagre price of Rs 26 crore, said a CBI officer. Over a dozen of IAS officers, who were part of disinvestment committee in the BSP government are bound to be in troubled, the CBI officer added. Perhaps, this is why, before formally raiding officers involved in the sale of the sugar mills, the CBI headquarters posted a full-fledged IPS officer in Lucknow as SP to pursue the investigations in this case. On July 10, the CBI raided two senior IAS officers along with lower rung officers to pursue its investigations. The CBI has also intensified its investigations in the mining licenses controversy that broke out in the previous Samajwadi Party government. Two IAS officers Abhay Kumar and B Chandrakala have already been booked after the CBI raids and many more of lower ranks also face probe while then mining minister of the same regime, Gayatri Prajapati, is already behind bars for over three years. In the last few days, CBI and ED have escalated inquiries into the construction of the Gomti River Front project, another project of the SP government, and seized properties of engineers involved in the project. Soon after coming to power in 2017, the Yogi government had ordered inquiry into alleged corruption in the project. The judicial committee and a high-powered committee headed by parliamentary affairs and urban development minister Suresh Khanna had nailed down half a dozen senior IAS officers for their suspicious role and on his recommendations, the Yogi government had sought CBI inquiry which is now looking into roles of those involved in it.

column2: Lucknow: Manager arrested for PICUP blaze
column3: LUCKNOW: A senior manager of the technical section of PICUP was arrested on Wednesday for allegedly triggering a fire in his chamber earlier this month. Police officers who took NK Singh into custody from his home said they had evidence that his activities were “suspicious” on the day. On July 3, important files, computers and furniture were gutted in a major fire that broke out on second floor of PICUP Bhavan. A committee formed by the CM to look into the causes headed by ADG (Intelligence) — submitted its report to the government on basis of which an FIR was registered by PICUP’s HRD deputy manager Richa Bhargava against an unidentified person. Gomtinagar CO Avnishwar Chandra Srivastava said, “Singh is seen in CCTV camera standing in front of the check-out machine, but not punching his card.”

column2: 2 fires and 6 deaths: Hotels demolished 6 yrs after order
column3: LUCKNOW: The process to demolish SSJ International and Viraat International, the two hotels in Charbagh that caught fire last year killing six people, began on Wednesday. This comes six years after their demolition was ordered by the Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) as they were constructed in a residential area. The order to demolish the buildings was passed in September 2013, but remained buried in files. Had the order been executed on time, the tragedy could have been averted. However, now the LDA has sought an explanation from the officer in charge of Charbagh to explain as to why directions to demolish the buildings were not carried out on time. TimesViewThe task and responsibility of authorities should not end merely with the demolition of the hotel buildings in the city. The state government must also ensure that the recommendations from the inquiry committees are acted upon and not buried like the 2013 order to demolish the hotels issued six years ago was. In fact, such laxity should be treated as criminal negligence as several lives and livelihoods are at stake. This action should become a precedent so that no such incident takes place in the future.The hotels were sealed after the fire on June 19, 2018. The state government had then set up a high-powered committee headed by additional director general of police, Lucknow Zone, to probe the causes of fire and fix accountability of officers and departments concerned. During the probe, the committee found that the land on which the two hotels were constructed was registered as residential in LDA records and the September 2013 order of demolition was never implemented. The committee submitted its report to the state government in August 2018, recommending action against 30 LDA engineers for laxity. The report was sent to the LDA on June 27 for action. While LDA vice-chairman is on leave, the secretary was not available for comments. Joint-secretary of the authority, Ritu Suhas, who is also the presiding officer of the LDA court, said that the order for demolishing the buildings were issued by the LDA court in September 2013 after it came to fore that the hotels were constructed on residential land. When asked why the order was not executed, she said that the executive engineer of zone-VI under whom Charbagh area comes, has been asked to explain the reasons about the delay in execution.

column2: School van hits 3-wheeler, 2 kids hurt; driver flees
column3: LUCKNOW: Two schoolchildren suffered injuries and six others had a narrow escape when their school van collided with a three-wheeler parked on the roadside in Para on Wednesday afternoon. The injured children were Aditya Yadav (10) and Paridhi Yadav (5). Locals informed police which took them to a nearby private hospital and informed their parents. They also informed parents of the other children who were badly shaken up and were crying. Initial investigation suggests that it was a case of negligent driving by the van driver who fled after the accident. The owner of the vehicle is also missing. Though the van had an RTO permit valid till July 27, the mandatory fire extinguisher and first-aid kit was missing, said police. Para SHO Triloki Singh said the incident occurred around 1.30pm. The three-wheeler had stopped to allow passengers to de-board when the speeding school van hit it from behind. The two children sitting in the front seat were injured. “Eyewitnesses told us that the driver was also injured, but he helped the kids come out of the van before fleeing,” Singh said. Alambagh CO Lal Pratap Singh said, “We have seized the van. The parents of the kids have not registered any case against the driver yet.” Aditya, a student of class IV, has suffered a hairline fracture on his left leg. His left cheek was cut by a piece of glass from the shattered windshield. Paridhi has also suffered injuries from pieces of glass. Aditya’s mother Urmila said she had lodged a complaint with the van owner a few months ago about the driver’s reckless driving but no action was taken.

column2: Lucknow waterlogged, rain to continue
column3: LUCKNOW: Intermittent rains for the past six days have compensated for the loss accrued by late arrival of monsoon in the city. The rainfall deficit, which had soared to 90% on July 2, came down to just 3% on Wednesday. Rains have kept weather pleasant but have also resulted in waterlogging across the city. More showers are likely till Saturday. The monsoon arrived in Lucknow this year on July 3, 15 days behind the normal date. After remaining weak for two days, it picked up pace on July 5 and has been active since then. Total rainfall from June 1 till date has been 143.9mm, which is 3% below normal, which is 148.4mm for the period. State Met director JP Gupta said that total 40mm rains were recorded in 24 hours since Tuesday evening. Intermittent light to moderate rains will continue till Saturday. Meanwhile, continuous downpour from Tuesday night till Wednesday morning and intermittent showers during the day led to waterlogging in several parts of the city. The areas worst affected included Faizullaganj, Gomtinagar, Aliganj, Mahanagar and Charbagh. At Charbagh railway station, passengers were seen struggling with baggage to cross the waterlogged section outside the building. Northern Railway officials held a choked drainage system responsible for waterlogging and said that they have written to the district magistrate and LMC but to no avail.

column2: In draft bill, panel moots action against UP cops in lynching cases
column3: LUCKNOW: Taking suo moto cognisance of about 50 cases of lynching and mob attacks in UP over the past five years, the State Law Commission has recommended to the state government that a law to prevent lynching should be prepared. Along with a report on mob lynching, the panel has also submitted a draft of the Uttar Pradesh Combating Mob Lynching Bill to chief minister Yogi Adityanath. Other than detailing action against perpetrators of lynching, the draft bill also recommends action against the police and administrative officials of the districts where such incidents take place. State Law Commission secretary Sapna Tripathi told TOI that the Supreme Court had passed an order in 2018, asking states and the Centre to frame rules to prevent lynching, but no state except Manipur acted on it. “We studied laws on lynching across the world and framed the draft bill which contains details of how lynching can be prevented and how to exercise authority against a mob. Punishment has been specified for the perpetrators depending on the result of the lynching, injury or death. We have also recommended fixing liability of police and district magistrate for failing in their duty to prevent mob violence,” she said, adding that hate crimes have also been included in the purview of the bill. Lynching has claimed 11 lives in UP in the past five years while 40 cases of mob attacks, including hate crimes, have been reported during the same period, said Tripathi. The commission has identified lynching by cow vigilantes as the major reason for lynching in the state. Interestingly, on Monday, CM Yogi Adityanath had issued directions to prevent lynching by cow vigilantes, asking the district administration to issue certificates to those transporting cattle to ensure that they are not mistaken as cow smugglers. In the report submitted to the CM, State Law Commission chairman Justice AN Mittal has mentioned various cases of lynching and mob violence in the state, including the 2015 killing of Mohammed Akhlaq in Dadri on suspicion of beef consumption, followed by the killing of Inspector Subodh Singh in December 3, 2018, in violence between police and Hindu groups in Bulandshahr after remains of cattle were found in a field. Mittal has also mentioned in the report how mobs are now turning on police as well. “Incidents of mob violence have taken place in districts of Farukkhabad, Unnao, Kanpur, Hapur and Muzaffarnagar etc. Police are also becoming victims of this violence and people have started thinking of them as their enemy. The killing of a head constable in Ghazipur and jail warden are examples of this,” Mittal has said.

column2: Onus of error-free marksheets on parents, teachers
column3: LUCKNOW: The Uttar Pradesh Secondary Education Board (UPSEB) has fixed the responsibility of producing error-free marksheets and certificates of Classes X and XII on parents, teachers and principals. While issuing the timetable for exam registration, UP Board officials said parents, teachers and principals would have to countersign the application form that bear details of students. This year, heads of all the 27,365 schools in the state will start online registration of private and regular students for board exams from August 5. The information updated on the website will be used to prepare results. The move to fix accountability comes in the wake of Allahabad High Court’s recent directive to the board, asking it to issue marksheets and certificates in both English and Hindi to avoid mistakes, particularly in names. “Parents, teachers and principals will have to countersign forms that have details of students before these are uploaded. The idea is to ensure that names of students on marksheet and certificates are correctly printed. They will be responsible for any error in the name of a student or their parents/guardians,” said Neena Srivastava, secretary, UPSEB. According to the registration schedule, school principals will have to deposit the fee in the treasury by August 10. Those students who fail to adhere to the given date can deposit the same by August 16, albeit with a late fee of Rs 100. “Principals will be given 10 days from August 21 to amend spelling errors and typos. During this period, no new student will be registered,” the UPSEB secretary said, adding that the registration process would be completed by September 10 midnight.

column2: NGT confirms blood mixed water flowing into Varuna river in Kashi
column3: LUCKNOW: The crimson-coloured sewage flowing into the Varuna river from Varanasi’s Ardali Bazar locality is, in fact, blood of illegally slaughtered animals, a panel constituted by National Green Tribunal has found. The NGT-constituted Eastern UP Rivers and Water Reservoirs Monitoring Committee (EWP-RWRMC) had taken note of the ‘red water’ during an inspection in January this year. It was accompanied by members of the CPCB, UPPCB and the Varanasi Municipal Corporation (VMC). In its report on the pollution of city’s Varuna and Assi rivers, submitted to the NGT on Wednesday, the EUP-RWRMC observed that the major and minor drains from Ardali Bazar carry “slaughterhouse untreated effluent” and domestic sewage into the Varuna, and eventually into the Ganga. It states that reports by various scientists have confirmed that the Varuna’s water quality is “poor” and oxygen levels of the river downstream are “below detectable limits”. Owing to this factor, CPCB has identified the Varuna’s stretch from Rameswar ghat to Adikeshwar ghat as polluted. “During monitoring it was observed that dissolved oxygen in upstream of Shastri ghat was found 2.5mg/L before mixing of drains. In downstream, where the drains from Ardali Bazaar mix with the river, the dissolved oxygen was found below detectable limits. This shows the impact of untreated effluent from slaughters mixing with the river, along with untreated domestic sewage. With zero per cent oxygen, it has made the water of river Varuna hazardous to public life,” said panel’s secretary Rajendra Singh. The EUP-RWRMC, chaired by Justice (retd) DP Singh, has recommended to NGT to impose an environmental penalty of more than Rs 27 lakh on Varanasi Municipal Corporation for non-compliance of Solid Waste Management Rules 2016. It has asked authorities to stop dumping solid waste at old Varuna bridge and other places within two months. It has also recommended that Varanasi administration and VMC must stop the flow of animal carcasses, blood and flesh from unauthorised colonies on the banks of the two rivers within two months. The NGT-panel has blamed the state government, UPPCB, Central Pollution Central Board, VMC, district authorities and Jal Nigam for pollution in the river. It has suggested to the government and district authorities to issue an advisory to people to not bathe in the Varuna and Assi as they are polluted. The panel has asked CPCB to inspect the two rivers in November this year. The water of the two rivers has been found to be unfit for drinking, outdoor bathing, fish culture and can only by used for irrigation, industrial cooling or controlled waste disposal, the committee has said.

column2: Vasectomy fear: More women go under scalpel
column3: LUCKNOW: Women shoulder the natural responsibility of bearing children. But in Lucknow, they are also burdened with the duty to not have too many children, going by the higher number of tubectomies than vasectomies. On the eve of World Population Day, data from National Health Mission (NHM) for Lucknow show a chasm between female and male sterilisation numbers, which has only been growing over the years. The misogynistic disparity stems from a number of myths such as vasectomy “weakens manhood”. And, it is no secret that most Indian women are prone to “keeping their husbands safe” even at their own cost. NHM statistics from 2014-15 to 2018-19 reveal that on an average, the number of female sterilisations for family planning was at least 20 times more than male sterilisation. In 2014-15, there were only 0.4% vasectomies recorded in Lucknow, which by default means the remaining 99.6% sterilisation process involved women or tubectomies. Similarly, in 2015-16, female sterilisation was as high as 97.4%. The rate of tubectomies dropped to 85.9% in 2016-17 only to rise to 91.8% in 2017-18. In 2018-19, female sterilisation was higher at 94.2% against 5.8% vasectomies. “Men have been found to put the burden of family planning largely on women. There are myths surrounding vasectomy too. Many couples believe that the procedure decreases a man’s libido. They call it ‘weakness’, but it is a myth. At times, women are also put through the process to save family honour in cases of extramarital affairs,” said Poonam Muttreja, executive director of Population Foundation of India. Professor Yashodhara Pradeep, head of gynaecology at Dr Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) Institute of Medical Sciences, pointed out that Indian women usually have a soft corner for their husbands and they deem it fit for themselves to undergo sterilisation rather than put the man they are married to through any “complication”. “Many women even ask for it while undergoing a C-section if they already have two to three children. There is also the myth that men won’t be capable of physical labour after vasectomy,” she added.

column2: No teacher, several Lucknow University colleges to shut depts
column3: LUCKNOW: It sounds bizarre but several government-aided colleges affiliated to Lucknow University have been managing their higher education with just one faculty member. And the quality of education has deteriorated further. Several departments, being run by a single faculty member, face closure with the retirement of 20% teachers on June 30. To teach around 20,000 students in 19 government-aided colleges, sanctioned teacher posts are 817. Of these, 197 are lying unfilled. According to University Grants Commission (UGC), the student-teacher ratio should be 1:40. However, it has crossed 1:50 in these colleges and would become 1:60 in the next session. In Shri Jai Narain PG College, for instance, 50 posts are lying vacant. Departments like geology and anthropology have no permanent faculty member. For 10,500 students, there are 139 sanctioned posts, but only 89 have been filled. The student-teacher has touched an alarming 1:90. “Around 50% of departments are dependent on guest faculty,” said principal S D Sharma. He added: “In geology, there are three sanctioned posts but two are vacant. The only faculty member is on leave.” For 4,000 students in Bappa Sri Narayan Vocational Degree College, sanctioned posts are 77, of which 31 are vacant. “If posts are not filled, many departments will face the threat of closure,” said principal Rakesh Chandra. Overall, he said, the teacher-student taught ratio is around 1:90. “Departments like ancient Indian history and Arab culture, which were running on a single faculty, have no teacher with the retirement of the serving ones,” he added. In Navyug Kanya Mahavidyalaya, there is only one teacher in departments of botany, education and philosophy for the past four years. In all, 19 posts are vacant with 3,500 students. Here, the ratio is 1:70. “The college, with its own resources, has appointed a guest faculty so that courses are not discontinued. The UP higher education service commission should fill in posts soon,” said principal Shrishti Srivastava. After a recent warning by the UGC to colleges and universities to fill vacant post within six months or else lose grant, the UP government on June 19 issued a circular directing higher education institutes to fill vacancies and upload data on the National Higher Education Resource Centre website. However, posts in LU-affiliated colleges are lying vacant because recruitments on all posts have not been done by the UP Higher Education Service Commission for the past few years. Regional higher education officer Rajiv Pandey said, “Information on vacant posts is being collected and will be given to the commission. They will be filled in soon. Two months back, appointments were done but not all colleges could be covered.” Lucknow University Associated College president Manoj Pandey said, “We have written it to the higher education department and deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma for filling vacant posts.”

column2: Weather office warns of heavy rainfall in Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP Met department on Wednesday issued a warning of widespread rains across the state, with heavy to very heavy spells predicted at some places till Saturday due to a low pressure area over east UP and monsoon trough, a low pressure belt, over west UP. State Met director JP Gupta said heavy to very rainfall is likely in east UP districts bordering Bihar and Nepal, besides terai and Bundelkhand regions. Other parts of the state will receives light to moderate rains, he predicted. The districts covered under the warning include - Pilibhit, Allahabad, Chandauli, Varanasi, Kaushambi, Mau, Faizabad, Rae Bareli, Gonda, Balrampur, Shravasti, Bahraich, Kheri, Rampur, Moradabad, Bijnor, Banda, Chitrakoot, Fatehpur, Hamirpur, Jalaun, Jhansi, Sant Kabir Nagar, Ballia, Gorakhpur, Bareilly, Kushinagar, Deoria, Maharajganj, Siddharthnagar, Basti, Ambedkarnagar, Azamgarh, Ghazipur, Jaunpur, Pratapgarh, Sant Ravidas Nagar, Sultanpur and Sitapur. Meanwhile, intermittent rains across the state for the past one week have improved UP's rainfall situation. The rainfall, which was over 50% below normal till June 30 due to late arrival of monsoon, has now reduced to 9% below normal. Total per district average rains this monsoon from June 1 till date have been 151.8 mm against the normal of 167.5% set for the period. Gupta said that the state, particularly eastern parts, received impressive rains since Monday evening, which contributed majorly in narrowing the deficit.

column2: Husband of ‘Gone Girl’ granted bail, 2 more charges slapped
column3: GHAZIABAD: Abhishek Chaudhary, the husband of Komal Talan (29) who had staged her own disappearance after leaving a suicide note in her car near Hindon canal five days ago, was granted bail till July 17 by a Ghaziabad court on Wednesday. Based on Komal’s statement given to Ghaziabad police on Tuesday night, police had added two more IPC sections – 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) in the FIR against Abhishek. Komal, a trainee manager with an insurance company on Barakhamba Road, had disappeared on July 5 from her parents-in-laws’ house in Delhi’s Pandav Nagar. A day later, her car was found parked under the Hindon Elevated Road in Ghaziabad with a note that said she was “going away”, and accusing her husband and in-laws of torturing her over dowry. The note and the location of the car, parked next to the Hindon canal, suggested she had committed suicide. On the basis of a complaint by Komal’s father, Anil Talan, a case was registered against Abhishek and her in-laws at Indirapuram police station on Saturday night. They were charged with domestic violence and kidnapping and under provisions of the Dowry Prohibition Act. Talan claimed he had given Rs 41 lakh in cash and an Audi car as dowry to Abhishek, and that his family was demanding another Rs 21 lakh for starting a business for him. Talan also accused Abhishek of murdering Komal and throwing her body. However, Komal was found to be alive and hopping from one city to another to ensure that her husband landed behind bars for ‘murder’. Abhishek was arrested on Tuesday night after her return. Police removed the kidnapping charges from the FIR, but added two new IPC sections. Abhishek’s counsel argued that Komal had left on her own accord and there was no case against his client. The court of CJM Viveka Nand Vishwakarma subsequently granted him bail. Sources said that the dowry and domestic violence cases are likely to be transferred to Greater Noida where Komal’s parents live. Police sources said Komal was in touch with one of her friends from office and continuously talking to him from a new number and taking stock of the situation in Ghaziabad. She was planning to fake her suicide on Friday night itself, the day she went missing, but could not finalise the place to park her vehicle, they added. It was Komal’s friend, a resident of Noida, who had come to Indirapuram on Saturday morning to park the vehicle near Hindon canal and later dropped her at the Anand Vihar bus stand. From there, she took an overnight bus to Jaipur, went on to buy air tickets for Mumbai using the name Kamakshi, with forged documents, and finally boarding the Coimbatore Express. She was finally found travelling in the second AC coach of the train on Monday evening near Bengaluru.

column2: Lucknow: Gangster shot at over parking contracts
column3: LUCKNOW: Gangster Gorakh Thakur, alias Virendra, was shot at to break his monopoly over parking contracts issued by Narkatiaganj Municipality in Bihar. This was revealed after the arrest of four persons involved in the attack, the GRP said on Wednesday. Thakur suffered multiple wounds when he was targeted by two men on a bike outside Charbagh railway station on July 2. Four persons, including two women, arrested have been identified as Miraj Khatoon, Mahi Talt, Mehrajuddin and Mehrajul. They were allegedly involved in the conspiracy while two shooters - Firdaus and Miktaul - are still on the run. GRP, Lucknow, SSP Saumitra Yadav told reporters that Thakur had over 23 criminal cases, including two murders and several cases of extortion and attempt to murder, pending in police records in Bettiah and West Champaran districts of Bihar. He was managing his gang in Bihar from Lucknow where he was living for the past six years using the alias Virendra.  Yadav said Firdaus, also a resident of Bihar, came to Lucknow in 2017 to pursue a diploma in electrical engineering from a private university. However, he dropped out after six months and took to crime. At present, he has five criminal cases, including attempt to murder, pending against him. He wanted to grab parking contracts of Narkatiaganj in West Champaran, on which Thakur and his gang had monopoly for the past seven years.

column2: CM Yogi Adityanath: Can’t get away by blaming driver for expressway accident
column3: LUCKNOW: In the aftermath of Monday’s bus accident on Yamuna Expressway, which claimed 29 lives, chief minister Yogi Adityanath has told officials that they cannot escape responsibility for the incident by putting the blame on the bus driver. The inquiry report in the incident, submitted to the CM on Tuesday, had held the driver, who also died in the accident, responsible for it. Asked how they had come to this conclusion, transport minister Swatantra Dev Singh was unable to give any explanation and was forced to cut short his press meet. Officials of Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority have been asked to carry out regular inspections of the road to determine whether the company is implementing all safety norms, along with the 13 suggestions on road safety which were proposed by IIT-Delhi. Sources said that the CM was extremely angry with officials for the continuing spate of accidents. In a report submitted to him on Thursday, the transport department pointed out that almost 72% of road deaths in UP every year since 2015 were taking place on expressways and highways. In 2018, the total number of deaths on Agra Expressway, Yamuna Expressway, 58 national highways and 87 state highways was 15,997 as against 11,851 in 2014. The CM also expressed anger at the state of school vans and buses, saying that no lessons had been learnt from the 2018 accident in Kushinagar where at least 13 children had died when their van had collided with a train at an unmanned crossing. “The CM said that rejected vehicles were being used in schools to ferry children. From now on, all school vehicles will have to undergo regular fitness tests and condemned vehicles will be scrapped. All school van and bus drivers will have to undergo medical tests and police verification,” said an official. Yogi has directed that medical check-up of drivers, inspection of licence and breath analyser test before the driver enters the bus and when he reaches the destination should be carried out. On routes that are more than 400km-long and driving is to be done at night, there will be two drivers in each bus. A medical check-up of drivers attached to officials and ministers would be done as well. The use of mobile phones by drivers will now be strictly prohibited and if proof otherwise is submitted to the government, the driver can be fined. Besides, a weekly break will have to be guaranteed to each driver. The home department will ensure strict checking of helmet and seat belt use with a special drive to be carried out in Noida and Ghaziabad. A crackdown on stunt biking will be initiated while licences of those found driving in an inebriated condition will be confiscated. Saying that there is a need to reform the transport department on war-footing, the CM has said that illegal dhabas along highways need to be removed. Automatic e-challans must be started at toll plazas and highways, rumble strips should be constructed every 15km and staff of highway patrolling, Dial 100 and ambulance personnel should be given proper training.
