column2: ‘Jaicky’ defends jail staff, says viral videos plot to defame administration
column3: LUCKNOW: In a bizarre explanation for emergence of videos from various prisons showing inmates brandishing guns, consuming liquor and enjoying lavish meals, jail minister Jai Singh ‘Jaicky’ on Friday said that this is an attempt to defame the jail administration which is otherwise doing a good job.  The minister remained silent on how guns, liquor and cellphones managed to find their way into jails and said he sensed a conspiracy against the government. Some officials and workers in jails, he claimed, were in collusion with criminals to bring a bad name to the government. “There are insiders involved in this and we are getting all videos investigated to see who is responsible. If I find someone guilty, I will dismiss them from service. The more important question is, why would these culprits make videos and leak them if they were genuinely getting facilities inside the jail,” Singh asked. TimesViewIn what appears to be a classic example of shooting the messenger, UP prisons minister Jai Singh ‘Jaicky’ has blamed the prison inmates for “leaking” videos of unlawful activities inside the jail while defending the jail officials for strictly implementing the jail manual norms. This has left unaddressed the fact that jail inmates are in possession of prohibited items and also have cellphones to shoot videos and proper connectivity make them viral on the social media.The minister had initially said that when the BJP-government was formed in UP in 2017, criminals were active from within jails. However, he said, chief minister Yogi Adityanath had acted to shift criminals from their choice of jails and transferred a large number of officials. “Criminal networks have now failed and therefore we are witnessing a new trend among criminals of shooting these videos and making them viral. When an official is strict, criminals often threaten to get them suspended. These videos are part of this conspiracy,” the minister said. He claimed that the jail administration was very strict and has clamped down on illegalities prevalent from the time of SP and BSP governments. “Sakhti karne ki wajah se hi to problem aa rahi hai aur yeh conspiracy ho rahi hai humare khilaf (It is because we are strict that this problem has cropped up and this conspiracy has been hatched against us),” he said. In the past few months, several videos from UP jails have emerged showing inmates with unauthorised possessions. In November 218, a video emerged from Rae Bareli jail showing inmates having liquor and making calls. In June this year, a video emerged from Unnao jail showing inmates brandishing guns and liquor bottles. Another video from Mau jail, made by an inmate, emerged in July this year.

column2: Draft law wants life term for mobsters to stop lynchings
column3: LUCKNOW: To clamp down on spate of lynchings, UP Law Commission has hammered out a draft bill that recommends life imprisonment for mobsters when victims die. District magistrates and policemen too won’t be spared and are liable to face imprisonment between 1-3 years if they fail to control mobs. On Wednesday, TOI was the first to report that law commission had taken cognizance of 50 cases of lynching and mob violence in five years and prepared a draft of Uttar Pradesh Combating of Mob Lynching Bill, 2019, and submitted it to chief minister Yogi Adityanath. In the draft, lynching has been defined as “act of spontaneous or planned violence by a mob on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, language, dietary practices, sexual orientation, political affiliation or ethnicity on mere suspicion of cognizable offence, not amounting to heinous crime”. Specifying that death of victim was not necessary to categorise the incident as lynching, secretary of UP law commission, Sapna Tripathi, said the penalty has been recommended on basis of severity of injury, leading to death. If a person suffers injury, accused can be imprisoned up to seven years and fined up to Rs 1 lakh. For causing grievous injuries, the penalty is imprisonment till 10 years and a fine of Rs 3 lakh. When a person is lynched to death, the draft Bill recommends rigorous life imprisonment for accused along with a fine of Rs 5 lakh. Even those who conspire, abet or attempt lynching will be considered to be accused and punished accordingly. The commission is of opinion that police and district administration should also be held responsible for “dereliction of duty”. This includes refusal to record FIRs. If charges are proved against a police officer or district magistrate, they can be imprisoned for 1-3 years and fined up to Rs 50,000. Those distributing offensive material can be jailed between one to three years and fined Rs 50,000. And those who contribute to creating a hostile environment can be imprisoned for up to six months.

column2: Patient dies in hospital, family thrashes doctor in Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: Less than a month after pan-India strike in the wake of violence against doctors in West Bengal, a doctor posted at Balrampur hospital was assaulted on duty by female attendants of a female patient who died on Friday morning. Accusing the doctor of negligence, the attendants assaulted the doctor with a cane, when he was performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation on a 63-year-old woman. The hospital, in its official complaint to the police, sought action against the family members under medical protection act for assaulting an on-duty doctor and disrupting public service.  Urmila Singh was admitted to emergency ward’s bed number 12 on Wednesday night with septic shock and multi-organ failure. Hospital’s chief medical superintendent (CMS) Dr Rishi Saxena said, “We had told the family several times that her condition is critical and she should be shifted to a higher medical facility. But they did not pay heed.” As per the family’s allegations, the doctor was scheduled to report at 8am on Friday morning, but he did not turn up till 10am. “Even after arriving, the doctor attended to another patient despite our patient’s condition deteriorating. This negligence led to her death,” said a relative.  Dr Saxena denied all allegations against the 32-year-old doctor. “We are already facing staff crunch and after this incident, this doctor also wants to resign. Nobody would want to work as a doctor if attendants get violent even when we try our best to save lives,” said Dr Saxena. He added that the doctor in the middle of all this chaos, suffered injuries on his neck and head.

column2: UP pushes for life term in lynching cases
column3: LUCKNOW: Taking cognisance of the spate of mob lynchings, including those by cow vigilantes, the UP Law Commission has come out with a draft bill that recommends life imprisonment for mobsters if the victim dies. District magistrates and policemen, too, will not be spared and can be imprisoned for 1-3 years if they fail in their duties to curb violence and death. The law commission took suo motu cognizance of 50 cases of lynching and mob violence registered in past five years and prepared the draft of the Uttar Pradesh Combating of Mob Lynching Bill and submitted it to chief minister Yogi Adityanath. In the draft bill, lynching has been defined as “an act of spontaneous or planned violence by a mob on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, language, dietary practices, sexual orientation, political affiliation or ethnicity on mere suspicion of cognizable offence, not amounting to heinous crime”. Specifying that the fatality of a victim is not necessary to categorise the incident as lynching, secretary of UP law commission, Sapna Tripathi, said the penalty has been recommended keeping in mind the “severity of injury, leading to death”. If a person suffers injury, the accused can be jailed for up to seven years and fined up to Rs 1 lakh. For causing grievous injuries, the penalty is imprisonment till 10 years and a fine of Rs 3 lakh. If a person is lynched to death, the draft bill recommends rigorous life imprisonment for accused along with a fine of Rs 5 lakh. Even those who conspire, abet or attempt lynching will be considered to be accused and punished accordingly. The commission is of opinion that police and district administration should also be held responsible for “dereliction of duty”. This includes refusal to record FIRs. If charges are proved against a police officer or district magistrate, they can be imprisoned for 1-3 years and fined up to Rs 50,000. Those distributing offensive material can be jailed between one to three years and fined Rs 50,000. And those who contribute to creating a hostile environment can be imprisoned for up to six months.

column2: A stamp to cement bonds between Ayodhya & South Korea
column3: LUCKNOW: The ancient bond between India and South Korea is set to assume the shape of a commemorative stamp. The two governments have agreed to bring out a stamp on Queen Heo Hwang-ok of Korea, aka Princess Suriratna of Ayodhya. The philately division of the department of post, India, has sought information from the Indian Council of Historical Research (ICHR) on the princess of Ayodhya. The ICHR has asked the state cultural department to help. According to official documents, “There is a widespread belief in South Korea and Central UP that in 48 AD, Princess Suriratna of Ayodhya travelled for three months by sea to marry King Suro, who founded the Karak dynasty in 42 AD. The capital of his kingdom was Gimhae City and millions of residents in South Korea trace their origin to the Karak clan.” The memorial of the princess, known as Queen Heo-Hwang-Ok or Queen Hu, in Ayodhya is a pilgrimage for South Koreans who consider themselves to be descendants of the royal couple. While there is enough anecdotal evidence on Queen Heo’s story, the department of post is looking for “authentic information, preferably from government sources, so that the Indian connection may be appropriately depicted on the stamp.” Officials in state culture department say they will decode the evidences such as the 11th century Korean chronicle Samyuk Yusa.

column2: Deathtraps dot Lucknow roads as LMC takes a nap
column3: LUCKNOW: A Mumbai toddler playing near his home fell into a storm water drain through an open manhole on Wednesday night and drowned. A tragedy of such enormity is waiting to happen any moment in Lucknow, where uncovered manholes and drains are a common sight. A TOI reality check on Friday exposed these deathtraps everywhere, from Indiranagar, Gomtinagar and Hazratganj to Jankipuram, Kaiserbagh and LDA Colony. On August 6, 2017, a child had drowned in a high drain in the city’s Riverbank Colony. Two years down the line, the life-threatening hole still exists. TimesViewMumbai incident is a wake up call for the civic authorities. Officials must react promptly without waiting for a tragedy to happen. We need to keep our Divyansh safe. Not just humans, even life of an animal is precious. Steps must be taken to survey the entire city and cover open manholes and drains on warfooting. Municipal commissioner has promised action in three days. We hope he will keep his promiseThe Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) had covered the drain a few times, but the concrete slab somehow went missing every time. Several commuters have sustained minor or major injuries in the recent past as well, but the accidents have failed to jolt the LMC into action. Left with no option, residents have themselves barricaded some open manholes or drains with bamboo sticks, or at least put up warning signs. “The drain here is deep enough to drown a two-wheeler. Residents had pasted LED strips and put up no-parking signs, but these were either stolen or washed away in the rain. The gaping hole continues to pose a major threat to people, particularly children, during heavy rain when its depth cannot be easily gauged,” said Rashmi Sinha, a resident of Riverbank Colony. At Takrohi in Indiranagar, an open drain next to a government school feels like the inescapable jaws of death. “The drain has been lying uncovered for over a year now. Fortunately, nothing has happened to the children. But, there have been instances when they have accidentally dropped their belongings into it,” said Pratima Das, a concerned parent. A manhole at Ashok Marg in Hazratganj was found to be several inches below the surface of the road, making it invisible during heavy showers. “Every other day, a dog or a cat slips in through the manhole. Several two-wheelers have also met with accidents. What happened in Mumbai can happen here any second,” said Priyanshu Bhatt, a resident. People in Mahanagar play dodge daily as they commute on roads dotted with either open manholes or manholes with broken covers. “Open manholes pose a major risk at night and during rain, particularly when street lights are not working,” said resident Charulata Mishra. In Aashiana, Akshat Asthana of Sector K sustained minor injuries last Tuesday when his bike hit an open drain. At Shivpuram colony in Neelmatha, Jal Sansthan has dug up a trench to lay a water pipeline, but hasn’t finished the job. It is quite the grave for anyone commuting during a downpour. While residents voiced their anger and resentment over civic inaction, municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi told TOI that an order to repair/plug manholes and drains had been issued. “Work will begin within three days,” he promised. With inputs from Anshika Mehrotra, Asheeza Baig and Nisha Yadav

column2: Sugar mills divestment: ED files money laundering case
column3: LUCKNOW: Enforcement Directorate has registered a case under Prevention of Money Laundering Act in the sugar mills divestment scam during the 2010-11 Mayawati regime. This comes two months after CBI registered an FIR in the case. The agency said disinvestment caused loss of Rs 1,719 crore to the state exchequer. ED officials said fake documents in the name of bogus firms were prepared to purchase 10 defunct sugar mills along with 11 operational mills as part of disinvestment scheme. “We will soon start searches at residences of those linked with sale and purchase of mills,” said an officer. Soon after coming to power in 2017, the BJP government on the basis of a CAG report of 2012 found 21 sugar mills were sold at “throwaway prices”, causing a loss of Rs 1,719 crore to the exchequer. In April 2018, CBI took over the probe in the case. Also, irregularities in bidding for two fake private companies to acquire tenders for sugar mills surfaced after a probe by Serious Fraud Investigations Office (SFIO) of corporate affairs ministry. The first FIR was registered at Gomtinagar police station on November 7, 2017, by S K Mehra, then MD of state Sugar Mills Limited. Mehra alleged two private companies — Giriyasho Private Ltd and Namrata Marketing Private Ltd — fudged balance sheets of financial year 2008-2009 with fake signatures to obtain tender. Giriyasho Private Limited had bid for sugar mill units in Barabanki, Ramkola and Chhitoni, while Namrata Marketing Private Limited had bid for mills in Deoria, Bareilly, Laxmiganj and Hardoi. A committee in UP Sugar Mills approved both the private companies as eligible for bidding in auctions by showing fake documents, said Mehra in his complaint to police. A case of forgery, dishonesty and falsification of accounts was registered. The government referred the case to CBI on April 4, 2018. The agency started conducting raids and on April 25 registered a fresh FIR against Rakesh Shrama, Suman Sharma, of Delhi, Dharmendra Gupta of Ghaziabad, Saurabh Mukund, Mohammed Naseem, Mohammed Javed, and Wajid Ali of Saharanpur. They had claimed to be directors of two private firms to bag tenders of sugar mills.

column2: Sugar mills divestment: ED files money laundering case
column3: LUCKNOW: Enforcement Directorate has registered a case under Prevention of Money Laundering Act in the sugar mills divestment scam during the 2010-11 Mayawati regime. This comes two months after CBI registered an FIR in the case. The agency said disinvestment caused loss of Rs 1,719 crore to the state exchequer. ED officials said fake documents in the name of bogus firms were prepared to purchase 10 defunct sugar mills along with 11 operational mills as part of disinvestment scheme. “We will soon start searches at residences of those linked with sale and purchase of mills,” said an officer. Soon after coming to power in 2017, the BJP government on the basis of a CAG report of 2012 found 21 sugar mills were sold at “throwaway prices”, causing a loss of Rs 1,719 crore to the exchequer. In April 2018, CBI took over the probe in the case. Also, irregularities in bidding for two fake private companies to acquire tenders for sugar mills surfaced after a probe by Serious Fraud Investigations Office (SFIO) of corporate affairs ministry. The first FIR was registered at Gomtinagar police station on November 7, 2017, by S K Mehra, then MD of state Sugar Mills Limited. Mehra alleged two private companies — Giriyasho Private Ltd and Namrata Marketing Private Ltd — fudged balance sheets of financial year 2008-2009 with fake signatures to obtain tender. Giriyasho Private Limited had bid for sugar mill units in Barabanki, Ramkola and Chhitoni, while Namrata Marketing Private Limited had bid for mills in Deoria, Bareilly, Laxmiganj and Hardoi. A committee in UP Sugar Mills approved both the private companies as eligible for bidding in auctions by showing fake documents, said Mehra in his complaint to police. A case of forgery, dishonesty and falsification of accounts was registered. The government referred the case to CBI on April 4, 2018. The agency started conducting raids and on April 25 registered a fresh FIR against Rakesh Shrama, Suman Sharma, of Delhi, Dharmendra Gupta of Ghaziabad, Saurabh Mukund, Mohammed Naseem, Mohammed Javed, and Wajid Ali of Saharanpur. They had claimed to be directors of two private firms to bag tenders of sugar mills.

column2: Lucknow: 400 vacant posts in five varsities ring alarm bells
column3: LUCKNOW: With more than 400 teaching posts lying vacant in four state universities and one central varsity in the city, students would be a disappointed lot as they won’t get the desired quality of education at the start of the new session. The University Grants Commission (UGC) has warned that these universities would lose grant if they fail to fill vacant posts within six months. The UGC had recently shot a letter to vice-chancellors, saying, “Shortage of faculty members in higher educational institutions (HEIs) is a major concern and needs to be addressed immediately for improving the quality of education.” Here’s a status report of the number of vacancies in these universities: Lucknow UniversityThe maximum 172 posts are lying vacant at LU. The total sanctioned posts at LU is 516 to cater to the student strength of around 25,000, which means one teacher should teach around 50 students. With only 344 permanent appointments in place at present, the student-teacher ratio has mounted to 1:70 from 1:50. The maximum 75 posts are vacant of assistant professors, while there are 37 and 60 vacancies of professors and associate professors. “We had filled the vacant posts in 2018 but thereafter there was a freeze on appointment by UGC because of change in rules. Hence, the process couldn’t be completed. We will fill the vacancies soon,” said vice-chancellor S P Singh. Shakuntala Misra National Rehabilitation UniversityA total of 156 posts are vacant in SMNRU. The student-teacher ratio is 1:60, which should be 1:20. This means 40 additional students are being taught by a single teacher. Total sanctioned teacher posts for around 3,000 students are 242, but there are only 86 permanent faculty members. Maximum 48 posts are vacant of assistant professors, while 12 and 22 posts of professors and associate professors are still to be filled. Two posts of special professors are also vacant. “The state government is yet to clear whether a roaster system by the central government will be adopted as it is or with some amendment,” said SMNRU spokesperson Ashwani Kumar Dubey. Dr Babasahebh Bhimaro Ambedkar UniversityThere are 33 vacant posts in BBAU. As many as 12 posts of professors, 14 of associate professors and seven of assistant professors have yet not filled. Of the 196 sanctioned posts for teaching 6,000 students, only 163 have been filled. Student-teacher ratio should be 1:30, which is presently around 1:36. “As a new vice-chancellor was not appointed for around seven months, vacancies could not be filled. We will follow UGC’s direction with immediate effect and will be recruiting soon,” said BBAU spokesperson Rachna Gangwar. Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti Arabi Farsi UniversityAs many as six posts of professors, 13 of associate professors and 27 of assistant professors are vacant at KMCAFU. Of the 74 sanctioned posts to teach 1,538 students, only 28 have been filled so far. The student-teacher ratio should be around 1:20, but it is presently 1:54 at KMCAFU. “Universities should be given autonomy to fill posts on their own as recruitment process is lengthy and rules of appointment change every now and then. Hence the post advertised in past could not be filled due to a rule change,” vice-chancellor Prof Mahrukh Mirza. Students shared that in the absence of faculty, new courses couldn’t be introduced. Dr APJ Kalam Technical UniversityA total of 18 posts are lying vacant in the only technical university in the state — Dr APJ Kalam Technical University. “We filled all the vacancies in the placement drive in 2018. Present vacancies are of professors who have resigned from the post,” AKTU spokesperson. The student-teacher ratio should be 1:15, which is presently 1:18 at AKTU.

column2: Modi-Shah duo will build Ram temple: Vedanti
column3: LUCKNOW: A day after Supreme Court (SC) asked the Ayodhya mediation panel to submit its report by a week, the executive president of Ram Janmabhoomi Nyas, Ram Vilas Vedanti, said the Narendra Modi-Amit Shah duo at the Centre would build the Ram temple within the contours of the Constitution in five years. Talking to reporters on Friday on the court’s decision to hold day-to-day hearings if mediation failed, he said, “Eighty per cent Muslims, barring fundamentalists, want the temple at the place where Ram Lalla is installed in Ayodhya.” Last year, the seer said if the Ram temple didn’t come up, he would immolate himself in 2019. On Friday, he skirted questions on self-immolation. “Take it as a threat or a suggestion, but there is no force that can rebuild the mosque at Ram Janmabhoomi,” said Vedanti. “Eighty percent Muslims in India want the Ram temple at the Ram Janmabhoomi site, which is now presided over by Ram Lalla. Vishwa Hindu Parishad, saints and the entire Hindu community want the temple at the site, except Pakistan-funded Sunni Waqf Board that’s against communal amity. In fact, Muslims should come forward and build the temple,” he said. To another query, Vedanti, a former BJP MP, said it was unfortunate that in a country of 90% Hindus, people are fighting a legal case for decades for construction of Ram temple.

column2: Rahul Gandhi has lost his mind, says UP cabinet minister
column3: LUCKNOW: UP minister Sidharth Nath Singh has kicked up a controversy by comparing Rahul Gandhi to an “old HMV record” and saying he has “lost his mind”. After a health department review meeting in Basti on Thursday, Singh took potshots at Rahul while speaking to reporters. “Hamare zamane mein HMV records hote they jo chalte chalte ghis jate they aur atakne lagte thay. Rahul Gandhiji ka haal bhi wahi ho gaya hai... paanch saal se unka record atka hua hai (When I was young, HMV records were in vogue. Once the records became old, the needle often got stuck and lyrics played in a loop. Rahul Gandhi’s state is the same. He is singing the same song for the past five years),” he said. “Hamare gaon ki bhasha mein kehte hain buddha sathiya gaya hai (Rahul has lost his mind, as goes the saying in my village about old people).” UP Congress leaders demanded an immediate apology from Singh. “The kind of words (he) used speaks for the mentality of BJP leaders… He must unconditionally apologise to Rahulji,” said Omkar Nath Singh “BJP leaders cannot think beyond Rahul Gandhi. They use such words to demoralise the cadre. But, the more attempts they make, it will only strengthen our love and respect for him (Rahul),” said Congress leader Pramod Pandey.

column2: Girl stays with kin for AIIMS entrance, uncle molests her
column3: GHAZIABAD: The 19-year-old daughter of a retired Army officer from Dehradun filed a complaint on Thursday against her uncle in Kavi Nagar police station, accusing him of molesting her when she had come to Ghaziabad to take an entrance examination for All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in May 2018. The girl’s family said she kept mum for a year but in June, when they asked her to attend a relative’s wedding in Ghaziabad, she broke down and revealed what had happened. Police said that the accused had clicked obscene pictures of the girl and made some videos in his house in Kavi Nagar while she was taking a bath and molested her whenever her aunt was out of the house. He also allegedly threatened to post the pictures and videos on social media websites if she protested. The girl arrived in Ghaziabad on May 25, 2018, her elder sister said. “After returning home, she used to sit alone and cry most of the time. Her mother tried to talk to her, but she never told us anything,” said the sister, who is also a doctor. Later, in June 2019, when the medical student’s family wanted her to attend the wedding in Ghaziabad, she said she didn’t want to return to the city. “She still lives in fear due to the threat received from our uncle. She told me that if he posted the images and videos online, she would commit suicide,” her sister said. After the revelation, the girl’s family approached the Dehradun SSP in June and an investigation was launched into the matter. “The investigation report has been received by the Ghaziabad police and an FIR on the basis has been lodged against the accused under IPC Section 354 (sexual harassment) at Kavi Nagar police station,” said Shlok Kumar, SP (city), Ghaziabad. When a police team went to the accused’s house on Thursday, they found it locked. “We have recorded the statement of the girl and the accused will be arrested soon,” the SP said.

column2: Biker on way home mowed down by car in Indirapuram
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 50-year-old man was killed after a speeding car rammed into the motorcycle he was riding in Indirapuram area on Thursday night. Police said the deceased, identified as Ashok Sharma, was a resident of Delhi and he used to run a printing press in Indirapuram. He was on his way home after closing the press for the day when the car hit the two-wheeler from the rear.  “The accident took place around 10.30 pm on Thursday and passersby informed the police immediately. A police team reached the spot and took him to Shanti Gopal Hospital in Indirapuram. But he died during treatment,” said Sandeep Kumar Singh, the SHO of Indirapuram police station. “According to the doctors at the hospital, he died of head injuries,” Singh added. “The car that hit the two-wheeler was travelling at about 60 kmph and the driver fled the spot after the accident. Police have lodged an FIR against unknown person under sections 279 (rash driving or riding on a public way), 304A (causing death by negligence) and 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of Rs 50),” Singh added. Sushant Sharma, the son of the deceased, said that most of the time, Sharma would use his car. But on Thursday, he was on his bike . “He left the house around 9 am on Thursday to go to the printing press. Our family got information about the accident from the police around 11 pm. We rushed to the hospital but by the time we reached, he was no more,” Sushant added.

column2: In Ghaziabad, youth fires at sister-in-law, kills self
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 26-year-old man allegedly shot himself after shooting at his sister-in-law on Friday morning. While the accused, Ramesh, died on the spot, the woman, Savita Devi (36), is said to be critical. She was shot at thrice in her abdomen. Police said Ramesh was a vegetable vendor in Sahibabad. On Thursday around 10pm, he went to his brother’s house in Haibatpur village in Greater Noida’s Bisrakh and shot at Savita. He then returned to his house in Jhandapura in Ghaziabad’s Link road and killed himself. The woman is survived by her husband and three minor children. Laxmi Chauhan, the SHO of Link Road police station said, police received the information about the death from Ramesh’s neighbour. “Police have found an illegal pistol and some bullets near the body,” she said. Jai Kumar, Ramesh’s elder brother and Savita’s husband said, “I never thought that Ramesh will try to kill my wife. He has defamed the image of the family by doing this.” Ravi Kumar Mishra, the circle officer said, Ramesh’s body was sent for an autopsy after which the it will be handed over to his family.

column2: 45 held in 2 weeks by ‘anti-Romeo’ squads
column3: GHAZIABAD: ‘Anti-Romeo’ squads have taken action against 45 people under Section 151 (arrest to prevent the commission of cognizable offences) of the CrPC during the first 12 days of their drive in the district. Police said that under the one-month “girls/women security” campaign, the squads checked 7,529 people around schools, colleges and public places and issued warnings to 1,351 of them. “We mainly checked people roaming on motorcycles near educational institutes. Those who could not give any valid reason for being there were issued warnings. Those who were found drunk and following girls were booked under 151 CrPC and produced before a magistrate,” said SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun, also the nodal officer of ‘anti-Romeo’ squads in the district. Jadaun added that so far, awareness campaigns have been conducted at 143 schools. Ghaziabad police have installed pink letterboxes in all private and government schools where girl students can drop anonymous complaints. Jadaun said 100 such letterboxes have been checked and five letters were found. “Action was required in two cases and that has been done,” he said. One girl wrote that on one hand police are asking them to register complaint, but on the other, they misbehave with complainants and make them feel guilty for doing so. SP (city) Shlok Kumar wrote back to the girl and also sent her a box of chocolates. “The police is for citizens security and no police officer worth his/her salt would misbehave with the aggrieved, especially if it is a brave girl like her,” he wrote.

column2: Neighbours rob couple with kid’s birthday party ruse in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: It’s difficult to turn down a little boy when he comes running to your house and invites you to his birthday party. The boy is a neighbour’s kid, you see him every day even if you don’t know the parents that well. You smile at him when your paths cross, even try to converse sometimes (“What’s your name?” “Which school do you go to?”). You surrender to his charms, the innocence melts your heart. You say yes. The Kumars, residents of Shalimar Garden in Sahibabad, were pleasantly surprised when their neighbours’ two sons, the younger one just five, landed up at their house on the morning of July 8 with the invitation to the 5-year-old’s birthday party. “The boys also asked us for our blessings,” says Abhay Kumar, still dazed by the events that followed. The Kumars had agreed, not realising that the invitation was part of an elaborate scheme by the boys’ parents to execute a robbery plan. Sending the boys, who enacted the plan in all innocence, was the first arrow fired. They were sure it wouldn’t miss. “That evening, when I returned from work, I wasn’t feeling well so I told my wife to go to the party and give the boy a birthday gift. My wife handed over the gift and returned after some time,” says Kumar, an RBS employee. But after some time, the boys’ parents — the Kumars’ next-door neighbours Adesh and Anjali — knocked on their door. “They came around 9pm and insisted that we have dinner at their place. They offered us snacks and soft drinks,” says Kumar. The drinks were laced with sedatives. The Kumars were soon asleep. There was Rs 10,000 cash in the Kumars’ house and jewellery worth Rs 2 lakh. When the Kumars regained consciousness, it was gone. A relative, Amit, found Abhay and his wife sprawled on the floor of their house the next morning when the family, worried they were not answering their calls, sent him to check. “When I sprinkled water on their faces, Abhay mentioned three words: cake, party and cold drink. I took them to hospital,” says Amit. Adesh and Anjali had come to live in the house adjacent to the Kumars’ four months ago. “We didn’t know too much about them. We didn't talk either as we weren’t sure about them,” says Abhay. SP (city) Shlok Kumar said an FIR was lodged at Sahibabad police station under the sections 328 (causing hurt by means of poison, etc) and 379 (theft) of the IPC: “We are trying to trace them and also checking CCTV footage from the nearby area.” Police have found that Adesh and Anjali are from Shamli.

column2: Fake job portal cons aspirants of Rs 1.7 lakh in Vikasnagar
column3: LUCKNOW: Two people were duped of Rs 1.7 lakh on the pretext of providing a job in Vikasnagar on Friday. According to police, Deepti Jain (25), a post-graduate in business administration, was conned of Rs 98,299 after being lured of a bank job. On July 4, Deepti received a call from a person who identified himself as Khushi, an employee of the portal where she had enlisted herself for the job. Jain was told that her resume had been selected for a job in a private bank and asked to pay a registration fee of Rs 1,499. She was given a bank account number for online payment. After Deepti made the payment, she got a call from a man, who posed himself as a bank officer and took her telephonic interview. He later told her that she has been selected for the job and asked her to pay a security amount of Rs 4,600. Thereafter, for next six days, she received regular calls asking for more payments on one pretext or another. She followed the instructions and gradually paid over Rs 98,000. She realised her mistakeon July 10, when she called back several times to inquire about the appointment letter only to find the number switched off. She lodged an FIR on Friday. In a similar case, Yati Vashya (22) was conned of Rs 8,999 by a man posing as a job portal employee. .

column2: After big burst, monsoon begins to lose steam
column3: LUCKNOW: After giving extensive rains in the city for a week, monsoon currents are now losing steam. The rainfall activity declined on Friday and is expected remain low till Tuesday. However, it may pick pace again from Wednesday. Moderate rainfall was recorded from Thursday night till the wee hours on Friday. The Met observatory at Amausi recorded 10 mm rains. Though sky remained overcast during the day, weather generally remained dry. Maximum and minimum temperatures were 33.7 and 24.2 degrees Celsius, respectively. State Met director JP Gupta said that the low pressure area over east UP that was responsible for heavy rains for the past one week has weakened, resulting in decline in rainfall activity on Friday. The rains would remain subdued for the next four days. Another system favourable for rains is expected to generate again next week. On Saturday, sky will be partly cloudy, with maximum and minimum temperatures expected to be around 34 and 24 degrees Celsius, respectively. Though there are possibilities of one or two light showers, weather may turn sultry during the day. So far since June 1, the city has received 258.1 mm rainfall, which is 57% more than the normal 164.9mm set for the period. Over 90% of this rain has occurred after July 5.

column2: Youths in UP beaten up for refusing to chant Jai Shri Ram
column3: UNNAO: A group of young students at a madrasa in Unnao district were allegedly forced to chant "Jai Shri Ram" and then beaten up when they refused to repeat the slogan. According to reports, the victims, who are all minors, had their clothes torn off and their bicycles were vandalized by the group when the children went to a ground to play cricket after concluding their afternoon namaz.  It was then that a group of four men arrived at the ground and after a debate over playing cricket, they allegedly started beating the children and even forced them to chant "Jai Shri Ram". After the incident, the children came back to the madrasa and narrated the incident. The police arrived, thereafter, and took cognisance of the matter. According to the Imam of the Jama Masjid, a group of men from Bajrang Dal were involved in the incident that took place on Thursday.  The police have registered a case in connection with the incident and have also identified three accused by tracing their Facebook accounts. The accused have purportedly identified themselves as members of Bajrang Dal in their social media accounts. Circle Officer Umesh Tyagi said that investigations were on in the matter. This is not for the first time that an incident like this has come to light in UP. In a similar incident on July 4, where an auto driver Mohammad Aatib, alleged that a group of men locked him up in a washroom and pelted stones for refusing to chant "Jai Shri Ram". Earlier, a Muslim youth, who was wearing a skull cap, was allegedly thrashed and insulted in Kanpur by some unidentified persons after he refused to chant "Jai Shri Ram". The attack took place when the youth, identified as Taj Mohammad, was returning to his home in the Barra area from the local madrasa.

column2: An electrifying evening for Kanpurites
column3: Sajan Kapoor and Nitin Vij threw a dance party for their friends, recently. Organised at a night club in Kanpur, close friends and family members of the couple ensured that they attend the do. (L) Akash Jain and Shweta Singh Rajpur (R) Aman Khanuja (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Akash Jain and Shweta Singh Rajpur (R) Aman Khanuja (BCCL/ IB Singh) Sajan’s wife Shweta played perfect hostess for the evening. With loads of naach-gaana, the do turned out to be an entertaining one for the guests as DJ Akbar Sami had the crowd grooving on peppy Bollywood remixes. We spotted Nikhil Vij, Ekta Jaggi, Puneet Kotwani, Rakesh Dhingra and Tanvi Dhingra dancing on peppy numbers. Also present were Ramji Shukla, Malika Arora, Tarang Arora, Gagandeep Kaur, and Jasvinder Singh. (L) Ashmita Narang and Ankit Narang (R) Ekta Jaggi and Shweta Kapoor (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Ashmita Narang and Ankit Narang (R) Ekta Jaggi and Shweta Kapoor (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Gagandeep Kaur and Jasvinder Singh (R) Kamaldeep Kaur and Preet Singh (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Gagandeep Kaur and Jasvinder Singh (R) Kamaldeep Kaur and Preet Singh (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Minnat Kaur and Nikita Kaur (C) Puneet Kotwani and Nikhil Vij (R) Simran Kaur (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Minnat Kaur and Nikita Kaur (C) Puneet Kotwani and Nikhil Vij (R) Simran Kaur (BCCL/ IB Singh)

column2: Centre measuring how we spend our time
column3: LUCKNOW: A pan-India survey is under way since January 2019, the first of its kind in India, to measure an individual’s use of his/ her time, evident in the very term Time User Survey. Conducted by the National Sample Survey Office, it is being carried out in four legs from January to December. Talking about the survey, chief statistician Pravin Srivastava on Saturday, while inaugurating a seminar on Statistics and Sustainable Development Goals at Lucknow University, said, “While paid activity will straddle business and jobs which accrue income, the survey will be a fountainhead of information on time spent in unpaid ventures, including volunteer work, domestic and household service”. Conducted by the ministry of statistics, the sampling is being done under two broad outlines — paid and unpaid activity. The second sampling will be particularly significant as it will cater to data on time spent on household work, volunteering, among other activities. A pilot TUS was first carried out in 1998-99 across six states — Haryana, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Odisha, Kerala and Meghalaya. It is for the first time the exercise is being carried out across all states. Srivastava explained the survey will analyse how people spend time. “There is much economic activity from their jobs, but with nuclear families being the trend, couples also spend much time in household work. For instance, cooking and rearing children by women helps men hit the field...” “But such activities have not been captured or collated till now,” Srivastava said. Read this story in Marathi

column2: Ghaziabad call centre cheated policyholders, 7 held
column3: GHAZIABAD: A fake call centre that was being run from a rented office at Cloud-9 in Vaishali area was busted on Saturday with the arrest of seven persons. The accused were allegedly involved in duping over 500 insurance policy holders. “They ran the call centre in the name of one M/S Italic Service at office no. 436, at Cloud-9 society’s commercial area in Sector 1, Vaishali area of Ghaziabad,” said a police officer. Police said the accused have been identified as Bharat Kumar and Gaurav Chandr, both from Vijay Nagar area of Ghaziabad, Sanjeev Singh, from Mandawali in Delhi, and four women, Jyoti Dinanath, Mamta Kumari, Puja and Bhavna, all of whom are from Delhi. The mastermind, Asif, who is from Haryana, is on the run, the police said. Shlok Kumar, the superintendent of police (city), told TOI that the accused claimed that the firm was under the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA) and targeted those whose life insurance policies were soon to get expired. “They would call up people and ask them to renew their insurance policies. When the respondents agreed, the accused would ask them to mail them their Aadhaar and PAN details. The accused would share with them account numbers where the renewal amount had to be deposited. Once the money was transferred, the accused would call up the respondents and confirm the transaction. Later, when the victims would try to get details of their policies, they would come to know about the fraud. When they tried to call on the numbers, they would find those switched off,” he added.  “The accused used to purchase data from one Ajeet, another accused in the case. He is on the run. Ajeet would sell the data of one person for Rs 10. It included name, address, contact details and details of insurance policy of a person. At a time, Ajeet would sell data of more than hundreds of people,” Kumar added. The call centre was being run for the past six months but the fraud came to light when an FIR was lodged by a victim at Indirapuram police station, alleging that a few people had duped him of over Rs 70 lakh. Apart from a fixed monthly salary of Rs 20,000, each call centre employee was given an incentive after a successful transaction. “All seven accused used to work with call centres in Delhi-NCR. Later, they formed a team. Asif is the mastermind. When money was deposited in the account mentioned by the callers, he would give a share of it to the team members,” Kumar said. The police have recovered Rs 5.25 lakh in cash, 16 phones and three notebooks.

column2: Ghaziabad: Law student commits suicide, 4 booked for abetment
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 20-year-old law student allegedly committed suicide by hanging himself from the ceiling fan of his house on Kavi Nagar on Thursday. Four students, including a girl, have been booked for allegedly harassing Vipin Kumar and abetting the suicide. Police said Vipin had shot a video before committing the suicide, in which he mentioned the names of his classmate and alleged that they harassed him mentally. Vipin’s father, a police constable, had lodged a complaint against the four students. On Thursday evening, Vipin Kumar, who was in the third-year at a private law college in Ghaziabad, was found hanging from the ceiling fan “Around 6pm on Thursday, Vipin had gone to the second floor of the house, but when he didn’t come down even after several calls, we went to look for him and found him hanging from the ceiling fan. In his phone, he shot a video accusing four students of mentally harassing him and passing lewd comments,” said Virendra Singh, Vipin’s father. Singh said Vipin had earlier complained to his parents about being mentally harassed. “He told his mother a few days ago that four students, including a girl, had been passing lewd comments against him. When we called one of the students, he assured us they won’t harass him any more. However, they kept on harassing him,” the father added.

column2: Boy in ICU after fall from school terrace in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: A ninth standard student at Everest Public school in Sahibabad was injured after allegedly falling from the terrace of the school’s second floor on Friday. The student’s family has claimed he was being thrashed by a teacher and fell as he tried to run away. But a teacher at the school said the boy had “misbehaved” with another student, a girl, and both students had been summoned for counselling. “Some students informed me someone had fallen from the terrace. I rushed to the spot and found the boy in front of the junior wing’s toilet. I took him to a nearby hospital, which referred him to another hospital,” the school’s sports teacher said. “CCTV footage clearly shows the boy running towards the terrace. He jumped from there, fearing his parents would be called to school,” he added. The boy’s father, who works with a private company in Ghaziabad, said one of the teachers had tortured and beaten his son. “He received fractures in his hands and leg and also sustained head injuries. He is critical and has been admitted to the ICU,” he said, adding he would file a police complaint after his son’s condition stabilised. Ravi Mishra, circle officer of the Sahibabad area, said, “School authorities informed police about the incident. We will check CCTV footage of the school and decide on what action to take.”

column2: Speeding bikers ram parked MUV on Agra Expressway, both die
column3: LUCKNOW: Two youths on a bike, allegedly cruising at over 100kmph without helmets, were killed when their two-wheeler ploughed into a parked multi-utility vehicle (MUV) on the Agra Expressway under Para police station limits around Saturday noon. The deceased have been identified as Monu Katiyar (27) and Arjun Kumar Singh (30), both residents of Bilhaur in Kanpur. According to police, the youths were returning to Kanpur and they hit the expressway near Mohan Road around 11.15am. The MUV, ferrying sadhus of Kanchi Kamkothi Peeth to Lokariya in Bihar, was stationed on the side of the road and the bike rammed it from behind. “The bike came hurtling towards us at over 100kmph and the youths were not wearing helmets,” Sawai Singh, the driver of the MUV, told police. “I had stopped my vehicle on the extreme right to track the route using Google Maps. Maharaj and his three disciples were on the passenger seats and by god’s grace, escaped unhurt,” he added. Singh, whose MUV was badly damaged on impact, both informed police and called an ambulance for the bikers. Para station house officer Triloki Singh said the youths were rushed to KGMU Trauma Centre, but were declared brought dead. “The driver of the other vehicle forgot his way and stopped to look for a guide map to Bihar. In the meantime, the youths on a bike rammed the vehicle from behind. They were without helmets,” the officer said, adding that the speeding angle was being probed. Police have informed the bereaved families and the bodies are being preserved in mortuary till their arrival. “The youths were jobless. Arjun was married,” a source in police said.

column2: Speeding bikers ram parked MUV on Agra Expressway, both die
column3: LUCKNOW: Two youths on a bike, allegedly cruising at over 100kmph without helmets, were killed when their two-wheeler ploughed into a parked multi-utility vehicle (MUV) on the Agra Expressway under Para police station limits around Saturday noon. The deceased have been identified as Monu Katiyar (27) and Arjun Kumar Singh (30), both residents of Bilhaur in Kanpur. According to police, the youths were returning to Kanpur and they hit the expressway near Mohan Road around 11.15am. The MUV, ferrying sadhus of Kanchi Kamkothi Peeth to Lokariya in Bihar, was stationed on the side of the road and the bike rammed it from behind. “The bike came hurtling towards us at over 100kmph and the youths were not wearing helmets,” Sawai Singh, the driver of the MUV, told police. “I had stopped my vehicle on the extreme right to track the route using Google Maps. Maharaj and his three disciples were on the passenger seats and by god’s grace, escaped unhurt,” he added. Singh, whose MUV was badly damaged on impact, both informed police and called an ambulance for the bikers. Para station house officer Triloki Singh said the youths were rushed to KGMU Trauma Centre, but were declared brought dead. “The driver of the other vehicle forgot his way and stopped to look for a guide map to Bihar. In the meantime, the youths on a bike rammed the vehicle from behind. They were without helmets,” the officer said, adding that the speeding angle was being probed. Police have informed the bereaved families and the bodies are being preserved in mortuary till their arrival. “The youths were jobless. Arjun was married,” a source in police said.

column2: KGMU doctors’ stir hits emergency services
column3: LUCKNOW: Emergency services were paralysed for more than 12 hours at Lari cardiology centre of King George’s Medical University (KGMU) on Saturday after resident doctors went on a flash strike to protest a mob attack following a patient’s death. This came a day after a doctor at Balrampur hospital was assaulted by women attendants of a patient, who died during treatment. This comes almost a month after a pan-India strike in the wake of violence against doctors in West Bengal. Though doctors resumed work after being assured of 24x7 police deployment at the hospital, patients coming to the emergency ward and out-patient-door (OPD) services had a harrowing time throughout the day. Later, an FIR was lodged against the attendants responsible for the attack. Saturday’s violence was the fourth such incident in KGMU this month. According to police, trouble started around 2am, when Khadra resident Shaira Bano (55) was brought to the hospital after she suffered a heart attack. All hell broke lose when doctors declared the patient brought dead. The family claimed that junior doctors gave CPR to the patient and the senior resident doctor did not come on time. Resident doctors said some among the family members called their friends and neighbours and soon the crowd swelled to over 150. Hurling abuses, the mob thrashed guards and tried to assault the doctors who locked themselves in washrooms to save escape the attack.

column2: Lucknow man poses as son's pal, molests woman
column3: LUCKNOW: A woman was allegedly molested in Madiaon by a youth who pretended to be her son's friend. A case was registered against one Rahul Singh (21) on Saturday in connection with the July 11 incident. He has been arrested. According to the 45-year-old complainant, she was on her way home from her workplace in Gomtinagar on Thursday night when the accused met her. "It was 9pm and I had reached near Ramleela Ground, where I ran into him (Rahul). He said he was a friend of my son and that his mother wished to talk to me. He sounded very convincing and I went with him to his house. But, there was no one else. When I sensed something foul, he quickly shut the main door and tried to force himself upon me," she said in her complaint. The woman told police she somehow managed to wriggle free and escape. She filed a written complaint at Madiaon thana only after she could come to terms with the initial shock. SHO Santosh Singh said a police team searched the said address, but found no one at home. "The accused was later nabbed from a nearby locality following a tip-off. He has been booked for outraging the modesty of a woman, wrongful confinement and punishment for causing hurt," the officer added.

column2: CCTV cameras and drones to monitor mining across Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: From October 1, all mining activity in the state will be done under surveillance of CCTV cameras and drones linked to a command centre in Lucknow. The directorate of geology and mining, government of Uttar Pradesh, has taken up several technological measures to stop illegal mining activity in the state. UP has been a hub of illegal mining for a long time. Recently, acting on the high court order of 2016, a CBI investigation was sought into one such case after a public interest litigation. Acting on it, the CBI had registered five FIRs and one was registered by the Enforcement Directorate. During investigation, the agencies found that a multi-crore mining scam was run from 2012-16 but the then-government had taken no steps to curb it. Action began soon after the Yogi Adityanath-led government came to power. Mining special secretary and director Roshan Jacob told TOI that integrated mining surveillance has been done to stop illegal mining. The command centre has recently been established in the directorate. “It has been linked with all mines in the state and is being monitored by artificial intelligence-based CCTV cameras and drones. Geo-fencing is also being set up gradually. It will enable us to curb mining in any area where a lease has not been issued,” Jacob told TOI. For the first time, the government has also decided to attach a vehicle tracking system (VTS) to trucks ferrying minerals from mines. This will give an update to the command centre during entry and exit from a mining area. The mining department has also decided to partner with the transport and GST departments. A mining officer said that until now, only the transport department had the database of trucks, but now, it will be with the mining department. “After every boarding from a mine, a mining officer will seal and scan the truck on an app before sending it to the command centre,” he added.

column2: Under-attack Bareilly MLA gets support from Dalit neta
column3: LUCKNOW: A Dalit lawmaker with BJP has come out in open support of the Bareilly legislator whose daughter accused him of unleashing death threats for marrying a Dalit. Shyam Prakash, MLA from Gopamau in Hardoi, sympathized with his colleague and advocated marrying within the caste. Only a father whose daughter or sister eloped and married a Dalit can empathize with Bareilly MLA Rajesh Mishra, alias Pappu Bhartaul, he said in a Facebook post. Prakash, who took to social media to air his views, also lashed out at a television anchor, asking if she would ever get her daughter married to his son, a Pasi. "Will you ever propose marriage of your daughter with my son, the son of a Dalit (Pasi), to set an example and prove you practise what you preach? Along with what we do, you and I are social beings, you should remember that," Prakash said. Earlier, he defended BJP MLA Rajesh Mishra, saying those blaming him during television debates would understand his plight only if they "suffered" a similar fate. "...they will understand the social embarrassment only when their own daughter or sister runs away with a Scheduled Caste man and marries him," he said. Mishra's son-in-law "brought a bad name to the entire Dalit community and betrayed his friend" and Dalits should boycott him, he added. On Wednesday, Mishra's daughter Sakshi released a video with her husband Ajitesh, saying she had married against her family's wishes and their lives were in danger. They also sought police protection from Allahabad High Court, saying if something were to happen to them, she would want her father behind bars. Mishra, who initially claimed he was not interfering with his daughter's life, on Saturday announced if he were asked any more questions about Sakshi, he would commit suicide. TOI made repeated attempts to contact the Gopamau MLA Shyam Prakash, but he did not respond to calls or text messages.

column2: Ghaziabad: Snubbed by lover, he donned a khaki uniform and took to crime
column3: GHAZIABAD: He burnt the midnight oil and wrote the Delhi Police test — all to impress his girlfriend. But as luck would have it, Asish Chaudhary failed to clear the exam by a few marks. The 20-year-old youth didn’t want to lose his girlfriend, who dreamt of seeing him as a cop some day. He donned the khaki, posed as a cop and took his girlfriend to restaurants and hotels where he could exert his influence in uniform. This went on for a few weeks until Asish’s girlfriend came to know about the truth and severed all ties. And after a few weeks, she married another man. Thus started Asish’s eight-year-old journey into the world of crime. Now 28, Asish was arrested from Sahibabad on Saturday for a series of robberies where he looted victims posing as a policeman. The latest of his robberies had come three weeks ago, when he targeted a 25-year-old trader who was returning home with the day’s collection. “On June 21, he had robbed a 25-year-old man of Rs 50,000 cash near the Hindon air base. The victim, Rizwan Khan, runs a shop of construction material in Sahibabad area,” a police officer said. Rizwan said he was on his way home around 10pm that evening when Asish stopped his bike for checking. The accused identified himself as a constable attached with the Tulsi Niketan outpost. “He hurled a flurry of questions at me. When he found I had cash at hand, he asked me to come with him to the police outpost. He asked me to show the bundle of notes I had, got on to his bike and fled. I could not chase him, he had taken along the keys to my bike,” Rizwan said. The trader dialled 100 and a police team reached the spot. When Rizwan was taken to the Tulsi Niketan police outpost, the “constable” who had robbed him was nowhere to be found. “He became a fake policeman only to marry his girlfriend. But when his girlfriend came to know about the truth, she married another man. Since then, he started robbing people posing as a cop. He told police he had spent all the money in gambling and on a tour to Shimla with his friends,” SP (city) Shlok Kumar said.

column2: Another death at Etawah safari, Jessica loses cub
column3: KANPUR: One of the four cubs birthed by Etawah Lion Safari lioness Jessica died due to dehydration on Friday, even before it could turn a month-old. The cub’s death is the sixth one to be reported at the safari since 2014. The casualty deals a blow to the safari’s plans to breed more lions and to help increase the number of big cats living in the state. Brought in from Gir National Park in Gujarat in December 2015, Jessica had mated with one of the lions at the safari, Manan, three months ago and had given birth to the four cubs on June 26. Officials said that the other three cubs appeared to be doing well and were feeding on their mother’s milk. A safari official said that this was first cub that Jessica lost since being shifted to Etawah. “The cub was suffering from dehydration and had not been having its mother’s milk since the past few days. We had started treating the cub, but it continued to lose weight. On Friday evening, we noticed that the newborn was lying motionless. We separated the mother and the cub and found it to be dead. The cub weighed 800 gram at the time of death. Jessica had fed the ill cub milk till Friday noon. The other three cubs weighed around 2.40kg,” said director of Etawah Lion Safari Vinod Krishna Singh. “A team of four veterinarians took the cub’s carcass to Bareilly’s Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) for an autopsy, which would ascertain the exact cause of death.” A special team of safari doctors would be monitoring the other cubs’ health. Earlier, Jessica had given birth to three cubs Sultan and Shimba, and Bahubali in 2016 and 2018 respectively. The Etawah Lion Safari currently is home to four lions and two lionesses—Jessica and Heer—and three cubs—Sultan, Shimba and Bahubali. The work on the safari started in 2005, but smooth way was paved in May 2013 after environmental clearances. Since 2014, the safari has reported 10 deaths—two lions and three lionesses, and five cubs. The decline in numbers started with the death of Laxmi and Vishnu in October and November 2014 respectively, followed by the demise of Tapasya and Kuber. Four cubs died in July 2015 soon after being born and another one died in August 2015. Safari officials claimed that the four adult lions died of canine distemper. It is a kind of viral infection which also affects dogs. Following the lion deaths, safari authorities launched a vaccination drive for stray and domestic dogs in nearby villages to check the spread of canine distemper.

column2: UP: Two arrested for selling branded juice that expired
column3: LUCKNOW: Two persons were arrested by joint teams of police and Food Safety and Drug Administration (FSDA) for selling expired fruit juices in newly packed boxes at Tedhipuliya crossing on Saturday. SP (trans-Gomti) Amit Kumar told TOI that Praveen Verma and Ashok Maurya were charged with forgery. They used to sell expired packaged fruit juices by changing their expiry dates. The arrests were made after a raid in a godown of a furniture shop in possession of the duo. “We recovered a huge stock of expired packaged fruit juices. There are machines and stamps to manipulate the expiry dates. There were also empty packs in which juices were being packed,” said Kumar. FSDA collected samples of the juices and has sent them for examination. The raids came after a case was registered at Gudumba police station on the directions of the court on the petition of Manoj Gupta, the owner of a food joint. Gupta had first approached Gudumba police earlier this year but when his complaint was not registered, he moved court.

column2: Skin infections stalking minors in UP, shows data
column3: LUCKNOW: One in four children screened under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) were found to be suffering from skin diseases. Health department data suggest over 13 lakh children, in the 0-18 years age group, were examined for diseases, defects and deficiencies across 75 districts of the state in the past three months. Of them, 55,049 were found to be ailing and 14,000 — almost 25% — had skin diseases. In 2018-19, prevalence of skin diseases among children was found to be lower at around 20%. The screening programme was launched under National Health Mission in 2014 to ensure early diagnosis of diseases, defects, deficiencies and disabilities in children under 18 years. The state health department has recently launched an application to monitor the scheme, which had reached out to over 2.87 crore children last year. The app records data against 38 diseases and is also used to follow up on the referred children. “Real-time data of medical tests will help understand patterns and trends of diseases, which will in turn aid strategy improvement,” said Anupam Srivastava, the programme officer monitoring the software solution. General manager, RBSK, Dr Manoj Shukul maintained that effective monitoring of the programme would go a long way in improving the overall state of child and adolescent health in UP. “The insight gathered from the programme will help us bring down the infant and under-five mortality rates, besides checking problems such as anaemia,” he said. Apart from skin diseases, close to 9,000 children with severe malnutrition were also identified during the exercise. Vitamin-A deficiency was noted in 5,083 children while 2,622 were found to be acutely anaemic. Over 600 children were diagnosed with rickets, a skeletal disorder caused by lack of Vitamin D, calcium or phosphate. As many as 684 children were diagnosed with congenital heart disease while an equal number were seen with a club foot. Cleft lip and palate were seen among 412 children while neural tube defect was detected in 166 children. Over 100 children with autism were also identified and referred for further treatment.

column2: One held for assault on madrassa students
column3: KANPUR: Two men, detained by the police for allegedly beating up four madrassa students with cricket bats on GIC grounds in Unnao on Friday, were released late in the night as their presence on the spot could not be established through CCTV footage. While the police arrested an accused in the case on Saturday, the Unnao district administration denied that the madrassa students were also forced to chant an objectionable slogan. Police said that they did not find the charge to be true. Unnao CO (City), Umesh Chandra Tyagi said, “During investigation it has been learnt that four madrassa students and some others were playing on the GIC ground. Meanwhile, some youths, identified as Golu, Sanket Bharti, Deepanshu Chaudhary and Santosh Kumar, who were also present there, had a heated argument with them over some petty issue and later both the groups clashed with each other.” He added that the police arrested Sanket Bharti on Saturday while the others were absconding. The CO said that two youths, who had been accused in the case earlier, were not present at the spot and were allowed to go after questioning. He also said that their absence was corroborated through statements of the eye-witnesses, CCTV footages and mobile location of these youths. An FIR was lodged by Unnao police on the complaint of the principal of madarssa Darul-Ulum Faize-Aam, Nisar Ahmed.

column2: Slow progress of Smart City project: Minister pulls up admin
column3: KANPUR: Terming development of the ‘smart city’ project as disappointing, minister for urban development Suresh Khanna said that out of Rs 303 crore allocated for the project, only Rs 113 crore had so far been spent by the agencies. There was a need to complete the project on a warfooting. The minister, presiding over a review meeting here on Saturday, said Rs 2,311 crore ‘smart city’ project is aimed at providing basic facilities to the residents by the local bodies. The city, he said, is facing serious problems of potable water, choked sewer lines and drainage system but the Jal Nigam and Jal Kal departments didn’t care to do anything in this regard. He asked the chairman-cum-managing director of the Jal Nigam to chalk out short term and long term plans for redressing the city’s problems. “Suspension is no remedy. The officers should perform their duties honestly and with full responsibility”, Khanna said. He told the officers either perform or be ready to bear the consequences. The executive officer (EO), who had not spent the funds allocated by the 14th Finance Commission, would be suspended, he further said. Minister for industrial development, Satish Mahana also expressed his displeasure on slow development of the ‘smart city’ project.While Kanpur was declared the ‘smart city’ in the second round, but only open gyms could be raised in some parks so far, he said.

column2: Government mulls Rs 2,000 incentive for a road accident Samaritan
column3: LUCKNOW: Taking an accident victim to hospital will not only be a good deed but a rewarding one too. The state government is considering giving an incentive of Rs 2,000 to those who carry road accident victims to hospital. Though the policy to protect Good Samaritans has been in effect since January 2016, it has failed to motivate people to save lives by taking those critically injured to hospital in the golden hour (crucial one hour after accident). A final decision on the move will be taken soon. The incentive will be paid from the Road Safety Fund and a special cell set up for this purpose might set aside Rs 50 lakh for the purpose for this financial year. If the proposal is approved, a corpus will be set up from next year. UP clocks the highest number of deaths due to road accidents every year. In 2018, in 42,568 road accidents, at least 22,200 people had died and 29,600 were left grievously injured. In 2019, from January till May, at least 18,500 road accidents have taken place in which more than 10,000 people have lost their lives. In 2016, acting on the guidelines of the Union ministry of road transport and highways (MoRTH), UP had implemented a policy saying that anyone who takes the injured to hospital after a road accident will be interrogated only once by the police and not face undue inconvenience. The interrogation will be held at the place, time and in the language preferred by the person. The person may also complain against harassment by police, if any, to the transport department. “The proposed amendment will supplement the existing policy,” said sources. The major role in the implementation of the move will be of the health department. Every hospital, including private ones, will have to be instructed to follow the rule. At the same time, people need to be made aware of the incentive.

column2: Meet the Samaritans who’re funding many a fair dream
column3: JHANSI: Books were always Anushukha Jatav’s best friend. Last year, the teenager sadly realised that her poor parents could no longer send her to school. She dropped out after Class VIII. And then, a miracle happened. She not just went back to school, but also cleared Class IX with 92% to make her parents proud. The 15-year-old resident of Bhaupura village in Konch block of Jalaun district is not the only lucky girl. There are 40 like her who are currently able to pursue their education because of a bunch of good Samaritans who are bearing the cost of their lodging and transportation too. The brainchild of Jalaun DM Mannan Akhtar, Kishori Samadhan Yojana is a Trust run through public funding. It has 40-odd members, including retired government employees, businessmen and corporate executives, who contribute both money and time to ensure meritorious girls from underprivileged families can continue with their education. “I want to complete school and college, and become an IAS officer,” Anushukha said, no longer afraid to voice her dreams. Father Chandrashekhar Jatav, who runs a small convenience store in their village, is supportive. “I have four children. It was not possible for me to fund their education. I am thankful to those who have taken the responsibility of helping my daughter pursue her ambition.” Incidentally, Jalaun is one of the most backward districts of India and has an adverse girl-boy ratio. Against every thousand boys, there are 865 girls while the national average is 945. Under such circumstances, girls dropping out of school has been a major concern. The Kishori Trust selects its beneficiaries on merit basis from eight Kasturba Gandhi residential schools, where they are taught till Class VIII. “Kasturba girls mostly belong to Scheduled Castes. Some come from poor families, some are orphans. Many are unable to complete school education. So, we decided to help,” DM Akhtar told TOI. Rajesh Kumar Sahi, who oversees the Kishori project and has contributed for the cause from his personal savings, said they had created a corpus of Rs 8-9 lakh for the education of these girls. Nilesh Singh (72), a retired principal who lives in Konch, has taken the responsibility of educating one of the girls till Class XII. “I have two daughters and a son who are well educated and settled. I understand the importance of education. Hence, I came to help in this wonderful initiative,” Singh said. Avinash Gupta (32), a manager with an insurance firm in Lucknow, said helping these girls brought him joy. “A friend of mine volunteers here and one day, he invited me to do so. It has been one of the best decisions of my life,” Gupta said.

column2: This was pure kids’ stuff on stage in Lucknow
column3: The play Did the Butler Do It, staged in the city recently by kids aged 7-13 was a big draw. Directed by Faisal Husain, the English play was set in England, where Lady Jemima Fitzwilliam loses her precious pearl necklace. The play revolved around the search for the necklace by the police and a private detective, Mrs Clues, appointed by Lady Jemima's husband. Carlyle Mcfarland and Pooja Bhatia (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Carlyle Mcfarland and Pooja Bhatia (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Geeta Gandhi Kingdon (L) and Dr Bharti Gandhi and Jasmine Jain (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Geeta Gandhi Kingdon (L) and Dr Bharti Gandhi and Jasmine Jain (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Khushboo (L) and Saumya with Tanupriya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Khushboo (L) and Saumya with Tanupriya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Neelam and Kiron Chopra with Vasundhara (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Neelam and Kiron Chopra with Vasundhara (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Rashi (L) and Sharon with Alpa Jain Kapoor (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Rashi (L) and Sharon with Alpa Jain Kapoor (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Diya Badgel (L) and Dr Mala Singh Mehra and director Faisal Husain (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Diya Badgel (L) and Dr Mala Singh Mehra and director Faisal Husain (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Present at the event was Carlyle McFarland, principal of a school in Lucknow, who was impressed by the acting of the children. “All the children acted exceptionally well. They definitely deserve a treat by their parents tonight. And I personally would like to request their parents not to trouble them for studies for the next few days. This form of art will make these kids grow in their life, they were filled with confidence tonight. I just loved the play,” he said. The play had 24 children playing different roles. Among which the characters of Lady Jemima Fitzwilliam, Jeeves the Butler, Inspector Vector and Mrs Clues were dramatised by Palak Popli, Dron Pandey, Parisha Agarwal and Aarushi Kapoor, respectively. The audience, comprising the parents of the kids, their friends and other well-known people from the city, loved every moment of the play and the kids, at the end, got a standing ovation from them all. — Saad Abbasi

column2: Caught on Camera: Kartik Aaryan on the edge in Lucknow
column3: W e caught Kartik Aaryan shooting for the film Pati, Patni Aur Woh at the PMG office in Hazratganj over the weekend. Giving him company during the shoot was his onscreen wife Bhumi Pednekar and his onscreen secretary-lover Ananya Panday and Aparshakti Khurana. The scene was of Kartik trying to hide and run away from both his wife and secretary. Sporting a moustache, Aaryan is seen climbing out of the window and standing on the ledge while Ananya, dressed in yellow trouser and top, is seen walking on the road and talking to Aparshakti. Kartik Aaryan's post on Instagram (BCCL)  Kartik Aaryan's post on Instagram (BCCL) Ananya Panday's post on Instagram hinted at her wanting to eat Lakhnawi kebabs (BCCL) Ananya Panday's post on Instagram hinted at her wanting to eat Lakhnawi kebabs (BCCL) The actors are excited to be shooting in Lucknow and Ananya had told us in a previous interview that she looked forward to being in the city again and feasting on Lakhnawi delicasies. She also put a post on Instagram in which she wrote about kebabs, hinting that she will be eating lots of them while here.

column2: Air cheer: PM10 level dipping in Delhi
column3: NEW DELHI: The national capital may be the most polluted city in the country but the level of a key pollutant, PM10, has been consistently declining here since 2016 unlike in less polluted cities such as Mumbai, Kolkata, Ahmedabad and Bhopal, where concentrations of the deadly particulate matter has increased in the last three years. Analysis of data for 50 metropolitan cities for 2016, 2017 and 2018 showed a declining trend in Delhi, Varanasi, Ranchi, Raipur, Vijayawada and Bengaluru, among others, whereas the level of PM10 rose in Surat, Vadodara, Rajkot (all in Gujarat), Jodhpur, Kota (both in Rajasthan), Gwalior and Jabalpur (MP). The government shared the data on PM10 in Parliament recently. Though data on PM2.5 levels are also available, the information is sketchy as many cities did not start measuring concentrations of these finer, respirable particles three years ago. There was an increasing trend in PM10 level in 14 cities and decreasing one in another 14 while a fluctuating trend was found in 22 cities like Agra, Kanpur, Lucknow, Allahabad, Patna, Amritsar, Nagpur, Pune, Hyderabad and Chandigarh. Though the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), launched in January to look beyond Delhi, aims to reduce both PM10 and PM2.5 concentrations in 102 cities by 20-30% by 2024 from the level of 2017, the PM2.5 trend is currently available for only 17 cities. Analysis showed that many cities suffering from high pollution levels, including Delhi, Varanasi, Lucknow, Kanpur, Jaipur, Mumbai, Kolkata and Ahmedabad, will continue to be polluted even if the target of reducing 30% of PM10 concentrations in the next five years is achieved. This means the current target is not enough to bring level of pollutants to the acceptable limit — that is, an annual average of 60 micrograms per cubic metre (ug/m3) — by 2024. It may be possible only by scaling up efforts in these cities. Particulate matter can get deep into the lungs (particularly PM2.5) and some may even get into the bloodstream, causing serious health problems. Steady decline in the levels of PM10 in Delhi may be attributed to multiple actions such as leapfrogging from BS-IV to BS-VI fuel standard, operationalisation of eastern and western peripheral expressways, implementing dust mitigation measures and closing down coal-based Badarpur thermal power plant, among others. Much more, however, needs to be done to substantially bring down the level of pollutants to the acceptable limit in the national capital and the other 101 cities identified under the NCAP. On PM2.5 levels in 17 cities, data showed an increasing trend in eight cities including Kolkata, Ahmedabad, Rajkot, Surat, Vadodara, Bhopal, Chennai and Hyderabad. The trend is quite worrying as it shows that PM2.5 level in five cities — Ahmedabad, Rajkot, Surat, Vadodara and Bhopal — has turned out to be hazardous in 2018 from acceptable limit (below 40 ug/m3) in 2016. Four cities — Chandigarh, Indore, Coimbatore and Asansol — showed a decreasing trend while the remaining five, including Delhi and Bengaluru, showed a fluctuating trend in terms of PM2.5 levels. In case of other pollutants, the data showed that sulphur dioxide (SO2) levels were within the acceptable limit in all 50 cities during 2016-18 while nitrogen dioxide (NO2) levels in 17 cities showed an increasing trend. Of the rest, 16 cities showed a decreasing trend, 16 others showed a fluctuating trend and one city showed steady concentration. Under the NCAP, the Centre has identified 102 cities, based on ambient air quality data for the period 2011-15 and the WHO report of 2018, for implementation of city-specific action plans. A total of 86 city specific plans have so far been approved for actions.
