Particulate matter can get deep into the lungs (particularly PM2.5) and some may even get into the bloodstream, causing serious health problems. Steady decline in the levels of PM10 in Delhi may be attributed to multiple actions such as leapfrogging from BS-IV to BS-VI fuel standard, operationalisation of eastern and western peripheral expressways, implementing dust mitigation measures and closing down coal-based Badarpur thermal power plant, among others. Much more, however, needs to be done to substantially bring down the level of pollutants to the acceptable limit in the national capital and the other 101 cities identified under the NCAP. On PM2.5 levels in 17 cities, data showed an increasing trend in eight cities including Kolkata, Ahmedabad, Rajkot, Surat, Vadodara, Bhopal, Chennai and Hyderabad. The trend is quite worrying as it shows that PM2.5 level in five cities — Ahmedabad, Rajkot, Surat, Vadodara and Bhopal — has turned out to be hazardous in 2018 from acceptable limit (below 40 ug/m3) in 2016. Four cities — Chandigarh, Indore, Coimbatore and Asansol — showed a decreasing trend while the remaining five, including Delhi and Bengaluru, showed a fluctuating trend in terms of PM2.5 levels. In case of other pollutants, the data showed that sulphur dioxide (SO2) levels were within the acceptable limit in all 50 cities during 2016-18 while nitrogen dioxide (NO2) levels in 17 cities showed an increasing trend. Of the rest, 16 cities showed a decreasing trend, 16 others showed a fluctuating trend and one city showed steady concentration. Under the NCAP, the Centre has identified 102 cities, based on ambient air quality data for the period 2011-15 and the WHO report of 2018, for implementation of city-specific action plans. A total of 86 city specific plans have so far been approved for actions.

column2: Serial cow deaths: Yogi Adityanath shunts out eight officials
column3: LUCKNOW: Battling an escalating crisis in government-run cow shelters with a climbing bovine death toll, chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday suspended eight officials, including chief veterinary officer of Mirzapur and three government vets in Ayodhya. He also issued a stern warning to officials to maintain cow sheds, arrange fodder or face the music. Taking cognizance of starvation deaths of 15 cows at a gaushala in Ayodhya, the chief minister swiftly convened a video conferencing with all 75 district magistrates and warned that cow deaths would invite immediate disciplinary action. Also, owners who abandon cattle on streets after milking them will be punished. Civic authorities in Lucknow, too, were put on notice if they failed to curb stray cattle menace on streets from Amausi airport to city arteries. During video conferencing, an agitated chief minister ordered suspension of block development officer, Milkipur, deputy chief veterinary officer of Ayodhya, village panchayat officer and two veterinary doctors of Ayodhya Municipal Corporation. Shocking video clips of cow carcasses lying on marshes at an Ayodhya shelter and the subsequent outcry from seers of the temple town drew attention of the chief minister, who not only announced suspension of five officers of the district, but also held out a stern warning to others. Dr A K Singh, chief veterinary officer of Mirzapur, and executive officer of Mirzapur town were also shunted out and the commissioner and district magistrate, Mirzapur, were asked to probe into circumstances that led to cow deaths in the district. Herding cows in schools: Yogi Adityanath warns of actionAfter 30 cows were electrocuted in Allahabad, the chief minister asked the commissioner to probe into the deaths and recommended action against officials responsible for maintenance of gaushalas, where trapped cows died after an electric pole fell on the waterlogged shelter. Amidst protests by farmers and people over cattle trampling upon crops or triggering accidents on streets, the Yogi government told district magistrates to rehabilitate abandoned cows in new shelters, while announcing a budgetary corpus for protection of bovines. On Sunday, the chief minister said, panchayat officials will be taken to task if cows were herded on school campuses. The Yogi government also slapped Rupee 1 cess on sale of every liquor bottle to generate funds. But district-rung officers struggled for funds to mobilise fodder for cows every day. With the first big crackdown by the Yogi government against veterinary doctors, district officers and cow owners, it has to be seen whether the BJP government will be able to stave off the cow crisis in the state.

column2: Mining scam: Former UP mantri Gayatri Prajapati's sons under ED lens
column3: LUCKNOW: The Enforcement Directorate has begun probe into firms floated by former Samajwadi Party minister Gayatri Prajapati's sons in connection with UP mining scam. The development comes amid CBI investigation into UP mining scam involving lease issued to businessmen in alleged connivance with IAS officers and flouting of e-bidding norms. The former minister's son Anil Prajapati has been director in as many as five companies - MSG realtors, MAGS Enterprises, MGA hospitality, MSA Infra Venture and MGM Agrotech Pvt Ltd since 2014. The same five firms have his other son Anurag also as director along with MGA colonisers which was floated by Gayatri Prajapati in 2009 but he had forsaken the directorship in 2013. Anurag has quietly withdrawn from six companies - Decent Contractors, Shubhang Exports, Lifecure Medical, Kanha Buildwell, Excel Buildtech and Daya Builders - since 2014 where too he was a director. ED is probing whether these companies completed any business transaction or were used to route kickback amounts from mining leases for 100 and 90 acre sites offered to two Fatehpur businessmen, Shiv Singh and Sukhraj, who, Gayatri Prajapati, allegedly gave favours despite several objections on environment and pending government dues from district administration officials. ‘May summon Gayatri sons’ED officials claim the companies were allegedly used to buy residential and commercial assets in Amethi, Rae Bareli and Lucknow, but the firms were either not filing mandatory returns before ministry of corporate affairs (MCA) or not conducting any business. The officials also said that Prajapati’s two sons may be summoned to explain the share-holding pattern in the companies as well. Asked about the mining scam, Anil Prajapati said that he was out of Lucknow and would only reply to investigation agencies. “I am out of the city. Summons were issued to my father, not to any other family member. If required, we will share the details on companies with agencies,” he said. Gayatri was recently shifted from Lucknow jail to King George’s Medical University in Lucknow after he complained of illness. He has been in the jail after a rape case was registered against him in 2017. Prajapati’s family has been active in Amethi for long.

column2: Muslims, Dalits to go for arms licence in self-defence against mob lynchings
column3: LUCKNOW: Reeling under the fear of mob lynchings, Dalits, tribals and Muslims will be applying for arms licences for self-defence - a pan-India movement which will commence in Lucknow on July 26. The brainchild of Supreme Court lawyer Mehmood Pracha, the first camp will be organized in Lucknow on the invitation of Shia cleric and general secretary of Majlis-e-Ulama-e-Hind, Maulana Kalbe Jawad. Pracha said, these camps would be organized in at least 12 cities, including six in Uttar Pradesh, where these communities are under threat and need legal help. Speaking to TOI, Pracha said, "SC/ST and minorities have been pushed to the edge by the government, which is soft on perpetrators of mob violence. In such a scenario, there is no option left, but self-defence." "Many from these communities face discrimination and they will avail of our legal expertise to fill forms and apply for arms licence," he said. The camp will ensure that applicants with criminal antecedents or those with political or business interest, will be kept out. ‘Drive not about Shias only’“Once they get the licence, we will deploy experts for arms training. And we will act against those who misuse their licence,” he said. Speaking to TOI, Maulana Kalbe Jawad said, “Legal experts will be coming to Lucknow for holding the camp. Clerics from others sects will also be included as the movement is not about Shias alone. The brunt of mob lynching is borne by Sunnis and Dalits.” Pracha said, “If the government took strong steps against perpetrators of hate crime, we would not have had to take up such a measure. There are tough laws in the Constitution and Indian Penal Code (IPC) which the government should invoke. The draft bill on lynching is a mere eye wash. If the government wakes up, we will withdraw the movement,” he said.

column2: Coast Guard's combat pilot jumps to death from apartment's 9th floor in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: A deputy commandant of the Indian Coast Guard, who was among the first four women to be trained to pilot a combat hovercraft after the 26/11 Mumbai terror attacks, apparently jumped to her death from the ninth floor of an apartment in a posh residential complex in Lucknow on Sunday morning. Preliminary investigation suggest Sneha Kathayat (32) had an argument with her husband over undergoing martial arts training. Police have sent the body for post-mortem and are scanning CCTV camera footage that show her taking the elevator outside their flat and then the stairs to reach the top floor of the building. Police said the Coast Guard officer took VRS on July 3 and returned home to Lucknow on July 6. She was staying at Celebrity Garden apartment in Sushant Golf City with her husband's elder brother Ajay Singh and his wife Supriya. She was a native of Pithoragarh in Uttarakhand. Around 9am, Sneha was found dead - her skull cracked and clothes torn - in front of the parking area on the apartment premises. Security guards informed the caretaker of the apartment and later, Supriya identified her. Sneha's husband Arvind Singh, a pilot with private commercial airline, reached the city from Pratapgarh and gave his statement at SGPGI police station. "She was planning to enrol in martial arts classes in Goa. But, I wanted to spend time with her and hence, disapproved of the same last week. We had frequent tiffs thereafter," Arvind said in his statement to police. SP (north) Sukirti Madhav Mishra told TOI that it appeared to be a case of suicide although no note was found. "The woman was seen taking the stairs to the top floor. The reason behind the suicide is yet to be ascertained. An autopsy will be conducted by a panel of doctors," he said. The officer added that Sneha had married Arvind on May 30 this year. "No injuries were found on the body (apart from those on the head). She spoke to her mother around 8.17am over phone, less than an hour before the body was found." TOI tried to reach pilot Arvind Singh, but he did not answer his phone.

column2: Shower show in Lucknow from midweek
column3: LUCKNOW: The city is expected to receive light and scattered rainfall until Tuesday after which the shower show may pick up pace, weathermen said on Sunday. Relative humidity is likely to remain high, but the sultriness may be less compared to last week. "A low-pressure area over east UP, which was responsible for heavy showers last week, has weakened and is resulting in a decline in rainfall activity. The rain will remain subdued for a day or two. The possibility of heavy showers is very unlikely," said state Met director JP Gupta. On Sunday, the maximum and minimum temperatures were 36.3 and 28.5 degrees Celsius, respectively. Monday will be partly cloudy and rain is "very likely" in some areas. Maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 35 and 28 degrees Celsius, respectively. According to Lucknow University's climate monitoring station, the El Nino - characterised by warming of surface temperature in the Pacific Ocean - is associated with lower than normal monsoon rainfall in India. "The El Nino effect is basically responsible for the episodic monsoon, with only some parts of the state receiving rainfall. A shifting low-pressure area has also affected the intensity of monsoon," said station director professor Dhruv Sen Singh.

column2: Delhi IRS official says wife stole secret data to blackmail
column3: GHAZIABAD: A senior IRS officer has lodged a police complaint accusing his wife of stealing private and confidential information from his mobile phone and blackmailing him with it. The officer, posted as a joint commissioner in the income tax department in Delhi, alleged that his wife installed an application on his phone, which reportedly helped her steal personal as well as official information stored in the gadget. He alleged that his wife, her two brothers and a sister are now trying to extort Rs 25 lakh from him. The officer’s mother had in June lodged an FIR of similar nature against the woman at Kavi Nagar police station. “She threatened me to get separated from my son or else she would make all those calls and chats viral, which would defame me and my son,” the complaint read. The officer said he got married to the woman in December 2007. He claimed that the couple would fight over trivial matters and she would threaten him often. “My wife, along with his two brothers and a sister, started snooping on me. Later, they bought a spy software from a Delhi-based company and installed it on my phone. With the help of the software, they started keeping tabs on every movement and would listen to the recordings of my calls on their phones. They also hacked videos and photographs and started blackmailing me with them,” he wrote in the complaint. The officer said that his wife had started pressuring him to severe ties with his parents and relatives and stay with her only. “On April 23, 2018, one of my wife’s brothers came to my house and threatened me with dire consequences if I kept meeting me parents,” he said. He alleged that his wife, along with the other accused, demanded Rs 25 lakh from him and threatened to make all the information collected through the spy software public in case of non-compliance. They also threatened to implicate him in false cases, the officer claimed. Based on the complaint, an FIR under IPC Section 507 (criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication) and under Section 66 C (identity theft) of the IT Act was registered against the four persons at Indirapuram police station on Thursday. “Both cases are being investigated by the cyber cell and no arrests have been made so far,” SP (city) Shlok Kumar said.

column2: Ghaziabad: BPO executive duped of Rs 16 lakh by Facebook friend
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 25-year-old BPO executive has been duped of Rs 16 lakh by a woman whom he befriended through Facebook last year. The woman lured him to invest his money in tonicfabzine – a raw material used for the production of animal antiviral and retroviral health vaccine products. The imposter allegedly stopped taking his call after he made the deposit in a bank. An FIR under IPC sections 420 (cheating), 406 (criminal breach of trust) and 506 (criminal intimidation) against two persons Grace Smith and Ashok Siddhiwala at Indirapuram police station on Saturday. The complainant, who did not wish to be named, said that he got a friend request from the Smith on Facebook last year in August. He accepted it and started chatting with her. She introduced herself as an employee of an UK-based company dealing in a chemical which is prepared in India and exported to the USA and the UK. She told him that she was the production manager and frequently visited India for this purpose. She told him that she bought the chemical from Ashok Siddhiwala from Gujarat. The executive said believing her he deposited Rs 4 lakh in Siddhiwala’s bank account and bought one litre of the chemical. Smith told him to buy at least five litres of chemical so that her company can do business with him. The complainant said he subsequently took a loan of Rs 12 lakh from bank and relatives and deposited in the Siddhiwala’s account, but soon after that, he stopped taking his calls. Once he took my call and threatened me of dire consequences if I did not stop calling him, he said. He alleged that he had been trying to lodge a complaint in this matter since December 2018, but the FIR was lodged only on Saturday.

column2: Car hits man, father claims attempt to murder
column3: GHAZIABAD:A 27-year-old man, who suffered a fracture in the collarbone after being hit by a car a week ago, has accused his brother-in-law of trying to kill him. Ranpal Singh, a businessman and the complainant in the case, claimed that his son Akshay was going home to Pandav Nagar in Kavi Nagar on a scooter on July 8 evening when a car hit him from behind. He claimed that the car was driven by Akshay’s brother-in-law Bhanu, a resident of Delhi. Ranpal told police that Akshay has filed a divorce case and his wife’s brother tried to kill him. He said Akshay fell on the ground and suffered injuries to the shoulder. Based on Ranpal’s complaint, an FIR was registered against Bhanu and one of his friends, who was allegedly accompanying him at the time of the accident, under IPC section 307 (attempt to murder) at Kavi Nagar police station on Saturday. Singh said his son had married a Delhi-based woman in April 2016 and the couple have a two-year-old daughter. Akshay had lodged a case against his wife, mother-in-law and two brother-in-laws for trespassing, robbery and criminal intimidation last year in September at Kavi Nagar police station.

column2: UP: Burglars strike at shop, damage CCTV camera
column3: LUCKNOW: Burglars struck at two shops under the limits of PGI station area in two separate incidents and made off with cash and other items, on Sunday morning. The two shops are located close to Kalli-Paschim police outpost. According to reports, PGI locality resident Mohammed Kalim's shop was burgled around 3am on Sunday in Ektanagar. . He told the police that the accused took Rs 78,000 cahs, goods worth Rs 25,000 and the digital video recorded of the CCTV camera installed in his shop. However, the crime was captured on the CCTV camera installed in one of the neighbouring shops In another incident, burglars struck at another PGI resident Karan Maurya's grocery shop and decamped with Rs 2,500 cash and dry fruits worth Rs 50,000. "The shop is located near a petrol filling station and there is a police picket nearby," he said. CO (Cantonment) Durgesh Kumar said FIRs have been registered in both the cases.

column2: Chaos continues in Chaudhary Charan Singh International Airport parking, lanes
column3: LUCKNOW: Chaudhary Charan Singh International Airport in Amausi has become the definition of chaos with no one to manage vehicles outside the terminal even two weeks after the Airports Authority of India (AAI) introduced parking fees and penalties. The blatant violation of pick-up and drop-off rules was highlighted by TOI in its Saturday edition, but neither reality nor reports seem to be enough to jolt the authorities out of their slumber. On July 1, the AAI had revised parking fees and the same was said to have been implemented by Amausi officials the next day. The new rate for four-wheelers was halved to Rs 30 for the first 30 minutes so that those coming to the airport to see off family and friends didn't feel the pinch. Two days after the AAI order, airport officials had told TOI that extra manpower would be harnessed to manage the parking lots. But, chaos reigned supreme on Friday and also on Sunday, when this newspaper visited Amausi a second time. Haphazard and unauthorised parking was the order of the day along both pick-up and drop-off lanes. According to the new rules, a vehicle can halt without charge only for three minutes. But, many people, including VIPs, were seen parking their vehicles for an hour or more and not being penalised for the same. Reema Saluja, who arrived from Delhi, had to wait for several minutes before she could cross the lane. "Such poor management of terminal space is frustrating, especially when you have two pieces of heavy luggage," she said. Kuldeep Shukla who came to receive his parents also complained of haphazard parking. "I couldn't drive my way through the maze of parked vehicles. My parents had to wait for over 20 minutes before I could finally pick them up." Airport director AK Sharma said he was aware of the problem. "We have floated a tender to hire around 35 ex-servicemen, certified by the Directorate General Resettlement (DGR). They are trained to enforce the discipline. Ex-servicemen will be deployed at parking lots and outside the terminal building," he said, insisting that the chaos would end in a month from now.

column2: Uttar Pradesh BJP leader’s bodyguard found dead
column3: LUCKNOW: A former national wrestler who worked as a bodyguard for the state BJP spokesperson was found hanging from a ceiling fan at the latter’s house in Sarfarazganj on his 27th birthday on Sunday. Resham Singh, a native of Balamau in Hardoi, came to the residence of Rukhsana Naqvi around 10pm on Saturday along with his friend Waris Gazi and stayed back in a ground floor room. On Sunday, when Singh did not respond to knocks, Naqvi’s son Ali Momin went in to find him hanging. “I do not know when Gazi left the house last (Saturday) night. Also, Singh was upset over losing his government IDs and documents,” the BJP spokesperson said, adding that her bodyguard lost his phone on Saturday and had lodged a complaint. Thakurganj SHO Neeraj Ojha said, “The postmortem report will ascertain the cause of death. There are no external injuries on the body.”

column2: St Francis' old boys give reunion a Sunday style
column3: LUCKNOW: What looked like a wild idea when conceived by five friends eight years ago is today a weekly reunion like no other. Jashn-e-Itwar, a morning tea gathering of old boys of St Francis' Inter College, Lucknow, entered its 400th edition this Sunday, with 150-odd alumni and their families coming together at a tea stall to take a walk down memory lane. Shantanu Kumar of 1991 batch, who now owns a firm that runs online executive management training programmes, said the idea of turning Sundays into fun days struck them while sipping tea at a famous stall in Hazratganj. It was implemented on November 2011. "The idea was circulated through social media groups and received overwhelming response. And today, our Jashn-e-Itwar group has 5,000 members. Even teachers come to these gatherings," he said. Besides Kumar, the founding team also comprises his batchmates Mohit Jaggi, now a printing press owner; Nitin Suri, a garments merchant; Syed Zafar, a financial consultant; and Maulik Sikka, an IT professional. A student of the 1960 batch, Vishan Prakash said Jashn-e-Itwar had helped him relive the days that were among the best in his life. Apart from chit-chat, there's also chai pe charcha on serious issues. The members organise and participate annually in a blood donation camp. So far, 800 units have been donated.

column2: Lucknow: Policemen, health workers botch up baby girl rescue
column3: LUCKNOW: Maggots were found in the private parts of a four-day-old girl who was spotted in an undergrowth along the road in Mohanlalganj area on Saturday, but put on ventilator support at a private hospital in the city only on Sunday. Doctors said the abandoned newborn was grappling with bloodstream infection and the next 72 hours were crucial for her. The child welfare committee has summoned policemen and health workers concerned on Monday to inquire into the alleged failure to follow protocol and consequent delay in providing her proper medical attention. Local villagers heard a baby crying and found the girl in the bushes on Saturday evening. They informed Mohanlalganj police who allegedly took her to the community health centre instead of a hospital equipped to care for newborns. The health centre referred her to a well-equipped hospital, but she was taken to a government hospital in Kaiserbagh that is lacking in life support systems. A health worker associated with NGO Asha, identified as Savitri, dialled Childline at 1098 from the hospital and allegedly vanished. On Sunday, the baby's condition deteriorated because the government hospital had no ventilator. She was finally admitted to a private hospital in Dalibagh by Childline. "The girl is a preemie and underweight. We removed around 30 maggots from her private parts. There were also insect bite marks on her legs and forehead. She has bloodstream infection and the next 72 hours are crucial for her," said Dr Mirza Waqar Beg at the Dalibagh hospital. Member of child welfare committee Sangeeta Sharma said the station house officer of Mohanlalganj police station and Asha worker Savitri had been summoned for questioning. "They were not following protocol. Childline should have been informed first about the abandoned baby. Their negligence in handling the case may be responsible for the baby's condition," she added. Mohanlalganj SHO Gaudin Shukla said, "We received an information about the baby around 6.30pm (Saturday) and immediately took her to the health centre and then to a state hospital along with a woman constable and an Asha worker. We are trying to locate her parents."

column2: Skin infections stalking minors in Uttar Pradesh, show data
column3: LUCKNOW: One in four children screened under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) were found to be suffering from skin diseases. Health department data suggest over 13 lakh children, in the 0-18 years age group, were examined for diseases, defects and deficiencies across 75 districts of the state in the past three months. Of them, 55,049 were found to be ailing and 14,000 — almost 25% — had skin diseases. In 2018-19, prevalence of skin diseases among children was found to be lower at around 20%. The screening programme was launched under National Health Mission in 2014 to ensure early diagnosis of diseases, defects, deficiencies and disabilities in children under 18 years. The state health department has recently launched an application to monitor the scheme, which had reached out to over 2.87 crore children last year. The app records data against 38 diseases and is also used to follow up on the referred children. “Real-time data of medical tests will help understand patterns and trends of diseases, which will in turn aid strategy improvement,” said Anupam Srivastava, the programme officer monitoring the software solution. General manager, RBSK, Dr Manoj Shukul maintained that effective monitoring of the programme would go a long way in improving the overall state of child and adolescent health in UP. “The insight gathered from the programme will help us bring down the infant and under-five mortality rates, besides checking problems such as anaemia,” he said. Apart from skin diseases, close to 9,000 children with severe malnutrition were also identified during the exercise. Vitamin-A deficiency was noted in 5,083 children while 2,622 were found to be acutely anaemic. Over 600 children were diagnosed with rickets, a skeletal disorder caused by lack of Vitamin D, calcium or phosphate. As many as 684 children were diagnosed with congenital heart disease while an equal number were seen with a club foot. Cleft lip and palate were seen among 412 children while neural tube defect was detected in 166 children.

column2: Get 50 into fold, grab a party post: BJP to cadre
column3: LUCKNOW: Seeking to expand its footprints in politically-crucial Uttar Pradesh through its ongoing membership drive, BJP has introduced a competition of its kind among its cadre - get 50 people on board and hold a party post in their respective district. Successful members will also get a chance to choose party ranks at booth and state levels. The party has set a target of making at least 50 lakh primary members during a month-long drive, which is seen to be crucial in the aftermath of UP regional giants SP and BSP severing their alliance. This, political experts said, would allow BJP to make inroads into the core vote bank of SP and BSP which had come together to arrest the saffron juggernaut in the recently-concluded Lok Sabha elections. There are around 75,000 active members of BJP in UP. The decision was recently taken by BJP working president Jai Prakash Nadda during his visit to Lucknow, where he held a marathon meeting with state BJP leadership and tasked them to expand the party in the areas where it is weak. BJP, as a matter of fact, has identified around 30,000 such booths where it could not register a win in the 2017 UP assembly elections and and 2019 Lok Sabha elections. BJP sources said every active party member has been given a bundle of 50 booklets, highlighting the achievements of the state and central governments for being distributed among the people. "Social media platforms will also be used to make primary members," said UP BJP spokesperson Rakesh Tripathi, conforming that those members who are able to make 50 primary members would not only be recognized as a party leader but will also be able to chose party ranks at booth and state levels. Sources said party functionaries have been asked to look out for beneficiaries of the state and the central government schemes and take them into party fold.

column2: Why KGMU’s burn care unit is still stuck in limbo
column3: LUCKNOW: Three years ago, it was announced that the plastic surgery department of King George’s Medical University (KGMU) will have a burn care wing. A year ago, the medical education department claimed it was launching the unit. Cut to present day: the facility is still under lock and key, waiting for the go-ahead to treat patients. The official reason for this inordinate delay is said to be government push for rationalisation of posts and resultant vacancies. According to officials, KGMU had sought sanction for 181 non-teaching posts, including that of grade III and grade IV employees. “We decreased the posts from 181 to 143 after the government’s demand for rationalisation and sent a fresh proposal,” said head of plastic surgery and in-charge of burn care professor AK Singh. “But, the request has been turned down again. The government wants us to reduce the numbers further. We have insisted that all the 143 posts are necessary to start the (burns) unit and that any query can be answered/ resolved in physical capacity for which we will be available,” the professor added. The department, which currently has three faculty members, also needs to recruit seven more plastic surgeons, four anaesthetists and four intensivists (critical care experts).

column2: Mouldable polymer plates to replace metal ones at PGI
column3: LUCKNOW: Metal plates and screws used in delicate facial surgeries will be replaced by mouldable and absorbable polymer plates at Sanjay Gandhi Post Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences. Introduced by the institute's plastic surgery department, the mouldable plates have become the gold standard of precision in plastic surgeries and are also used in brain surgeries in select centres around the world. "The biggest advantage of polymer plates is that they end the possibility of post-surgery complications caused by metal plates. The gain overshadows its otherwise higher cost," said Prof Rajeev Agarwal, the head of the plastic surgery department. He also said that SGPGI was the first centre in UP to be using these plates. From the patient's point of view, absorbable polymer plates can eliminate pain caused by piercing edges and even breakage. "Injuries caused by the edges also prepared ground for infections and created the need for a revision surgery," explained Prof Agarwal. During the surgery, thin polymer flakes are first soaked in a water bath (special solution) to give them a clay-like texture. They are then applied on the affected area to complete the sculpting, explained Prof Rajeev Agarwal.

column2: Uttar Pradesh needs skin bank for 25,000 patients
column3: LUCKNOW: UP needs a skin bank to cater to about 25,000 burn cases reported annually in hospitals across the state. This was emphasised by Dr Manish Singhal, head of plastic surgery department AIIMS Delhi, at a seminar titled "Burn Update" here. Such skin banks are functional in Delhi and Maharashtra. "Skin bank can be created through cadaveric donation. Donated skin can be preserved up to six months for use and does not require matching with the recipient before transplant," said Dr Rajiv Agarwal, head, plastic surgery department, SGPGI Lucknow.

column2: Doctors losing respect due to commercial shift: Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday said respect for doctors was diminishing because of their priority shift to commercial goals. Yogi's observation came at the launch of 'Smile Mashal Jyoti' programme - cleft lip awareness campaign - from his residence in Lucknow. The CM said the emotional connect between doctors and patients was lost in this commercial age. The initiative is an attempt to restore dialogue between doctors and common man, he said. The chief minister's remark comes just days after doctors at Balrampur Hospital and KGMU's cardiac wing faced mob violence. Also, Yogi cited three reasons for failure of government schemes. Either the scheme was unplanned or there was lack of awareness or those responsible for implementation were lax, he said. Describing the 'Smile Mashal Jyoti' programme as a big campaign, he said if majority citizens join the awareness programme, it could be a mass movement. The CM felicitated children associated with Smile Foundation and released a book on cleft care by Dr AK Singh of KGMU. He also honored doctors from different districts. Earlier, a Smile Mashal Jyoti rally was organized at 1090 crossing in the state capital. An awareness campaign was also organised through a street play.

column2: Decked chariot, flowers to see off favourite cop
column3: KANPUR: Inspector of Sikandara police station Shiv Kumar Rathore was given a tearful farewell as he packed his bags after his transfer, on Sunday. The villagers showered flower petals, arranged for a chariot and a band party to take out a procession across the village to give him a royal ride before he left the village. A few months ago, when inspector Rathore got posted at Sikandara police station in Kanpur Dehat, the villagers had no idea about the kind of impact he would leave on the people there. The villagers garlanded him and showered flower petals on him as they bid him farewell. Rajesh, a villager who participated in the farewell procession taken out from the Sikandara police station to the village, told TOI that, "The women-folks broke down before the official and requested him with folded hands to return soon to Sikandara." Only on July 11, similar scenes were witnessed in Mangalpur area of Kanpur Dehat, wherein inspector Mangalpur Tulsiram Pandey was given a farewell after his transfer to other police station.

column2: Riled with non-performance, Yogi Adityanath sacks Lok Kalyan Mitras
column3: LUCKNOW: Upset at the functioning of Lok Kalyan Mitras (LKMs), chief minister Yogi Adityanath has ordered that all LKMs appointed so far will not continue in service after July 15. Lok Kalyan Mitras were appointed by the BJP government with much fanfare earlier this year to help in implementation of social welfare schemes across the state. "The CM had been receiving complaints against them, including the fact that many were not trained properly and none of them were using the LKM application on which they were supposed to have updated details of their work. The agency hired to appoint LKMs also did not perform its job properly. UP Small Industries Corporation will now engage a new agency which will hire fresh recruits," said a senior government official. The decision to replace more than 400 LKMs has been taken ahead of upcoming bylections on 12 assembly seats. The move to appoint 822 LKMs across all blocks was taken by the state cabinet in August 2018 and met with fierce criticism by the Opposition which said that not only was government machinery already in place to monitor implementation of government schemes for which the LKMs were being hired but also alleged that the government would appoint people close to BJP. The appointment carried a monthly remuneration of Rs 25,000 and was to have been for a year, subject to review by the CM. The government had claimed that because of the immense work of implementing more than 100 schemes of the Centre and state, district and block level officials were under lot of pressure and LKMs would have helped in streamlining the work. They had been tasked with visiting beneficiaries in their respective areas to review how schemes were being implemented and connect a larger number of people with these schemes. "The agency started recruitments late and had appointed just a little over 400 LKMs. Because of the complaints with their work, no payment has been released to them for the three months of their appointment so far. We are now looking to overhaul the system and see how many of the LKMs will be paid, depending on the quality of work they have put in," said the official.

column2: 105 students complete IIT Kanpur’s Summer of Code programme
column3: KANPUR: A two-month long programme ‘Summer of Code’ for the first year students of IIT-K for improving their skill development using computing technology for solving various social needs concluded here on Saturday. The programme for intensive training on full-stack development of applications for socially relevant problems started last year by the computer science department of IIT-K. Last year, more than 100 students, who had been trained, showed their acquired skills through team projects. This year, the programme was completely student driven. Three second year students--Tanmay Jadav (civil engineering), Yasarth Bajpai (electrical engineering), Yogesh Kothari (computer science) spearheaded the two-month long programme which was funded by Nutanix and UPSIDC. During the closing ceremony Prof BV Phani inspired the students to take their projects in the programme to the next level of entrepreneurship. Ritesh Ranjan, senior director of Nutanix India also encouraged the students by showing that how some of the team projects this year can lead to successful startups. Twenty-three projects were demonstrated at the closing ceremony from 23 teams, and 105 students successfully completed the programme. Prof Nitin Saxena, Prof Nisheeth Srivastava and Prof Debadatta Mishra of IIT-Kanpur judged the projects and selected top 3 projects for awards. Tech@Farm project bagged the first prize, and the winners are Ishanh Misra, Yash Vardhan Raizada, Dibyojyoti Sinha, Aditya Dikshit and Shubham Gupta. MyMoney project got the second prize. The idea of the project was based on use of UPI, Paytm or any other type of online platforms to make payments. The winners are Vikrant Malik, Divyanshu Bharadwaj, Manas Aggarwal, Aman Mittal, Darsh Sharma. The third prize went to the HealthBuddy project, a web based platform which will make the entire process of health centre paper-less. It will have separate endpoints for various departments like reception, doctor, user, pharmacy etc. Paras Mittal, Sarthak Dubey, Guntas Singh Brar, Nitian Garg, Rythm Agarwal are the winners of this project.

column2: ‘Fugitive’ officer held for army job fraud
column3: KANPUR: A “fugitive junior commissioned officer (JCO)” of the Indian Army, who swindled hundreds of youths out of crores on the pretext of helping them get jobs in the forces, was arrested from the Cantonment area of the city on Sunday. Alok Kumar Awasthi, a native of Bighapur Raithana village in Unnao district, is said to have duped nearly 150 unemployed persons. “The victims are from Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and Bihar. Each was cheated of Rs 1 lakh to Rs 8 lakh,” said inspector (STF) Ghanshyam Yadav. STF sources said Awasthi invested several crores of rupees to raise a palatial house at his native village. “An FIR under relevant sections of IPC has been lodged at Cantonment police station. He was declared a fugitive by the army and is being questioned about his aides. We are trying to get in touch with the victims to know about his modus operandi,” Yadav said, adding that there could be more than 150 victims. Awasthi lured his targets using forged army canteen card, and also conducted physical and medical tests to win their confidence. “He called applicants only through the internet and got the amount deposited into an account with the Union Bank of India,” the STF inspector said. Police had launched a manhunt for Awasthi after several youths filed complaints. A senior STF officer told TOI that they had seized a fake army ID, cheque books, cash and also a car with an army logo. During questioning, the accused has revealed names of some victims. “He duped one Neeraj Agrahari of Rs 2,60,000, Om Prakash Dhushia of Rs 50,000, Rajveer Singh of Rs 100,000, Vipin Rathore of 1,50,000, Somlata of Rs 50,000, Piyush of Rs 100,000 and Bhawani of Rs 100,000,” said an STF officer.

column2: Two bike-borne men loot jeweller of cash, ornaments
column3: KANPUR: Two unidentified motorcycle-borne miscreants looted a jeweller of cash and jewellery outside his shop in Bidhnoo area of the district on Sunday morning. According to reports, the jeweller, identified as Ramakant Verma, a native of Sainik Chauraha in Naubasta area of the city, was trying to unlock he his shop located at Gopal Nagar in Bidhnoo, when two miscreants on a two-wheeler arrived and snatched the bag containing cash and jewellery worth Rs 4.7 lakh from him. The jeweller raised alarm and chased them. He managed to catch hold of their bike in a bid to stop them but was dragged for around 50m causing serious injuries. Later, the victim alerted the police control room, which in turn informed the Bidhnoo police. According to inspector Bidhnoo, Anurag Singh, the CCTV footage procured from various junctions, showed two persons coming to the shop on a two-wheeler and later escaping with a bag. The police have launched a massive checking drive in the area. “An FIR against unidentified miscreants has been lodged.We are investigating into the case on the basis of CCTV footages,” said the inspector. Further investigation into the case is underway.

column2: High-tension wire falls on school, 53 hurt
column3: LUCKNOW: At least 53 students sustained burn injuries due to electric shock when a 11,000V cable fell on the rain-soaked walls of a government primary school in Utraula village of Uttar Pradesh’s Balrampur district on Monday. The students were returning to their classrooms after having midday meal when the high tension cable — which had been dangling for months — fell on the building and burst, injuring the children. It also snapped power supply to the premises. While there were 110 children in the school, 53 in the class suffered electric shock. Some of them even fell unconscious due to panic while others sustained burn injuries on their limbs. While 30 children have been admitted to a private hospital, the remaining are in a community health centre. Balrampur district magistrate Krishna Karunesh has recommended action against a junior engineer and suspended a lineman of the power department with immediate effect for failing to remove the dangling wire despite complaints. Basic Shiksha Adhikari Harihar Prasad said, “Eyewitnesses claimed that the wire was dangling for several months and used to swing during heavy rain and wind. Villagers had made several complaints to the power department to remove the wire but in vain.” On Saturday, a tree had fallen over and broken the wire after heavy storm and rain. A rusty electric pole had also bent over one side. While linemen had repaired the cable, they failed to replace the pole. On Monday noon, as the children were huddling inside the classrooms, the pole collapsed and the wire fell over the walls. Instantly, electricity ran through the damp school walls and floor. Officials said power got disrupted within a second of the wire falling, resulting in disruption of supply else there could have been serious fatalities. The panicked teachers and headmaster stopped other students from entering the classrooms and rushed the injured to community health centre (CHC) and to a nearby private hospital. Karunesh said, “All the children are out of danger and some were discharged by evening. As many as 29 students admitted to the private hospital are undergoing treatment.” Chief minister Yogi Adityanath has instructed Karunesh to provide every possible assistance and treatment to the injured schoolchildren. He has also directed the managing director of Madhyanchal Power Corporation to take action against the people responsible for the accident. The CM has ordered the principal secretary (energy) and managing director of UPPCL to start a drive to repair high-tension wires across the state and remove high-tension wires passing over schools.

column2: Ma, will come home soon: A promise they can’t keep
column3: LUCKNOW: Before leaving home on Sunday evening, 23-year-old Siddhartha Dubey promised his mother and younger brother that he would be back in 15 days with his first salary and they would all have a party. In less than 24 hours, the news of his death arrived. Siddhartha, who had recently completed his engineering and joined a software company in Delhi, was among the six victims from Lucknow who were on board the UPSRTC deluxe bus that skidded off the Yamuna Expressway and plunged 40ft into a nullah early on Monday, leaving 29 dead and 23 injured. A pall of gloom descended in the Dubey household at Tiwariganj in Chinhat as the tragic news reached. Father Rajesh Dubey, who works in a plywood company, was numbed to silence as he took the phone call from Agra police. “Bhaiya zinda hain, Delhi se aa rahe hain (Brother is alive and will come from Delhi),” 16-year-old Shantanu made a desperate attempt to console their mother. The scene was equally heart-rending at Motijheel in Para, where 32-year-old Deepak Singh — a senior analyst with a US-based healthcare MNC — lived. He had promised to come home next week to spend quality time with his family. “We were so excited... He loved music and played the guitar so well... How can god be so cruel?” said an inconsolable Vaishali, Deepak’s younger sister. Deepak’s father had died three years ago and he was the eldest among four siblings. Parents of Dheeraj Pandey (30) were looking for a suitable match for him. “He was working with a pharmaceutical company and had a job that made him travel a lot. We wanted him to settle down,” said a grief-stricken father Prem Prakash Pandey while leaving for Agra from Gomtinagar to receive the body. Intkhab Ahmad (45) was the lone breadwinner of his family of four. He worked at a paan masala firm in Delhi and visited his family once every month. Before leaving, he had told his 83-year-old father that he would come home for Bakri Eid on August 12. His wife is shell-shocked while daughter, a Class V student, still doesn’t know that her father won’t come home with gifts ever again.

column2: Veering off ideology cost L K Advani his job, BJP tells its cadres
column3: LUCKNOW: BJP has kicked off special training camps for its cadres where they are being specially tutored that any drift from the core ideology of nationalism could cost them their job. To buttress this point, Sangh trainers are citing a case study of none other than BJP patriarch L K Advani, who lost his job as party president after he praised Pakistan founder M A Jinnah as “secular” in 2005. Speaking to TOI, UP BJP vice-president J P S Rathore said no person is above ideology. “And that’s what party ranks are being told. They are being given instances of top leaders, including Advani ji, who lost their job after drifting from party’s ideology,” Rathore, who is overseeing the training camps being organised in all six regions of the state, said. Another case study for the grassroots cadres is former Uttar Pradesh CM and once a poster boy of the Ayodhya movement, Kalyan Singh, who had to quit BJP after he announced support to Samajwadi Party in 2009. His cooling off period continued till 2014, when he rejoined the party and was later appointed Rajasthan governor. “There are numerous cases. Where is former Gujarat BJP veteran Shankersinh Vaghela today? Nowhere,” Rathore said.

His posters are a common sight at election rallies of Vaiko's MDMK, Thol Thirumavalavan's VCK, Seeman's NTK, Ramadoss's PMK and T Velmurugan's TVK, showing their solidarity.'Waze destroyed 5 mobiles on day Hiran's body found'Two police inspectors and a senior police officer of Mumbai police are under the scanner and are likely to be summoned by the NIA in a day or two in connection with Mansukh Hiran's murder case. Sachin Waze, the key accused, has reportedly told NIA that on March 6, a day after Hiran's body was found, he destroyed five mobile phones, including his official one.“There are numerous cases. Where is former Gujarat BJP veteran Shankersinh Vaghela today? Nowhere,” Rathore said.

column2: Lucknow: Four schoolkids hurt after school van collides with bus, overturns
column3: LUCKNOW: Four schoolchildren suffered head and limb injuries on Monday morning after their van collided with a bus at Samtamulak Chowk due to rash and negligent driving of the van driver. This is the second such incident in the past five days. Driver Shahrukh Khan (20) also suffered head injuries but was later arrested on charges of gross negligence. Barely two years over the legal driving age, he did not have the five-year driving experience required for school vehicles. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.Neither he nor the children sitting in the front seat were wearing seat belts. Police have also booked the van owner and school administration in the FIR, charging them with negligence that endangered life of children. Khan, police said, was driving on the wrong side when the accident occurred around 6.40am. Instead of driving around the roundabout, he took a wrong turn at Samtamulak crossing and the van hit a UPSRTC bus coming from the opposite direction. Back from the jaws of death: ChildThe van turned turtle, injuring four students-—Shivani Yadav (10), Anurag Yadav (15), Sahana Khan (15) and Ankur Yadav (15)—all students of a private school in Virat Khand. Locals rescued children and took them to hospital as well as informed their parents and police. TOI visited the injured students in the hospital. Anurag, who suffered injuries on the head and shoulder, said he was in the front seat while his sister Shivani along with Sahana and Ankur was in the back seat. “Neither I nor the driver was wearing the seat belt. As the van collided with the bus, I felt I would die. I lost consciousness for some time,” said a dazed Anurag. When he gained consciousness, he recalled, he heard Sahana and Shivani screaming. “People around us had started helping us out of the van,” he said. Class V student Shivani, who has diabetes, lost a lot of blood due to a head injury and cuts made by glass shattered from the window pane. “I felt a shooting pain in the head after the accident and within seconds, blood was all over my face and clothes,” she narrated the horrifying incident. Sahana, a class XI student, said, “After the car rolled over, I felt like I was going to die. There was blood everywhere and people had surrounded us. A man brought us to hospital in his car.” Khan said he had started driving the school van about a week ago. Before that, he drove a pick-up truck for a dairy company for about one-and-ahalf years. Shivani and Anurag’s father Raj Kumar (37) said he pays a fee to the school for van facility and therefore, the school is also accountable for ensuring safety of children. Supporting Kumar’s statement, Sahana’s mother Resham Bano said, “My husband works abroad and there is no one to help me if something happens to my child.” SP north Sukirti Madhav said, “We have registered a case of negligence against the school administration, vehicle owner and van driver.” Assistant regional transport officer Sanjeev Gupta said, “As per guidelines, the school van driver must have five-year experience but here was a 20-year-old. A person can obtain a driving licence only after 18 years of age, hence he did not have the required experience. The owner has to ensure these guidelines are being adhered to.”

column2: UP: Now, restaurants selling liquor can stock more
column3: LUCKNOW: Expensive brands of liquor, often unavailable at most restaurants, may now be easier to get. To improve the availability of liquor in the state, the cabinet has approved a proposal to allow restaurants and commercial establishments to stock mono cartons of liquor which costs more than Rs 4,000 per bottle. Till now, they were required to purchase a full carton of any liquor that they would be selling, often making it unviable to stock expensive brands. Now, they will be free to stock as many bottles as they like. The revisions in the excise policy have made it further difficult to sell illicit liquor, bringing in strong penalty for selling or distributing illicit liquor. Meanwhile, the penalty for selling liquor at a rate higher than the MRP will also invite a higher penalty. For the first violation, the new penalty is Rs 75,000 while the fine on the second violation is Rs 1.5 lakh. If violations continue, the seller will lose the licence. The amendments in the policy have also eased the rule on supplying liquor within three days of receiving the work order. At present, the rule states that all distilleries will ensure that liquor is supplied within three days of receiving indent. If they are unable to do so, they will be charged a penalty at the rate of 0.5% for each day of delay in supply. However, since there are many distilleries already at peak production but which are still unable to meet the demand within three days of receiving an order, it has been decided to exempt such distilleries from paying the fine. column2: Kanpur family goes missing from Jhansi
column3: JHANSI: A family from Kanpur went missing from Jhansi under mysterious circumstances. They were last seen on Friday evening when their car crossed Semri toll plaza near Moth at 7.23pm. According to the sources, Amit Kesarwani, a businessman from Sisamau, Kanpur left his home along with his wife, Laxmi, and three children on July 12. They were planning to visit Varanasi however their last location was traced at Chitra crossing in Jhansi after which their phone was found switched off. Latest CommentSurprised why they had to travel to Jhansi if the intended destination was Varanasi. Anyway hope the family is safe .Sukumar IyerSee All CommentsAdd commentOn their sudden disappearance, Vinod Kesarwani, Amit’s brother-in-law reached Jhansi on July 13 and met SSP Jhansi. “We have got assurance from the Jhansi police for their cooperation and are now waiting for some breakthrough. we are trying to gather details of GPS of their vehicle. We are now planning to lodge a police complaint here at Kanpur,” said Vinod denying having received any ransom call. He returned after a massive search on possible locations including railway station, bus stand and hotels on July 14. SSP Jhansi, OP Singh said, “We are trying to trace location of the missing family and are working on all possibilities.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. column2: 60-year-old walking on footpath hit by car, dies
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 60-year-old pedestrian was killed by a speeding car near Link Road on Sunday. “The accident took place when the deceased was going to Mohan Nagar area from Sahibabad Sabzi Mandi along with his son,” police said. According to police, the deceased was identified as Mahadev Jha, a resident of Sahibabad. Laxmi Chauhan, SHO, Link Road police station told TOI that the incident happened on Sunday night around 8pm, when the father-son duo were going towards Mohan Nagar. “A speeding Swift Dzire car hit Mahadev from behind and he received injuries on his head and other parts of the body. As per some eyewitnesses, the speed of the vehicle was over 60kmph. The driver fled with the car after the incident,” Chauhan said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.She added that the police received the information from a passerby and a team immediately reached the spot and took him to a private hospital in Mohan Nagar. Mahadev died around 10am on Monday during the treatment. “On the basis of the complaint filed by Mahadev’s son, an FIR has been lodged under sections 279 (Rash driving or riding on a public way) and 304A (Causing death by negligence) of IPC against the unknown person,” the SHO said.

column2: Mid-air scare: Flight hovers over 3 airports
column3: Lucknow: Bad weather forced a Mumbai-Delhi Vistara flight with 180 passengers onboard to finally make an emergency landing with minimum fuel at Lucknow airport on Monday, but not before criss-crossing the skies for two hours over three other airports, where it was denied touchdown. Around 5 pm, the Mumbai-Delhi Vistara-944 airlines was told by Air Traffic Control at Indira Gandhi International (IGI) that it cannot land due to bad weather. While the flight was hovering over IGI, the aircraft was diverted to Lucknow. But when the plane was about to touchdown at Amausi, the pilot encountered windy weather and low visibility and sought diversion to Kanpur. The flight was diverted to Kanpur, but again it failed to land after ATC, Kanpur, denied permission. By this time, passengers and crew were on the edge and an SOS was sent to ATC Lucknow that the plane was low on fuel and needed swift landing. The pilot sought diversion to Bamrauli airport, Allahabad. After covering 40 miles, the pilot received an alert from ATC Lucknow that weather had normalized and landing was possible at Amausi. The pilot again took a U-turn towards Lucknow. Before touchdown, the pilot received an emergency alert from the aircraft system about low fuel. However, the plane successfully landed around 6.50 pm. Till late night, the flight was stationed at Amausi and passengers were served food at airport. Latest CommentIts safety breach... DGCA wake up call - what was tye level of fuel that the flight could not stay aflot for another hour and ran out of fuel... when the capacity of A 320 / B747 which Vistara has co...Read MoreAaaa BbbbSee All CommentsAdd commentSpokesperson of Vistara, Shabih Rizvi, confirmed to TOI about multiple diversions of the flight before it landed safely at Lucknow airport. “The flight is scheduled to take off for Delhi after midnight,” said Rizvi. The situation at Amausi airport from 6 pm till late night remained chaotic

But when the plane was about to touchdown at Amausi, the pilot encountered windy weather and low visibility and sought diversion to Kanpur. The flight was diverted to Kanpur, but again it failed to land after ATC, Kanpur, denied permission. By this time, passengers and crew were on the edge and an SOS was sent to ATC Lucknow that the plane was low on fuel and needed swift landing. The pilot sought diversion to Bamrauli airport, Allahabad. After covering 40 miles, the pilot received an alert from ATC Lucknow that weather had normalized and landing was possible at Amausi. The pilot again took a U-turn towards Lucknow. Before touchdown, the pilot received an emergency alert from the aircraft system about low fuel. However, the plane successfully landed around 6.50 pm. Till late night, the flight was stationed at Amausi and passengers were served food at airport. Latest CommentIts safety breach... DGCA wake up call - what was tye level of fuel that the flight could not stay aflot for another hour and ran out of fuel... when the capacity of A 320 / B747 which Vistara has co...Read MoreAaaa BbbbSee All CommentsAdd commentSpokesperson of Vistara, Shabih Rizvi, confirmed to TOI about multiple diversions of the flight before it landed safely at Lucknow airport. “The flight is scheduled to take off for Delhi after midnight,” said Rizvi. The situation at Amausi airport from 6 pm till late night remained chaotic

column2: Lineman electrocuted while fixing electric pole
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 32-year-old contractual lineman died after getting electrocuted and falling from a 25-feet electric pole while trying to fix power supply in Meerut road Industrial area on Monday morning. Latest Commentcost of an Indian''s life= 5 lacsVishwas SaxenaSee All CommentsAdd commentAccording to reports, the power supply was interrupted in Sihani Chungi. Ravi along with other staff had gone to the spot around 6.30 am on Monday to fix the issue. Officials said the power supply was shut from the powerhouse. Suddenly, Ravi was electrocuted by the power flow in the cable. He fell and hit his head on a wall before hitting the ground. Sunil Kapoor, superintendent engineer, said, “A detailed inquiry will be conducted. The family of the deceased had been given a cheque of Rs 5 lakh as an immediate relief.”

column2: New Ghaziabad DM has tough task at hand: Tackling pollution
column3: GHAZIABAD: The issue of pollution and traffic management will be on top of the priority list, Ajay Shankar Pandey, who took charge as the district magistrate of Ghaziabad, said on Monday. Pandey, a 2005 batch IAS officer, also that said he will ensure to provide a “transparent, responsive and corruption-free administration”. He, however, said his immediate priority will be to organise a smooth Kanwad Yatra, as chief minister Yogi Adityanath during his recent visit to Muzaffarnagar had laid emphasis on it. Pandey was the district magistrate of Muzaffarnagar before taking up the new post. Latest CommentDelhi Public world school SUBHANPUR will be open tomorrow. They are not following orders please take strict actiondeepak kumarSee All CommentsAdd comment“Ghaziabad is not new to me, as in the past, I had served the place as the municipal commissioner and the chief development officer. That was about 10 years ago and a lot has changed since then,” he said. “Pollution and traffic management have emerged as challenges and so is solid waste management. I will ensure that these problems are dealt with as effectively as possible.” “Apart from this, I will work to provide a transparent, responsive and corruption-free administration. The development index in the urban and rural areas vary, as focus is on the urban areas. But I hope to provide balanced development to both areas and it is something that I intend to take up soon,” added Pandey. Pandey came to limelight in 2014 when he was seen sweeping his office floor with a broom. One of his old acquaintances said: “Every morning, first thing he did after entering his office was that he swept the office floor himself, much to the amusement of his subordinates. I don’t know if he still does it. But I have heard that he continued with the practice wherever he was transferred.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Rivers swell, flood threat in twin districts
column3: LUCKNOW: Flood threat looms large over Lakhimpur Kheri and Balrampur, with rivers Sharda and Rapti breaching the danger mark on Monday. Rivers Ganga and Ramganga also continued to swell in several parts of the state. The situation, however, improved slightly on Monday as rivers in various places showed a receding trend. On Monday, Sharda at Palia Kalan in Lakhimpur Kheri was at least 0.6 metres above the red mark, but the water level was stable. Rapti, which was recorded at 0.3 metres above the danger mark, continued to rise in Balrampur. Ganga showed a rising trend in Kanpur Dehat, Farrukhabad, Kannauj, Ghazipur and Ballia. In a welcome relief from last week, the river ebbed in Kanpur city, Allahabad and Varanasi. UP irrigation department has been monitoring the water level of at least 20 rivers in the state since June. The rivers have been on a rising spree since July 3. Ganga, Ramganga, Betwa, Ken, Chambal, Gomti, Yamuna, Gandak, Kuaon, Rohini, Rapti, Ghaghra, Suheli, Sharda, Kunhara , Saryu Babai, Boodhi Rapti and Chhoti Gandak are the major rivers under constant monitoring in the state. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Ramganga was rising at all the four monitoring stations in Moradabad, Bareilly, Bijnor and Shahjahanpur, while Yamuna was on the rise in Agra.

column2: Salary of 16 GDA staffers held back for delaying work
column3: GHAZIABAD: The vice-chairperson of Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA), Kanchan Verma, has withheld a month’s salary of 16 junior engineers for failing to complete work within the time specified on two portals of the development agency and the UP government. Verma has recently issued an order saying that the salaries of more employees would be held back if the two portals show pending work. “According to the office order issued recently, the salaries of 12 junior engineers in the property department and four in the enforcement department have been withheld as they failed to wrap up work within the stipulated time,” said Verma. “They have been given time to finish off the work, failing which a departmental inquiry could also be initiated against them,” she added. Verma said she had withheld her own salary for 10 days when projects failed to be completed in time. “As GDA vice-chairperson, it is my overall responsibility to oversee the progress of progress. Since the order is binding on all employees, including the vice-chairperson, I delayed my own salary of 10 days and availed it only when 80% of a project was cleared,” said Verma. “The erring employees were also found to be lagging in clearing complaints raised through the UP government’s janhit portal,” Verma added. Latest Commentvery good decisionKeysman KSee All CommentsAdd commentThe GDA had recently introduced a single-window system in an attempt to ensure transparency and accountability in the overall working of the agency. The window system was created to attend to public queries, complaints and keep track on work progress of different departments. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Each project generated in the system has been assigned a time period, under which the department concerned will have to wrap it up. The work progress in the system is directly monitored by the GDA vice-chairperson, secretary and chief engineer. Any inordinate delay invites explanation from the department or the desk concerned and action, such as withholding salaries, is initiated in case of unsatisfactory replies.

column2: Two municipal bodies to raise Rs 350 crore via bonds
column3: LUCKNOW: For the first time in the state, two municipal corporations, Lucknow and Ghaziabad, will float bonds to raise funds for infrastructure projects. The cabinet, which met on Monday as chief minister Yogi Adityanath will be in Gorakhpur for Guru Purnima celebrations on Tuesday, the day usually reserved for cabinet meetings, has cleared the proposal to raise funds through bonds. Lucknow Municipal Corporation is to raise Rs 200 crore for water and sewerage projects while Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation needs to raise Rs 150 crore for tertiary treatment of sewage. “This is the first time that something like this is being undertaken in UP. Some municipal corporations like in Ahmedabad have issued bonds in the past. These will be 10-year bonds and we have identified projects which will give a good return so that we can also meet interest payment charges through them,” said Manoj Singh, principal secretary, urban development. The bonds will fetch interest at the rate of 8.5-9%, as per the market rate. Singh added that under a central scheme, for raising funds of Rs 200 crore, the Centre will give a subsidy of Rs 26 crore, thereby effectively bringing down the rate of interest to 8-8.5% for the government. “We have made a presentation on this to BSE and will be issuing bonds as per Sebi guidelines. By undertaking such a method of raising funds, we will also be putting the functioning of corporations to test ,” said Singh. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.
