column2: Teach epics in varsities, says ABVP
column3: LUCKNOW: Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarthi Parishad wants the inclusion of the epics, Ramayana and Mahabharata, in the new education policy draft on the premise that they are not just religious textbooks but are the basis of various scientific inventions. The suggestion was made by ABVP all India university in-charge Shreehari Borkar at a talk on the ‘education policy’ at Lucknow University on Monday. “The fact that Laxmanrekha (a line drawn by Laxman to protect Sita in the Ramayana) actually exists has been proven in a research done in Germany. The research scientifically proves that Laxmanrekha is a line which one can cross but cannot re-enter,” he said. Borkar said our education system should be made India centric as we have given maximum scientific concepts to the world. The scientific methods of agriculture originated in India and yet we study the American agriculture policy, he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Overloaded school vans? Parents will face action
column3: LUCKNOW: After two accidents involving school vans due to negligence of drivers were reported in one week, the district administration woke up and issued a slew of directions, including a provision to penalise parents if the vehicle is found to be packed beyond capacity. The decisions were taken at a meeting of the District Safe School Transport Vehicle Committee constituted under the guidelines introduced in May after amendment of the Motor Vehicle Act 1998. The 7-member committee headed by the district magistrate met for the first time on Monday after its constitution. It announced that in case of overloading, parents will also be penalised along with the van drivers and owners, if vehicles are found to be overloaded. “Parents will be made to sign a bond under CrPC,” said DM Kaushal Raj Sharma. “A notice will be served from the ACM courts to such parents. Repeat offenders will be imposed with monetary fine. The onus of children’s security is also on the parents,” he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Regarding the delay in the first meeting, he said it was because the committee was recently formed. The committee also directed all the schools to form a Safe School Transport Committee, that will also include representatives of parents, by August 15 to examine whether the vans are following the rules or not and to decide the fare. It was also decided that all van drivers found eligible will be issued a smart card. The drivers will also have to undergo eye test. It will be mandatory to make students wear seat belt along with the driver. Besides, all vans will have to take fitness certificates by the weekend and install CCTV camera, alarm and location tracking device within three months. “Officers have been asked to ensure vans follow guidelines like to paint van/bus in yellow along with name and phone number of the school and set speed limit and specific seating capacity,” said the DM. Sharma also said that a joint operation of the road transport and traffic departments to check school vans will commence from Tuesday and will continue till Saturday.

column2: Newborn was found at noon, treated 8 hours later
column3: LUCKNOW: Two days after Lucknow police claimed that a four-day-old abandoned girl child was found on Saturday evening, investigation has revealed that the child was actually found at 1pm on Saturday in bushes in Mohanlalganj. This shows that there was a delay of at least eight hours between the newborn’s discovery and the required medical treatment to have begun at the government hospital where she was admitted on Saturday. When TOI spoke to SHO Mohanlalganj Gaudin Shukla on Sunday and Monday, he maintained that the newborn was found at 7pm on Saturday evening. “Information was received on dial 100 at 7pm on Saturday and immediately a sub-inspector was sent to the site,” he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.However, investigating officer Rafi Alam confirmed that the child was found on Saturday afternoon. “Village watchman Ram Sagar heard the child’s wails and found her at 12.30pm on Saturday. The police were informed at 1pm and the child was rushed to the nearest community health centre with an Asha worker.” The child was referred to Veeranagana Avanti Bai women’s hospital. “The child was taken there between 4.30pm and 5pm,” added Alam. The Child Welfare Committee (CWC) that has raised questions on the delay in providing medical treatment to the child at the hands of the police and healthcare worker, has, however, said that there is discrepancy between the time the girl was found and the time she got treatment. “Around 12.30pm, I received a call from someone from Mohanlalganj police station saying a newborn girl child has been found. I told the caller to contact Childline on its 1098 helpline and get the child admitted,” said CWC head Kuldeep Ranjan. However, Childline got the call only at 8pm. “When we reached the hospital, the process of patient admission was underway. Around 9pm, the newborn was finally admitted for treatment,” said Childline member Brijendra. The child is now in a private hospital. Following the botched-up rescue, the CWC had summoned both Mohanlalganj SHO and the Asha worker to their office on Monday. SHO did not turn up on the day. “The information of the summons came late and we don’t know why we are being called,” said SHO Shukla.

column2: Officer spoke to mother 5 minutes before fatal fall
column3: LUCKNOW: Former deputy commandant in Indian Coast Guard Sneha Kathayat (32), who fell to death from the ninth floor of her apartment building on Rae Bareli Road on Sunday, had spoken to her mother five minutes before the incident. SHO SGPGI Ashok Saroj told TOI that call detail records showed that Sneha called her mother Suman around 8.20am and the call lasted till 8.40am. “Five minutes after that call, Sneha is seen in the CCTV coming out of her flat on the second floor and going towards the lift. At 8.45am, she is seen coming out of the lift on the eighth floor and rushing to the staircase for the terrace on the ninth floor,” he said. “We don’t know what happened in the five minutes after the call with her mother ended and she fell to death. Nobody was seen in the CCTV footage to be entering or leaving the terrace an hour before or after the incident. There should be a strong motive for suicide which we haven’t found yet,” he said. “We are waiting for her parents to arrive,” he added. Investigation have revealed that Sneha had taken voluntary retirement from the service on July 3, and come to Lucknow on July 6 to stay with the family of her husband’s elder brother. He husband, Arvind Kumar Singh, is a pilot with a private airline. Sneha reportedly had a tiff with Arvind after he stopped her from going to Goa for a martial arts course. Arvind was in Pratapgarh at the time of the incident and came to Lucknow on Sunday.

column2: Some monsoon masti for Lucknowites
column3: It was raining, but without any clouds in the sky. Yes, you read it right! Lucknowites had loads of fun at this recently organised rain dance party by a private club in the city. The party had people coming in large numbers. It was not only the youngsters who had fun, but even adults and kids. The rain dance party kick-started at night around 10 pm and went on till wee hours. (L) Akanksha and Shweta (R) Lavanya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Akanksha and Shweta (R) Lavanya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Dancing was the highlight of the do where guests were seen dancing to hit Bollywood tracks like Kaala Chashma, The Hookup Song, Tip Tip Barsa Paani, etc. Some people were also spotted dancing with their umbrellas under the artificial showers. column2: Alladin cast enjoys rains in Lucknow
column3: Actor Siddharth Nigam was recently in the city along with actress and co-star Avneet Kaur. And since it wasn’t their first visit here, the two had lots to share about their memories of the city. But before they could start about that, both Siddharth and Avneet shared how coming to Lucknow was like a nightmare this time. "Because of the thunderstorm and heavy rainfall in the city, there was a lot of turbulence in the aircraft. Ek toh waise hi I am scared of travelling in planes upar se this turbulence. I was really frightened during the landing at the Lucknow airport," shared Avneet, to which Siddharth jokingly added, "So aise swagat hua humara Lucknow mein!" But the two love monsoons otherwise. "I love having adrak waali chai and pakoras when it rains. Monsoon is my absolute favourite season," said Siddharth Nigam of Dhoom 3 fame. Avneet, who was also seen in the movie Mardani, added, "I love and hate monsoon at the same time. Hate because monsoons in Mumbai are really terrible as there is water logging everywhere. But yes, as a weather, monsoons are really romantic!" Coming back to their Lucknow connection, Siddharth, who is from Allahabad, says he has been to the city several times. "I feel well connected with Lucknow. It’s a beautiful city and I have explored it thoroughly because I have my relatives here. I’ve been to Hazratganj, Chowk, Rumi Darwaaza, and even the parks here. I remember going to Janeshwar Mishra Park in Gomti Nagar. It is huge!" said Siddharth, adding, "I have some emotional memories of the Passport Office here as I got my passport made here for the very first time. The officials their were very kind and helpful.” Avneet, on the other hand, said, “I have visited Lucknow several times myself. I happen to have a very close friend living here and I try to meet her every time I visit Lucknow." Siddharth Nigam (and Avneet Kaur (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Siddharth Nigam (and Avneet Kaur (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The teenage stars who have been showered with praise for their reel life chemistry in the serial Alladin - Naam Toh Suna Hoga, claim to be just good friends. "Siddharth is an amazingly supportive person. He’s a wonderful co-star to work with. Sid saves me from hurting myself on the set. He helps me with all my stunts and action sequences. He’s been my best friend since we worked together on the show Chandra Nandini. We keep playing pranks on one another on the sets and that makes shooting all the more fun. But we are not a couple," said Avneet. Siddhart, who has also worked with Aamir Khan in Dhoom 3, said, "Avneet and I share a very close bond. We have been blessed to receive much appreciation from the public for our onscreen chemistry and we’re very grateful. Avneet helps me up my social media game. She tells me what to upload on Instagram, how to upload and other little things since she’s so active on social media. I, on the other hand, help her with action sequences. So our bond is really different and unexplainable." Interestingly, both Siddharth and Avneet also share a very close bond with their respective mothers. So much so, that the two were accompanied by their moms to Lucknow. "My mother is my world. While a lot of people today might find it unbelievable, but actually my mother comes with me to the sets of my films and serials. Even today she has come with me for this press conference. I am 18, but I am still a mamma’s boy and I have no problem in acknowledging this. I consult her before making any decisions. In fact, it is she only who decides which show I should do and not do. I’ll let my mother only decide a girl for me too, then whether it is a girlfriend or my wife." However, Avneet says she is close to her mom but she gets enough space from her to live her life. "Like Siddharth’s, my mom is also here. But she is very cool and chilled out. Every time I want to go out and chill, I just inform my mother and I’m out. There are times when you can get recognized in public, so I wear my scarf and step out. It’s all cool. I manage to balance my personal and professional life, I guess," said Avneet. — Akash.Wadhwa@timesgroup.com and Yashi Agarwal

column2: Three officers, 36 engineers to be prosecuted
column3: LUCKNOW: The Uttar Pradesh government has approved prosecution of three officers and 36 engineers in the Memorial scam case. The sanction for prosecution was pending for the past two years. Memorial scam worth Rs 1,410 crore had taken place during BSP rule (2007-12). The scam had come to fore in 2013, when the then Lokayukta, in a report to Akhilesh government, had indicted former BSP ministers Naseemuddin Siddiqui and Babu Singh Kushwaha along with 199 others for misappropriation of Rs 1,410 crore. ED had also registered a case after anomalies in the memorial scam were detected during a separate investigation done by the state vigilance department in 2014 which is still on.  On Monday, UP government gave prosecution sanction against then director minerals RB Maurya, then MD of Nirman Nigam CP Singh and then joint-director mining Suhail Ahmad Farooqui along with 36 other engineers in Nirman Nigam. It was found during investigations that Rs 4,276 crore were sanctioned for the memorials, out of which Rs 1,410 crores were pocketed by then ministers and the said persons.

column2: Rains lead to 14 deaths across Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: At least 14 persons lost their lives in the state due to natural causes. Revealing data for 24 hours up to 6 pm on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said that four persons died due to snake bites, one each in Ambedkarnagar and Pratapgarh and two in Pilibhit. Three people, two in Moradabad and one in Shahjahanpur, died when they were struck by lightning.  Heavy rain claimed one life each in Bareilly, Muzaffarnagar and Pratapgarh while one person died in Unnao and Ballia, respectively, in thunderstorm. In Allahabad, one person died due to drowning while one person was killed in a wild boar attack in Azamgarh. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy. Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath asked district administration to immediately release the compensation amount of Rs 4 lakh for the families of the deceased and extend all help on behalf of the state. Between Sunday evening and Monday evening, seven persons had reportedly lost their lives due to natural causes.

column2: Lucknow: Leaking drain spurs 40m road cave-in
column3: LUCKNOW: Commuting on the Sector 14 road in Indiranagar has become a risky affair for three days now, with a cave-in leaving a 40-metre stretch out of bounds for both residents and visitors. The road caved in by 18 feet on Saturday night, as the soil beneath it weakened allegedly due to continuous leakage from a nearby underground drain. The maimed stretch is not only causing traffic disruption, but also frequent accidents including one that took place on Monday. Fortunately, no casualties or grievous injuries have been reported. According to residents, they heard a loud, crumbling noise around 8pm on Saturday and rushed out of their homes to see the road sinking. They barricaded the stretch to warn commuters and informed the public works department. A preliminary inspection by PWD officials has revealed that the damage was triggered by a leak in an adjacent, underground drain. Seeping rainwater, mixed with drain water, gradually eroded the soil base, leading to the cave-in. It is yet to be ascertained for how long the drain has been leaking. Residents accused Lucknow Municipal Corporation of not heeding their complaints about clogged, congested and weathered drains. Municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi said work had begun to assess the extent of drain leak and fix it. "A technical team is on the job. The PWD will rebuild the road once the LMC repairs the drain," he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Ghaziabad: Woman, lesbian partner seek police help
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two women, both around 24 years old, on Tuesday sought police protection from their families, claiming they had got married recently at a temple. The women, originally from Shamli, now live in the Sihani Gate area of Ghaziabad and work at a private company in Sahibabad. They told police they had become friends in college and had fallen in love. They sought protection as their families have now become aware of their relationship. They told cops at Sihani Gate police station they had been living Ghaziabad for the past two months. “The women were told to approach the SSP’s office for seeking police protection. However, we gave the contact number of the police station to them so that they could seek our help in case the need arises,” a police official said. At the same police station, a 20-year-old woman’s family has filed a missing person’s complaint. The BBA student left home on July 12 to be with a woman who was a tenant in her house till March this year while she was doing a nursing course (she is from Hapur). NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Three held for duping policyholders in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: Three youths who were running a fake call centre and allegedly cheated several insurance policyholders in Vijay Nagar were arrested on Tuesday. They targeted people from Odisha and made them buy new policies and charged them money in the name of GST on their old policies. The accused have been identified as Sonu (26), Balram Singh (28), from Bihar’s Buxar who stayed in Vijay Nagar area, and Aman (25), a resident of Sahibabad. They were running the call centre from a building in Sector 12, Pratap Vihar, for a few months. Police recovered Rs 1.9 lakh, phone receivers and mobile phones, registers with details of policyholders, rubber stamps and letterheads from the trio. Vijay Nagar SHO Shyamveer Singh said: “They would tell policyholders that they would help them get premiums deposited. But for that, they were to pay GST. Each person was charged Rs 30,000 to Rs 40,000. The trio would buy new policies and keep the commission.” The fraud came to light after police got information about the call centre and raided it on Monday. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Ghaziabad: Three minors held for bike theft
column3: GHAZIABAD: Three minor boys were detained on Monday night from Indirapuram for allegedly stealing over 50 two-wheelers for joy rides. Police said six motorcycles worth Rs 1 lakh have been recovered from their possession. The boys, aged between 15-17 years, had been stealing two-wheelers from Ghaziabad, Noida and Delhi since December 2017 to fulfil their various ambitions. One of the accused, who is studying in Class X of a private school, told police that after stealing the bikes, he participated in racing along with some friends. “He told us that he wants to become a bike racer in the future,” said Sandeep Kumar Singh, the SHO of Indirapuram police station. “The boys admitted to stealing bikes from Indirapuram, Sahibabad and Kavi Nagar in the past two years,” Singh said.

column2: ‘She buried her sorrow in books’: Now, IAF pilot’s wife to don blue uniform
column3: GHAZIABAD: On the 17th of July, whenever Squadron Leader Samir Abrol could manage leave to come home for his birthday, wife Garima would try to fulfil his “long” wishlist for home-cooked food. This year, she will fulfil his dreams. On Wednesday, the widow of the Air Force officer who died in a Mirage crash in February this year, will write her MBA second semester exams in Bengaluru. She has already cleared the Services Selection Board, which will allow her to don the blue Air Force uniform that his husband would once come home in. “Samir did not want her to sit at home. He wanted to see his wife independent and insisted that she enroll for an MBA course. It was his wish, and Garima has always ensured that whatever Samir wished for is fulfilled. Her exam date clashes with Samir’s birthday this year. It is only for the sake of his wish that she is sitting for an exam on July 17,” said Sanjeev Abrol, Garima’s father-in-law. Squadron Leaders Samir Abrol and Siddhartha Negi were test-flying a Mirage 2000 fighter jet when it crashed during take-off on February 1, killing both. It was not easy for Garima to prepare for the Air Force test and her MBA exam simultaneously. “She was doing it all for her husband. She would bury herself in books, may be to hide her sorrows. Little did she know she would come out a winner. She will now get to wear the blue uniform that Samir once donned, she will be as independent as Samir had wanted her to be,” Sanjeev Abrol said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Garima’s resolve to get into the IAF started with an offer from the officers who had come to meet Samir’s family after his death. Even though the offer had come from the Air Force itself, it was easier said than done as Garima needed to pass the rigorous SSB, which involves a written as well as physical test. Latest Commentgood luck to her brave ladyKeysman KSee All CommentsAdd comment“Never did she step back. Instead, she saw this as an opportunity to be closer to Samir. Her hard work eventually paid off,” Sanjeev Abrol said. Though Garima has cracked the SSB, she is yet to pass the medical test. If all results are positive, Garima will join the IAF academy in Telangana’s Dundigal from January next year. There, she will train for a year to become a flying officer. However, unlike her husband, she will not get to fly a fighter jet but will be given an administrative post. “Nevertheless, she will don the uniform,” her father-in-law said.

column2: Ghaziabad: 78-year-old loses Rs 1 lakh in credit card fraud
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 78-year-old man man lost money to the tune of around Rs 1 lakh after his credit card was used for two fraudulent transactions. The victim, Shiv Shankar Sharma, is a retired chief engineer from Power Corporation and a resident of Kavi Nagar. Sharma told police that he received a call from a number which was registered in the name of a SBI bank manager on Truecaller. Sharma told TOI that around 4 pm on July 14, he received a call on his landline number and the caller introduced himself as a Rahul Bharadwaj, a manager in SBI’s Sector 63 branch. “He asked for my credit card number claiming my account had been deactivated. I told him that my account is active and on the night of July 13 itself I withdrew money by using the ATM card. But the fraudster told me very confidently that my account was deactivated as I had not done the KYC. He took my credit card details, name and address ,” Sharma said. “After an hour, I received two messages of transactions worth Rs 49,999 and Rs 47,999 debited from my account," he added. Rajkumar Sharma, SHO of Kavi Nagar police station said that an FIR has been registered against Rahul Bharadwaj under sections 420 (punishment for cheating) and 379 (punishment for theft) of the IPC.

column2: Ghaziabad: Rainwater harvesting not in place at 280 societies
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) has concluded its inspection on rain water harvesting system in societies. It has been revealed that of the 670-odd societies inspected, 236 have not installed the system. In 51 societies, it was found to be defunct. The GDA vice-chairperson, Kanchan Verma, has given the societies 10 days’ time to install the system failing which the authority will proceed to cancel building plans. Latest CommentRain water harvesting plant should be made compulsory for all the residential and commercial buildings by the govt. Make a Law and tell every body that registry or license will only be given if the b...Read MoreJagdeep SinghSee All CommentsAdd comment“An inspection of 673 buildings/societies across GDA’s eight zones was conducted and it has been found that in 236 buildings/societies, there is no rain water harvesting system, while in 51 it is lying defunct. In 130 societies, the system is under construction,” Verma said. “Only 253 buildings/societies had functional systems in place,” added Verma. In three societies, new systems are being installed. Notices have been issued to societies where the system is not in place. “They have been asked to install it in 10 days after which the GDA will cancel the building plans and the security deposit will be forfeited,” said Verma. The GDA plans to carry out inspections to find out violations pertaining to set back area clause in building bylaws. Set back area is area that needs to be left vacant in housing societies and individual plots. “We will carry out inspections,” Verma said.

column2: It means a great deal to have someone like Salman Khan backing my film: Satish Kaushik in Lucknow
column3: Actor-director Satish Kaushik is a busy man these days. The 'Mr India' actor has recently finished shooting his directorial venture 'Kaagaz', which has been shot in and around Lucknow and Kanpur. He is also kicked about the release of his next in which he will be seen on screen with Kangana Ranaut and Rajkummar Rao. Kaushik, who’s returned to direction after a gap of five years, says he took his time in directing a film because, "I wanted to reinvent myself as a director. The films being made these days have very interesting stories and this film Kaagaz is also one of them." The story of 'Kaagaz' is based on the life of Lal Bihari ‘Mritak’ of Azamgarh, who was declared dead in revenue records and his property was usurped by his relatives. "This story is very close to my heart and I wanted to share the story of Lal Bihari Mritak with the people. I wanted people to know about his struggle. A struggle of a man to prove himself alive to the government." Satish Kaushik and (inset) the article published in LT on Wednesday, July 10, about Salman Khan producing the film (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Satish Kaushik and (inset) the article published in LT on Wednesday, July 10, about Salman Khan producing the film (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The film, which stars Pankaj Tripathi and Monal Gajjar, is also being backed by Salman Khan. Talking about the 'Dabangg' actor, Satish said, "It means a great deal to have someone like Salman backing the film. He is my lucky charm. We were shooting for Bharat in Malta when Salman asked me what I was working on and when I told him about the story of my film, he was really excited and later decided to come on board. Salman has always been a warm person. I have seen him grow as an actor and its always lovely working with him." Having shot the film entirely in and around Lucknow, Sitapur and Kanpur, Satish says he has had one of the best shoots in these places. "We mostly shot the film in a small village near Biswa, Sitapur district. It was one of the best experiences I have had while shooting. It makes me so happy to see that there’s still so much innocence left in villages. It was wonderful shooting there. Also, I believe I was lucky to have shot in pleasant weather," said he. After having earned accolades for his acting in Bharat, Kaushik is now kicked about his next 'Judgementall Hai Kya'. In the film, Kaushik plays a cop who tries to solve the mystery in the Kangana Ranaut and Rajkummar Rao-starrer. "The role I have played in this film is very different from the ones I have played in the past. It’s an important role and I’m very happy to be a part of it," he shared. Satish Kaushik (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Satish Kaushik (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Adding further he said, "These days scripts aren’t that repetitive and so the roles are getting more and more challenging. My role in this film is subtle and different from other humorous roles I have played in the past." We asked the actor about the name change of the film and he commented, "If the earlier name hurts the sentiments of a community, we understand that. Although, I feel it doesn’t really make much of a difference to the film. It is, however, the freedom of a director to choose/select a name for his project." -Yashi Agarwal

column2: A psychopath gigolo’s story gets staged in Lucknow
column3: Staged once again on public demand, this one man show titled Gigolo was a hit among theatre lovers in the city. Based on the true story of a psychopath gigolo who had killed several people, the play revolved around sensitive topics like child abuse and domestic violence. Actor Devang Tewari’s performance was well-appreciated by the audience with several rounds of applause in between the scenes. Devang not only acted in the play but it was also written and directed by him. (L) Arisha (C) Ishita Singh (R) Parth Tewari (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Arisha (C) Ishita Singh (R) Parth Tewari (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Meanwhile, Devang’s brother Parth Tewari was spotted looking after the last minute arrangements. (L) Neha Mishra (R) Prashant and Aman (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Neha Mishra (R) Prashant and Aman (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Pragya Singh (R) Saurabh Gupta (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Pragya Singh (R) Saurabh Gupta (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Swati (R) Abhishek (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Swati (R) Abhishek (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: Ghaziabad: Hit by husband, woman sets self, kids on fire, dies
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 30-year-old woman, beaten up by her husband with slippers, took her 2-year-old daughter and 6-year-old son in her arms, doused herself in kerosene and set herself on fire in Muradnagar on Wednesday afternoon. While the woman and her daughter died, the son, who managed to free himself and run away, is being treated for burn injuries. Om Prakash Singh, the SHO of Muradnagar police station, said the woman, Deepa, took the extreme step because of frequent quarrels with her husband, a daily wage labourer. “Around 9am on Wednesday, her husband Kailash demanded Rs 2,000 from her. The woman refused to give the money, following which she was beaten up with slippers by Kailash,” Singh said. A few hours later, Deepa locked herself in a room along with the children and set herself on fire. Lalit, the boy, ran outside the house after unlocking the door and was saved by the neighbours who covered him in blankets. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“The girl died on the spot, while a severely burnt Deepa and her son were taken to a private hospital in Muradnagar. Deepa was declared dead on arrival, and her son is being treated for burns in the hands,” Singh said. Top Commentwhat was the fault of kids, she should have moved out of his house with the kids, and filled a case against him. Taking self life and of those innocent children is a crime in itself. may God be with their soles.SaurabhSee All CommentsAdd commentAccording to sources, Kailash and Deepa had married three years ago after the woman’s first husband divorced her. “She got the divorce in 2014. Lalit is the son from her first husband while Reena was the daughter of Kailash and Deepa,” the SHO said. Police have been waiting for Deepa’s parents to hand over her body after an autopsy. “After autopsies of Deepa and his daughter, police will record the statements of Deepa’s husband. The bodies of the deceased will be given to her parents for the last rites,” he added.

column2: UP: CBI searches houses, offices of Atiq Ahmad and aides, seize papers
column3: LUCKNOW/ALLAHABAD: The CBI on Wednesday conducted marathon searches at the residences and offices of jailed don Atiq Ahmad and his aides in Allahabad and Lucknow. Several documents were reportedly taken during the operation, which began around 7.30am and continued till evening. The searches were carried out on the orders of the Supreme Court in connection with the case related to the alleged kidnapping of a Lucknow-based businessman. The SC had on April 23 directed the CBI to register a case. The agency had filed an FIR against Atiq and 12 others on June 12. A six-member CBI team from Delhi swooped on the residences of two acquaintances of Atiq in Lucknow. CBI searches premises of Atiq’s aides in LucknowNEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A separate team searched four places in Allahabad, including residential and office premises of the don, who is also a former lawmaker, his son, the don’s in-laws and others named in the FIR. DIG (Allahabad range) KP Singh said Chakia and its adjoining areas were turned into a fortress. No one was allowed to enter the houses and office premises during the search. The CBI, it is learnt, also quizzed close aides of the jailed don. Latest CommentHiSahadat HussainSee All CommentsAdd commentIn Lucknow, the team first searched the premises of a chartered accountant in Krishnanagar and later that of a man in Indiranagar who manages Atiq’s real estate business. A CBI source told TOI that some documents were found details of which had been submitted to the head office in Delhi. Real estate dealer Mohit Jaiswal had filed an FIR on December 28 last year, alleging that he was kidnapped from Lucknow and taken to Deoria jail where he was assaulted by Atiq and the latter’s aides who then forced him to transfer his business to them. Atiq was later shifted to Ahmedabad jail.

column2: 10 die, 20 hurt, 5 held as UP gang goes on shooting spree over land dispute
column3: VARANASI/LUCKNOW: Ten persons, including three women, were shot dead over a land dispute in eastern UP’s Sonbhadra district on Wednesday. At least 19 others were injured in the indiscriminate firing. Five persons have been arrested and six others detained for questioning. The incident took place at Umbhha village, under Ghorawal thana, where pradhan Yagyadutt Bhurtiya claimed to have purchased 90 bighas two years ago. When the village head and his armed henchmen went to take possession of the land, villagers opposed. This prompted Yagyadutt’s men to open fire, police said. Reports said all the victims belonged to the predominant Gond tribe in the village, but police didn’t confirm the same. They, however, conceded that pradhan Yagyadutt was the prime accused. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Chief minister Yogi Adityanath has taken cognisance of the incident and directed DGP to personally monitor the case. He has also directed the district magistrate to make necessary arrangements for treatment of the injured. DGP OP Singh said the two sides had clashed around two months ago on the same issue, but the matter was resolved following police intervention. “We have arrested five of the accused. ADG (Varanasi zone) and commissioner (Mirzapur) will submit a detailed report to the government about the incident and the action taken thereafter within 24 hours,” Singh said. ADG (law and order) PV Ramasastry said pradhan Yagyadutt reached Umbhha and asked local villagers to vacate his land. The latter didn’t budge and voiced their resentment, following which the pradhan’s supporters opened fire. Nine were killed and over a dozen suffered gunshot wounds, the officer said. Akhilesh, Priyanka slam UP govtPolice have taken the bodies into custody and the injured have been sent to hospital. Some have been admitted to the district hospital and the rest are being treated at the community health centre in Ghorawal,” the officer added. Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav and Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra took to Twitter to slam the Yogi government. Top CommentIsn't it more politicians are in making??? The trend we have seen is, higher the crime higher the chances of getting top position to rule the rest of the country!PolSee All CommentsAdd commentAkhilesh tweeted: “Sonbhadra mein bhu-mafia dwara... 9 logon ki hatya dahshat aur daman ka pratik (The killing of nine persons by the land mafia in Sonbhadra represents a culture of coercion).” He also demanded Rs 20 lakh compensation for each of the deceased. Priyanka said the “coldblooded murder of 9 Gondh tribals” was heart-rending. “Is the state government fast asleep? Is this the way UP will become a crime-free state?” she tweeted.

column2: Lucknow: Man bleeds to death from deep gash, spurs whodunit
column3: LUCKNOW: A 31-year-old manager of a private hospital bled to death from an hitherto unexplained stab-like wound in his stomach received at his Vishwas Khand home in Gomtinagar in the small hours of Wednesday. Family members found Vishwajeet Singh Pundir without clothes and bleeding profusely from the deep gash. He was rushed to hospital, but did not respond to treatment. The postmortem report mentions “shock and haemorrhage caused by excessive bleeding” as the cause of his death. A murder case has been lodged against unidentified persons based on the complaint of family members. Police are scanning Pundir’s phone records and an accident angle is also being probed. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Police said the youth worked in Mahanagar and lived in Gomtinagar with mother Mangla, elder brother Indrajeet, his wife Poonam and their daughter Bani. Vikas, a servant, also lives with the family. On Tuesday, Pundir came home around 9.30pm and retired to his room on the second floor. Around 1.30am (Wednesday), Mangla said she heard him banging on her door and screaming, “Mujhe bacha lo… main bed par se gir gaya hoon (Help me… I have fallen off the bed)”. She found him slumped at her door without clothes, covering the stomach wound with a towel. With the help of others, he was taken to hospital. Police were informed around 4.15am. A team led by SP (North) Sukirti Madhav Mishra and forensic experts reached the house. Puddles of blood were found all the way from Pundir’s room to that of his mother’s, besides near the backyard gate. SHO, Gomtinagar, RS Sonkar said cigarettes, ganja and beer cans were found in Pundir’s room. “It is possible he was high, lost control and fell from the second floor balcony. He may have been impaled on the iron railing over the boundary wall.” Latest CommentThe fact that there are no stains of blood on boundary wall or the grill clearly shows there is something fishy in the story. 98% seems to be the case of murder, police should investigate this thoroughly.Utkarsh UpadhyayaSee All CommentsAdd commentThe only problem with this accident theory is that the forensic team found no blood on the iron railing or the boundary wall. The team has though collected a strand of hair from near the backyard gate. SP Mishra said postmortem revealed a 10cm piercing in the stomach and a punctured heart. Two wounds were clinically seen on the body, one in the stomach and another on the back. “We are probing if it is a case of accident or murder,” he said. Cabinet minister Jai Pratap Singh visited Pundir’s family on Wednesday morning. He asked police to thoroughly investigate the murder angle.

column2: Lucknow University teacher accused of tweaking marks on portal, probe ordered
column3: LUCKNOW: After the marksheet racket, a controversy over manipulation of marks is here to haunt Lucknow University. The varsity’s coordinator of physical education Neeraj Jain on Tuesday accused an assistant professor of his department of altering marks he allotted to BPEd second semester students. Vice-chancellor SP Singh formed a three-member probe team on Wednesday. In his letter, also forwarded to governor and chancellor Ram Naik, Jain said he was the internal examiner of the ‘leadership in training camp’ paper and had uploaded marks of 26 BPEd students on the LU website on April 12. “On June 22, the marks were deleted/replaced by an assistant professor of the department with help from some officials in the university administration,” says the letter, a copy of which is in TOI’s possession. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Demanding a thorough probe, Jain has pointed out that only the coordinator and department head had access to the portal for uploading marks, . VC Singh said a panel, led by pro-VC RK Singh, was looking into the allegations.

column2: Crorepati for a day: Snag parks Rs 4 crore in man’s account
column3: KANPUR: Deepak Singh, a vegetable vendor in Labedi area of Etawah, on Tuesday was shocked to find about Rs 4 crore credited to his State Bank of India (SBI) account on its own. It was only after he approached the bank to probe how the money had been transferred to his account, it came to light that the transaction was an error caused by fault in the bank’s server. “I had opened a savings account at SBI’s Labedi branch and till date deposited Rs 39,000 from my daily earnings. I couldn’t believe my luck when I got my passbook updated at the bank on Tuesday, as it showed almost Rs 4 crores in my account. On inquiry, I was told that it happened due to a server fault,” Deepak told TOI on Wednesday. He added, “As soon as I saw my passbook with an entry of Rs 3.94 crore, I started calculations in the bank itself and asked myself as to how this money came into my account,” said Deepak. But the happy moments didn’t last for long for Deepak. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“When I again went to the bank counter and got my account cross-checked, the cashier was stunned to see the hefty amount credited to me. He then apprised his seniors about the issue. I was told that it all happened due to some technical snag in the computer server,” he added. Top CommentNo prize for honest man by bank?Ramesh SachdevSee All CommentsAdd commentBranch manager Vijay Kumar said: “We’ve investigated as to how this could have occurred. It came to fore that the error happened due to a fault in the computer server, which has been rectified and now the account of the customer is showing a balance of Rs 39,000. The account, which was put on hold temporarily, has been activated.” Read the story in Bengali

column2: Few trees? Building plans under scanner
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) is planning to cancel the building plans of all group housing societies and individual plots that have not adhered to mandatory tree plantation norms. In building bylaws, there is a set of rules governing mandatory tree plantation depending on plot size and population and the GDA provides completion certificate only after assurance that the norms will be followed. However, hardly any group housing societies have fully adhered to it. “Compulsory tree plantation is a must as per building by laws but it has come to our notice that many individual plots, group housing societies, institutional and industrial units have not taken it seriously,” Kanchan Verma, vice-chairperson, GDA, said, adding, “We intend to cancel their building plans. We will carry out an inspection shortly.” As per building bylaws , a minimum of two trees at 10 m needs to be planted in a plot area of up to 200 sq m. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“In housing societies, occupancy is the yardstick to determine the number of trees to be planted. As per bylaws, it should be 40 trees per 100 people,” said Verma. “Societies that have erred will be issued notices and will be given time to come up with an assurance. If they fail to initiate any action, their building plan will be cancelled,” said Verma.

column2: Ghaziabad: Woman calls off wedding over dowry
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 27-year-old woman called off her wedding after the groom’s family allegedly demanded Rs 15 lakh and an SUV as dowry. The woman had got engaged to Peeyush Singh, a private firm employee, three months ago. Top CommentPlease Name and Shame the Guilty party. There would be greater punishment than them losing their fake respect & dignity in the society.AmrikSee All CommentsAdd commentHer family said the wedding was supposed to take place on November 22 this year. Peeyush’s father had not demanded any gifts till the engagement ceremony on April 19, but sought an SUV, Rs 15 lakh in cash and gifts for all the relatives after that, the FIR said. “She is strictly against the concept of dowry. She doesn’t want to go to a family that doesn’t respect a woman or honour their word,” the woman’s father said. The father said that on June 25, Peeyush’s family called them over for lunch at their Indirapuram house and complained about arrangements during the engagement. “They said their relatives should have been given gold rings and demanded an SUV and a wedding in a five-star hotel,” the FIR said. When her parents returned home and told what had happened to the woman, she cancelled the wedding.

column2: Lessons from Mirzapur to save schoolkids from dangling wires
column3: LUCKNOW: For 15 years, children in 27 government schools of UP’s Mirzapur district studied under dangerously dangling high tension wires until the district administration stepped in and raised funds through gram panchayats and kshetra panchayats and got the wires removed in March this year. Now plans are afoot to replicate the ‘Mirzapur model’ in other UP districts, specially in wake of the mishap in Balrampur district where 53 children suffered burns when high tension wires fell on the school building on Monday. This model would be incorporated in districts where the problem of high tension wires ricocheting over schools have been reported, principal secretary, energy, Alok Kumar told TOI. Kumar added that all DMs would be asked to study the model and get the high tension wires removed from over the schools. “We assessed the situation and roped in gram panchayats and kshetra panchayats depending upon the expenses which were to be incurred in doing the job,” Mirzapur DM Anurag Patel told TOI. He said the funds given to the gram and kshetra panchayats under State Finance Commission and 14th Finance Commission were used to remove the high tension wires which posed danger to the lives of children. The energy department’s initiative to use the Mirzapur model comes two days after chief minister Yogi Adityanath ordered a probe into the Balrampur incident and asked the officials to frame a long term strategy to address the problem of high tension wires dangling over school buildings. The National Human Rights Commission has also sought explanation from UP government on Balrampur incident and has recommended ex gratia relief for the victims.

column2: Smart traffic system work from August 15
column3: GHAZIABAD: The work of installing the Integrated Traffic Management System (ITMS) across the city will start from 15 August, officials said. The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) on Wednesday finalised company that would be entrusted with the job. “Three companies were in the fray and after analysing their technical and financial proposals, we have finalised one that will go about installing ITMS from 15 August,” said Kanchan Verma, vice-chairperson, GDA. “Earlier, it had quoted Rs 84 crore, including maintenance for five years. But the final price we have agreed on is Rs 76 crore, including maintenance for five years.” Latest CommentThe traffic lights at the Sector 15 and Sec 12 junction Of Faridabad are not functioning since the last few days and is a real hazard as everyone is in a hurryDreetSee All CommentsAdd comment On August 15, the Meerut tri-section may be chosen to install ITMS. The other junctions and cross-sections would be covered within nine months. The GDA had earlier decided to implement the installation of the system in a phased manner. The city area was to be covered in the first phase and NH9 would be taken up in the next phase. column2: UP House to adopt glass half-full policy to save water
column3: LUCKNOW: Taking a cue from Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s appeal for a mass movement for water conservation during his recent ‘Mann Ki Baat’, Uttar Pradesh Speaker Hriday Narain Dixit has decided that only half a glass of water will be served to all in the Assembly in order to prevent wastage of water. More water will be served only if guests ask. On the Speaker’s direction, UP Vidhan Sabha principal secretary Pradip Dubey has issued a departmental order for all officers and employees to pay heed to the Speaker’s concern for water conservation and prevent water wastage. Dixit told TOI that members of the House would also follow the practice. “It has been noticed that if a glassful of water is served to a visitor or a guest, they would take just a few gulps, resulting in wastage of almost two thirds of water in the glass,” said Dixit.“In order to save water, only half a glass will be served initially and more water will be served only when asked for. I have asked my office implement this from Friday,” said Dixit. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.First time, Centre also set up ‘Jal Shakti’ ministryDixit who has been writing on environment protection, reviving dying rivers and pollution in major rivers of the state.The monsoon session of the Assembly began on Thursday. Latest CommentGood step sirKamalSee All CommentsAdd commentIn his ‘Mann Ki Baat’, the Prime Minister had recently exhorted the nation for a mass movement for water conservation as strong as the Swachchta campaign. The Centre also, for the first time, set up a ‘Jal Shakti’ ministry and the PM has launched a social media campaign — #janshakti4jalshakti — and invited innovative ideas from civil society. The speaker of the UP Assembly is the first to respond to the PM’s call for a mass movement for water conservation with innovative ideas.

column2: Woman molested, hubby assaulted on Gomtinagar riverfront
column3: LUCKNOW: Four men who said they were from the army allegedly molested a woman, assaulted her husband and manhandled a policeman who came to the couple’s rescue on riverfront in Gomtinagar on Thursday morning. The four were taken into custody, but later released on bail because the victim reportedly couldn’t identify them. According to the FIR lodged by the woman, who is a resident of Alambagh, she had come to the riverfront for a stroll with her husband around 4am. Five men made a pass at her. When her husband protested, they mobilised a gang of around 15 others and targeted the couple. Her cries for help brought sub-inspector Amarnath Tyagi, who was on routine patrol, rushing. But, he was easily outnumbered. Tyagi, who has lodged a separate FIR, said he responded to the woman’s screams for help. “When I tried to stop the group from assaulting the woman and her husband, they snatched my insignia and roughed me up. I immediately called for back up from Gomtinagar police station and, with assistance, nabbed four of the culprits. The others managed to flee. We took the four into custody and brought them to Gomtinagar police station,” his FIR stated. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Unidentified persons have been booked for molestation and for voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from duty. SHO, Gomtinagar, RS Sonkar said while the incident took place, the woman failed to identify the accused. “As a result, we had to release the four accused on bail from the police station.” Sonkar also didn’t confirm that SI Tyagi was manhandled.

column2: UP: Jolt deaths doubled in seven years
column3: LUCKNOW: Even as the Yogi Adityanath government cracks down on errant power officials responsible for the Balrampur school accident that left over 50 students injured, the Directorate of Electrical Safety (DES) has revealed that the electrocution toll in UP almost doubled in the past seven years. Data show the number of jolt deaths rose from 570 in 2012-13 to nearly 1,120 in 2018-19, which means that three persons lost their lives every day. The highest number of electrocution was reported in 2017-18, with the toll being 1,131. Incidentally, the number of electricity-related accidents has varied between 1,000 and 2,000 in the past seven years. While in 2012-13, 1,048 mishaps were reported, the figure was 1,073 in 2018-19. The highest number of 1,824 accidents were reported in 2017-18. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Cumulatively, more than 5,700 people were electrocuted in over 9,300 accidents between 2012 and 19. Studies have shown that most deaths were concentrated in monsoon, hinting at the importance of weather in these fatal accidents. Principal secretary (energy) Alok Kumar conceded that the situation was alarming. “The department has constituted a team under director (electrical safety) to study the situation and come up with remedial measures,” he said. Kumar added that the committee set up to probe the Balrampur incident had also been asked to come up with strategies to buffer accidents. Officials in the power department said the increase in the number of mishaps followed a rise in electricity network over the years. Latest CommentHiSahadat HussainSee All CommentsAdd comment“We have been raising the issue before the UP Electricity Regulatory Commission and the UPPCL, but in vain,” said AK Verma, president of UP Rajya Vidyut Upbhogta Parishad. Callous attitude of power officials has also resulted in death of animals and burning of crops, Verma said, adding that a delegation would soon meet energy minister Srikant Sharma and apprise him of the situation.

column3: A get-together organised by a ladies club in Kanpur was an entertaining affair. The do themed jungle, was organized at a hotel in the city. Going by the theme, the members of the club came dressed in Cheetah and Leopard pattern attires. Some of them also chose to be dressed as big cats, hunters and tribals. Vinti Seth and Nishpreet Saluja ensured that the do was a success. column3: The wedding ceremony of the brother of TV actor Pranay Dixit, of 'Bhabhi Ji Ghar Par Hain' fame, was a memorable affair. Pranay’s brother Udbhav Dixit recently tied the knot with Preetika Tiwari in a ceremony held at a private hotel in the city. (L) Vinita Singh (R) Neha and Pranay Dixit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Vinita Singh (R) Neha and Pranay Dixit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) While Udbhav’s parents, Suman and Ashok Kumar Dixit looked after the baraatis, Preetika’s mom Sushila was spotted looking after the arrangements. In fact, he used to always joke with me to get married fast so that uska number bhi aa sakey." column2: Bhumi Pednekar’s big b’day celebrations in Lucknow
column3: It was a working birthday for actress Bhumi Pednekar in Lucknow on Thursday, who celebrated the day on the set of her film 'Pati Patni Aur Woh', which is being shot in the city these days. The celebrations began from early morning for Bhumi, who was gifted a chocolate cake and flowers by mother Sumitra and sister Samiksha, who were in Lucknow for her birthday. Later in the day, Bhumi celebrated her day with her co-stars Kartik Aaryan, Ananya Panday, director Mudassar Aziz and producers Juno Chopra and Bhushan Kumar on the shoot location at a house in a colony in Gomti Nagar extension. Bhumi celebrating her birthday on the sets of the movie Pati, Patni Aur Woh in Lucknow with Kartik Aaryan, Ananya Pandey and producer Bhushan Kumar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Bhumi celebrating her birthday on the sets of the movie Pati, Patni Aur Woh in Lucknow with Kartik Aaryan, Ananya Pandey and producer Bhushan Kumar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) A huge chocolate cake was ordered for Bhumi which she cut as her film crew and the cast sang the birthday song. She then fed the cake to Kartik, Ananya, Juno, Mudassar and Bhushan Kumar and thanked everyone for wishing her and organising this little party. Bhumi celebrating her birthday on the sets of the movie Pati, Patni Aur Woh in Lucknow (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Bhumi celebrating her birthday on the sets of the movie Pati, Patni Aur Woh in Lucknow (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Word had spread around in the colony that it was Bhumi's birthday and so people from the neighbourhood also dropped in to see the ‘party’. "It was nice to see so many stars celebrating one star’s birthday and we also got to be a distant part of it," said a resident of the colony. A pic posted by Ayushmann Khurrana on Instagram of their late-night party (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) A pic posted by Ayushmann Khurrana on Instagram of their late-night party (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) In the night, there was more celebration in store for Bhumi as she partied till late at night with former co-star of 'Dum Laga Ke Haisha' and 'Bala', Ayushmann Khurrana and her current co-star Aparshakti Khurana along with her sister, Kartik, Ananya and Juno Chopra, at the hotel they are staying at in the city.

Bornali Bora as Chandi Daasi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Bornali Bora as Chandi Daasi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The auditorium was packed to its capacity. So much so was the craze among theatre lovers in the city for the play that a few didn’t mind standing up to watch it. The play was based on the story Bayan that was written by famous Indian writer Mahasweta Devi. It highlighted communities living in the lower strata of society and being deprived of basic human rights.
