column2: 5.6 crore Indians lived outside their state of birth in 2011
column3: More than 56 million Indians lived in states other than the ones they were born in, newly released census data for 2011 shows. While UP, Bihar, Rajasthan and MP had the highest ‘out-migration’, Maharashtra, Delhi and Gujarat saw the largest ‘in-migration’. Among larger states, Bihar had the lowest number of people migrating into the state with most of the one million plus migrants coming from Jharkhand and UP. In the case of UP, which had just over four million in-migrants compared to almost 13 million out-migrants, a lot of the in-migration could also be due to people from all of India flocking to the NCR cities of Noida and Ghaziabad. In Haryana too, Gurgaon and Faridabad could account for a sizeable chunk of the 3.7 million in-migrants. While the general thumb rule is that states with a high level of development have lesser out-migration and more people migrating into them, census data shows that states like Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh actually had higher out-migration than Bengal or Assam, clearly less developed than the southern states. And Uttarakhand, Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand actually had more in-migration than out-migration. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.People born in UP constituted the largest chunk (45%) of Delhi’s migrant population followed by Madhya Pradesh (41%), Maharashtra (31%), and Gujarat (24%). Contrary to the popular perception of Biharis moving in droves to Punjab, Haryana, Delhi or Mumbai, migrants from Bihar moved more towards the east. People born in Bihar thus constituted 62% of migrants in Jharkhand, 47% in West Bengal, 31% in Assam and other north-eastern states compared to just 18% in Delhi and 6% in Maharashtra. Top CommentNorth Indians are like a Cancer Tumor on your @ssh0le. You can neither remove it nor cure it.DeadpoolSee All CommentsAdd commentIn most southern states, people from neighbouring states constituted the bulk of the migrant population. In Kerala, Bengalis, who constituted 5% of the migrant population were the only significant non-southern chunk, with Tamils (53.2%) and Kannadigas (16.4%) being the most numerous among non-locals. Similarly, in Punjab, Himachal, Uttarakhand and Haryana, people from neighbouring states account for most of the migrant population, though natives of UP and Bihar, too, have a sizeable presence in these states. Rajasthanis mostly moved to Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Haryana. They, however, constitute the biggest chunk of those from the North (5%), among migrants in Tamil Nadu and other southern states like Andhra and Karnataka.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Man branded thief, thrashed and set on fire
column3: LUCKNOW: Mistaken for a thief, a 28-year-old man was allegedly stripped, beaten up and set on fire by a mob in Dewa area of Barabanki late on Thursday night. Sujeet Kumar, who was rescued by police and admitted to a private hospital, was later referred to the civil hospital in Lucknow. Doctors here have said he has sustained 30% burns. SkipA case has been registered against four persons. Three named accused have been arrested and a manhunt has been launched for a fourth who is unidentified. According to police, Sujeet — a Dalit and resident of Tindoli Tauki Mati — was going to his in-laws’ house when he was chased by a pack of stray dogs in Raghupurwa village. The scared youth sought refuge in a shed outside a house in the same village. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Villagers, identified as Shrawan Kumar, Umesh and Ram Lakhan and two others, saw him holed up near the house and began grilling him. Sujeet said he was going to bring his wife back home, but the group didn’t listen. They allegedly labelled him a thief and began beating him up. He was stripped, bathed in petrol and set on fire. Top CommentThe courts due to lack of adequate number of judges and faulty legal procedure  are not able to conduct quick hearing and deliver judgement in reasonable time . Everybody knows ''delay in justice is ...Read MoreRam Dularay VermaSee All CommentsAdd commentSome people alerted UP 100 and a patrol vehicle came to Sujeet’s rescue. He was first taken to a private hospital and later shifted to Lucknow. SP Barabanki Akash Tomar said a case had been registered under the SC/ST Act and sections of the IPC, including attempt to murder and voluntarily causing hurt. “Three persons have been arrested,” Tomar confirmed. Chief medical superintendent (civil hospital) Dr Ashutosh Dubey said Sujeet had sustained burns from his thighs to feet. “He is under observation with 30% burns,” Dubey added.

column2: Lucknow: School manager arrested for molesting Class XII girl
column3: LUCKNOW: A Class XII student of a private institution in Krishnanagar was allegedly molested by the school manager on Friday, prompting protests on the campus that led to the cradle being shut for the day and the accused arrested. According to the complaint lodged by the 18-year-old girl, she was assaulted by Atul Verma in the principal’s office in the morning while the latter was not around. She said she went to the principal’s chamber to collect some documents. She found Verma in the office instead. The manager allegedly touched her inappropriately. She pushed him away, ran out of the chamber and went home, the complaint said. Krishnanagar sub-inspector Pankaj Singh said as the news spread on the campus, other students and their parents staged a protest. Some allegedly broke windowpanes too. “The girl and her parents also took part in the protest. They forced the school to close for the day. Later, the girl lodged a complaint with police.” Pradeep Kumar Singh, SHO of Krishnanagar, said the accused was arrested around 1.30pm from his residence. “He has been booked for molesting the student. We are also inquiring if he had violated other girls in the school.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Verma, in his defence, is learnt to have told police that when the girl came to the principal’s office, he only tried to adjust her badge. The accused is married and has a 12-year-old daughter.

column2: Lucknow cop assaults auto driver, viral video sends him to jail
column3: LUCKNOW: A police sub-inspector was arrested and suspended from duty on Friday after a CCTV camera’s footage, showing him assaulting an elderly auto-rickshaw driver and making the latter touch his feet, went viral on social media. This is the third case in a month where a policeman has assaulted a city resident. Spokesperson for Lucknow police Ashish Dwivedi confirmed that sub-inspector Ashok Kumar Sharma, posted at Manaknagar thana, had been sent to jail after auto driver Chandra Prakash, 63, lodged an FIR. The incident occurred around 2pm on Thursday when Prakash was going home to LDA Colony from Charbagh. The FIR says when he reached near Sarafa police outpost, SI Sharma intercepted his auto on a bike. The cop allegedly dragged Prakash out of the auto and began beating him. The policeman is said to have hurled abuses, accusing the driver of a rash turn that could have caused a collision. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Prakash said the Sarafa police outpost in-charge tried to save him, but SI Sharma kept hitting him with boots. “I even lost a tooth when he hit me on the face,” the auto driver said. The torment continued for around 15 minutes after which the accused left the spot. However, his act was caught on a CCTV camera installed at a nearby shop. Family members took Prakash to hospital from where he was discharged after first aid. Later, his son procured the footage, which went viral on social media. Late on Thursday night, the driver lodged an FIR at Krishnanagar police station. “On Friday morning, the SSP took note of the video and suspended the cop who was also arrested later,” spokesperson Dwivedi said.

column2: UP: An extra fruity boost to government school nutrition
column3: LUCKNOW: Students of government primary and aided schools in UP are being promised more nutrition, with an extra fruit being added to their monthly diet. According to the latest directive from the state authorities, the children will get one fresh, seasonal fruit on the last Thursday of every month, beginning July. With this, the students will be eating fruits five times a month instead of four. Till now, every student was eating a fruit every Monday morning. The project approval board (PAB) meeting in June cleared the provision for an extra fruit per student. “Fruits are not only nutritious, they also satisfy hunger,” said an official. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The erstwhile Akhilesh Yadav government had, in 2016, passed an order to introduce fresh and seasonal fruits in midday meals. The latest directive says fruits with high nutritional value like guava, banana, apple, orange, sapota (cheeku), peach and custard apple will be given to students as morning snack. The idea is to ensure that students get sufficient calorie intake before starting school, an official said. Instructions have been issued to not serve fruits like papaya, watermelon and musk melon, to keep a check on quality and to ensure that the fruits are fresh. Stale fruits are strictly to be avoided. Fruits have to be average in terms of weight and size. “In case the size is small, then the quantity should be increased,” the order reads. Latest Commentup to ho to hain nutrients fir childrens.s mishraSee All CommentsAdd commentAccording to Amit Srivastava, chief accounts officer (midday meal), the Union government has sanctioned Rs 44 crore for distributing fruits for 10 months under a flexi scheme. “The scheme has a Centre-state share of 60:40,” he said. The state has around 1.61 lakh government-run and aided primary schools with an approximate total enrolment of 1.58 crore students.

column2: I am ready to go to jail, will not furnish bail amount: Priyanka Gandhi
column3: LUCKNOW: Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra on Friday night insisted on meeting the families of the victims of Sonbhadra firing incident, stressing that she was ready to go to jail for it. In a series of tweets in Hindi, Gandhi, who was detained in Mirzapur on her way to Sonbhadra this morning, said, "If the government wants to put me in jail for the crime of meeting the victims, I am fully prepared for it. "I have come here to meet the poor adivasis who had faced the massacre and know about their problems. This is my 'dharma' as the 'sevak' of the people and also my moral right. My decision to meet them is firm," she said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy."Uttar Pradesh administration has arrested and kept me in the the Chunar Fort for the past 9 hours and is saying that I will have to take bail of Rs. 50,000 or else I will be punished and put in jail for 14 days but they will not allow me to go to Sonbhadra as this is an order from the higher ups," she said. "I have not broken any law or committed crime. I had made it clear in the morning that I can go alone to meet the families in the adivasi village and the administration can take me there as it wants," she said. Gandhi said the people "are seeing everything" and refused to take bail. Top CommentPriyanka Vadra is moving with half a dozen black Cat commandos still 100% security is not assured. Hence jail is better for Priyanka Vadra, 100% security is assured. RavindranSee All CommentsAdd comment"I do not consider bail in this connection as morally right and am not ready for it. My clear demand is that I be allowed to meet the adivasis. Government can do whatever it feels is right," she added. Ten people from the Gond tribe were gunned down in Sonbhadra on Wednesday after they resisted an attempt by a village head and his supporters to take possession of 90 bighas of disputed land in the district's Ghorawal area.

column2: Vehicles to be weighed at Agra expressway toll plaza
column3: KANPUR: In a bid to curb rising number of accidents, the Uttar Pradesh Expressways Industrial Development Authority (UPEIDA) is installing electronic weighing machines at toll plaza on Agra -Lucknow Expressway to calculate the weight of the vehicle when it passes over it. “If the vehicle is found to be overweight, we will ask the driver to pay fine because they tend to damage the roads and are also unsafe as they topple at times and become a safety hazard,” said Ramesh Chandra Dubey, chief security officer of UPEIDA, who added that excess loading has been damaging highways, expressways, bridges and culverts, thus reducing their lifespan. In case a vehicle speeds away, UPIEDA will send challan through postal service to the offender's address, said a UPIEDA official. “Or, if the violator does not have money to pay spot fine, we will also send the challan through postal service on his/her address,” he said and added, “If one does not pay fine, details of those booked will be forwarded to the RTO for suspension of licences.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The 302-km-long expressway connects Agra and Lucknow via Shikohabad, Firozabad, Mainpuri, Etawah, Auraiya, Kanpur, Kannauj and Unnao. It starts at Etmadpur Madra village near Agra and ends at Sarosa Bharosa village near Mohan Road, Lucknow.

column2: Waterbodies dying, Ghaziabad finally wakes up
column3: GHAZIABAD: Worried about the falling groundwater table, the district administration has decided to go all out to restore and rejuvenate waterbodies. Ghaziabad has around 1,000 ponds and lakes in urban and rural areas, many of which, like Arthala, have been severely encroached on, reducing them in size. Removal of squatters is no easy job and could limit the outcome of this exercise. The step is similar to that of neighbouring Noida, which also fears a water crisis and has undertaken a project to revive wetlands. “There are 791 waterbodies in rural areas and 200 in urban centres. By August 15, we will rejuvenate 180 in rural centres and by September, 68 in urban areas will be attended to,” said Ramesh Ranjan, the chief development officer. “We have already wrapped up work on 57 waterbodies in both urban and rural areas,” he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The cost of restoring waterbodies varies from Rs 1 lakh to Rs 50 lakh, depending on size. The work primarily includes clearing encroachments and de-siltation to augment catchment areas. “Three years ago, we used to get funds to pay workers who were involved in rejuvenating waterbodies, under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA). However, these days workforce is not available at the wage being offered. Therefore, local and urban bodies are spending from their own funds,” said Ranjan. Apart from waterbodies, the administration’s focus is also on rainwater harvesting systems on rooftops. “In every 161 gram panchayats, we have selected one primary school where we have installed rooftop rainwater harvesting systems and we are on the verge of completing 144 such schools,” said Ranjan. “We have also selected 9 offices at block levels where rooftop rainwater harvesting will be done,” added Ranjan. Additionally, 175 soak pits would be dug up in rural areas and 129 in urban areas. “The soak pits are being dug up near handpumps where water is made to sieve through sand and pebbles and this is being considered as an effective way to increase the groundwater table,” said Ranjan. He added three out of four blocks in Ghaziabad are in the dark zone. “Loni, Razapur and Bhojpur have been declared to be in the dark zone where groundwater table has receded to almost 120 feet and water extraction has been banned, except for drinking purposes,” said Ranjan. According the groundwater department, from 2013 to 2018, piezometer readings in urban areas of Ghaziabad also showed that of the 38 spots, 11 have gone dry. This means the water levels have plummeted so much that it did not register in piezometer readings. Makanpur in Indirapuram is one of these spots. The other areas are Krishi Beej Bhandar (Kaushambi), Zila Ganna Adhikarai (Surya Nagar), Bhovapur, Hindon Motel (Patel Nagar), Civil Lines, Lajpat Nagar (Sahibabad), Sikandarpur and Police Lines. The water table has plunged below 30 metres at Vaishali, Maharajpur, Prahladgarhi, Jhandapur, CIPL (Sanjay Nagar), CGO complex (Hapur Road), government nursery (Kavinagar), Dundahera and Pasunda. In Vijay Nagar, it has fallen below 40 metres.

column2: 34-year-old biker hit by truck, dies
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 34-year-old man was crushed to death by a truck in Masuri area of Ghaziabad late on Thursday. The deceased, Suresh Kumar, was a resident of Delhi. He was a clerk at a private company in Noida and was returning home on his motorcycle after meeting a relative in Masuri when the accident occurred. “A passerby informed the police about the accident around 1 am. A truck hit his bike from the rear and the truck driver fled after the accident,” said Praveen Sharma, the SHO, Masuri police station.
