column2: Gomti Riverfront molesters army recruits, say police
column3: LUCKNOW: Police on Friday confirmed that the four men, who were taken into custody for allegedly molesting a woman and manhandling a cop on the Gomti riverfront on Thursday and later released, were recruits undergoing training at the Army Medical Corps of Central Command. Spokesperson for Lucknow police Ashish Dwivedi said, “The accused belong to Army Medical Corps (AMC) unit and were released on personal bond from the police station because the victim couldn’t identify them.” Gomtinagar sub-inspector Sanjay Kumar Gupta, also the investigating officer, said two FIRs had been lodged. “The first by the woman and the second by the cop who was roughed up. We are investigating both cases.” According to the two FIRs, the incident took place around 4am. The woman was enjoying a stroll with her husband along the riverfront when a group of men made a pass at her. They molested her and assaulted her husband when they protested. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.SI Amarkant Tyagi, who was on routine patrol with constable Rakee Tewatia, heard the woman’s cries for help and came to the couple’s rescue, but he was also allegedly manhandled by the group. Tyagi, who sustained bruises on the face and left hand, told TOI that Tewatia called for back-up and soon two more policemen joined them. “Together, we managed to nab four while others managed to flee. The accused tried to intimidate me by saying that they were from the army. I told them that it doesn’t give them the right to misbehave with a woman. I have mentioned the name of all the accused in the FIR and stand by my statement,” he said. The army officer who came to secure release of the men, he denied the molestation. The officer said that the four would be pulled up by military police for violating code, as they were outside the campus without permission.

column2: Lapses in liquor policy cost Rs 24,000-crore loss to UP
column3: LUCKNOW: A report from the Comptroller and Auditor General on pricing, production and sale of liquor in UP from 2008 to 2018 has found several lapses which have resulted in losses of around Rs 24,806 crore to the exchequer. These include irregular creation of special zones to prevent smuggling of liquor into the state which did not include two crucial border districts of Aligarh and Mathura, renewal of licences for retail shops for nine years without any open tendering and undue benefit to distillers by calculation of incorrect ex-distillery price, among others. The report has calculated potential revenue loss of Rs 13,247 crore to the government with the excise department failing to fix the minimum guaranteed quantity (MGQ) of Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL) and beer. MGQ is the quantity that a retailer is bound to sell in one excise year. It should be fixed by the excise department but that was not done. “Short fixation of MGQ of country liquor during 2011-18 led to potential revenue loss of Rs 3,675 crore”, it said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Following the excise policy of 2009-10, the government had created a special zone to check smuggling of liquor into UP from neighbouring states. This zone was to include 15 districts. However, it was found that two crucial border districts of Aligarh and Mathura were left out of this special zone. Meanwhile, seven districts which were not close to the border were included. The report says that while this special zone failed to achieve the desired result, the system continued for nine years. As an example of its failure, the CAG report says that consumption of IMFL dropped by 38% between 2011-12 and 2015-16. Sale of beer too dropped by 6% in the same period. Between 2013-14 and 2015-16, revenue from sale of IMFL fell from Rs 3,672 crore to Rs 3,293 crore. The report further said that the various excise policies between 2008 and 2018 allowed breweries and distilleries to determine the ex-brewery price (EBP) and ex-distillery price (EDP) of beer and IMFL, the result of which was inflated costs of liquor in the state. Compared to neighbouring states, the cost of IMFL and beer was 46% and 135% higher in UP, leading to undue gains of Rs 5,525 crore to brewers and distillers from 2008 to 2018. Wholesalers and retailers also gained to the tune of Rs 1,644 crore due to the inflated pricing. Latest CommentHah you came to know today.. After creating ponty chadha and other mafia.. God help our stateKamalSee All CommentsAdd commentDistilleries further fixed EDP for 180ml and 90ml bottles of IMFL at 187.5ml and 93.75 mlrespectively. The excise department failed to detect this malpractice for 10 years and calculated duty at 180ml and 90ml, resulting in loss of excise duty worth Rs 228 crore between 2008 and 2018. Similarly, the department failed to detect the incorrect computation of maximum wholesale price of IMFL, leading to shortfall of Rs 4.85 crore in 2013-14. It further renewed licences for retail shops for nine years without reporting to open tendering and thereby eliminating possibility of competition in production and sale of liquor.

column2: UP: Photos of teacher sleeping in class go viral, suspended
column3: LUCKNOW: Minister of basic education (independent charge) Anupama Jaiswal on Friday ordered suspension of a teacher posted in Sitapur after photographs showing him sleeping on a mat in classroom went viral on WhatsApp. The action was taken after the minister herself received the photos on her messaging app. The teacher Atul Kumar Mishra employed in primary school Sasirdipur in block Pisawan of Sitapur district was shown to be in deep sleep with a cloth covering his head. He was surrounded by students seated with books on their head. Surprisingly, children too were seated on a cushion on mat in the absence of desk and benches. The picture, taken by someone, through mobile phone soon started doing rounds in WhatsApp. It also landed on the cell phone of the basic education minister on Thursday. Anupama Jaiswal forwarded the photos to basic siksha adhikari (BSA) Sitapur directing him to probe over the viral photos received on her mobile number. BSA Ajay Kumar during probe found that Mishra was a regular absentee and used to sleep in classroom during school hours. Another teacher Rekha Rani was found to be putting signature in advance and showing indiscipline after which their suspension of both was ordered. Anupama Jaiswal said such a lax approach by teaching fraternity would not be tolerated anymore.

column2: Shower of joy after three-day swelter spell
column3: LUCKNOW: A brief spell of heavy rain on Friday evening brought much-needed relief from the sultry weather the city has been grappling with for the past three days. The bad news is that hot and humid conditions will return to torment residents on Saturday. The good news is that a cyclonic circulation developing over the Bay of Bengal is expected to bring widespread rainfall in the state and city from Tuesday. The Friday temperature, which was 28.6°C — three degrees above normal — in the small hours, soared to 37.3°C, also three degrees above normal, during the day. The mercury coupled with high relative humidity, oscillating between 54% and 97%, pushed up the discomfort index. But, the skies became overcast towards evening and the city soaked in 13.6mm rainfall for 30 minutes. The Celsius plunged by around four degrees and the weather remained pleasant till late in the night. The respite will not last long. Met officials have predicted maximum and minimum temperatures around 38°C and 28°C on Saturday. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.State Met director JP Gupta said the precipitation on Friday was due to local clouds triggered by high temperatures and moisture accumulation. “Barring a few spells, nothing is expected till Monday. But, a Bay system may trigger widespread rain from Tuesday.”

column2: Over 6,000 powerline snapping cases in UP in 2 years: Minister informs House
column3: LUCKNOW: UP witnessed over 6,100 incidents of snapping of live electricity wires often leading to loss of life and property in the last two years, energy minister Srikant Sharma informed the assembly on the second day of the monsoon session on Friday. The information comes amid UP government cracking down on erring power officials responsible for Balrampur incident, where a high-tension wire snapped and fell on a school leaving over 50 children injured. The issue came to the fore after SP MLA Mohammad Faim Irfan raised the issue of snapping of wires. Energy minister said that in the last two years, a compensation of over Rs 43 crore has been paid to those affected by accidents related to electricity. To another question raised by BJP's Barauli MLA Dalveer Singh about shifting of overhead high-tension wires, Sharma said that shifting of high-tension wires from houses of people of BPL category is being done through power development fund. Sharma submitted that overhead high-tension wires will either be converted into aerial bunch conductors or would be shifted as per the cost incurred in the work. Sharma said that 15% of the charges recovered through sale of electricity would be used to rectify power infrastructure, including strengthening of dilapidated wires and replacement of bamboo poles with conventional electricity poles. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Inspection bares 17 dengue, malaria vector dens at KGMU
column3: LUCKNOW: A premier state-run hospital doesn’t seem to be practising what it preaches. Health department teams, during a surprise inspection on Friday, found at least 17 spots rife with larvae of dengue and malaria causing mosquitoes on the premises of King George’s Medical University (KGMU). A notice has been served to the KGMU authorities to sanitise the breeding grounds within 24 hours. SkipAs many as 40 teams, comprising a total of 100 personnel, scoured the KGMU premises in the morning. Larvae of Aedes aegypti (vector for dengue virus) and the female Anopheles (vector for the malarial parasite) were found in air coolers at cardiology and psychiatry wards, premises of Queen Mary’s Hospital (gynaecology department), garbage bins at Gandhi ward in the medicine department and in terrace puddles in surgery and paediatrics departments. Similarly, samples taken from flower pots at Buddha hostel for resident doctors, air coolers in the administrative block, garbage bins in the canteen of the Trauma Centre and flowerpots at the police outpost on the campus, among others, were found to be breeding mosquito larvae. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.KP Tripathi, in-charge of vector control in the state health department, said notices had been served to officials responsible for various KGMU departments. “They have been asked to sanitise the areas in 24 hours. We will conduct another inspection after a week and this time, impose penalties,” he added. Chief medical superintendent, KGMU, Dr SN Shankhwar said directives to clean vector dens had been issued. Civil engineers have also been asked to take measures to check accumulation of water, he said. On July 9, a similar inspection had found disease-causing mosquito larvae at eight government hospitals, but no follow-up action was done. Last year, over 570 cases of dengue and malaria were reported in the city. This year, 38 have been reported so far since January 1.

column2: Priyanka Gandhi spent night at Chunar guesthouse
column3: LUCKNOW: Congress General Secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra spent the night at the Chunar guesthouse in Mirzapur district, turning down all requests of the local administration to return without meeting the Sonbhadra clash victims. In a late-night tweet, she said she is ready to go to jail if she is not allowed to go ahead. The second round of talks held between the Congress leaders and local administration late in the night proved futile and Priyanka preferred staying back in the guesthouse along with her supporters, the party sources said. In a series of tweets, Priyanka said Uttar Pradesh government sent ADG Varanasi Brij Bhushan, Commissioner Varanasi Deepak Agarwal and DIG to tell her to return without meeting the victims . NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy."I have clearly statedÂ that I have come here not to violate any law but to meet the victims,"she said and also posted a video showing the officials leaving Chunar Fort in Mirzapur at 1.15 am. In another tweet, she said that her advocates have told her that her detention is totally illegal. "They (officials) are sitting with me for around one hour. They did not tell me the ground of detention nor showed any papers," she said. The Congress general secretary also shared a video of aggrieved Sonbhadra families who were seen mourning the death of their near ones. "Is it a crime to wipe these tears?" she asked in a tweet. Latest CommentNo usd ma'am. The fuse bulbs dont glow. The credibility is lost and pokitics over dead is not acceptable if all appeers to be drama. AjeetSee All CommentsAdd commentMeanwhile, Congress legislature party leader, Ajay Kumar Lallu who was with Priyanka told PTI that water and power connections were cut in the night to force the Congressmen to return but they remained at the guest house insisting on permission to meet the victims. "At around 4.30 am, Priyanka Gandhi sat with the party workers. The government had made no arrangements for breakfast at the guest house. Local residents and party workers are making arrangements," he added.

column2: Four days and counting: No one to pull up reckless school vehicles
column3: LUCKNOW: Are the authorities waiting for a fatal accident to happen before they rein in rogue school vans? The question stems from the chronic defiance of safety regulations displayed by vehicles ferrying students in the city. School vans and buses continued to flout the one-way traffic rule with impunity near Gomti Barrage, as police presence on Friday remained zilch despite promises made by none other than the traffic SP in the past. Violations were rampant in other parts of Lucknow as well. A reality check on Shahnajaf Road in Hazratganj showed several vans packed beyond capacity while students seated in the front had no seat belt on. “I keep telling driver bhaiya that there is no place to sit, but he doesn’t pay heed,” complained a Class VIII student. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The TOI has been highlighting violations for four days now, but has failed to jolt the authorities out of their slumber. On Thursday, traffic SP Purnendu Singh had promised that a team would be deployed near Gomti Barrage to enforce the one-way rule. But, between 6am and 7.15am on Friday, 11 school vans and buses were caught on camera breaching the no-entry lane. DM Kaushal Raj Sharma said he had convened a meeting with SSP, RTO and traffic SP on Saturday. “From Monday onwards, things will change near Gomti Barrage and elsewhere. We will fix responsibility on all stakeholders (vehicle owners/drivers, schools and parents),” he said.

column2: Rae Bareli rail coach factory staff red flags corporatization proposal, holds protest
column3: LUCKNOW: Staff at the Modern Coach Factory (MCF), Rae Bareli, on Friday held a protest at the factory against the Centre’s move to corporatize eight production units of the rolling stock, which is to begin with MCF. RITES, a consultancy organization of the Union government under the aegis of the Indian Railways, has been given 10 days time (since the initiation date) to submit a proposal on the corporatization of MCF. Though RITES is yet to start the survey, staff at the factory is up in arms against the move. On Friday, close to 300 workers protested at the factory gate holding black flags. “It is happening everyday since the start of July. At least 300 workers hold gate meetings on daily basis,” said an agitating worker. Rae Bareli MP and Congress Parliamentary Party chief Sonia Gandhi, on July 2, had raised the issue in Lok Sabha saying that government is “secretly” trying to privatise the factory. “Rae Bareli Sadar MLA Aditi Singh had come to support us. She took our memorandum and has handed it over to the rail minister,” said the worker. RITES will study MCF with respect to “capabilities and capacity, assessment of assets, working capital requirement, inventory sizing for the assessed capacity, other working expenses and over heads”. The study will also include assessment of existing quality systems. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The June 24 letter by the railway ministry to RITES (copy of which is with TOI) has sought consultancy report within 45 days from the date of assignment. “MCF has been chosen because it is most recent compared to other seven units and has lesser staff, about 2,200. Once the units are incorporated in a company, it will be possible for the private shareholders to have a stake. And it could be the first step towards privatization,” claimed sources. MCF has a sanctioned capacity of 1,000 coaches. The factory came into existence to bridge the gap between demand and supply of rail coaches which RCF, Kapurthala and ICF, Chennai could not meet.

column2: HC nod to minor rape survivor’s abortion plea
column3: LUCKNOW: Considering the agony and trauma that the minor rape survivor may face if she has to give birth to an unwanted unborn child, Allahabad high court’s Lucknow bench on Friday permitted her to medically terminate the pregnancy, even if it crossed 20 weeks, which is the permissible limit given in Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971. The court asked her to get herself admitted in KGMU on the day itself. The court also asked a panel of doctors to preserve the residue of the embryo so that it may be available for any scientific investigation. A bench of Justice D K Upadhyay and Justice Alok Mathur passed the order on a writ petition moved by the rape survivor’s father . It was pleaded that the girl was raped and became pregnant. An FIR was lodged against the accused person, who is nearly as old as the survivor’s father. The petitioner pleaded that under the MTP Act, since pregnancy of 21 weeks, as in this case, cannot be terminated and as such it is only the high court which could pass the appropriate direction to permit the survivor to get rid of the unwanted unborn child. On July 17, the court had directed KGMU to constitute a panel of four doctors to mull whether the termination can be allowed in the present case looking to the physical and mental condition of the survivor during pregnancy and after she has to give birth to the child. KGMU counsel Abhinav N Trivedi presented the report in the court on Thursday. The court then requested senior counsel JN Mathur and Bulbul Godial to assist it as amicus curie (friend to the court). On Friday, the two counsels suggested that it would be just to allow the termination. Meanwhile, an application was moved on behalf of the key accused through his advocates Chandan Srivastava and Yogesh Somvanshi, requesting the court that in case the court was permitting the survivor to terminate the pregnancy, the court should pass appropriate direction to preserve the residue of the embryo so that it can be used during investigation, as the accused was pleading for DNA test while denying that he was biological father of the unborn child. The court called upon government advocate Vimal Srivastava to address it. After hearing him, the court directed for preservation of tissues of the embryo after its termination so that it can be available during investigation if so required.

column2: Four land in extortion net while aping web series
column3: LUCKNOW: Four undergraduate students were arrested in the small hours of Friday for allegedly making extortion calls to 15 people, including a doctor and a jeweller, having drawn inspiration from some popular web series. Luck ran out on Sharad Kumar (22), Mohammad Aleem (22), Mohsin Khan (21) and Vishal Shukla (20) because they forgot to switch off the phone used in the crime. The quartet, all natives of Barabanki district and pursuing graduation from a private university, were rounded up from Kaiserbagh area. Circle officer Sanjeev Kumar Sinha said Sharad and Vishal had confessed that they were inspired by internet videos and web series. “The gang bought a SIM card using a fake ID, shortlisted potential targets by researching financial backgrounds, extracted numbers from online directories and made the calls. They demanded anything between Rs 10 lakh and Rs 30 lakh as ‘protection money’,” Sinha said. SP (West) Vikas Chandra Tripathi said investigations had revealed that the gang made calls to at least 15 people. However, only two of the victims lodged complaints. One is a skin and hair specialist in Kaiserbagh and another a jeweller in PGI area. They were asked to cough up Rs 30 lakh and Rs 8 lakh, respectively. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“The gang had a neat plan. The only problem was that they forgot to switch off the phone after making the extortion calls. It helped us track their location and arrest them,” Tripathi added.

column2: Health department all set to tackle dengue, malaria cases in Kanpur
column3: KANPUR: The district heath department has geared itself by taking several measures to check malaria an dengue before they reach an epidemic level. Reports regarding spread of malaria in Bilhaur and two cases of dengue patients in Kalyanpur locality have put the health department on toes, said chief medical officer (CMO) of Kanpur Nagar Dr Ashok Kumar Shukla. Talking to reporters at a media workshop, Dr Shukla said the district administration is alert to check cases of malaria and dengue fever as several cases of malaria were spotted in Bilhaur tehsil. Asha Bahus have been asked to prepare slides of the suspected patients in the town as well as in villages across the tehsil, he added. "They (Asha Bahus have been asked to prepare slides with details along with Aadhar number of each suspect person. Similar instructions have been issued to urban primary health centres and other medical institutions in the city, the CMO said. The health department and Kanpur Municipal Corporation (KMC) have chalked out a joint programme to counter malaria and dengue, the two deadly diseases, which spread as epidemics after every three years and cannot be controlled in the primary stage, he further said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.As many as 40 teams have been constituted for fogging in 40 localities of the city in just one day. Previously, KMC and health department teams used to work separately, but now KMC team would assist the health department. KMC has provided 18 vehicles for the job, he added. The CMO informed that besides LLR hospital, ELISA test kits have also been made available in Ursula Horseman Hospital to identify dengue virus. "The dengue tests will commence at UHM Hospital as soon as the testing regent is made available there". Rs one lakh has been released for buying the regent, he added. Replying to a question, the CMO stated that certain areas in the city had been identified as malaria or dengue prone, and precautionary measures were being taken to control them at the primary stage. The CMO admitted that mosquitoes have become resistant to certain pesticides because of increase in their immunity. "We are watching these changes and will change pesticides after observing their effect on mosquitoes", he added.

column2: Wild tuskers find ‘home’ in Pilibhit Tiger Reserve
column3: KANPUR: Two wild tuskers, which had probably strayed in the Rohilkhand region from the Terai belt of the Himalayan Kingdom (Nepal) on June 27, have been successfully released in the Pilibhit Tiger Reserve. A team of vets and senior forest officials had to toil hard for the past couple of days to capture both the wild elephants, which had trampled four to death, including a forest guard. A team of vets, including Mujeeb-ur-Rahman from Karnataka, Dushyant and Vimal Raj from Jim Corbett National Park, Sanath Muliya from Wildlife Institute of India, Dehradun, and RK Singh from Kanpur zoo, under the supervision of the project manager and chief conservator of forest, Jhansi, PP Singh, carried out the operation of capturing the wild tuskers. Among vets was also senior veterinarian of Kanpur zoo, Dr RK Singh, who co-ordinated and supervised the entire exercise. Both the tuskers were violent and had to be captured at the earliest to minimise losses. Talking to TOI over phone from Piliphit Tiger Reserve, Singh said that both the tuskers had probably strayed into the Indian territory from Nepal. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.He said that both are wild, and one of them is very aggressive and violent. It was a risky operation since both the tuskers were violent and one of them used to attack while the other one had to be tied after being tranqualised, Singh further said. "As they had strayed into the villages of Bareilly and Rampur, the two tuskers drew large crowds. They wrecked havoc and had killed four people. We, therefore, had to capture them immediately for which they were first tranqualised on July 17. They were tied to a tree in Rampur, and were given booster sedation dose to load them in two separate vehicles and were finally transported to Pilibhit. It was on late Thursday night that they were relocated to Pilibhit Tiger Reserve", said Singh while talking in detail about the entire exercise. He also said that three JCB cranes and hydra vehicles had to be used during the operation. Also, three cow elephants from Dudhwa Tiger Reserve were used in the operation to attract the male wild elephants. "The operation was risky. As the two elephants were inseparable, this made our task of cornering and tranqualising them very difficult. Though one of the tuskers is violent, but we were successful in relocating them to Pilibhit Tiger Reserve", he added.

column2: Whose land is it anyway...Will the land dispute with DEO disrupt working at LRC?
column3: The Lucknow Race Course (LRC), the only one-of-its-kind in the country that has an anti-clockwise racing track, situated in Cantonment, has been issued an eviction notice by the Ministry of Defence. All activities of the LRC have been put on hold by the Defence Estate Office, which owns most of the land the race course is built on, due to non-payment of dues and because of the lease not being renewed for the past 40 years. "Lucknow Race Fund (LRF), the body which was supposed to pay the rent and which manages the LRC, has failed to do so and hence we have no choice but to serve them a notice to vacate the land," informs Abhishek Mani Tripathi, Defence Estate Officer (DEO), Lucknow. The LRC remained the highlight every Sunday morning from October till March every year, during winters where people would flock to see Indian bred and thoroughbreds racing on the track. Except for this last season, when only one race was held in the calendar year of the LRC, the racing track would make it to the social calendar as an important event. The LRC also provides patrons and people to bet online for horse races held in centres at Mumbai, Bengaluru, Kolkata, Mysore and Ooty, due to which it remains in the running for most of the year. The eviction notice served to the Secretary Lucknow Race Fund on July 8, 2019, by the DEO, Lucknow (BCCL) The eviction notice served to the Secretary Lucknow Race Fund on July 8, 2019, by the DEO, Lucknow (BCCL) LRC has also played host to prestigious events like the Army Commander’s Cup race, the Mahomed Bagh Club Cup race apart from social activities including vintage cars show, dog show, fashion shows, band performances, among others. It is one of the most must-seen places in the city during the racing season where ladies come dressed in their Sunday best and the men folk love to flaunt their races-wali hats and breeches and hobnob over drinks and snacks. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy. Several well-known people of the city, including Jaideep Narain Mathur, former Additional Advocate General, UP, along with businessman Rajneesh Chopra, Amar Habibullah and Sudhir Halwasiya, among others, have their horses trained and housed at the LRC.  Giving us details of the cause and effect of the eviction notice, Abhishek Mani Tripathi says, "The major part of the racecourse is on leased land. There is an association known as the Lucknow Race Fund which manages the race course and the land around it. The land had been let out to the LRF in 1978 and since then they were supposed to pay a stipulated rent of Rs 34,625 per month but they failed to pay it to the government. In 2017, the Ministry of Defence came up with a policy in which they gave all these people, who were not paying rent to the government of India, a proposal to pay the rent amounting to Rs41,37,927 and have their lease renewed and that it will be extended to December 31, 2019. So, we on the behalf of the government of India, because we are the ones who manage the land, sent a demand notice to them saying that please pay the rent. However, they declined it and categorically said that they will not pay up. So, on this ground, under Section 4 (1) of the Public Premises Eviction Act, 1971 we have declared Lucknow Race Fund (the body which manages Lucknow Race Course ) as as on July 8, 2019, as unauthorised occupants and are seeking the arrears of lease rent amounting Rs 41,37,927 under Section 7 of the same Act. From July 8 onwards, they won’t be able to organize races at the LRC. The Lucknow Race Fund still has time to settle all the dues till the end of this month, or else they will have to vacate the land,” informs Abhishek Mani Tripathi. (BCCL) (BCCL) And while speculation is rife whether that will mean an end to the horse racing and other events at the Lucknow Race Course, officials at the LRC say this does not affect the functioning of the Lucknow Race Course nor are the races likely to be called off. On the condition of anonymity, an official of the LRC says, "There are two kinds of lands or leases at the LRC – one is permanent lease of which the custodian is the Lucknow Race Course and the other is the renewal lease which the DEO has served the LRF a notice of eviction for. Under the permanent lease comes the area like the racing track, conference room, front area, lawns – in short – major parts of LRC is under it. While there is an area around the race course called the 14 Furlong Area where around 45 ex-servicemen are staying, which comes under the renewal lease of the DEO. That lease, which is the talking point, was last renewed in 1978. As a custodian, we are taking care of that part of land and despite sending reminders to the concerned authorities for renewing the lease or taking it under their full control. It doesn’t become a no-man’s land if the deed is not renewed and so we have been taking care of it since. When the committee meeting will take place, all these points will be raised. The races and the LRC’s functioning will not be affected, that one can be sure of because of this land dispute." Spread in an area of 70.22 acres, the Lucknow Race Course is the longest course in the country and the only one which has an anti-clockwise track. While the racing track, the stands, stables and the conference room, the front area and the lawns come under lease of the LRC, the rest of the adjoining area is what the DEO has asked to be vacated where the civilians are living and have their unauthorised living quarters. The history of the racecourse goes back to the 17th century when Nawab Shuja-ud-Daula constructed it in 1764. In the year 1857, the racecourse club opened for the British Army’s officers. The first Civil Service Cup held in 1880 had horses from the Arabian and Australian breed running on the tracks. The first polo match held in 1912 at the polo grounds in Cantonment was organised by the Lucknow Race Course club. The same club in 2012 started the Awadh Polo Cup and hosted the first horse polo matches in the city in decades. — Akash.Wadhwa@timesgroup.com and Saad Abbasi

column2: Highlighting the different phases of a woman’s life
column3: An art exhibition based on the various phases of a woman’s life was recently exhibited by seven students of Lucknow College of Arts and Crafts at the Lalit Kala Akademi in Aliganj. The exhibition was inaugurated by politician Neeraj Bora along with Nawab Jafar Mir Abdullah, Sanjeev Kumar Gautam, Dean of Lucknow College of Arts and Crafts and Dr Arun Parashar, professor SGPGI. The exhibition, which comprised 35 paintings and one installation, was organized by Shivam Sinha. Masood Abdullah (L) and Syed Masoom Raza (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Masood Abdullah (L) and Syed Masoom Raza (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) “The efforts by the students of the Arts College is admirable. It is really commendable to see these students express their emotions so well through the medium of these paintings. Through the artwork they have conveyed a powerful message for the society,” said an elated Neeraj. (L) Neeraj Bora (R) Madiha Ansari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Neeraj Bora (R) Madiha Ansari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Nawab Jafar Mir Abdullah, while admiring the exhibition, said, “These paintings are beautifully arranged and each of them has a certain message that the students have tried to convey. They have shown the life of the fish connecting with life itself. Every painting conveys a positive message. As far as the colour combinations are concerned, the quality of the paintings too is very good. If students of third year have made such beautiful pieces, I wonder how much of their talent will increase when they do their masters. Overall, it’s a very good effort.” (L) Sakshi and Ankita (R) Nidhi Rastogi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Sakshi and Ankita (R) Nidhi Rastogi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The highlight of the exhibition however was the the huge installation put up by the students, who through it, conveyed how the vibrancy in the life of a girl child is diminishing due to society. — Yashi Agarwal (L) Pratima Singh (R) Sanjeev Gautam and Jafar Mir Abdullah (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Pratima Singh (R) Sanjeev Gautam and Jafar Mir Abdullah (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Vaishnavi Dixit (C) Srishti Rastogi (R) Shivam Sinha (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Vaishnavi Dixit (C) Srishti Rastogi (R) Shivam Sinha (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Anshika Sahu (R) Manie Kapoor (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Anshika Sahu (R) Manie Kapoor (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: It’s all about dancing at this event in Lucknow
column3: A dance centric event titled Colours of Dance was recently staged at Rai Umanath Bali auditorium. The directors of the performance were Tanisha Prajapati and Divya Tripathi, who put their best foot forward to train their students. (L) Madhu Narayan (R) Dr Herman Minz (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Madhu Narayan (R) Dr Herman Minz (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The children, between the age group 5 to 14 years, did wonders on the stage on songs like Chak Dhoom Dhoom, Morni Banke and Hawa Hawai among others. The chief guest of the event was Madhu Narayan, the Principal of a school in the city. The children also performed a dance on a medley of Hindi and English songs. — Saad Abbasi NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Mohan Soni and Paridhi Bansal (R) Ananya Tripathi and Hardik Kapoor (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Mohan Soni and Paridhi Bansal (R) Ananya Tripathi and Hardik Kapoor (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Ranu Vishwakarma (L) and Pragya (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Ranu Vishwakarma (L) and Pragya (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

column2: Akansha tops PCS(J), UP gets 610 civil judges
column3: LUCKNOW: Akansha Tiwari of Gonda clinched the first position in Provincial Civil Services (Judicial) Exam-2018, the results of which were declared by the Uttar Pradesh Public Service Commission on Saturday. Harihar Gupta of Nainital stood second while Azamgarh lad Prateek Tripathi came third. With it, the state has got 610 new civil judges in district courts. Talking to TOI, Akansha credited her success to her parents. “I was not expecting to top the exam... motivation from my parents helped,” she said. Second ranker Harihar Gupta is posted as assistant district attorney in Faridabad, Haryana. He said his father is a retired high court judge and had secured fourth rank in higher judicial service. “He wanted me to bag a good rank in the exam. I am happy that I fulfilled his dream.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy. He also thanked his mother Sushila Gupta for the achievement. Third ranker Prateek Tripathi is working as judicial magistrate in Patna, after getting selected through Bihar Public Service Commission (BPSC) in 2018. “I wanted to be back in my home state,” said Prateek, who gave credit of his success to his father, a judicial magistrate posted in Bareilly, and his homemaker mother. A number of candidates from the city have also qualified. Nikita Sengar, who did her LLB (Hons) from a private law college in Pune, bagged 109th rank. “I believed in self-made short notes and in-depth study of the bare act. I would be the first judge in my family,” she said. Sonam Sharma of Lucknow secured 338th rank. She did law from Dr Ram Manohar Lohia National Law University, Lucknow. Utkarsh Singh, who completed LLM from LU, bagged 542th rank. He said self-study and guidance from university professors helped him. “I didn’t join any coaching after LLB (Hons) in 2016. I plan to support the poor and those who can’t afford to fight the legal battle,” he said. Former LU student, Rajat Shukla, who completed LLB in 2016, also cleared the exam. Rajat said he made sure to develop an understanding of every law and Act. The exam is officially called UP Judicial Service Civil Judges (Junior Division) Exam. It is held in three stages. The prelims was conducted on December 16, mains from January 30 to February 1 and interviews from June 21 to July 17. UPPSC secretary Jagdish said provisionally selected candidates should submit their documents or else their selection would be cancelled.

column2: Boy drowns after falling in uncovered hole in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 15-year-boy cycling through a waterlogged road in Vijay Nagar fell into a drain through a gaping 8 by8 feet hole left by the Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation that had repaired the stretch two weeks ago. The body of Deepanshu Pal, a Class X student of St. Teresa’s Convent, was fished out after three hours of search by an NDRF team, 200 metres from the spot where he drowned. Residents of Sarvodaya Nagar said GMC had not bothered to even place a signboard near the hole to warn people against straying nearby. The civic body had created such holes in several places on the road to clean a drain flowing underneath, but had left them uncovered. A spell of afternoon rain on Saturday left the road under knee-deep water and it became impossible for anyone to spot the holes from a distance. Late on Saturday, GMC ordered a probe into the accident. The boy’s grandmother (centre) and relatives mourn the deathDeepanshu’s family members said he and his younger brother Subham, who, too, studied in the same school, would return home together on a bicycle. But on Saturday, Deepanshu asked Subham to go home alone and said he would return after sometime. The boy’s father, Ashok Pal, is an accountant with a private firm in Ghaziabad, while his mother Sonu works in the tehsil office in Dadri. His elder sister Vidhi passed Class XII this year. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.According to Deepanshu’s uncle Praveen Pal, the two brothers would take a different route to return home from school. “We have no idea how Deepanshu reached the place where people are saying he drowned. It is not the road that the boys would take to come back from school. Shubham had asked Deepanshu to take the cycle with him and returned home walking along with a friend,” he said. When Deepanshu did not reach home even after 3pm, his grandfather went to the school to enquire about his whereabouts. After reaching the school, Asharam Pal was told that a boy about the same age as Deepanshu had drowned in the 12ft drain, just 500 metres away. He rushed to the spot, and saw Deepanshu’s cycle, which had been fished out by then. Till the time Asharam identified the cycle as Deepanshu’s, police were clueless about the identity of the boy. Amit Kumar, who was witness to the incident, said: “The boy had been alerted by a few kids about the broken road and the hole, but he did not take it seriously. He was wearing a yellow T-shirt and off-white trousers.” After Deepanshu fell into the overflowing drain, two passersby — Kalua and Bhairav — jumped into it and fished out the cycle. A police team that reached the spot used an earthmover to clear the area. SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh, SP (city) Shlok Kumar and other senior administrative and GMC officials inspected the spot. Latest CommentWe give votes in hope that work will be done in our area but after taking votes our MP/MLA''s just sit in the AC cabins and start filling their bank accounts with notes for five years and people are ...Read MoreJagdeep SinghSee All CommentsAdd commentThe NDRF team and two local divers managed to recover the body around 5pm. Deepanshu was declared dead on arrival at MMG District Hospital. Parents of the boy refused to get an autopsy done and took the body with themselves. Police said they were yet to get a complaint in the matter. GMC commissioner Dinesh Chandra said he had constituted a three-member committee under the additional municipal commissioner to probe the matter and submit a report in the next 24 hours.

column2: Lucknow University departments fail deadline, NAAC process delayed
column3: LUCKNOW: With nearly 50% of the departments submitting incomplete reports, Lucknow University (LU) will have to wait for at least three more months for grading by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC). LU authorities have directed departments to file complete reports by July 30. The reports will be analysed by the university’s Internal Quality Assessment Cell (IQAC) before drafting a self study report (SSR) and then be uploaded on the NAAC website. NAAC will then award marks after evaluating the SSR and send a team to LU for ground evaluation. The final grading will be based on points scored in SSR (80%) and ground evaluation (20%). The absence of a NAAC grade will increase LU’s risk of losing UGC funds for major projects and also foreign collaborations for which the tag is a must. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.NAAC had given LU ‘B’ grade in the last assessment in 2015 that expired on May 5. The re-accreditation process should have been completed before the expiry. All 42 departments were given an April 25 deadline to submit SSR. The deadline was extended twice—May 25 and June 30. “The SSRs were submitted late and we have found that the reports of 22 departments are incomplete,” said an official of the IQAC. “If departments submit full reports by July 30, it will take at least three months to complete the entire process of grading,” he added. LU spokesperson NK Pandey said, “The process will be expedited to get the assessment at the earliest.” “If this matter lingers, LU may not get the grading by November 25, when its 100th foundation day celebrations are scheduled,” said a senior officer,

column2: UP: Posing as IPS officers’ wives, women stole jewellery, held
column3: LUCKNOW: Two women who used to steal jewellery from shops posing as wives of IPS officers were arrested on Saturday. Chunna Tiwari and Babli Tiwari, both from Hardoi, confessed to their crimes in Mohanlalganj.  Police recovered eight pairs of silver anklets and 10 pairs of silver toe rings from them. Sub-inspector Shashikala Singh got a tip-off about the women whose images were captured live during the act on CCTV last week. “Later, a shop owner identified them,” police said. SHO Mohanlalganj Gaudeen Shukla said the women used to dress in expensive attire and pose as wives of IPS officers at jewellery shops. Sometimes, they took an aide with them who acted as a government police guard.  They used to ask the shop owners to show them jewellery. “Taking advantage of any distraction of the shop owner, they used to steal the ornaments in their multi-layered purses. Shop owners could not dare to quiz them,” added Shukla.

column2: CM Yogi Adityanath moots inter-district police duty meet for stronger khaki bonding
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Saturday mooted the idea of organising duty meet of UP districts on the lines of inter-state duty meet for better coordination and camaraderie among police personnel. Yogi made the suggestion while presiding over the closing ceremony of 62nd All India Police Duty meet at 35th PAC battalion headquarters in Mahanagar, Lucknow . UP hosted the event after 20 years. Maharashtra Police lifted the champion’s trophy in the meet which saw the participation of police units from 22 states and seven central forces in six categories. The meet was inaugurated on July 16. Five policemen from other states were awarded the PM’s Police Medal for saving the lives of people. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.State police teams which won: Tamil Nadu emerged victorious in forensic sciences; ITBP and BSF were declared joint winners in anti-sabotage check; Kerala and UP Police were joint winners in computer awareness; Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh were joint winners in videography; Andhra Pradesh and ITBP were joint winners in photography, and Tamil Nadu and SSB were winners in dog squads.

column2: Ghaziabad: Multi-level parking work to start soon
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) will finalise tenders for two proposed multi-level parking lots in the city, one at Raj Nagar District Centre and the other at Indirapuram, by the end of July. “In the first week of August, we hope to start work on two parking areas in RDC and Indirapuram. By July, we will finalise bidders,” said Kanchan Verma, the vice-chairperson, GDA. The parking lots would be three-storeyed and will be able to accommodate 150 four-wheelers. The parking lot at Indirapuram, near Swarn Jyanti Park, will cater to 300-odd vehicles. The GDA is also working on a plan to develop two more parking lots at Madhuban Bapudham. “Madhuban Bapudham housing scheme spread about 1,200 acres is going to be the next big thing as it will have commercial and residential installations and we can already foresee parking problem in the area,” said Verma. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Lucknow: Sultry weather back, wait for rain extends
column3: LUCKNOW: Sapping sultry conditions were back to torment people on Saturday, further extending the hot and humid conditions prevailing for the past three days except for a brief respite brought about by Friday evening downpour. People will have to wait till Tuesday-Wednesday for typical monsoon rains when a weather system developing over the Bay of Bengal is expected to create favourable atmosphere for widespread rains across the state and city. The pleasant weather after rains on Friday evening lasted for only few hours. As mercury and relative humidity started rising again, the minimum temperature recorded during wee hours touched 27 degree Celsius, a degree above normal. The condition deteriorated further during the day when temperature soared to 37.4 degree Celsius, four degrees above normal and relative humidity rose to an enervating high of 92%. High discomfort levels prevailed all through the day. No relief is expected on Sunday too with the state Met office predicting partly cloudy sky and maximum and minimum temperatures around 37 and 27 degree Celsius, respectively. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.State Met director J P Gupta said that excessive heat and humidity may cause one or two thundershowers, but by and large rainfall activity will largely remain subdued. However, he added, a cyclonic circulation developing over the Bay of Bengal is expected to revive rainfall in the city by Tuesday-Wednesday. Meanwhile, scanty rains in the past one week brought down the rainfall average in the city from 50% above normal on last Friday to just 23% above average on Saturday.

column2: Pay tribute to Kargil war heroes with music, art
column3: LUCKNOW: From interaction of children with war veterans who have served in Kargil to a fusion band performance in public places, the Central Command has planned a host of activities starting from July 22 to commemorate the 20th anniversary of Kargil war in the city. Remembered as ‘Kargil Vijay Diwas’, the day commemorates the events of July 26, 1999, when the Indian Army successfully took command of the high-altitude outposts after driving out Pakistani intruders. This year, Central Command has decided to involve people in paying homage to the martyrs and celebrations to commemorate India’s victory. According to the public relations officer of the Central Command, painting and debate competitions for school students will be organised from July 22. Children will also be encouraged to participate in the wreath-laying ceremony at Smritika War Memorial in Cantonment on July 26 in the morning. The war memorial will remain open for the public to pay their tributes to the martyrs. In the evening, war veterans will interact with children by sharing their experiences of Kargil at Puneet Dutt Auditorium in Cantonment. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A fusion band performance for public to pay tributes to the bravehearts will be organised at Janeshwar Mishra Park on July 27 and Husainabad Clock Tower on July 28 from 6pm to 7.30pm. Entry to these events will be free.

column2: ‘Mango festival is a food paradise, shouldn’t be missed’
column3: LUCKNOW: A wok full of biryani steamed with chicken pieces marinated with raw mangoes was one of the many hit dishes which attracted people at the three-day Mango Food Festival organised by UP Tourism on Saturday. Apart from the ‘mango murgh biryani’, other unique dishes made with a dash of mango were ‘karari mango tikki’, ‘mango sewayin’ and many more. The festival, organised every year, aims to bring varieties of mango lovers and sellers under one roof. “Local chefs have prepared delicacies that we had never heard of. Even for vegetarians, there is a variety of dishes,” said Rajiv Suri, from Vipin Khand. “Nobody should miss this festival. This is a food paradise. Lucknow serves the best non-vegetarian dishes in India and having a mango festival with ‘aam biryani’ is something you just cannot miss,” said Supriya Agarwal, a resident of Ikshupuri Colony. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Besides an elaborate menu stressing on mango-based delicacies, a quiz based on the king of fruits and a live ‘qissagoi’ session on Mirza Ghalib and his love for the fruit turned heads. Visitors were treated to a variety of mangoes, including Alphonso, Dusshehri, Chausa, and Langda. “This is a unique festival which covers all aspects of this tropical fruit,” said Vasvi Verma, a visitor.

column2: Questions linger in hospital manager’s death mystery
column3: LUCKNOW: The autopsy report of private hospital manager Vishwajeet Pundir (31) who bled to death on July 17 from an inexplicable wound in his stomach does not support the police theory of accidental fall and leaves behind many unanswered questions. Though police lodged a case of murder on the Pundir family’s complaint, it has been maintaining that it appears to be an accident. “Prima facie, it appears that Pundir was high on drugs, he lost balance and fell from the balcony of his room on the second floor on the iron railing on the boundary wall of his house in Vishwas Khand,” police had said in press statement. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Police based its observation on recovery of cannabis and beer cans in his room and blood on the floor near the boundary wall besides two identical wounds at a distance of 10cm on the stomach caused due to a pointed object similar to the iron fence. The postmortem report is silent on whether Pundir was intoxicated at the time of death or not since doctors could not conclude whether he was under influence of any drug at the time of death and have suggested to preserve viscera for further probe. The report also states that the wounds were caused by either a sharp object or stabbing. No blood was found on the iron fence. Police are now depending on forensic analysis of the grille to trace blood. Pundir died to excessive bleeding from a punctured artery. SP (north) Sukirti Madhav Mishra said, “The iron rods on fence are 10cm apart like the wounds. If he had been attacked, he would have told his family member. In fact, he told his mother that he fell from the bed. We have decided to recreate the crime scene to ascertain the likely sequence of events. We have not concluded our probe yet.”

column2: UP: Two minors booked for gangrape of 9-year-old
column3: LUCKNOW: A nine-year-old was allegedly gang-raped in Sidhauli area of Sitapur. Police on Saturday detained two minor boys, aged 15 and 10, accused of gang rape by the girl. According to police, on July 18, around 8.30 pm, the survivor who lives in Sidhauli had gone to give food to her brother, who was working at an underconstruction house 500 m from her residence. However, on the way, “Two boys of the same area stopped her. They lured her with a ride on bike and took her to a secluded place, where they forced themselves upon her,” said police. In the meanwhile, the minor’s parents came searching for her and took her home, the police added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.SHO Sidhauli, Sanjay Kumar told TOI that the survivor’s parents came to lodge a complaint on July 19 evening on the basis of which an FIR was lodged and two youth, aged15 and 10, were nabbed on Saturday. “The two have been booked in a case of gang rape, abduction, causing hurt,” added Kumar. “A detailed medical report of the minor is awaited and will determine the nature of sexual assault. The location of the two is also being verified,” he said. “The survivor’s statement is also still to be recorded. The two were nabbed because they were named by the survivor,” Kumar added. SP Sitapur LR Kumar said that he would comment only when the medical of the survivor is conducted.

column2: Her concern for victims a drama: Swatantra Dev
column3: LUCKNOW: Newly appointed UP BJP chief Swatantra Dev Singh said on Friday that Priyanka Gandhi Vadra’s insistence to meet the families of Sonbhadra massacre victims was a mere drama. Even after the state government allowed her to meet the victims’ families, Priyanka played politics and sat on a dharna, Singh said at his first press conference as UP BJP chief here. Reiterating CM Yogi’s remarks, Singh said Congress was the root cause of Sonbhadra killings. “Gandhi’s protest at the guest house and her fake sympathy for the victims were an attempt to divert the attention from Congress’ role in the matter. It is an old habit of Congress to play politics over dead,” Singh said. He added that the state government responded promptly to the tragedy.

column2: Music, yoga and more on course for KGMU freshers
column3: LUCKNOW: Music, they say, is a mood-altering wonder drug. No wonder King George’s Medical University wants its budding doctors to experience the healing power of music — and more. In accordance with Medical Council of India guidelines, a month-long foundation course is being added to KGMU’s first-year curriculum and it comprises lessons in dance, yoga, English and computers, besides soul-delivering music. The mandatory course begins from August 3. Three hours will be set aside daily for the extracurricular activities. “We have tied up with government institutes for the various classes. The schedule will be announced soon,” said dean of medicine professor Vineeta Das. Officials at KGMU said while computer and language classes will help students have a better grasp on medical studies, yoga will teach them how to balance body, mind and soul. Music and dance, on the other hand, will act as natural stress-busters. Those who want to pursue these activities further will be encouraged to do so. “Our students come from socio-cultural backgrounds. Some come from rural areas. Many struggle to understand lessons because most medical books are in English,” Dr Shally Awasthi, the curriculum in-charge at KGMU, explained the need for the foundation course. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Students unanimously welcomed the move. “I wish English and computer lessons were introduced last year,” said Shubham Gupta, a secondyear MBBS student, as he recalled how being schooled in Hindi medium hindered his comprehension of concepts explained in English. “I had to read a chapter or topic several times to make sense out of it. I am glad my juniors won’t face the challenge,” he added.

column2: IIT-Kanpur welcomes over 2,000 new students on campus
column3: KANPUR: IIT-K authorities gave a warm welcome to around 2,000 new students who arrived on the instutute campus on Saturday. They were accompanied with their parents and relatives. The counselling service of the institute smoothly conducted the reporting of over 2000 new students over a period of two days, making it one of the toughest feats, said an official of the institute. The reporting on Saturday was followed by high tea in the evening, catering to over 3,500 people, including parents, students and teachers. Latest CommentDone okay ok ok ok ok ok ok ok o ko k ok o ko ko k ok o k ok o k o lo k o o ko k o ko k o k o k o k k o kk o kSPYDER the conquerorSee All CommentsAdd commentThe teachers from all 13 departments were invited to answer questions of parents regarding departments of their wards, academic culture in the institute and opportunities for students in future. “We assured parents that their wards will be studying under the teachers who are masters of their subjects, and the institute will help build character of every individual student along with their academic growth", said a teacher. The interaction with professors in the evening, and the process of room allotment ensured the parents that their wards would be looked after well.
