The new students also made purchases of necessities articles such as bicycles, buckets, mattresses, pillows etc.

column2: How did Harshita die? Forensic experts recreate ‘crime’ scene
column3: KANPUR: A forensic team on Saturday recreated the fall of Harshita, who had died under mysterious circumstances after falling from the seventh floor of her apartment in Allenganj area of the city on July 6. To ascertain the facts that led to the death of Harshita, a forensic team under the supervision of CO Swaroop Nagar Ajit Singh Chauhan on Saturday afternoon reached her apartment no: 706 located at the seventh floor of Eldorado apartment and recreated the incident scene. The forensic team will place the findings of the recreated scene to the investigating team. On the basis of the result of which the case will be probed further, said CO Chauhan. “We recreated the incident scene by throwing a dummy from the seventh floor to ascertain whether Harshita committed suicide, or was pushed to death or fell accidentally off the high-rise,” Chauhan added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.On July, a 27-year-old Harshita, had allegedly died after falling from from the seventh floor of her apartment, and her parents suspects foul play in her death and has demanded a fair probe into it. Subsequently, her husband Utkarsh, in-laws including father-in-law Sushil Agarwal and mother-in-law Ranu Agarwal were arrested and sent to jail following a complaint by her parents wherein they have accused them of harassing their daughter for dowry, the police said. Harshita, along with her husband Utkarsh and latter's parents was staying in an apartment in Allenganj area of the city since their marriage in 2017, according to police. “According to the complaint, Harshita’s family had got a call on July 6 that she had fell off the seventh floor of her house. When the family reached the spot, they were told by her in-laws that she was dead,” police said.

column2: 60 parakeets stuffed in cage found in Delhi-bound bus
column3: GHAZIABAD: Around 60 parakeets, crammed into a 3X2 feet cage, were rescued from a Delhi-bound bus on Saturday morning. The parakeets were brought like that all the way from Moradabad district in Uttar Pradesh to Ghaziabad’s Mohan Nagar area from where they were rescued. The cage was perched on top of the bus throughout the journey. Forest ranger Navratan Singh said most of the parakeets looked traumatised. “In order to hide the cage, a gunny bag was placed over it. The birds endured about three hours of journey without food and water. Fortunately, none of them died,” he said. SkipGhaziabad forest officials managed to rescue the birds after they got a tip off from the Wildlife Crime Control Bureau that some caged parakeets were being smuggled in a bus. Police also arrested the bus driver, Jai Prakash, and helper Sehad Ali from the spot who informed that the caged birds were to be delivered to a person in Delhi’s Seelampuri area and from there, they would eventually be sold in the national capital’s illegal bird market. “The accused were booked under relevant sections of the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 and were produced in a city court from that sent them to jail,” said the district forest officer Deeksha Bhandari. “The birds have been kept in the DFO’s office and are being fed properly,” said the forest ranger. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The Parakeets (Psittacidae) commonly called rose-ringed parakeets are listed under Schedule IV of the Wildlife Protection Act and its hunting, capturing and sale is illegal. They are mostly caught from forests area on Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Haryana. “They are smuggled in buses, trains and private vehicles to cites like Delhi where a pair is sold at about Rs 150,” said a city-based wildlife expert Ruchin Mehra.

column2: Three criminals nabbed in encounter with UP police
column3: LUCKNOW: Continuing crackdown against the hardcore criminals in Uttar Pradesh, police teams of Krishnanagar, Alambagh and Naka nabbed three serial offenders bearing a cash prize of Rs 75,000 each during an encounter with them in Kesarikheda area under Krishnanagar police station in the wee hours of Sunday. The miscreants were identified as Ajay Gupta aka Tinku Nepali, Laik, and Mohak Shastri. They suffered injuries on their legs when the police opened fire on them and were later admitted to a government hospital. Police claimed that the miscreants were on a dacoity bid in the city. Police also recovered a motorcycle and two country-made pistols from their possession. Inspector general of police (Lucknow range) SK Bhagat said the gang was involved in a loot in Naka on January 12 this year, while in another incident the same gang had shot dead two persons and looted ornaments worth Rs 4 lakh from RK Jewellers in Alambagh on March 3. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Police were tipped off about the movement of the gang in the city late Saturday night. SHO Naka, Sujeet Dubey said they came to know that Tinku Nepali and his two aides were to move to Kesarikheda locality in Krishnanagar and so they laid a trap there.  "Around 4am on Sunday, the gang was seen passing on a bike via the check-point and was stopped after which they opened fire at the police party,” he said. The SHO said the police had to open fire on the miscreants in defense.

column2: Lucknow to get its 2nd largest park
column3: LUCKNOW: The city will get another green oasis in midst of concrete structures. Lucknow Development Authority will build a grand park on 160-acre land in Vasant Kunj near SGPGI. Powered By                          10 Sec      Stuck Ship in Suez Canal Holds Up Oil and LNG Shipments	.stlp0{fill:#FF3E5F;}	.st1{fill:#fffffe;}	.st2{fill:#FF3E5F;}         .clsx-1{isolation:isolate;}.clsx-2{fill:#ff3e5f;}.clsx-3{fill:#fff;}NextStay     Stuck Ship in Suez Canal Holds Up Oil and LNG ShipmentsNOW  PLAYINGWork to Re-Float Stuck Boat in Suez Canal SuspendedNOW  PLAYINGThe secret network helping Myanmar police fleeNOW  PLAYINGMobius Sees Turkish Lira Remaining Steady as Dollar WeakensNOW  PLAYINGIndia orders deportation of migrants who fled Myanmar military coupNOW  PLAYINGBangladesh deploys border guards after deadly anti-Modi protestsNOW  PLAYINGBlocked Suez Forces Ships to Look at Long Trip Around AfricaNOW  PLAYINGIndian farmers dance to mark four months of protestsNOW  PLAYINGAt least four dead in Bangladesh Modi protestsNOW  PLAYINGSuez Canal Not Expected to Open Anytime SoonNOW  PLAYING  Arrow Left #1 Icon Created with Sketch.                 Arrow right #1 Icon Created with Sketch.               Christened as City Forest, the green structure will cost Rs 50 crore. The construction will begin this month and the park is expected to be ready in next two years. It will be the second largest park in Lucknow after Janeshwar Mishra Park in Gomtinagar. The park will have three gardens — butterfly, herbal and bamboo, besides an orchard. It will boast of facilities like food court, jogging track, open-air gym and multi-activity spot. The orchard will have trees of orange, guava, litchi, mango and cashew. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Garden in charge, LDA, SP Sisodiya said they are also mulling construction of a library in the park where books on plants and tree will be available for visitors. In addition, the park will have an airconditioned auditorium for cultural and social programmes. Its seating capacity would be 2,000. The entry ticket will be Rs 10 per person.

column2: Fire in Ghaziabad's sales tax office, files burnt
column3: GHAZIABAD: Several files were damaged in a fire that broke out at Ghaziabad’s sales tax office early on Saturday. Flames were first noticed by a guard who was on night duty and he informed the fire department. It took around two hours to put out the blaze, officials said. “It is very difficult to ascertain the cause of the fire, as we are still investigating. But we found that fire fighting measures were not in place at the office,” said fire officer Sushil Yadav.

column2: Two dupe Moradabad trader, held
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two persons were arrested on Saturday for allegedly duping a Moradabad-based grain merchant of Rs 16 lakh on the pretext of giving him a lift on their motorcycle 15 days ago. The duo has been identified as Mohsin and Riyazuddin, both from Masuri. Their third accomplice, Taufeeq, also a resident of Masuri, is on the run. The duo was caught from Hapur around 3.30am on Saturday. The merchant, Bilal, who was carrying the money in a bag, was on his way to Moradabad on July 5. SP (city) Shlok Kumar said, “Over Rs 10 lakh has been recovered."

column2: Mandi broker rapes two minor girls, arrested in Sahibabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 31-year-old man was arrested in Sahibabad on Saturday for allegedly raping two girls, aged nine and 10 years. Police said he raped the girls twice between July 14 and July 16. The matter came to light when one of the girls fell unconscious and was taken to a doctor. Later, she narrated the incident after being coaxed by her mother. The girls are neighbours and stay in the same building. The arrested person, Ashok Yadav, is a broker who works at Sahibabad vegetable wholesale market. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The SHO of Link Road police station, Laxmi Chauhan, said: “Yadav knew the mother of one of the girls and frequented their house. On July 14, he went to the house and found the girls playing. He lured them to Sahibabad vegetable market on the pretext of buying them candies and sweets and then took them to a secluded room in the market and raped both of them.” Latest CommentJust executeKeysman KSee All CommentsAdd comment“He threatened them after that and the girls did not tell their parents anything out of fear. On July 16 evening, Yadav went to the house again and raped the girls. He left the house after one of the girls fell unconscious,” the SHO added. The girls’ mothers filed a police complaint on July 18. Thereafter, Yadav was booked under sections 376 (rape) 506 (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and also under relevant sections of the Protection of Children against Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act.

column2: A comedy of errors in Lucknow
column3: A play titled Do Phool Ek Maali was staged recently at Sangeet Natak Akademi. The play, which was directed by Sanjay Daglurkar, saw theatre veterans from the city like Urmil Kumar Thapliyal, Anil Rastogi and Sangam Bahuguna in attendance. A scene from the play (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  A scene from the play (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Pratisha (L) and Reetam Pandey (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  Pratisha (L) and Reetam Pandey (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Eva Roy (L) and Jitendra Mittal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  Eva Roy (L) and Jitendra Mittal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Major Abhishek & Rupam Roy (L) and Poornima Pandey (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  Major Abhishek & Rupam Roy (L) and Poornima Pandey (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L-R) Radheshyam Soni, Ravi Khary and Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  (L-R) Radheshyam Soni, Ravi Khary and Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The play revolved around a philanderer Madhav, who marries two girls in secrecy. While one of his wives lives in Bandra, the other resides in Santa Cruz. The comedy play took a funny turn when Madhav meets with an accident and his wives come to know about the truth and together they teach him a lesson. Ambrish Bobby played the character of Madhav while Alka Vivek and Shreya Awasthi played his wives. Other actors who acted in the play included Shalini Shukla and Ankit Srivastava. — Saad Abbasi

column2: Ghaziabad: Two boys playing on roof touch air cooler wire, electrocuted
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two minor boys playing on the roof of a house during a farewell party were electrocuted after they accidentally touched a wire dangling from an air cooler in Khoda Colony on Saturday night. The two boys had come to the house an hour earlier to attend a party in honour of their grandfather, who is supposed to retire from the Indian Railways on July 30. During the party, Aditya (11) and Kuldeep (14) were told to go to the roof and play. The area where the air cooler was placed had a puddle of water around it after half an hour of rain on Friday. The wire, too, was wet. Md. Shahid, a neighbour, told TOI that Aditya was the grandson of Hiraral, for whom the party had been organised. Though the family declined to speak to the media, neighbours said the two boys were disturbing their parents and were told to go to the terrace. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“The accident occurred around 8pm on Saturday. We immediately took them to a nearby hospital, and doctors there referred the two to Lal Bahadur Shastri hospital in Delhi. The two were declared dead on arrival at the Delhi hospital. Police handed over the bodies to their families and the last rites were performed on Sunday,” he added. Till late on Sunday evening, police were yet to register any case as the families refused to get a complaint lodged. “The kids died in an accident. They touched the leaking wire and were electrocuted. Their families have not lodged any complaint into the matter,” said Satendra Prakash Singh, the station house officer of Khoda police station. Top CommentVery very unfortunate incident happened due to families negligence taking two lives! How can someone keep the reachable wires open in rainy season!PolSee All CommentsAdd commentIn the wake of the accident, a neighbour demanded that the electricity department fix all naked wires in the area. She said though Saturday’s accident happened because of apparent negligence on the part of the family, there have been several instances of kids getting electrocuted in Khoda Colony, where overhead wires are within metres from the roof of houses. On April 23, a 25-year-old youth was electrocuted and two kids suffered burns after they touched a kite string that was dangling from the overhead wires. Police said the string or ‘manjha’ was coated with a metal strip, and allowed electricity to pass.

column2: Lucknow: Hubby chopped woman's body, buried remains
column3: LUCKNOW: A property dealer allegedly killed his wife with his two aides, severed her head and threw it in a canal, chopped her remaining body into pieces and buried them along a canal in Rae Bareli. The gory details were revealed when police arrested the accused and recovered decomposed body parts, knife and country-made pistol near Deepemau village in Rae Bareli district. The woman's aunt had lodged a complaint at Sarojninagar police station in city. The deceased, Madhu Tiwari (29), had married Shiv Prasad (30) after having an affair with him and has a 9-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter. The family lived in Sarojininagar. Madhu suddenly went missing in February following which her aunt Gayatri Dubey questioned Shiv several times but he claimed she went somewhere on her own. "Madhu suspected foul play. On July 18, she lodged a complaint at Sarojinagar police station against Shiv, Sachin Singh (28), a first-year LLB student, and Arvind Kumar Mishra (29), a farmer, accusing them of kidnapping and killing Madhu," said crime branch inspector Anjani Pandey. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.When police took the three in custody, Shiv confessed to his crime during interrogation. Shiv said he developed relations with Madhu's cousin and married her secretly. He then decided to get rid og Madhu and gave Rs 3 lakh to Sachin and Arvind to kill her. On February 16, Shiv took Madhu to Lalganj on the pretext of showing a plot and took her to a secluded spot where Sachin shot her with a .315 bore country-made gun. Shiv, Sachin and Arvind severed her head and chopped her body into pieces using butchers' knife. The head was thrown into the canal, while body parts were buried at the spot. "Shiv led us to the spot from where we recovered bones as flesh had decomposed. We will get DNA test and forensic exam done to establish identity and ascertain cause of death. The gun and knife used in the crime were also recovered," said Pandey.

column2: Lucknow accident: Girl in mother’s lap flung into air, dies
column3: LUCKNOW: A two-year-old girl was flung into air and died after hitting the road when the scooter she was riding with her parents was hit by an army truck on Faizabad Road in Indiranagar on Sunday. The army truck driver has been charged with causing death due to negligence and rash driving, while the parents who also suffered injuries were in a state of shock on losing their only child. SkipMashooq Ali (28), a resident of Aliganj, was going to his in-law's house in Gomtinagar at around 3.30pm with wife Husna Bano (24) and daughter Mahira (2) when an army truck of Dogra regiment going to Faizabad hit them near Polytechnic crossing. Eyewitnesses told TOI that Mahira flung into the air due to the impact and suffered serious head injuries after hitting the road. Locals rushed the three to a nearby private hospital where the baby died during treatment, while parents were referred to KGMU Trauma Centre. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Truck driver, Ashwani Kanaujia, was arrested by police but was released on signing a personal bond. Mashooq worked at a hospital in Noida and married Bano three years ago. The couple moved to Lucknow, their native place, six months ago after Mashooq got a job as sales representative in a food and beverage firm. "I was driving, while Bano riding pillion was holding Mahira. About 100 metre from polytechnic, the truck hit my scooter while trying to overtake," said Mashooq. Latest CommentSuperb 😊P S Gupta GuptaSee All CommentsAdd commentMashooq's brother Shanu Ali said, "Mahira was darling of entire family. It is still very difficult to believe that she is no more with us." He added that army should consider giving compensation to the family. Ghazipur station house officer, Brijesh Kumar Singh said, "We have lodged an FIR against the truck driver Ashwani Kanaujia and have seized the truck. The body of the girl has been sent for post-mortem."

column2: Lucknow: Pattern of wounds trashes cops' theory of death-by-fall
column3: LUCKNOW: Police recreated the 'crime' scene on Sunday evening to work out the mystery of hospital manager's death in Vishwaskhand but the results ended up raising question marks on its own theory of accidental death. Police used a dummy while working on two probabilities: the deceased Vishwajeet Pundir (31) tripping and falling off the balcony of his second floor room himself, or being pushed off. However, the patterns of injuries on the dummy in both cases did not match the actual wounds on Pundir's body anyhow. Pundir's family, however, questioned the accuracy of the exercise saying the weight and height of dummy used was quite less than actual. Police had been maintaining that Pundir, who bled to dead from inexplicable wounds on July 17, was high on cannabis, lost balance and fell on iron grille of boundary wall on ground floor from the balcony of his room on the second floor of the Vishwaskhand residence. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.According to the post-mortem report, Pundir had suffered two identical wounds on the stomach 10cm apart from a sharp object. When the dummy was thrown off the balcony to imitate tripping and fall, it got stuck in the branches of the tree adjacent to boundary and resulted in abrasions on chest and a gash on the left knee which hit the grille. When the dummy was thrown as if it was pushed off the balcony, it fell on the grille resulting in multiple piercing wounds in head, shoulder, chest, stomach, groin and thigh. In both scenarios, injury pattern was different than the actual wounds on the body and as mentioned in the autopsy report. Pundir's brother, Indrajeet accused police of doing mockery in the name of investigation. "My brother was 5 feet 11 inch tall and weighed around 78 kg, whereas the dummy used was shorter and hardly 20kg," he said. When TOI asked Forensic Science Lab (FSL) deputy director Dr G Khan about the discrepancies, he said he will comment only after examining the injury patterns in the lab.

column2: KGMU reunites Assam man with family
column3: LUCKNOW: A man who had been separated from his family was reunited with them thanks to the efforts of King George's Medical University (KGMU) staff on Sunday, three days after he was hospitalised after being injured due to coming in contact with a loose electric wire. This was the 16th such incident reported at KGMU in the past one-and-a-half years. On Thursday, Rafeek was found lying unconscious with an injury on his head near Kanpur Bypass Crossing in Dubagga. He was rushed to KGMU's neurosurgery department. After waking up,he could identify himself, but couldn't recall anything apart from the fact that he lived on Campbell Road. "We sent a team to the area to trace his family. On Sunday, Rafeek took us to his sister's house. We later came to know that Rafeek came to Lucknow from Assam to meet his sister, but was injured after he touched an stray electric wire," said head of KGMU's neurosurgery department Prof BK Ojha.

He was rushed to KGMU's neurosurgery department. After waking up,he could identify himself, but couldn't recall anything apart from the fact that he lived on Campbell Road. "We sent a team to the area to trace his family. On Sunday, Rafeek took us to his sister's house. We later came to know that Rafeek came to Lucknow from Assam to meet his sister, but was injured after he touched an stray electric wire," said head of KGMU's neurosurgery department Prof BK Ojha.

column2: Boys not ill-treated, says Ghaziabad madrassa
column3: GHAZIABAD: A day after five teenagers, who ran away from a Ghaziabad-based madrassa were found in Aligarh railway station, the staffers of the institution denied all allegations of ill-treatment. On Saturday, when Aligarh police found the children, they had reportedly said they were not treated well at the madrassa and not given food regularly. They said that they wanted to return home, but could not contact their parents. Meanwhile, the madrassa staffers have claimed that the children living there had no such issues. The rescued boys are Israel (11), his two brothers Irshad (10) and Ishrafeel (7). The three are from Basatpur in Banka district of Bihar. The two other boys are Bahruddin (11) and Mohammad Amir (9). They are from Purnia. Md Nazim, a teacher and also a manager in the madrassa, told TOI that Jamia Millia Madina-tul-ilm has been running for six years now in Balaji Vihar area in Pusta Road. “We have 150 children and five teachers. While around 15 children come from other cities, the others belong to nearby areas,” he added. “There are five rooms for children who are not from Ghaziabad and they are cleaned by Nagar Nigam staff. The people who reside near the madrassa often give food to the children. Also, we have tied up with a hotel that provides food for the children,” Naxim said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“At 5 pm on Friday, the five children had gone to a nearby playground. When they didn't return, I sent a staffer to check on them. When he didn’t locate them, we started to look in nearby areas. Around 8 pm, one of the teachers received a call from a person in Anand Vihar railway station saying that the children are sitting on the platform," he added. Another teacher, Rehmadulah, said, “We thought about lodging a report in the police station the next day but were informed that the children were rescued in Aligarh,” he said. “The boys told me in front of police that they got scared and gave a statement against the madrasa,” he added. Senior superintendent of police (Ghaziabad) Sudhir Kumar Singh, said that no missing report has been lodged in any police station in the city. Meanwhile, Vikas Chandra, additional probation officer (Ghaziabad) told TOI, “We will check whether the madrassa is registered or not and then an appropriate action will be taken,” he added

column2: Ghaziabad: Two held after gunfight for BJP worker’s murder
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two men were arrested following a gunfight with policemen in Masuri area on Saturday night, hours after they had pumped four bullets into a BJP functionary. The two men, identified as Shahrukh (22) and Tehseem (24), carried a reward of Rs 25,000 each on their head. Around 9.30pm on Saturday, Balbir Singh Tomar, BJP’s zonal president in Dasna, was shot dead by four bike-borne men. Tomar ran a nursing home in Dhoodhiya-Peepal area and was standing near a paan shop when he was attacked. SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun told TOI that a few hours later, four policemen had set up a check-post around 1km from the spot where Tomar was shot. “The team of policemen signalled the duo to stop but they started firing at them instead. One of the policemen in the team called for reinforcements and another team reached the spot from Masuri police station. The team chased the accused and managed to nabbed them after 2km,” Jadaun said. “Shahrukh and Tahseem were arrested and the scooter they were riding was seized. The scooter belongs to Shahrukh. We also recovered two country-made pistols from them,” he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Police said they were looking for two more — Salman and Aman — in connection with Tomar’s murder. The arrested duo have apparently told interrogators that four of them had surrounded Tomar and shot him with their country-made guns. “They pumped one bullet each into the BJP worker,” the officer said. According to police, Tomar’s murder was the fallout of a controversy surrounding a woman who had eloped with a man from her neighbourhood on July 4. The BJP member had apparently supported the man’s family, which angered relatives of the woman. Ghaziabad SP Sudhir Singh said: “Aman is the brother of the woman who had run away, while Salman is her cousin. As Tomar supported the man, the woman’s brother decided to kill him.” The station house officer of Masuri police station and a police post in-charge have been suspended for dereliction of duty following the murder. “It was a planned murder. Despite the controversy that erupted after the woman fled and the BJP worker getting involved in it, the two officers could not intensify vigil in the area,” the SSP said.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: No more tipsy trips for UPSRTC drivers
column3: LUCKNOW: Drivers of UPSRTC buses can no longer dare to “drink and drive”. To ensure that its drivers are not under the influence of alcohol while on duty, Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation has decided to use breath analyser on each of them before and after completion of every trip. Even the contractual drivers of UPSRTC will have to undergo the tests. On Sunday, the corporation officials issued a mandate that all 286 state-run bus stations in the state must be equipped with breath analysers. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.UPSRTC, which at present has 36 breath analysers, will buy 250 more machines to enforce the ‘Don’t drink and drive’ rule. The corporation will also conduct surprise breath analyser tests on drivers during the trips. “Any bus driver found drunk during checking will be suspended immediately while contractual drivers will be removed from service on the spot,” UPSRTC managing director Raj Shekhar told TOI. At present, there are 286 bus stations in 75 UP districts. Until now, UPSRTC was using only 36 breath analysers in key districts such as Lucknow, Gorakhpur, Allahabad, Varanasi, Agra and Moradabad. “UPSRTC has sanctioned the budget and issued instructions for purchase of 250 more breath analysers. They will be bought in next two weeks after which the checking on all routes will begin. The safety of passengers is our top priority,” said Raj Shekhar. Latest CommentOnly when the lives are lost, the authorities get a jolt of get going. Why aren''t the passenger safety measures implement beforehand? UP is a terrible state because of its lazy and ignorant authorities and police.Abhishek BaliSee All CommentsAdd commentThe corporation has begun ting measures for passengers’ safety in the aftermath of the recent accident on Yamuna Expressway in which 29 people were killed when their bus plunged into a gorge after its driver dozed off. UPSRTC has also directed its regional and assistant regional managers to set up awareness camps on ‘Safe driving habits’ and “safety of passengers” at all bus stations. The initiative is aimed at motivating drivers to give up drinking for their good health and safety of passengers whom they ferry every day.

column2: Kanpur: Muslims bond with Shiva devotees outside temples
column3: KANPUR: The growing communal strife and incidents of attacks on innocent youths might have made the region sensitive, but still there are instances which present a perfect example of communal harmony. On Sunday, a group of Muslims at Jajmau’s Siddhnath Ghat Shiv temple, during the ongoing Shrawan month, showed an exemplary gesture that gave a message of communal harmony. On the first ‘Somvar’ (Monday) of the Shrawan month, when Hindus were visiting Shiv temple at Siddhnath Ghat, the Muslims welcomed the devotees by offering them fruit, juice, water and milk. They also extended festival wishes to the devotees. Shiv temple at Siddhnath Ghat on the banks of the Ganga is a prominent Shiv temples in the city. The initiative to offer fruit juice and milk and welcoming the Hindu devotees at the temple was taken by the management of Kanpur Samaj Samiti, known for working to maintain Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb in the city. Top CommentIt is only the dirty politicians who divide the people for their selfish political game!!😢😢😢RameshSee All CommentsAdd comment“While this is a Hindu festival, in an extremely touching gesture of brotherhood, the way the Muslims distribute fruit, juice, water and milk to the devotees is praiseworthy,” said a devotee. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Most of the devotees come from far off places. Such refreshments not only help them maintain their energy, it also spreads a gesture of love, brotherhood, and help maintain peace in the society,” said a local Shailendra Dwivedi. President of Kanpur Samaj Samiti Anwar Husain said, “India is a home to many religions, and all religions preach compassion, love for human beings and virtues. We should respect all religions the way we respect our own religion since the message of all religions is the same.”

column2: Lucknow: Students make their varsity proud with PCS(J) success
column3: Lucknow: Dr Ram Manohar Lohiya National Law University (RMLNLU) couldn't be any more proud with as many as 30 of its present and former students cracking the Provincial Civil Services (Judicial) Exam-2018, the results of which were declared on Saturday. The number is expected to cross 50 as over 100 students from the university, who had appeared for the Mains exam, are yet to share their results. RMNLU officials said the university's social media accounts were flooded with entries just a few hours after it asked present and former students to share their PCS (J) results. "At RMNLU, faculty members train students to rise up to meet the intricate challenges of litigation. We are happy to know that a many of our students will be adorning benches in courts. It's a good sign for India that students from National Law Universities are now willing to join the judiciary," said RMNLU's vice-chancellor SK Bhatnagar. The maximum number of students qualifying the PCS (J) examination were from the 2016 and 2017 batch of BBA LLB (Hons). Two research scholars- Anurag and Sonal Upadhyay-secured the highest ranks among RMNLU students who qualified the exam. Anurag who bagged the 66th rank is researching on 'utility of forensic science in criminal justice administration'. "The dedication of the faculty members is a big reason for our success. There is no match for professors like KA Pandey whose criminal law classes have groomed hundreds of judicial services aspirants," said Anurag. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: With her Sonbhadra ‘satyagraha’, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra floors other parties
column3: Lucknow: Did Priyanka Gandhi Vadra manage to hog all the limelight during her 48-hour “satyagraha” to meet family members of the victims of the Sonbhadra massacre, where 10 people were killed last week, and leave other political parties floored? By taking on the state government head on, a belligerent Priyanka has also attempted to draw up a roadmap for the forthcoming 12 byelections, and then the Assembly elections in 2022 in the state, by sending out a clear message that she would make her presence felt in Uttar Pradesh. On July 17, a land dispute led to 10 people being killed in Ubha village in Sonbhadra district. Priyanka smelt an opportunity to attack the ruling BJP and rushed from Delhi to meet the victims’ kin when district authorities stopped her from reaching Sonbhadra and the confrontation lasted for almost three days. When Priyanka dug her heels in, despite being stopped on her tracks in the adjoining Mirzapur district state government agreed to allow victims’ kin to come and meet her. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath visited the victims’ families on Sunday, allowing Priyanka to take a pot shot at him on Twitter. During her three-daylong stay in UP, which the ruling BJP dubbed as “drama”, Priyanka had questioned why not a single representative of the BJP went to share their condolences. Priyanka’s approach also left the two regional parties – Samajwadi Party and Bahujan Samaj Party – behind in seizing the opportunity to make a mark. The SP and BSP leadership remained confined to statements on Twitter from Lucknow, while Priyanka was on ground, staging protests and confronting district officers in the heat and dust. Even Apna Dal MP from Mirzapur Anupriya Patel, an ally of the BJP, did not turn up to meet the families of the victims. Priyanka met kin of victims on Saturday at Chunar guesthouse

column2: A musical night in Lucknow
column3: A private academy of dance and music organised its 13th annual function titled Hunar-e-Awadh recently at the Urdu Academy auditorium. The chief guest of the event was Preeti M Shah while the other honourable guests included Ratnakar Maurya, film and serial producer, Harsh Vardhan Agarwal, former member of Film Bandhu and Vijay Banerjee. (L) Harsh Vardhan Agarwal (R) Preeti M Shah (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Harsh Vardhan Agarwal (R) Preeti M Shah (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) The very first performance of the evening was of Kathak on the song 'Namo Namo Ji Shankara'. Soon after that, contemporary and other dance forms were performed by the students of the academy on different songs including 'Yeh Ratein Yeh Mausam', 'Ghar More Pardesia', etc. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Priya Srivastava (R) Shraddha Agarwal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Priya Srivastava (R) Shraddha Agarwal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) A Kathak fusion by Aadya Mishra on the song Mere Rashke Qamar earned her a huge round of applause. And the event was not only about dancing but singing too. Pankaj Sharma’s melodious singing on the song Gulabi Ankhein earned him an encore from the audience. — Saad Abbasi

column2: Lucknowites laughed out loud watching this play
column3: Theatre lovers waited eagerly in large numbers outside the Thrust auditorium of Bhartendu Natya Akademi in Gomti Nagar when the play 'Jaat Hi Pucho Sadhu Ki' was staged there, recently. The play had actors of the National School of Drama Repertory performing on stage. (L) Basant (R) Shubham Pareek and Shruti Mishra (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Basant (R) Shubham Pareek and Shruti Mishra (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The play was a Hindi translation of acclaimed playwright Vijay Tendulkar's Marathi play Pahije Jatiche by Vasant Dev and was directed by Rajinder Nath. The comedy play started with the lead character Mahipat, who gives a biographical sketch of his life. He talks about accomplishing the only one thing he aimed to do in his life, completing MA before dying. The play focused on how Mahipat lands a job in a university but ends up being an educated unemployed young man. "Of all the comedy plays written in any Indian language I know of, I consider Jaat Hi Pucho Saadhu Ki as the best," said Rajinder Nath. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Prafull Gaur (R) Pragya Saxena (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Prafull Gaur (R) Pragya Saxena (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Shubham Pareek essayed the role of Mahipat and was successful in making the audience laugh with his wit and punches. Other characters in the play included Sina, Ishwar Bhai, Laundry Wala and Hanuman Seth which were played by Suresh Sharma, Raju Roy, Moti Lal Khare and Siddheswar Kashinath Thorat, respectively. "The play had me in a rollercoaster of laughter. It was worth watching this two-hour long drama," saidPratyaksh. column2: A power packed act by these class XII students in Lucknow
column3: A play titled 'Hamara Adhikaar' was recently staged at Rai Umanatah Bali Auditorium. The highlight of the play was that it was written and directed by students of class XII. While Mohd Aman directed it, Mohd Saif and Kajal Gautam, along with Aman, wrote the play. The chief guests of the event were Vijay Kumar and Aditi Umrav who lit the inaugural lamp. (L) Aditi Umrav (R) Amresh Kumar (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Aditi Umrav (R) Amresh Kumar (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The plot of the play revolved around four friends named Arya, Raghav, Manav and Paune Teen. All of them being huge fans of cricket, stride off after their studies in search of a job. Unfortunately, none of them gets a job. And when they notice that non-deserving candidates are getting jobs with the power of money, the disappointment they feel causes their lives to take an unfortunate turn. All of them plan a bank robbery and end up stabbing the bank manager. (L) Dr Anil Kumar (R) Mahesh Chandra Deva (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Dr Anil Kumar (R) Mahesh Chandra Deva (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Dr Rajendra and Dr Sarla Chaudhary (R) Naval Shukla (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Dr Rajendra and Dr Sarla Chaudhary (R) Naval Shukla (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Vaibhav Kanti (R) Vijay Kumar (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Vaibhav Kanti (R) Vijay Kumar (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

column2: Chandrayaan-2: Tense 48-day journey begins
column3: As Chandrayaan-2 sunbathes and stargazes its way to Moon, Isro scientists will be on the edge of their seats till the September 7 landing. Once on Moon, lander and rover will spend 14 earth days looking for water, minerals and just about anything interesting.While Chandrayaan’s entry into the initial orbit had Isro scientists at Sriharikota lean back on their chairs, it brought around 100 scientists and engineers to the edge of their seats at the Isro Telemetry, Tracking and Command (Istrac) centre in Bengaluru. “It’ll be like this for the next 62 days (48 during the journey and 14 days after the rover touches down on Moon),” said a scientist at Istrac. Chandrayaan-2 is now under Istrac’s control, and the centre is using all its ground stations in Bengaluru, Lucknow, Mauritius, Sriharikota, Port Blair, Thiruvananthapuram, Brunei, Biak (Indonesia) and the deep space network stations which will provide tracking support. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.It will be giving commands to guide the spacecraft to Moon, land and unload the rover. “Since we don’t have coverage everywhere, USowned ground stations will be helping us,” said another scientist. Istrac has got control of the spacecraft, which used its onboard sensors to correct course and align itself with Sun. “We have turned on the star sensor onboard the module,” the scientist said. In between these operations, the solar panels were deployed allowing the craft to ‘sunbathe’. While solar energy is key for its survival through the journey to Moon, the other sensor does ‘star gazing’ for coordinates to ensure it goes in the right direction. “Without gazing at the stars continuously, the spacecraft won’t be able to know where it is going. The sensor puts in the satellite’s memory patterns of stars that tell it where to go,” another scientist explained. Istrac will give commands for the orbit-raising manoeuvres. After these, the team will give commands for trans-lunar injection, putting Chandrayaan in the path of Moon. “From there on, we will push it closer to Moon with multiple engine burns and insert it into the lunar orbit,” the scientist explained. Isro chairman K Sivan was reflecting the excitement when he said the final descent “fifteen minutes of terror.” If Chandrayaan-2 was launched without a glitch on July 15, it would have reached the lunar orbit in 22 days and gone around Moon for 28 days. As per the revised schedule, the module will remain in the 100km x 100km orbit for 13 days. The orbiter, which will have the lander and rover integrated, will orbit Moon before the lander with the rover inside it separates from it. Four days after the separation, Vikram (lander) will land on the 48th day—and four hours after that, the rover (Pragyan) will crawl out of the lander. Latest CommentComplex and challenging. But if anybody can do it, the women and men of ISRO can do it. Above all backed by the good wishes of 1.3 B people minus you know who.  One point of concern, long term ISRO s...Read MoreSuvle SeekerSee All CommentsAdd commentWhile this marks the completion of the mission’s first objective, scientists at Istrac have another 14 Days of work with Pragyan —which is not autonomous — as it moves on the lunar surface for one lunar day (14 Earth days). “Pragyan has to be guided through every step. While everything that needs to be done has been done, we have to wait to see how the systems perform when they actually land on Moon,” the scientist said.

column2: 'Over 400 kids abandoned in UP since April 2017'
column3: LUCKNOW: As many as 424 infants and children were found abandoned in Uttar Pradesh between April 2017 and March 2019, chief minister Yogi Adityanath informed the assembly on Monday. Yogi said that the abandoned children were being taken care of by five state child care institutes (CCIs) and 13 non-government organisations. The centres are regulated under Adoption Regulations, 2017, envisaging adoption of children by childless couples. He was replying to a query of SP MLA Irfan Solanki who sought to know how many instances of infant killing and children being abandoned had been reported in UP.  National Commission for Protection of Child Rights has asked the government to set up more CCIs where abandoned children could be kept. As per an estimate, there are around 8,000 registered and unregistered CCIs. Kids in unregistered CCIs are more vulnerable to poor care, physical and sexual abuse, and trafficking, NCPCR had observed.

column2: Healthcare boost: UP government mulls two six-hour OPD shifts in hospitals
column3: LUCKNOW: Patients can now hope for better healthcare as the Yogi Adityanath government is planning to run out patient department (OPD) services in two sixhour shifts in all government hospitals, community health centres (CHCs) and primary health centres (PHCs) in the state. Sharing the information in the assembly on Monday, health minister Sidharth Nath Singh said the government would soon bring a proposal to this effect in cabinet. The OPD timings are from 8am to 2pm now. If the government goes ahead with the proposal, another shift of OPD would run from 2pm to 8pm. The minister was responding to a joint query raised by BSP’s deputy legislative party leader Uma Shankar Singh and Congress MLA Aditi Singh, seeking to know if the government had any plans to extend OPD timings considering the rise in number of patients and rush in hospitals. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Singh said the government was aware of the problems and was considering a proposal to extend OPD timings by another six hours. “A proposal would soon be brought in the cabinet,” Singh said. He added that the state still faces a shortage of over 2,300 doctors in district hospitals, CHCs and PHCs. Latest CommentWhere are the doctors? first increase the infra, beds and HR in govt. hospitals before any such move.IndiansSee All CommentsAdd commentSP MLA Manoj Pandey asked how many CHCs and PHCs had been constructed but were non-functional and sought to know if the government planned to make them functional in a time-bound manner. Pandey said that patients were falling prey to quacks due to shortage of doctors in government hospitals. He said around 700 people have lost their lives since 2016 after getting treated by quacks. Replying to the query, Singh said 18 CHCs and 10 PHCs were non-functional due to lack of doctors and paramedical staff. He said the government has made 52 PHCs and 47 CHCs functional since coming to power in 2017.

column2: Dalit youth set ablaze by mob in Dewa dies
column3: LUCKNOW: A Dalit youth, who was attacked and set on fire by a mob in Barabanki on July 18, died at Civil hospital here on Monday. The victim, Sujeet Kumar (26), named five persons in his dying declaration. While three accused were arrested on July 19, the remaining two accused were held on Monday. Sujeet, a resident of Tindoli Tauki Mati in Barabanki's Dewa area, had gone to his in-laws' home in Raghupurwa village when he was chased by stray dogs. Sujeet took refuge in a shed outside a house. But local villagers, including the five accused, mistook Sujeet for a thief and assaulted him. The group then poured petrol on Sujeet and set him on fire even as he kept saying that he was not a thief. Latest CommentThose who set him on fire did not know about his caste, they assumed him to be a thief. Then why use d word dalit. I wonder where is  responsible journalismPoonam DubeySee All CommentsAdd commentIn the meantime, some villagers had informed police. But by the time police rescued Sujeet, he had sustained 30% burns. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.SP Barabanki Akash Tomar said Sujeet was drunk when he was nabbed by the villagers. "Villagers drenched Sujeet in petrol with the fuel pipe of a generator before setting him on fire," Tomar added. While police claimed that only five persons lynched Sujeet, eyewitnesses said more persons were involved.

column2: Lucknow: Now, pay double for your trash collection
column3: LUCKNOW: All households in the city will now have to give their garbage to Eco-Green and pay double user charge from August. Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) has directed its waste management partner to increase coverage of door-to-door garbage collection from existing 60% households in the city to 100% within three months and has given a nod to hiking the monthly user charge from Rs 40 to Rs 80. There are 5.48 lakh households in the city. Of these, Eco-Green is covering about 3 lakh. At some places, people have hired private agencies for door-to-door garbage collection. The implementation of the new rule means that Eco-Green will replace all the private contractors. The target is to achieve Rs 2 crore revenue every month. Additional municipal commissioner Amit Singh said, "Residents currently giving Rs 40 per month for household garbage collection to Eco-Green will have to pay Rs 80 from next month. People who have hired private workers to collect daily garbage will have to stop that service and only give trash to Eco-Green." NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Earlier, LMC had decided that they will share the work burden by dividing the city in two parts. Garbage collection of zones 1 to 4 was given to Eco-Green, while zones 5 to 8 were handed to private agencies. However, the decision was changed after corporators demanded that only Eco-Green should be responsible for household garbage collection and private agencies should be deployed for cleaning of drains, sweeping of roads and collecting waste from garbage bins. After protest by corporators, LMC has given a deadline of three months to Eco-Green to cover all the 5.48 lakh households under door-to-door garbage collection. If it fails to do so, its contract will be cancelled and it will be blacklisted.

column2: 12 child marriages took place last year, says Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath also informed the House that 12 child marriages were reported from April 1 to October 2018 in the state. Maximum three child marriages were reported from Firozabad, followed by two in Agra and one each in Gautam Buddh Nagar, Hardoi, Kasganj, Maharajganj, Mainpuri, Etah and Sant Kabirnagar. SP MLA Irfan Solanki had enquired about child marriages in the state. In 2001 census report, India stated that no girl below 10 years of age was married. Since 2001, child marriage rate in India has fallen, reaching nationwide average of 7% by 2009. The Child Marriage Act has undergone several revisions since 1950. Since 1978, the minimum legal age for marriage has been 18 for women and 21 for men.

column2: UP: 103 schools used ‘ghost’ students to swindle Rs 14 crore
column3: LUCKNOW: The economic offences wing (EOW) of Uttar Pradesh Police has now unearthed a scholarship scam of Rs 14 crore in Etawah district. EOW officials on Monday said that an ongoing preliminary probe revealed that as many 103 schools, including government and private, siphoned of Rs 14 crore as scholarship for ‘ghost students’ in 2008-2009. An FIR has been registered against eight persons, including the basic shiksha adhikari, district minority officer, and principals and managers of some schools. Investigation officer of EOW, Sanjay Singh told TOI that principals and managers of 103 schools prepared fake documents in connivance with government officials to inflate student enrolment to claim and swindle scholarships given to ST/SC, minority and general category students below poverty line. “Schools that had only 20 students on roll showed enrolment of 2,000 to claim more scholarships,” added Singh. Since 2018, EOW is working on scholarship scams in previous governments. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Since, last year the economic offences wing had unearthed scams in three UP districts — Etawah, Kanpur and Meerut. Director general, EOW, R P Singh told TOI, “Soon after it came to power, the Yogi government had ordered a state-wide probe into scholarships scam.”

column2: Lucknow: Repaired before summer, ravaged by rain
column3: LUCKNOW: Two weeks' rain has exposed cosmetic repair of several city roads, where cracks and craters have resurfaced to threaten commuters within a few months. The nationally accepted standard is that a road constructed or repaired should last at least five years at a stretch, but a TOI survey in Aliganj, Jankipuram, Alambagh, Indiranagar, Mahanagar and Krishnanagar on Thursday revealed many that were tended to between January and March this year are either caving in or already riddled with ugly warts.  Asha Singh, a private tutor in Indiranagar, said she had complained to Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) several times, but in vain. "This road in Sector 21 was fixed in January, but the cosmetic fillings were washed away by the first monsoon showers. My students have sustained injuries after their cycles skidded on the uneven road. The LMC is hardly hearing my pleas," she told TOI.  Another arterial stretch between Jankipuram Sector 1 and Madiaon, which was repaired three months ago, has started wearing off. Local residents said heavy vehicles plying on this link road to Sitapur highway was taking a toll. "We suspect substandard construction. The stretch has become dangerous for commuters," said Priya Singh, a teacher. In Krishnanagar, the road near a kindergarten has developed deadly craters following waterlogging over the past week. Commuters complained that the risk of an accident increased manifold after sundown when vehicles were unable to gauge the depth of these water-filled holes. Axles can break or cars can overturn, not to mention the peril it poses to two-wheelers, they said. Let alone repaired roads, the newly built artery leading to Kathautha Chauraha in Viraj Khand, Gomtinagar, has potholes all over. Residents allege shoddy construction work for maximum profit. The substandard materials used to make the road has been unable to withstand a few spells of rain, they said.  Similar complaints are also pouring from Mahanagar, Alambagh, Sringarnagar, LDA Sector D and Chowk. Municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi denied the allegation of poor quality of road construction. "We are provisionally plugging potholes and evening out roads. Once the rainy season is over, we will revamp the roads. I can assure you that there has been no neglect on the part of officials. However, we will probe if quality of construction was not up to the mark," he said.

column2: Ghaziabad: Gang of five robbers held
column3: GHAZIABAD: A gang of five thieves, accused of committing several robberies in residential societies in the city, were arrested on Monday morning from Vijay Nagar. Jewellery worth Rs 3 lakh was recovered from their possession. The arrested have been identified as Kapil, Shariduddin, Cheen Mohammad, Sudhir and Ankit, all belonging to Bulandshahr. “The accused were produced in a city court on Monday that sent them to jail,” said Shyamvir Singh, the SHO of Vijay Nagar police station.

column2: Ghaziabad: Cop suspended, three shifted to police lines
column3: GHAZIABAD: SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh has suspended a sub-inspector, who was posted at Modinagar, for allegedly sexually harassing a woman constable. The SSP has also sent an SHO, a sub-inspector and a chowki in-charge to police lines after they were booked for corruption charges. The three police officers accused of corruption have been identified as Loni SHO Sanjay Pandey, sub-inspector at Shipra Suncity police chowki Sachin Kumar Tomar and chowki in-charge of Nehru Nagar Anirudh Kumar. In May this year, a government contractor Tushar Goel filed a complaint against the trio in the anti-corruption court for trying to implicate him in a cheating and forgery case in September 2018. He claimed that the police officers wanted to extort Rs 2 lakh from him. Latest CommentMost of these are Unpad Jahil Gawar Type people.  Prostitutes are better then these corrupt idiots.   I read on your newpaper itself, Sector 39, Sector 20 SHO in Noida were arrested running prostitution rackets.upenderSee All CommentsAdd commentOn July 17, an FIR was subsequently lodged against the three police officers under IPC sections 420 (cheating), 467 (forgery of valuable security), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), 471 (using as genuine a forged document or electronic record), 506 (criminal intimidation) and 504 (breach of peace) and under relevant sections of the Prevention of Corruption Act. column2: Historic Kakori case to come alive through dastangoi
column3: LUCKNOW: With the reverberations of ‘Rang de basanti chola’ and ‘Sarfaroshi ki tamanna’, Lucknowites will witness the saga of the Kakori Train action that will come alive through a Dastangoi session on August 9. Commemorating the 94th anniversary of Kakori case, city-based artist Himanshu Bajpai will recreate this important milestone in the history of Indian freedom struggle using the centuries’ old art of storytelling at Kakori Shaheed Smarak Sthal. SkipVarious ‘nazms’ written and sung by Kakori revolutionaries Ashfaqulla Khan, Ram Prasad Bismil, Roshan Singh and others while spending their time behind the bars at Lucknow Central Jail will be presented in the one-and-a-half-hour show. “The song ‘Mera rang de basanti chola’ was originally written by Bismil and other freedom-fighters when behind the bars. The musical ‘dastangoi’ will give an insight into the episode,” said Bajpai. column2: Commuters to face diversions for kanwariyas’ smooth passage
column3: GHAZIABAD: Commuters are set to face several route diversions that are being put in place for the kanwar season. Movement of heavy vehicles on Delhi-Meerut road has been banned till July 31. The same rule will become applicable to light vehicles from July 25. Heavy vehicles moving from Delhi towards Bulandshahr and Haridwar have been diverted to NH-9 via UP Gate. Vehicles going towards Meerut will first reach Hapur and then move towards their destination. SkipOne side of the Delhi-Meerut carriageway (from Meerut to Ghaziabad) has been kept for kanwariyas. Till July 25, cars and two-wheelers will be allowed to move in both directions on the adjacent side of the carriageway. Movement of vehicles on GT Road from Chaudhary Mor to Jassipura has completely stopped. Vehicles have also been banned from Police Chowki Teela Mor to Muradnagr via Pipeline Road. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy. A special mobile phone app has been developed to provide information about schedules to facilitate smooth conduct of the yatra. Meanwhile, massive security arrangements have been put in place to ensure the smooth movement of kanwariyas. Over 20 lakh devotees are expected to pass through the district in the next nine days. More than 200 cameras have been installed on the route from Modinagar to Ghaziabad and police have sought permission for drones and choppers to monitor the area. SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun, the nodal officer, said, “The cameras are being set up at spots identified by police. A control room has been set up at Meerut road trisection.” Top Commenthope this time commuters will not been beaten up or their vehciles won't be burned AbhishekSee All CommentsAdd commentBesides 1,500 local police, PAC teams have been deployed on the route. A NDRF team has also been kept in reserve, police said. ADM (city) Shailendra Kumar Singh said, “Altogether 90 camps have been put up for kanwariyas’ night stay. Security at Dudheshwar Nath temple in Kotwali area, where devotees will pay a visit, has been tightened.” Meat shops on the kanwar route have been asked to shut down during this period.

column2: An 'aam' affair for Kanpur ladies
column3: A ladies club in Kanpur organized a mango festival theme party, recently. Organised at a banquet hall in the city, the members of the club gathered in full strength to make the do a successful one. Most of the women, going by the theme came dressed in yellow Indian and western attires. Even the venue was beautifully decorated with cut-outs of mangoes and mango trees apart from other matching decorations. column2: Pata nahi bachchon se milne aaye hain ya TV dekhne aaye hain Lucknow: Ayushmann Khurrana
column3: Regular to Lucknow now, all thanks to back-to-back shootings of his films in the city, actor Ayushmann Khurrana is not missing any opportunity to explore the city. A few days back, the actor had posted an online video of his secret visit to the Saadat Ali’s Maqbara in Qaiserbagh. Even his wife Tahira Kashyap Khurrana had paid him a surprise visit last week with their two kids. And it is now learnt that the 'Badhaai Ho' actor’s parents were in Lucknow to spend time with him and his brother Aparshakti, who is also shooting for a film in Lucknow these days. A complete foodie at heart, Ayushmann shared a picture of pinni ke laddoo which his mom had got for them from Chandigarh. "Mumma pinniyaan le ke aayi hai Chandigarh se, humare liye Lucknow," he shared on his Instagram account. Ayushmann Khurrana posted a picture on Instagram of his parents watching TV while in Lucknow (BCCL/ @ayushmannk) Ayushmann Khurrana posted a picture on Instagram of his parents watching TV while in Lucknow (BCCL/ @ayushmannk) And while the actor, who is presently shooting for Gulabo Sitabo in the city, had plans to take his parents out for Lucknow darshan, they had some other plans on mind. Ayushmann jokingly complained wrote on Insta, about his parents relaxing in the hotel room watching TV. "Pata nahi bachchon se milne aaye hain ya TV dekhne aaye hain Lucknow," wrote the actor and also shared a small video of theirs.
