column2: Isro chief, Lalu Yadav lose central security cover
column3: NEW DELHI: In a major review of security cover of various politicians and VIPs, the home ministry has withdrawn the central security of RJD chief Lalu Prasad and BSP leader Satish Chandra Mishra, apart from reviewing NSG protection to former UP CM Akhilesh Yadav. The security cover of several others has been downgraded as part of a review involving over 100 cases. Lalu and UP minister Suresh Rana have been removed from the central protectees list, while UP MLA Sangeet Som's security has been downgraded from 'Z' to 'Y' category. The security of Isro chairman K Sivan too has been withdrawn, PTI said. Other 'Y-plus' protectees removed from the central list include ex-MP Avtar Singh Bhadana, ex-MP from Bihar Jitendra Swami, Punjab MLA Rana Gurmeet Singh Sodhi and Bihar ex-MP Sabir Ali. TNN & AGENCIES According to a PTI report, 'Z-plus' NSG protectee Akhilesh Yadav, 'Z' category protectees Lalu, BJP MP and ex-minister Rajiv Pratap Rudy, former BJP members Kirti Azad and Shatrughan Sinha have been taken off the central list of protectees. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Newly appointed Himachal Pradesh governor Kalraj Mishra, former Lok Sabha Speaker Meira Kumar, two granddaughters and a grandson of former President Pranab Mukherjee, daughter and grandson of former PM Manmohan Singh have been taken off the central list of protectees. These VIPs were being secured by armed commandos of Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs) like the CRPF, CISF and NSG besides Delhi Police. As per an order on Monday, Satish Mishra, until now a 'Z plus' protectee, has been removed from the central list and will only be provided 'Z' security in UP. JVM(P) leader Babulal Marandi will now get 'Z' cover protection in Jharkhand only. Adviser to J&K governor K Vijay Kumar has been removed from the central list but will be entitled to 'Z plus' cover in LWE-affected states. The security of Abhijeet Mukherjee, the MP-son of former President Pranab Mukherjee, Congress leader Anand Sharma, Raj Babbar, Digvijaya Singh, A K Antony, Manish Tewari, Loktantrik Janata Dal Party leader Sharad Yadav, CPM leader Sitaram Yechury, former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee's foster daughter Namita Kaul Bhattacharya and former BJP leader Yashwant Sinha has also been downgraded. Others whose security has been withdrawn include MP from Bihar's Vaishali seat Veena Devi, former MP from the state Uday Singh, UP minister Brajesh Pathak, BJP politician Anupam Hazra, former scientific adviser R Chidambaram and Congress leader Deependra Hooda, PTI said. Top CommentISRO Chief''s security must be restored. That is awrong decision.Ashok BhagatSee All CommentsAdd commentBJP's Rajya Sabha MP O P Mathur; Achrya Pramod Krishnam, who unsuccessfully contested from the Lucknow parliamentary seat on a Congress ticket; RSS leader Indresh Kumar; former BJP MP Udit Raj; and sitting BJP MP from Etawah Ram Shankar Katheria have also been taken off from the protection list of central security forces. The cover of UP deputy CM Dinesh Sharma, Punjab minister Rana Gurmit Sodhi, ex-Bihar MP Sabir Ali, Congress MP from Punjab Pratap Singh Bajwa, VC of Manipur University Adya Prasad Pandey, space scientist T K Alex and a few others have also been taken off the central list.

column2: Was Gumnami Baba Netaji? Not sure: Report
column3: LUCKNOW: The Justice Vishnu Sahai Commission’s report on the mysterious ‘Gumnami Baba’, which was tabled in the UP cabinet on Tuesday, says it’s difficult to determine whether he was indeed Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, as popularly believed. The findings of the commission formed in 2016, which will now be tabled in the UP assembly, reportedly only draw parallels between Bose and the Baba. It mentions that other than literature in English, Bengali and Hindi, the three languages in which Netaji was fluent, books on Bose himself and authors he liked to read have been recovered. Sources said that the report also mentions that Gumnami Baba was also fluent in these three languages and was an influential person to whom people flocked. “As per the report, Gumnami Baba continued to stay in his Faizabad house till rumours of him being Subhash Chandra Bose surfaced, after which he left that place,” said the source. The report, prepared by Justice Vishnu Sahai, was commissioned by the SP government in 2016 on directions of Allahabad HC. The court order followed a PIL, in which the petitioner claimed that Gumnami Baba was Netaji. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Sahai had told TOI in September 2017 — a day after submitting the report to the governor — that many people he interviewed had come with the pre-conceived notion that Gumnami Baba was Bose. He said collecting reliable testimony was a challenge since Baba died in 1985 and witnesses deposed before the commission only in 2016 and 2017. Read this story in Bengali

column2: Lucknow mother tosses baby out of hospital window
column3: LUCKNOW: Depressed over the medical condition of her three-month-old son, a woman tossed him out of the fourth floor window of Trauma Centre of King George's Medical University (KGMU) early Tuesday. The baby died instantly. He was being treated for congenital liver disease at the neonatal unit of the hospital since May 26. The mother, Shanti, wife of a daily wager Rajan Singh of Kaushambi, was arrested on the complaint of her husband and hospital administration. While Shanti sat emotionless at the police station and refused to answer queries from police, Rajan said his wife sunk into depression after suffering three miscarriages. "The deteriorating health of the baby took a toll on her mental health. I told my wife several times the situation would improve, but to no avail. I never imagined she would take such an extreme step," he said. Top CommentInstead of arrest her and pressuring more, give better counselling and normalise her mental state. The poor woman already in depression and need a better assistance good peopleMakdxbSee All CommentsAdd commentThe baby was born premature on April 23 at BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur and was suffering from liver disease, jaundice, pyogenic meningitis (bacterial infection of membrane that surrounds the brain). He was referred to KGMU for advanced treatment. column2: Rs 1,150 crore budget booster for Bundelkhand e-way
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government tabled a supplementary budget of Rs 13,594 crore in UP assembly on Tuesday, signifying its emphasis on infrastructure development with allocations for Bundelkhand expressway, Purvanchal expressway and Ganga Expressway. The government also gave budgetary thrust to development of Ayodhya and Vindhyachal to boost religious tourism in state. The supplementary demands for current 2019-20 financial year were tabled by finance minister Rajesh Agarwal in presence of CM Yogi Adityanath. The government had tabled annual Budget 2019-20 of Rs 4.79 lakh crore on February 7. The supplementary budget is presented when the general Budget is not enough for government schemes. Of Rs 13,594 crore, capital expenditure accounts for over Rs 5,200 crore, and Rs 8,300 crore for expenses. Infrastructural projects got a total of around Rs 2,100 crore, including Rs 1,150 crore allocation for Bundelkhand expressway, Rs 850 crore for Purvanchal expressway and Rs 15 crore for preparation of detailed project report for Ganga expressway. The allocation for the 294 km green-field expressway connecting Etawah with Chitrakoot bears out the government's focus on development of the backward Bundelkhand region. column2: Lucknow: Patient dies of lethal fungal infection
column3: LUCKNOW: A patient, who died of sepsis at the ventilator unit of King George’s Medical University Trauma Centre on Monday, was also suffering from the lethal fungal infection caused by Candida auris. The infection was confirmed in microbiology test reports that arrived on Tuesday, making it the second case at the facility in the last one week. It is the first time Candida auris has been reported in KGMU. The ventilator unit has been closed following an alert by the Infection Control Cell. Trauma Centre in-charge and King George’s Medical University spokesperson, Dr Sandeep Tiwari, said the deceased, Abdul Mangi (45) was admitted on July 12 with intestinal perforation caused by typhoid that also led to sepsis. After corrective surgery, he was kept on ventilator in the intensive care unit (ICU). NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Mangi’s bed was adjacent to Khoob Lal, who was being treated for head injuries caused in an accident. As Lal developed symptoms caused by Candida auris, doctors sent his blood samples for test on July 13. The reports arrived on July 18 confirming Lal had the infection. He was immediately shifted to isolation room. “On July 20, blood samples of all six ICU patients and staff members were sent for test. However, Mangi’s condition deteriorated and he died on Monday. The reports that arrived on Tuesday showed Mangi was infected,” said Prof GP Singh, incharge of Trauma Centre ventilator units and head of anaesthesia department. When asked if Mangi died of sepsis or Candida auris infection, Dr Tiwari said, “Nothing can be said with certainty now. We have taken all precautionary measures to check the spread of infection. The ICU has been shut for fumigation. Samples have also been collected from walls, beds and floor. Khoob Lal responded to antifungal drugs and is out of danger now.” Dr D Himanshu, department of medicine, under whose supervision Lal is being treated now, said “Candida auris can be fatal because it often does not respond to commonly used antifungal drugs, making infections difficult to treat. It occurs in patients with low immunity, especially in ICU, and can spread in entire body through bloodstream.”

column2: Ayodhya’s Saryu banks in for a Har ki Pauri-like makeover
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP government has grandiose plans to remodel Ayodhya’s Saryu banks around Haridwar’s Har ki Pauri and has allocated Rs 10 crore for the project in the supplementary budget tabled in the assembly on Tuesday. A flight of steps takes pilgrims to Ayodhya’s Ram ki Paidi on Nayaghat where they bathe in the Saryu. In another funds boost for the temple town, Rs 6 crore has been allocated for the forthcoming ‘Deepotsav’, which is organized on Diwali since BJP came to power in 2017. In another boost to tourism, Rs 20 crore has been allocated in the budget for the under-construction Mughal Museum in Agra. Last year, chief minister Yogi Adityanath had renamed Faizabad district as Ayodhya and proposed Rs 101 crore for integrated development of the temple town. On Tuesday, finance minister Rajesh Agarwal announced Rs 100 crore for development of various tourist spots in the state. Vindhyavasini Dham in Mirzapur too got a funds thrust with the government allocating Rs 10 crore for its development. The presiding deity, Vindhyavasini, is considered to be a manifestation of Durga and is family goddess (Kul Devi). NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Situated on the banks of Ganga and strategically located between two prominent Hindu cities of Prayag (Allahabad) and Kashi (Varanasi), Vindhyavasini Dham is visited by lakhs of pilgrims every year. The state government also allocated Rs 10 crore for Namisharanya in Sitapur district. Likewise, a budgetary allocation of Rs 2 crore was made for development of Raja Rao Ram Baksh Singh park in Unnao.

column2: Not sure if Gumnami Baba was Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose: Report
column3: LUCKNOW: The Justice Vishnu Sahai Commission’s report on the mysterious ‘Gumnami Baba’, which was tabled in the UP cabinet on Tuesday, says it’s difficult to determine whether he was indeed Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose, as popularly believed. The findings of the commission formed in 2016, which will now be tabled in the UP Assembly, reportedly only draw parallels between Bose and the Baba. It mentions that other than literature in English, Bengali and Hindi, the three languages in which Netaji was fluent, books on Bose himself and authors he liked to read have been recovered. Sources said that the report also mentions that Gumnami Baba was also fluent in these three languages and was an influential person to whom people flocked. The report also mentions Gumnami Baba’s love for music and cigars,” said the source. The report, prepared by Justice Vishnu Sahai, was commissioned by the SP government in 2016 on directions of Allahabad High Court. The court order followed a PIL, in which the petitioner claimed that Gumnami Baba was Netaji. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Sahai had told TOI in September 2017, a day after submitting the report to the governor, that many people he interviewed had come with the pre-conceived notion that Gumnami Baba was indeed Bose. He, however, added that collecting reliable testimony was a challenge since the Baba died in 1985 and witnesses deposed before the commission only in 2016 and 2017.

column2: ‘Police didn’t act against guilty in Kashi stampede’
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government presented the action taken report (ATR) of the stampede at Rajghat in Varanasi during a ‘shobha yatra’ (religious procession) in October 2016 in the assembly on Tuesday. The report says that police did not take action against prime accused Pankaj Maharaj of Jai Gurudev Sanstha, responsible for the death of 25 pilgrims in the stampede in October 2016 when Samajwadi Party government was in power. Jai Gurudev Santha had sought permission from district administration for taking out a ‘shobha yatra’ near Rajghat in Varanasi. As the procession reached Rajghat bridge, there was a stampede leading to death of 25 pilgrims on the spot and causing injuries to many. The report states there was a minor clash on October 15 between two bikers at Rajghat bridge causing injuries to a woman which led to a verbal dual between the two causing a traffic jam on the bridge. In the meantime, the participants of Jaigurudev yatra also arrived. While there was a jam, a train passed below the bridge causing tremors. Some pilgrims jumped off the bridge while others ran helter-skelter leading to on the spot death of 25 participants of shobha yatra and leaving scores injured. The one-man judicial commission headed by Justice (retired) Rajmani Chauhan found that the chairman of Jai Gurudev Sanstha, Pankaj Maharaj kept police and district administration in dark about the huge crowd and said only 3,000 people would join the shobha yatra. “Police had registered criminal case against Pankaj Maharaj, but one does not know why no action was taken against him. It raises a question mark over the functioning of local police,” the commission’s report said. The commission recommended that in future any claims of Jai Gurudev Sanstha for organising any such programme be strictly verified and only then be allowed. CM Yogi Adityanath signed the ATR and informed the House that the recommendations of the commission have been implemented.

column2: Lucknow cops face non-bailable warrants for botching up probe
column3: LUCKNOW: A lower court on Tuesday issued non-bailable warrants (NBWs) against two policemen for “failing to appear in the murder case” of Rahul Sridhar. A Class IX student of La Martiniere College, Rahul had fallen to his death from the 100ft Constantia building on the campus on April 10, 2015. The order has been issued on the complaint of Rahul’s kin who had on September 14, 2017, moved court against then Gautampalli SHO Surendra Katiyar and SI Ram Naresh Singh. The family had said the boy was murdered and insisted the two policemen, investigating the case, had tampered with evidence to pass it off as suicide. Rahul’s mother Annamma told TOI that on the day of the incident, she had written an application asking for “fair probe” into her son’s “murder”, but SHO Katiyar got another application drafted in Hindi and “forced” her to sign it. Annamma, who is from Kerala, does not read or write Hindi. The bereaved mother said the inquest details were also tampered with and witness signatures on the report forged. The procedure of performing inquest in the presence of a magistrate was not followed either. The bed linen in which Rahul’s body was brought to the mortuary was burnt while his school uniform went missing. Police recovered the student’s phone 24 hours later and tampered with it, the mother alleged. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The family’s lawyer Alok Kumar Singh said police had till date not clarified the role of Larry Conners who was in touch with Rahul over Facebook, and had allegedly lured the boy into dark and violent web games.

column2: Additional funds to equip SGPGI with advanced technology
column3: LUCKNOW: The allocations made by the state government for Sanjay Gandhi Post-Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences would be used to buy new medical equipment for the apex trauma centre. A provision of Rs 7 crore has been made in the supplementary budget for the institute. While a part of the money would go for the purchase of necessary equipment to conduct neuroendoscopy, the remaining would be used in the installation of VATS (video-assisted thorascopic surgery system). The equipment will be procured and installed before March 31, 2020. Chief medical superintendent, SGPGIMS, Prof Amit Aggarwal said, “Neuroendoscopy is a minimally-invasive surgical procedure which removes the tumor through small holes made in the skull or through the mouth or nose. VATS is a thoracic surgery performed using a small video camera which is introduced into the patient’s chest via small incisions.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Both the equipment will enhance surgical precision which will minimise the risk of human error. Patients will also recover faster because of smaller incisions and reduced hospitalisation,” said Prof Aggarwal. Nearly a decade after its inception, SGPGI’s apex trauma centre started in July last year with 60 beds. The number of beds would be increased to 210 in a phased manner.

column2: UP supplementary budget gives boost to tourism, infrastructure
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government tabled a supplementary budget of Rs 13,594 crore in UP assembly on Tuesday, signifying emphasis on infrastructure development with allocations for Bundelkhand expressway, Poorvanchal expressway and Ganga expressway. The government also gave budgetary thrust to development of Ayodhya and Vindhyachal to boost religious tourism in state.  The supplementary demands for current 2019-20 financial year were tabled by finance minister Rajesh Agrawal in presence of CM Adityanath. The government had tabled annual budget 2019-20 of Rs 4.79 lakh crore on February 7. The supplementary budget is presented when the general budget is not enough for government schemes.

column2: Ghaziabad: Students protest over admission
column3: GHAZIABAD: Around hundred students, including some members of the Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), allegedly barged into the principal’s office at Lajpat Rai College in Sahibabad on Tuesday and staged a protest after officials denied admission to some students named in the last cut-off list. The students locked up the main door for over four hours and demanded that the principal meets them. The students alleged that the management of the college was admitting students who got lower marks than those whose names appeaared in the list. But, principal S D Kaushik said, “All admissions were done according to UGC rules.”

column2: And these boys are back to school in Lucknow!
column3: WALKING DOWN MEMORY LANE: Continuing the tradition of meeting on Sunday morning for some gupshup and chai, the old boys of a boys’ college recently met to celebrate the event, Jashn-e-Itwar’s 400th edition. Around 100 alumni, along with their families, came to take a walk down memory lane and enjoy the celebrations. What made the do more special was the presence of several teachers and the former principal of the college who too joined the celebrations. (L) Dr Pooja and Dr Manish Gulati (R) Himani and Mayank (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Dr Pooja and Dr Manish Gulati (R) Himani and Mayank (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) OLD IS GOLD: A student of the 1960 batch Vishan Prakash, said, "It really feels nice to be here, meeting old friends today, several childhood memories got refreshed." Shantanu Kumar, Deep Prakash and Dharmendra Sikka were seen welcoming the alumni for the celebrations. (L) Fr Vincent Pinto (R) Humera and Arshaq Abdul (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Fr Vincent Pinto (R) Humera and Arshaq Abdul (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.SCHOOL-TIME STORIES: Sharing some fond memories of the days spent in school, Deep Prakash recalled how he was beaten up not only by his teacher but also his dad for a mischief. "I am not complaining about being beaten up here because today whatever I am is because of that only. We really miss this institution and a big thank you to this institution for everything." (L) Reeta (R) Manan Sharma and Vikas Mehta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Ma'am Reeta (R) Manan Sharma and Vikas Mehta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Another pass-out Anurag Mishra getting nostalgic, shared, "It is a pleasure and honour being back here. You feel as if you have never grown up. Every time I visit the college, it feels like I am still one of those 15-16 year old boys who is studying here. Every day spent here is a memory." Adding further with a laugh, he said, "I used to be mostly on the field with my friends and the teachers used to scold us. We have been to the principal’s room a couple of times and as a punishment got beaten up with a cane too." — Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui (L) Tanu Prakash (R) Deep Prakash and Shantanu Kumar (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Tanu Prakash (R) Deep Prakash and Shantanu Kumar (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Sanjay Pratap and Sanjay Malik (R) Shalini Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Sanjay Pratap and Sanjay Malik (R) Shalini Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Sameer and Seetu (R) Vishan Prakash (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Sameer and Seetu (R) Vishan Prakash (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Anurag Mishra (C) Nidhi Kapoor (R) Sachidanand Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Anurag Mishra (C) Nidhi Kapoor (R) Sachidanand Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: CBI charges retd HC judge, 6 others in medical college case
column3: NEW DELHI: The Central Bureau of Investigation has chargesheeted retired Odisha HC justice IM Quddusi and six others for allegedly conspiring to settle debarment of a private medical college in Lucknow.  Besides the former judge, the CBI has accused Bhawna Pandey, Bhagwan Prasad Yadav, Palash Yadav, Sudhir Giri, Bishwanath Agarwala and Ram Dev Saraswat of corruption and criminal conspiracy. The CBI has alleged that Quddusi, with the assistance of other accused, not only legally guided the functionaries of the private medical college but also assured them of a favourable judicial settlement. The chargesheet was filed before special judge Anil Kumar Sisodia on July 8 and posted for consideration on August 2. Advocate Vijay Aggarwal, who is representing Quddusi and other accused persons, said, "As there is no public servant in the chargesheet, a corruption case won't survive. My clients even got bail on the same argument."  The CBI had carried out raids in Bhubaneswar, Lucknow and Delhi, including at the Greater Kailash residence of Justice Quddusi (Retd). CBI also raided several private persons and a hawala dealer from whom a Rs 1 crore bribe was being collected to be paid on to some government servants in Delhi to settle the matter. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy. Quddusi and others were booked under sections of the IPC. The CBI had received information that Prasad Institute of Medical College was among the 46 colleges barred by the government from admitting medical students for the forthcoming one or two years because of substandard facilities and non-fulfilment of the required criteria. The Yadavs, who run the institute, had challenged the debarment in the SC in 2017. Top CommentTime for public not to show undue respects to judges. They r also corrupt! The punishment for them should be much much higher.Domo SlateSee All CommentsAdd comment On August 1, 2017, the SC had directed the government to consider afresh the material on record pertaining to the issue of confirmation or otherwise of the letter of permission granted to the petitioner college. A hearing was given to the college by the government, which made a reasoned decision on August 10, 2017 to debar the college from admitting fresh students for 2017-18 and 2018-19 and to authorise MCI to encash the bank guarantees of Rs 2 crore. The CBI received information that BP Yadav had allegedly got in touch with Quddusi and Pandey through Giri of Venkateshwara Medical College in Meerut and conspired to get the matter settled.

column2: Athletics coach’s wife arrested for abetting Etawah student’s suicide
column3: KANPUR: Two days after Saloni Sharma (14), a class VIII student of Major Dhyan Chand Sports College in Saifai, Etawah, committed suicide in the women’s hostel, police arrested athletics coach Siddhartha’s wife Yamini on Wednesday on charges of abetting suicide. Yamini has been arrested under section 306 (abetment to suicide) of the Indian Penal Code, said a police officer. Saloni, a native of Jarar area of Baah, Agra, was a badminton player. She hanged herself from the ceiling of her hostel room on Monday night. She left behind a suicide note addressed to her family, stating that she was reeling under depression after being harassed by Yamini. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.In the suicide note, Saloni narrated that Yamini had rebuked her over a personal issue. “She said in suicide note that she does not deserve to live, and has mentioned coach Siddartha’s wife Yamini’s conversation questioning her dignity,” said DSP, Saifai, Massa Singh. Palak, a friend of the deceased had overheard the conversation between Yamini and her, he added. Saloni’s two roommates, both students of class VI, told police that 12 students were present in the hostel. “After dinner, all the girls went to sleep in their respective rooms. Saloni’s two roommates said that they heard her murmuring and writing something on a paper,” he added. Saloni’s father, Vijay Kumar, meanwhile, said that he still cannot believe that she committed suicide. “My daughter was very brave. How could she take such a step, is beyond my understanding. Police should probe the case in transparent manner and punish those responsible for her death,” he said. SSP Etawah, Santosh Misra said, “The girl’s family has not given any complaint but we took note of the suicide note and registered an FIR at Saifai Kotwali police station. We arrested Yamini on the basis of suicide note. We will investigate the case from every possible angle.” “Police later recovered a suicide note written in Hindi and English from her room, in which she had sought apology from her parents and family members for taking the extreme step,” said CO Saifai. Saloni had taken admission in the college in 2016.

column2: Roofs leak at Lucknow University, classes suspended
column3: LUCKNOW: Teaching remained suspended in science and arts faculties of Lucknow University due to leakage from roofs in classrooms following Wednesday’s rain. In physics department, practicals could not be held while classes of ancient Indian history, Sanskrit, western history, zoology, chemistry and other subjects had to be stopped midway due to leakage in classrooms following heavy rain. “There was water everywhere in the laboratory as there was leakage in all the corners of the room,” said Ankita Singh, an MSc student. “Those sitting on back rows had to move out as rain water filled the classroom,” said Deepak Rai, another student. LU spokesperson NK Pandey said, “The building is around 100 years old and is in need of massive repair and maintenance. The university doesn’t have funds to renovate all the departments.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: UP: Power bills may soon come in Hindi
column3: LUCKNOW: Energy minister Shrikant Sharma on Wednesday said that the government will try to issue power bills in Hindi in the coming days. Sharma was responding to a question by SP MLC Pervez Ali, who claimed that most people in the state were comfortable with Hindi and could not comprehend their power bills which are being issued in English. Sharma further announced that if consumers who have taken a power connection of 2KW get an annual bill of more than Rs 20,000, the government would automatically check them for discrepancies. “We will be rolling out this project from July 31. As far as issuing bills in Hindi is concerned, we will try and do that. However, certain technical phrases will continue to be in English,” he said. The power minister also revealed that more than 3,000 people were killed in 2018-19 by coming in contact with dilapidated power lines. In response to MLC Lilawati Kushwaha, Sharma said that close to 6,000 people have died in the state in 2017-18 and 2018-19 after coming in contact with dilapidated power lines. “This includes 2,877 people who died in 2017-18 and 3,029 who died in 2018-19. In 2017-18, 2,233 animals died in a similar way, followed by 1,251 deaths in 2018-19. The government has released Rs 43 crore as compensation for them,” Sharma said. The minister said the government has taken a loan of Rs 3,064 crore for changing 66,000km of lines till 2021. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: UP government busted 40,000 hooch units in last financial year
column3: LUCKNOW: More than 40,000 illicit liquor manufacturing units were busted in UP between April 2018 and March 2019, the government informed the Assembly on Wednesday. This means that more than 100 cases of hooch manufacturing were registered in the state every day during the said period. Hooch has claimed several lives in UP in the recent months. Sharing this information in the Assembly, UP excise minister Jay Pratap Singh said the government took action in over 15,000 cases through enforcement squads which included police and excise officials. The issue of hooch deaths was raised by SP legislators Manoj Pandey, Sanjay Garg, Ujjawal Raman Singh; BSP legislator Mohammad Aslam Raini and Congress MLA Aditi Singh during the question hour. They demanded the state government’s reply on the steps taken to crackdown on illicit liquor units and curbing the rising hooch death toll. SP MLA Ujjawal Raman Singh said that despite many instances of consumption of illicit liquor, the government was not doing enough to control the situation. The Opposition also alleged that the government has failed to break the nexus of police and excise officials even though illicit liquor consumption has taken several lives. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The government also informed the House about the number of hooch deaths — 26 in Azamgarh in 2017, 4 in Barabanki in 2018, 4 in Ghaziabad, and 5 in Kanpur in 2018. The highest death toll, the excise minister said, was in Saharanpur where 36 people died in February this year, while 24 hooch deaths were recorded in Barabanki in May this year, the minister said. The Opposition dismissed the government’s figures in Saharanpur tragedy and said the death toll was over 100. “Many victims were referred to Meerut medical college. Their postmortem reports are now out and clearly suggest that they died after consuming illicit liquor,” Ujjawal Raman Singh said.

They demanded the state government’s reply on the steps taken to crackdown on illicit liquor units and curbing the rising hooch death toll. SP MLA Ujjawal Raman Singh said that despite many instances of consumption of illicit liquor, the government was not doing enough to control the situation. The Opposition also alleged that the government has failed to break the nexus of police and excise officials even though illicit liquor consumption has taken several lives. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The government also informed the House about the number of hooch deaths — 26 in Azamgarh in 2017, 4 in Barabanki in 2018, 4 in Ghaziabad, and 5 in Kanpur in 2018. The highest death toll, the excise minister said, was in Saharanpur where 36 people died in February this year, while 24 hooch deaths were recorded in Barabanki in May this year, the minister said. The Opposition dismissed the government’s figures in Saharanpur tragedy and said the death toll was over 100. “Many victims were referred to Meerut medical college. Their postmortem reports are now out and clearly suggest that they died after consuming illicit liquor,” Ujjawal Raman Singh said.

column2: UP government busted 40,000 hooch units in last financial year
column3: LUCKNOW: More than 40,000 illicit liquor manufacturing units were busted in UP between April 2018 and March 2019, the government informed the Assembly on Wednesday. This means that more than 100 cases of hooch manufacturing were registered in the state every day during the said period. Hooch has claimed several lives in UP in the recent months. Sharing this information in the Assembly, UP excise minister Jay Pratap Singh said the government took action in over 15,000 cases through enforcement squads which included police and excise officials. The issue of hooch deaths was raised by SP legislators Manoj Pandey, Sanjay Garg, Ujjawal Raman Singh; BSP legislator Mohammad Aslam Raini and Congress MLA Aditi Singh during the question hour. They demanded the state government’s reply on the steps taken to crackdown on illicit liquor units and curbing the rising hooch death toll. SP MLA Ujjawal Raman Singh said that despite many instances of consumption of illicit liquor, the government was not doing enough to control the situation. The Opposition also alleged that the government has failed to break the nexus of police and excise officials even though illicit liquor consumption has taken several lives. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The government also informed the House about the number of hooch deaths — 26 in Azamgarh in 2017, 4 in Barabanki in 2018, 4 in Ghaziabad, and 5 in Kanpur in 2018. The highest death toll, the excise minister said, was in Saharanpur where 36 people died in February this year, while 24 hooch deaths were recorded in Barabanki in May this year, the minister said. The Opposition dismissed the government’s figures in Saharanpur tragedy and said the death toll was over 100. “Many victims were referred to Meerut medical college. Their postmortem reports are now out and clearly suggest that they died after consuming illicit liquor,” Ujjawal Raman Singh said.

column2: Smuggled liquor found in police officer’s private car
column3: LUCKNOW: Senior UP Police officials were left red-faced on Wednesday when photos of seized liquor being transported in the private vehicle of a police inspector in Kushinagar were posted on social media. As the photos clicked by some mediapersons went viral on Wednesday, senior officials took cognizance and sent the erring inspector to lines. Eight persons had died after consuming illicit liquor in Tarya Sujan police station area of Kushinagar between February 6 and February 8. Police had then claimed that hooch had been smuggled from Bihar and launched a crackdown on bootlegging and liquor smuggling. However, on Tuesday, instead of preventing liquor smuggling, the station house officer of Kasia, Sunil Rai, was found taking smuggled liquor seized in a raid in his private vehicle. Kushinagar SP Rajeev Mishra told TOI, “SHO Kasia, Sunil Rai was sent to the lines for not following procedures and using his private vehicle for raid.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“We have issued a show-cause notice to the SHO for using his private vehicle in raid. An ASP is probing the incident,” added Mishra. However, the report of the incident, which was sent to the DGP office tells a completely different story. TOI learnt from highly placed sources that the report sent to DGP office said that the circle officer had seized liquor from the bus stop at 3am on July 23 and summoned SHO Kasia. Instead of arresting liquor mafia Manish Rai, the SHO released him. No alcohol seizure was shown by the SHO, the report said.

column2: Ram Manohar Lohia said governments that ensure LPG, toilets rule for 50 years: Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath invoked Ram Manohar Lohia in assembly on Wednesday and said that BJP government was following the principles of socialist leader who once said that government which achieved the twin objectives of providing toilets and LPG connections to all people would rule country for 50 years. Targeting Samajwadi Party, Yogi said the opposition does politics in the name of Lohia but never even thought of abiding by his principles."A lot of people have been doing politics in Lohia ji's name, but it is BJP which abided by his principles," he said in the UP assembly. Yogi said a government which delivers what it promises comes back to power again and again. "That is why people reposed faith in us and brought BJP to power again in Lok Sabha elections," he said. This, he said, was despite the 'Gathbandhan' between SP and BSP. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy." Ab unka bhi talaq ho gaya hai (Now, they have broken up),'' he said, while taking a jibe at opposition benches. Yogi said that the government has tabled a supplementary budget of Rs 13,594 crore and now the total state budget has reached over Rs 5 lakh crore, which shows its commitment to expediting projects and schemes related to people's welfare. "The GDP of UP is around Rs 15 lakh crore. We need to increase it further," he said. The government has changed perception about the state in terms of execution of projects and on law and order front, the CM added.

column2: Green court allows Haj House in Ghaziabad to open for one month
column3: GHAZIABAD: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has ordered the de-sealing of Haj House in Ghaziabad for four weeks to ascertain the level of compliance of its sewage treatment plant (STP) that was installed recently. The Haj House was sealed on NGT orders in February last year for flouting environmental norms on a petition filed by city-based environmentalist Sushil Raghav. The NGT order, which was passed on Tuesday, said: “Let the building be de-sealed for the purpose of inspecting the compliance in the light of optimum operation of the STP. Such opening will be initially for four weeks. Thereafter, in the light of the inspection report, the SPCB (UPPCB) will be at liberty to take further decision in the matter in accordance with the law.” “We had contended in NGT when he had filed a case against construction of Haj House on the ground that it was built on Hindon flood plain area and hence it be demolished,” said Raghav, the co-petitioner. “The court, however, in its subsequent order had turned down our demolition plea but had ordered officials to ensure that a STP to treat 136 KLD of waste water has been installed in the complex or not, but since it was not installed the NGT in February last year had ordered to seal it till the time STP was installed,” added Raghav. “The court now wants to ascertain the efficiency of the STP and for that it has ordered de-sealing for four weeks and in that time the officials have been asked to ascertain whether it is working to optimum capacity,” he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The UP Pollution Control Board, after inspecting STP’s efficiency for four weeks, will have the final say in deciding whether the Haj House can be de-sealed permanently or not. The Haj House was inaugurated by the then chief minister Akhilesh Yadav in 2016.

column2: Lucknow: Pilots, parajumpers pay tribute to Kargil victory
column3: LUCKNOW: It was a burst of bold colours in the sky as wing commander TK Chaudhari para-jumped from 2,000ft, along with his team of four, at Bakshi ka Talab airbase to commemorate Kargil Vijay Diwas on Wednesday. The event, which also included motor glider and hang glider stunts, is part of a four-day programme to celebrate India’s victory in the 1999 Kargil War. Around 2,000 students from five schools and a college cheered the eight-odd performers on Day One. Owing to low visibility, a smoke trail was used on the runway to guide ALH pilots squadron leader Ajay Kumar and flying officer Shobit Oberoi who ferried the five parajumpers — wing commander DK Tyagi, master warrant officer RJ Singh, warrant officer RS Patel and sergeant B Singh, besides Chaudhary. Each jumper took nearly five minutes to touch base after which they indulged in a photo-op with students. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The motor glider show was piloted by sergeant Vishal and the hang glider stunt was presented by junior warrant officer ML Yadav. Students from Air Force School (BKT), Delhi Public School (BKT), Central Academy Jankipuram, Millennium School, Kendriya Vidyalaya Jankipuram and agriculture degree college also had the privilege to see MiG-21 engine and fuel tanks at a simultaneous exhibition at the airbase. “I want to fly the machine (an aircraft) when I grow up,” beamed KG student Aseet. Hemant, another student, expressed his ambition to become a fighter pilot someday. Twelfth grader Laxmi Singh said women para-jumpers were breaking a glass ceiling and she would like to make history too.

column2: How a Bulandshahr teen won the Param Vir Chakra
column3: LUCKNOW: Two days after his wedding in May 1999, Subedar Yogendra Singh Yadav had a nightmare. He saw a man snatching the fluttering Indian flag from a peak and running away with it. And, he knew the time had come for him to serve his motherland. Two months later, on July 4, 1999, his regiment — the 18 Grenadiers — was ordered to recapture Tiger Hill, one of the highest peaks in the Drass-Kargil sector of Jammu and Kashmir. The 19-year-old Bulandshahr boy took 14 enemy bullets, accomplished the mission and survived to become the youngest recipient of the Param Vir Chakra, India’s highest military decoration. Being the son of Karan Singh Yadav, a soldier in the Kumaon Regiment who fought the 1971 Indo-Pak War, courage was already in Yogendra’s genes. Behind enemy lines, courage under fire became his undying motto. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The Bulandshahr boy had grown up hearing awe-inspiring stories about unsung heroes who protected the nation. He joined the defence forces at 16 while he was still appearing for his high school examination. Later, he was enlisted into the 18 Grenadiers. During the 1999 Kargil War, Yogendra became a part of the commando platoon nicknamed Ghatak, which had to undertake a 90-degree vertical climb to bust three strategic bunkers of the Pakistani army on Tiger Hill. With only seven young soldiers and a handful of ammunition to thwart the enemy, he reclaimed the peak and it became a turning point not just in the Kargil War, but also in his life. A Subedar Major now, Yogendra is a non-commissioned officer of the army, currently serving in Bareilly. His wife Reena lives in Ghaziabad with their two sons, Prashant and Vishant. The stories of his bravery are already legendary. “I thought it was a dream he saw,” recalled Reena. “But, the call of duty came soon enough to tell us it was more than just a dream. My mother-in-law insisted that he stay back, but my husband wouldn’t let down his country at any cost. Today, he is a constant source of inspiration for our two sons who aspire to join the army someday,” she said. According to the Param Vir Chakra citation on the official army website, “unmindful of the danger involved in the snowy weather and surrounded by enemies, Subedar Yogendra Singh Yadav volunteered to lead and fix the rope for his team to climb up the steep slope. When the enemy saw them, it attacked with... artillery fire, killing the commander, his two colleagues and in return stalling the platoon”. Latest CommentsaluteKapilSee All CommentsAdd commentRealising the seriousness of the situation, the citation states, Yadav crawled up the enemy position to silence it and in the process sustained multiple bullet wounds. “Despite taking the heavy bullet shots, he continued climbing towards the enemy position, lobbed grenades, continued firing weapons and killed four of the enemy soldiers in hand-to-hand combat. With multiple bullet injuries and a determination to fight back, he refused to be evacuated and continued the charge”. In a nutshell, he was a hero. For, a hero is a man who is afraid to run away.

column2: 4 Lucknow University students booked for attacking 2 over FB post
column3: LUCKNOW: Two students were injured when attacked by a group of students near Tilak hostel in Lucknow University late on Tuesday night over a petty dispute. An FIR was lodged against four students by BA final year students Suraj Singh and Anuj Mishra, who were badly injured in the attack. LU proctorial board was informed about the incident by Hasanganj police. The two boys, in their police complaint, said that four boys with whom they had had a dispute in the past session blocked their way and abused them on Tuesday night. The four asked the duo to apologise for a Facebook post allegedly mocking their group. When Singh and Mishra tried to ignore and leave, the four boys allegedly pushed them and began hitting them. The accused, Ashish Dwivedi of BA final year, Himanshu Upadhyay, Om Pandey and Abhay Gupta of BCom final year, fled when hostellers came to the spot after hearing the screams of the duo. The hostellers took the injured boys to a private hospital for treatment. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“LU students Suraj and Anuj, who had sustained head injuries, lodged a complaint on Wednesday morning after which an FIR for voluntarily causing hurt, intentional hurt and criminal intimidation has been lodged,” said LU outpost in charge Abhay Kumar Singh. LU spokesperson NK Pandey said the incident will be probed.

column2: Newly built stretch of Kisan Path caves in
column3: LUCKNOW: A 13-metre stretch of the newly constructed service lane of Kisan Path, a part of the outer Ring Road inaugurated by Lucknow MP and Union defence minister Rajnath Singh before Lok Sabha elections, caved in on Wednesday afternoon following overnight moderate rain. According to local residents, the incident took place near a private dental college in Chinhat at around 1pm when the stretch suddenly collapsed leaving behind a huge crater. The road has been closed for traffic and repair work has begun. “A probe has been ordered into the reasons of the collapse. It will take at least 45 days to repair the stretch,” said a senior officer at the UP public works department (PWD). The 15km Kisan Path is a part of the ambitious 108km eight-lane outer Ring Road being constructed at the cost of over Rs 5,000 crore around Lucknow to ease traffic in the city. The road is being constructed in five parts — four by the National Highways Authority of India and one (Kisan Path) by UP PWD. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.TOI recently reported how roads constructed just last year are showing signs of damage just a few weeks into the monsoon season. As per the nationally accepted standard, a road constructed or repaired should last at least five years at a stretch.

column2: Hostel room or cobwebbed dungeon? Ask special students
column3: LUCKNOW: The struggles of differently abled students of Dr Shakuntala Misra National Rehabilitation University are far from over. While many still haven’t been allotted hostel facilities, those who have been — following sustained protests — claim the rooms are not fit for living, thanks to broken doors, horrible hygiene and, of course, no electricity. “The varsity made false promises and hurriedly allotted a few rooms in order to quell the campus agitation. The rooms, we can feel, are filthy and covered in cobwebs. Toilets are dirty because they stink,” said BEd student Shaukat Ali Khan who is visually challenged. Shanti, another BEd student, said the authorities had asked them to fill up forms if they needed rooms. “But, officials are not helping visually challenged students like me to complete the application process. My friend and I are yet to get a hostel room,” she added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Suman Upadhyay, an MA student who is wheelchair-bound, claimed only 15 had been allotted rooms. “My friends and I are not among them. Those who got lucky are ruing the horrible condition the rooms are in. Imagine the health hazards these rooms posing to students with challenges,” she said. Following pressure mounted by 30-odd students for two consecutive days since Monday, the varsity finally allotted hostel rooms to around 40% special pupils who had applied for the same. University spokesperson professor AK Dubey said, “We are trying to make room for everyone. Maintenance work has also been expedited. Rooms will be cleaned and repaired soon.”

column2: A day of name calling for Vidhan Parishad members
column3: LUCKNOW: A significant part of the first half of Wednesday’s business in Vidhan Sabha was dedicated to members calling each other names, finally prompting a BSP member and the leader of the House to demand that members be respectful towards each other. In the middle of the ruckus was rural development minister Mahendra Singh, who was caught in a similar controversy on Tuesday in the Vidhan Sabha where he got into a spat with Leader of Opposition Ram Govind Chaudhary. It was after much back and forth and pleas to consider what would appear in the next day’s newspapers about them that finally prompted the members to apologise to each other. The exchange of words started when SP MLC Madhukar Jaitley was questioning the government over accidents on the Agra Expressway. Reacting to the data read out by Singh, an agitated Jaitley started calling BJP paapiyon ki party (party of sinners). Singh retaliated saying that the paapi were actually sitting in the Opposition benches, referring to SP, adding “aap paapi log hain, dange kara ke, kidney bech ke...paap ka ghada bhar liya (You are sinners, you added to your sins by instigating riots, selling kidneys)”. This drew shrieks of protest from SP members even as both parties continued to exchange barbs. Later, Singh and SP’s Shatrudra Prakash got into a similar spat where, frustrated with Singh’s reaction to a notice on the budget, Prakash said: “Jabse mantri bane hain inka dimaag kharab ho gaya hai (He has lost his mind since he became a minister)”. Singh retaliated to this, saying: “Aap mansik roop se diwaliya ho gaye hain (You have lost your mental balance).” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Things did not end there, with Congress MLC Deepak Singh calling Singh “gyan ka sagar”. Singh retaliated by calling him “gyan ka talab (pond of knowledge)”. By this time, most members and BSP’s Dinesh Chandra and BJP’s Dinesh Sharma insisted that the name calling stop.

column2: CM Yogi: NSA on builders for illegal projects
column3: LUCKNOW: Builders responsible for illegal construction would be booked under the National Security Act, said CM Yogi Adityanath in a review meeting with officials from Noida, Greater Noida and Yamuna Expressway authorities in connection with the Shahberi case here on Wednesday. Stating that accountability should be fixed for officials and builders responsible for illegal construction, and those who have played with the lives of thousands of residents should be sent to jail, the CM said that FIR must be lodged against such builders including those in Shahberi under NSA. SkipThe Greater Noida Authority has identified over 1,450 unauthorised buildings in Shahberi village. Most of these constructions were found to have taken place between 2014 and 2018. He also directed officials to prepare a list of officials involved in land-related matters so that action could be taken against them.

column2: UP: Statewide survey on septic tank deaths in the pipeline
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP government will conduct a statewide survey on the death of manual scavengers with restrospective effect from 1993, state urban development minister Suresh Khanna told the assembly on Wednesday, adding that the decision had been taken to honour a 2014 Supreme Court ruling. Khanna’s announcement came after Samajwadi Party MLA Sushma Patel raised the issue during question hour and sought to know what steps had been taken to stem the rising septic tank and manhole toll. The minister, who informed the House that as many as 25 persons lost their lives while cleaning septic tanks and manholes between January 2017 and March 2019, said the government would rope in police and urban local bodies for the survey. Khanna said families of 16 victims had been paid a compensation of Rs 10 lakh each. “The state will compensate the rest after due examination,” he told the House. Legislator Patel pointed out that the toll being cited by the government appeared to be inaccurate because Lucknow alone reported 12 manual scavenger deaths in the past two years. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The minister squarely blamed deployment of unskilled labour for the toll. He said the government would soon frame a policy wherein only skilled workers would be employed for cleaning septic tanks. Manual scavengers, he added, would be provided adequate protection including mask and gloves.

column2: Fun & learning for these kids in Lucknow
column3: A play titled Murgi Chor was recently staged at Rai Umanath Bali auditorium. The play was written by Murari Lal Srivastava and was directed by Shaan Srivastava. The chief guest at the event was veteran theatre artist Lalit Singh Pokhariya, who also lit the inaugural lamp. (L) Kaustubh Mishra and Prayas Das Gupta (R) Lalit Singh Pokhariya (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Kaustubh Mishra and Prayas Das Gupta (R) Lalit Singh Pokhariya (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Children from different schools, who took part in the summer workshop, performed in the play. The play showcased how a person wants several comforts in life without wanting to earn them ethically. The character Jhagdu Miyan in the play stole chickens from his neighbours for his survival. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Satya Prakash and SP Dwivedi (R) Shaan Srivastava (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Satya Prakash and SP Dwivedi (R) Shaan Srivastava (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) "I have trained these kids for days and now they are performing in front of the audience, I feel proud of them," said Shaan. "The energy in the kids was outstanding. I just loved their voice modulations.
