column2: A discussion on Urdu theatre and its influence on Bollywood held in Lucknow
column3: Held at a prominent club in the city recently, this literary event titled Samvad was attended by the literati. The event revolved around the topic titled Indra Sabha, the court of Indra and the rebirth of the 19th century Urdu theatre. The discussion, which was carried on by Afroz Taj and John Caldwell, professors of the University of North Carolina, was Urdu theatre-centric. It dealt with how the Urdu theatre started, who were the torch bearers, how it influences the present theatre scene and in what ways it has affected the Bollywood industry. (L) Chandra Shekhar Varma (R) Faiza Mumtaz (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Chandra Shekhar Varma (R) Faiza Mumtaz (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Present at the event was Prof Mahrukh Mirza, VC of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti Urdu, Arabi-Farsi University with his wife Kaneez Fatima who were the guests of honour. The panel discussion which was moderated by CS Varma seemed to illuminate students who also attended the event. "This was so enlightening. I mean professors from a foreign university talking about the theatre of the 19th century," said Akash Yadav, a student. (L) Jyoti Sinha (R) Mahrukh Mirza (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Jyoti Sinha (R) Mahrukh Mirza (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A small session of audience interaction was also held where several people cleared their doubts with the panellists about the origin of Urdu theatre. — Saad Abbasi (L) Manju Anand (R) Nootan Tuli (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Manju Anand (R) Nootan Tuli (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Ravi and Geetanjali Joshi (R) Vijay Sahi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Ravi and Geetanjali Joshi (R) Vijay Sahi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Tanu Tandon (R) Vineeta Mishra (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Tanu Tandon (R) Vineeta Mishra (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: Rumble strips to check speeding on Yamuna Expressway
column3: LUCKNOW: The Uttar Pradesh government has decided to install rumble strips every 15km on the Yamuna Expressway to prevent drivers from exceeding the speed limit and to keep them alert on the wheel, state industrial development minister Satish Mahana said in the assembly on Thursday. The announcement comes a fortnight after a bus skidded off the Yamuna Expressway, killing 29 passengers on board, taking the total number of deaths on the high-speed road to 120 this year. He also said all gaps and open culverts on the expressway would be levelled and cemented to ensure driver safety. The issue was raised by BSP MLA Sukdeo Rajbhar who pointed out that most accidents were caused by tyre bursts and drivers dozing off on the wheel. 'Rumble strips defeat the purpose of expressway'NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.More than 400 accidents have taken place on Lucknow-Agra Expressway since it became operational, he claimed. Rumble strips, also known as sleeper lines, are a road safety feature to alert inattentive drivers of potential danger, by causing a tactile vibration and audible rumbling transmitted through the wheels into the vehicle interior. Experts, however, stressed rumble strips defeat the purpose of an expressway. "This is not the correct way to control speed. The government should ensure compliance of speed limits, rather than put up speed breakers," said former PWD chief engineer, JP Jain. Mahana also told the Assembly that the state government would set up a trauma centre at Kannauj to provide "urgent medical help" to accident victims. Top CommentAbsolutely stupid solution. Defeats the very objective of an expressway. The better way is to have Patrol car or hidden camera surveillance and levy heavy punitive fines including jail for traffic vi...Read MoreVenugopalSee All CommentsAdd commentThe government would also launch a mobile app that would allow passengers to track location of ambulances and police once they are on the expressway. Illegal dhabas along the expressway would be shut as they pose a hazard, Mahana said. To ensure free flow of traffic, parking of heavy vehicles, including trucks and buses along the expressway, would be totally banned. The government's overdrive to curb accidents comes close on heels of UP Expressway Industrial Development Authority setting a three-hour time limit for plying on the Lucknow-Agra Expressway. Mahana said the state government has already begun issuing e-challans to drivers who exceed speeds of 100 km/hr or cover the expressway in less than three hours.

column2: Yogi Adityanath: Muzaffarnagar brothers characterless, didn't die in riots
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath, in a written response in the assembly, said a police probe found Nawab and Shahid - two brothers killed during 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots - were "unrighteous and characterless" and their deaths had nothing to do with the communal violence. The chief minister's statement followed a query by SP legislator Haji Irfan Solanki on the March 11 murder of Asbab, a key witness to murder of two brothers. Solanki also sought to know about security provided to other witnesses. Yogi said in his written reply that Nawab and Shahid would go door-to-door selling milk. Citing the police probe, the CM said, "Nawab badchalan, charitraheen kism ka vyakti tha jiske gaon ke Shri Krishnapal ki aurat ke saath avaidh sambandh the... (Nawab was unrighteous, characterless and had illicit relations with wife of one Krishnapal). The chief minister said, the allegations were also corroborated by the murder accused during investigations. The CM said on basis of evidence, a charge-sheet was submitted in court. "It's clear the incident is not related to Muzaffarnagar riots," he said. Yogi said Asbab was murdered on March 11 and a case was lodged under section 302 (murder) of IPC against unidentified persons with Khatauli police station the same day. Later, names of Vasu alias Deepak Chaudhary, Bholu alias Amardeep, Shrikant, Sahdev, Manjeet, Monty alias Ranveer and Ajit have surfaced in the murder of eye-witness Asbab. While Vasu was arrested, Bholu, Shrikant, Ajit, Manjit and Monty subsequently surrendered. Yogi said other witnesses have been given security in Muzaffarnagar. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Reacting to chief minister's statement, Samajwadi Party spokesperson Udayveer Singh said: "It's unparliamentary to talk about the character of people who are dead. Also, even if accusations against them were true, they should have been tried under law and not by a mob. The murders cannot be justified." While Congress said BJP was trying to polarize the people, a senior BSP member said the CM's comments were shameful.

column2: Finally, UPPSC announces exam calendar for two years
column3: LUCKNOW: Following postponement of examinations due to the arrest of UPPSC examination controller Anju Katiyar in connection with paper leak case, the Commssion for the first time declared the examination calendar for two years simultaneously on Thursday. As per the new schedule, UPPSC will conduct the much-awaited Provincial Civil Services (preliminary) examination, 2019, on December 15. Those clearing the preliminary examination will appear for the main examination which has been rescheduled for April 20 next year. The final results after interviews are expected to be announced in December next year. The examination, earlier scheduled on October 20, was postponed for an indefinite period after the arrest of Katiyar. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.According to the schedule, a total of 14 examinations will be conducted, including six which were postponed after paper leak expose. These include PCS (mains)-2018 (October 18), Government Inter College Exam-2017 for recruitment of lecturers (November 3), programmer grade-B exam-2019 (September 1), programmer grade-II exam-2019 (September 15) and programmer grade-II exam-2019 (October 13). “The examinations scheduled in 2020 include assistant prosecution officer preliminary exam-2018 (February 16), assistant forest conservator/range forest officer (mains) exam-2018 (February 23) and APO mains exam-2018 (May 16),” said examination controller, UPPSC, Arvind Kumar Mishra.

column2: Lucknow: ‘Beggar’ boss turned minors into sex slaves & thieves, now in net
column3: LUCKNOW: A 55-year-old man who masqueraded as a beggar, but groomed children for thievery and flesh trade on the sly, was arrested on Thursday after two boys and as many girls escaped from his clutches. The unaccompanied teenagers — the girls aged 15 and 16, and the boys 14 — were spotted on a train to Barabanki at Badshahnagar railway station in the city during a routine RPF check around 4am. Based on their accounts, Vijay Badri, alias Bangali, was rounded up from his den in Munshipulia. The children are being rehabilitated at a state-run shelter while police are looking for Bangali’s accomplices, said to be 3-15 in number. More minors may be in their captivity. According to the rescued boys and girls, their tormentor, who is a right foot amputee, not just forced them into illegal acts but also sedated them, slashed their bodies with a blade and smeared their blood on his bandaged leg to garner sympathy as a beggar. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The children have told RPF that they stole for Bangali items ranging from mobile phones and wallets to luggage and e-rickshaw batteries. The girls were allegedly forced to “please customers”, sometimes more than one at a time, for anything between Rs 150 and Rs 500. They slept on the pavements of Munshipulia and received a daily food allowance of Rs 100 each from Bangali who took away whatever else they stole or earned. “We have tried to escape in the past, but were always caught and thrashed by his 14-15 aides. This time, we managed to save up Rs 70 and buy train tickets. We sneaked out early when they were all sleeping,” an RPF source quoted one of the teens as saying. While the girls and a boy are from Lucknow, the other boy is from Barabanki, where they had hoped to take refuge. Bangali, a native of Bengal who was picked up from his shanty in Munshipulia, has confessed to running the racket with three aides. “He took to begging after losing a foot in an accident, but soon started luring slum kids with food, clothes and money to use them for prostitution and thievery,” said RPF inspector MK Khan. Top CommentHe should be given harsher punishment for this sinister sin.Prashant Bhushan TyagiSee All CommentsAdd commentRajdev Mishra, inspector, Gazipur police station said Bangali was booked for kidnapping, child trafficking and exploitation. “Victims have told police that there are at least 10 more minors in captivity. We are looking for associates of the key accused and will probe if the racket is bigger than it seems,” Mishra added. The rescued four were handed over to Childline and produced before the child welfare committee in Lucknow. Member Sangeeta Sharma said, “They have been sent to a government shelter. We are trying to locate their parents.”

column2: Harassed 16-year-old stops going to school, stalker held in Aliganj
column3: LUCKNOW: A youth who stalked a Class X student in Aliganj for 10 days, and scared her to the extent that she stopped going to school, was arrested on Thursday. Shashank Mishra, 22, a resident of Aliganj and unemployed, has been booked for harassment and criminal intimidation. "The accused followed the 16-year-old schoolgirl on her way home from the campus and made obscene passes. On several occasions, he allegedly blocked her way and asked her to marry him," said Aliganj SHO Fareed Ahmed. Top CommentJail for a month and fine him too.  Then he should do 100 hours of community service such as cleaning public toilets and streets. At the end take in writing that he will never do such things, ever.Oswald SequeiraSee All CommentsAdd commentPolice said the girl always walked to and fro from school, which is barely a kilometre from her house. The youth began stalking her 10 days ago. She initially did not report the matter out of fear. But, on Monday, the accused blocked her way and tried to grab her hand. When she resisted, he threatened to kill her. She stopped going to school from Tuesday. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy."Initially, her parents thought she was not well, but soon realised she was scared about something. When coaxed, she confided in them. The family lodged a complaint on Wednesday evening. Today (Thursday), police laid a trap and caught her stalker. He has been sent to jail," SHO Ahmed added.

column2: Kanpur: Molested minor faces cop's fashion policing
column3: KANPUR: A video clip showing a city police constable dress-shaming a purported molestation survivor has gone viral on social media and invited flak from Twitter users, including Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, on Thursday. The constable, who has been suspended, will face a departmental inquiry. The 100-second clip shows the girl, said to be aged around 16, narrating her ordeal to head constable Taar Babu at Nazirabad police station on Wednesday. She names three youths - Ashiq, Amar and Vicky - who allegedly molested her on Tuesday. She also says that they tried to drag her away when she went to fetch water from a hand pump. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Instead of helping her lodge a formal complaint, the policeman is heard reprimanding her for "accessorizing too much and thereby, drawing attention". The constable chides her for wearing finger rings, bangles and a necklace. He is heard lecturing her on how being "fashionable" invites "such kind of trouble". He even tells her mother to keep her "on leash". Priyanka reacted sharply to the incident while sharing the video on her Twitter handle. "...Ek taraf Uttar Pradesh mein mahilaon ke khilaf apradh kam nahin ho rahe, dusri taraf kanoon ke rakhwalon ka ye bartav. Mahilaon ko nyay dilane ki pehli siri hai unki baat sunna (On the one hand, attrocities against women are not going down in Uttar pradesh, on the other this is the behaviour of the police. To ensure justice to women, the first duty is to listen to them)," she tweeted. Latest Commentwell this is a shameful act, would suggest to arrange a mandatory moral class session for the department, a suspension is just the work around.AaaaSee All CommentsAdd commentThe girl has alleged that the head constable also tore up her application and asked her to write what he dictated. She said she told the policeman that the molest gang thrashed her brother for protesting, but claimed the cop interpreted it the other way. SP, South, Raveena Tyagi confirmed to TOI that Taar Babu had been suspended with immediate effect. "We will initiate a departmental inquiry against him. Police have arrested (one of the accused molesters) Amar and a hunt is on for the others," Tyagi said.

column2: Lucknow: 'Dada gave me food, then he raped me'
column3: LUCKNOW: Neetu curses the day she accepted a lunch invite from a stranger two years ago. "I was returning home to a slum at Ballu Adda that day. Two girls approached me near Samtamulak crossing and took me to Bangali (Vijay Badri). He gave me chicken to eat, and gifted new clothes and money. I come from a poor family; how could I even resist the temptation?" she recalled. The 15-year-old was not alone to have found who she then thought was a good Samaritan. There were more boys and girls her age. She was offered the "royal treatment" the next day too, but there was a catch. "This time, Bangali laced my food with sedatives. He raped me and held me captive for a few days before pushing me into prostitution. He used to send me away with men and take all the money," said the survivor who was rescued by RPF with three others, two boys and a girl, on Thursday. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Neetu tried to escape several times in the past, but was caught and beaten up by Bangali's goons. Like her, other children were also born and bred in poverty. They were lured by Bangali - whom they learnt to call 'Dada' - into a life that they soon realised they didn't want. Top CommentWe need to fence the Nepal border also, there''s too much human trafficking across that border and it doesn''t matter if they are a friendly country - criminals are criminals whether from a friendly country or otherwise.ShajiSee All CommentsAdd commentNilesh, 14, a native of Barabanki said, "I came to Lucknow to find work, but was trapped by Dada. He made me beg, steal and run errands." ( Names changed to protect identity of the victims )

column2: Soon, three more parks to have paid entry in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) will soon begin charging a fee from people visiting three parks in the city. They include Central park and Manav Aushadi park in Raj Nagar and Shilp Udyan park in Sanjay Nagar. According to officials, the fee will be collected by private contractors. Visitors would be charged Rs 10 per person for entering Central park and Shilp Udyan park, while at Manav Aushadhi park it would cost Rs 5. Additionally, to access an open gym in Central park people will have to pay Rs 10. The new plan is expected to be implemented in the first week of August. The Authority is also planning to introduce various monthly, quarterly, half-yearly and yearly plans for the park visitors. Meanwhile, for couples, the price at Central park and Shilp Udyan park has been set at Rs 2,000 for an entire year and at Manav Aushudhi park, the annual charge is Rs 1,000. The GDA has also decided to provide free entry to senior citizens in all the mentioned parks before 9 am and after 6 pm every day. Children up to the age of 12 years will get free entry throughout the day. Also, no fee will be charged from anyone on national holidays. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.According to officials, the money thus collected will be used for the development and upkeep of the parks. It will also help in improving safety and security at parks by keeping anti-social elements at bay. Currently, the civic body collects entry fees at City forest, Lohia park, Ambedkar park and Swarnjayanti park. “GDA has around 120 parks under its jurisdiction. In the past year, we have received Rs 13 lakh each as revenue from Lohia park and Swarn Jyanti park, Rs 7.7 lakh from City forest and Rs 10 lakh from Ambedkar park. It has proved to be a major source of income for GDA, which spends around Rs 22 crore annually on the horticulture department,” said S P Sisodiya, horticulture in-charge, GDA. The central park in Raj Nagar is spread in an area of 15 acres, Manav Aushadhi park in 2.5 acres and Shilp Udyan is spread across 5.5 acres.

column2: Kanwar yatra: Ghaziabad schools, colleges shut for five days
column3: GHAZIABAD: The district magistrate on Thursday ordered closure of all schools, both private and government, and colleges from July 26 to July 30 because of heavy movement during Kanwar yatra for Shivratri. “Like every year, Shravan Shivratri will be celebrated on July 30. As a large number of devotees is expected to participate in the occasion, all schools and colleges (engineering, management and medical among others) will remain closed from July 26 to July 30,” DM Ajay Shankar Pandey said. Officials have been directed to ensure that the order is followed. The district administration passes similar orders every year anticipating huge rush during the last leg of Kanwar yatra. On Thursday, a command centre at Meerut tri-section was inaugurated by the DM and the SSP from where the Kanwar yatra will be monitored. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The district administration and police have chalked out an elaborate plan to provide hassle-free passage to Kanwariyas. In total, around 1,500 police personnel, 1,000 volunteers, 13 drone cameras, and anti-terrorism squad (ATS) commandes have deployed across the district. Moreover, 208 CCTV cameras have been installed along the route, from Modinagar to Ghaziabad. The police have plans to use a helicopter for carrying out inspections on July 29 and 30. Heavy vehicles have been banned on the Delhi-Meerut road from July 22 to July 31. The same rule became applicable for light vehicles from July 25. Top Commentshutting schools for this menace is unacceptable...shame on administrationBandSee All CommentsAdd commentHeavy vehicles moving towards Bulandshahr and Haridwar from Delhi are being diverted to NH-9 via UP Gate. They can go through through Dasna, Pilkhuwa and Hapur to reach their destinations. Vehicles going towards Meerut are required to go to Hapur and then move towards their destinations.

column2: Lucknow University to honour alumna who directed moon mission
column3: LUCKNOW: While the city is over the moon, revelling over Chandrayaan-2 mission director Ritu Karidhal Srivastava’s Lucknow links, her alma mater has decided to recommend her name for the institution’s highest honour. Lucknow University (LU) wants to confer upon its alumna the honoris causa (an honorary degree) during the convocation scheduled for October 14. At a preparation meeting held recently, it was decided that her name will be recommended to the governor who is also the chancellor of all state universities. “Ritu finished her postgraduation in 1997 and got enrolled in a doctorate course in the physics department. She later taught in the same department. She has made her university and the entire nation proud by playing a key role in India’s second moon mission. We will take forward her name for honoris causa,” said LU vice-chancellor SP Singh. Singh said university officials and all professors unanimously wanted to honour her contribution, hard work and excellence. The final nod will be given by the chancellor and the executive council members, he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Srivastava completed her schooling from Navyug Girls College and joined LU prior to cracking the prestigious Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering. She was a research scholar at LU for six months and left after clearing GATE. She joined IISc, Bangalore, to pursue a masters in aerospace engineering. Honoris causa may include DLitt for persons who have contributed substantially to the advancement of literature, philosophy, arts, music, painting or any other the subject assigned to the faculty of arts; DSc for aiding advancement of any branch of science or technology or to planning, organising or developing scientific and technological institutions in the country; and LLD for distinguished lawyers, judges, jurists and statesmen.

column2: Infant’s death: Government officer’s report indicts three doctors for negligence, medics question probe
column3: GHAZIABAD: An inquiry conducted by the additional city magistrate into the death of a two-month-old boy at the state-run MMG Hospital on July 17 has named three doctors for negligence. Hospital sources said the doctors were unhappy with the way the inquiry was conducted and wondered how an investigation into alleged negligence could be instituted without a doctor on the panel. District magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey, however, said the inquiry did not look at the medical aspects. “The inquiry centred around administrative lapses and it was not mandated to investigate medical lapses, which was obviously not the case here,” Pandey said. On July 17, Masuri resident Mohammad Irshad had brought his son to MMG hospital after the child had respiratory problems. “My wife and I were directed to the OPD (outpatient department) of the hospital from the women’s hospital, where we had initially gone. After I reached there, I was told to get the OPD slip,” Irshad said, adding even as he stood in queue, the boy’s condition deteriorated and his skin began turning blue. He claimed he rushed to the OPD in Ward No. 15 where a “doctor” told him to get the slip first. “By that time, my son was gasping for breath and before we could take him to the emergency ward, he passed away,” Irshad said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The DM took suo motu cognisance and ordered an inquiry by additional city magistrate Khalid Anjum. “After questioning doctors and the victims’ parents, I concluded that the three doctors who were on duty at that time had not discharged their duties properly,” said Khalid Anjum, additional city magistrate. “The inquiry did not look into the medical aspect. I only looked into the sequence of events that led to such an unfortunate incident and what I concluded was that the child was not entertained at the right time because the child’s mother, in her statement, said they were made to get OPD slips even though his condition was worsening,” he added. The doctors are disappointed by the report. “In the OPD, it’s a practice to get a slip first,” said NK Gupta, chief medical officer, adding serious patients are treated in the emergency section and can go there directly. “In this case, the patient’s family had come to the OPD. Had they come to the emergency ward, the child would have been automatically taken care of,” added Gupta. Another senior doctor at the hospital said none of three doctors implicated in the report had asked the child’s parents to get the OPD slip. “The parents never approached the three doctors who were on duty at the time because, after checking their log book, they together attended to 208 patients that day. The child’s name did not figure in the log book,” said Dr Ravinder Rana, chief medical superintendent at the hospital. “The allegations made by the child’s parents that a doctor turned them away is not correct. It’s quite possible that whosoever asked them to get the OPD slip may have been an attendant of a patient or someone else who the child’s parents mistook for a doctor,” Rana added. The report will now be submitted to the DM, who in turn can forward his recommendations to the health department for action against the doctors.

column2: Ghaziabad’s CISF road to get walkway plan in a week
column3: GHAZIABAD: To provide seamless pedestrian movement in Indirapuram, the Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) has hired a consultant to make a walkability plan along the 2km stretch of CISF road. The GDA is expecting the plan to be ready in a week after which it plans to implement it. “While a lot of stress is laid on the traffic mobility plan for unhindered traffic movement, pedestrian safety, somehow, takes a backseat. So, we came up with the idea of providing a walkability plan and we have hired a consultant for the same,” said V N Singh, chief engineer in the GDA. column2: Ghaziabad: Three days after death of woman, her husband held
column3: GHAZIABAD: The husband and father-in-law of a woman who was found dead in her house at Shipra Suncity in Indirapuram earlier this week have been arrested. Divya Singh (34) was found hanging from the ceiling fan of her room last Monday. Police also found a note that purportedly said she was committing suicide and asked her father to take care of her one-year-old son. SkipPolice had filed a case under section 302 (murder) of the IPC after Divya’s father Vinod Yadav, a former bureaucrat, filed a complaint, accusing her husband and in-laws of killing her. He alleged Divya was forced to quit multiple jobs and do household chores by her in-laws. Divya’s husband Shailendra is a senior executive with a private firm based in Gurugram. Before the court hearing, Shailendra told this correspondent he was in office when he got a call from his father. “He told me she (Divya) had committed suicide. Divya was suffering from depression and for the last two years, her treatment was on at a private hospital. We also submitted her prescription file to the police.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.After the autopsy report, police filed a case under Section 306 (abetment to suicide) instead of Section 302. SP (city) Shlok Kumar said the report revealed the cause of death was hanging. Shailendra and his father have been sent to judicial custody.

column2: 20-year-old goes missing in Loni
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 20-year-old youth allegedly went missing from his house in Loni area of Ghaziabad on Thursday evening. His parents have claimed that later in the day, they received his image through WhatsApp and he can be seen lying unconscious on the road. The youth, Irfaan alias Kala, is a resident of Kanchan Park Colony in Loni area. His father Salimuddin told TOI that Irfaan left the house around 3.30 pm on Thursday on the pretext of meeting with friends. “Around 6pm, I got a WhatsApp image on my mobile from Irfaan’s phone and in the image, he was tied up with a rope and a cloth had been stuffed into his mouth,” he added. He alleged that Irfaan had been kidnapped by a neighbour. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Neeraj Kumar Jadaun, superintendent of police (rural), said: “The family said neighbours kidnapped the youth. During investigation, it was found that a girl in the neighbour is also missing. The sender of the image did not mention the name of the place where the boy was seen. The is switched off now. Police are trying to trace it.”

column2: Lucknow aake mujhe aisa lagta hai main ghar aa gaya: Jameel Khan
column3: Being born in a typical Muslim family, Bhadohi-born actor Jameel Khan, who was recently in the city, says he is in love with Lucknow’s culture and language. "Badi izzat aur mohabbat se log milte hain Lucknow mein. In fact, yahan ki badi pyari zubaan hai. The Urdu language that we speak is really hatt ke, which makes us UPites different from others," he says, adding, "Lucknow ka experience hamesha khushnuma rehta hai. Yahan ke log bahut pyare hain, tehzeeb aur adab ka sheher hai yeh. Yahan ke khane ka zayka mere ghar ke jaise zayke waala hai. Lucknow aake mujhe aisa lagta hai jaise main ghar aa gaya hoon." Having acted in films like the Arjun Rampal-starrer Asambhav, Gangs of Wasseypur, Goliyon Ki Rasleela Ram-Leela and Baby, Jameel shared with us about his journey from Bhadohi to Mumbai. "I completed my schooling from Sherwood College, Nainital and went to Aligarh Muslim University for further studies but during my studies, I always stayed connected to theatre. My first love is and will always remain theatre. I was so much into acting and theatre that after completing my BA, I went to Mumbai to make a career in acting." column2: A Chak De! India moment for these hockey players in Lucknow
column3: The All-India Women’s Hockey tournament kicked off in Lucknow from the Padmashri Mohammad Shahid Synthetic Hockey Stadium on Thursday afternoon. The tournament had the players full of enthusiasm despite a miserably low turn out of spectators in the stadium. The tournament has a total of 8 teams playing from different states and cities including Bhopal, Gorakhpur, Jhansi among others. (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The first day of the tournament had women players of the Sports Authority of India (SAI), Bhopal, and the Shanti Foundation playing a match in which the former emerged the winner with two goals. The team’s centre-forward, Vartika and Kanchan’s exceptional goal at the 13th and the 46th minute, respectively, booked their team a spot in the next round of the tournament. (L) Meenu Rani (R) Rachna Govil (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Meenu Rani (R) Rachna Govil (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.In the next match, the Lucknow Hostel team struck good luck and got a walkover while qualifying for the next round as the SAI Lucknow team couldn’t make it to the stadium for some unknown reasons. The next part of the tournament held on Friday had the North Eastern Railways team playing against the Sports College Gorakhpur team, and the team of Meerut playing against the Jhansi team. “This is the first tournament of this season and I am filled with happiness winning the first match of it. It is a great feeling, my girls played well and we struck two goals. Even though the number of spectators is less, the ones present are quite cheerful,” said Meenu, captain of the Bhopal team. (L) Shivani Singh Saini (R) Ravinder Pal Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shivani Singh Saini (R) Ravinder Pal Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) “I really appreciate this initiative of organising a Women’s Hockey tournament. Women hockey players deserve motivation and a confidence boost and through this tournament I’m sure we’re moving a step ahead. I hope women who are playing in this tournament will display their skills at large and will make their state and country proud,” said Ravinder Pal Singh, former hockey player and athlete representative at Hockey India. — Saad Abbasi and Yashi Agarwal

column2: Art got digitalised at this exhibition in Lucknow
column3: A digital art show exhibition was held recently in the city. Organised by Dr Geetanjali Joshi, a digital art trainer, a total of 150 selected art pieces were put on display. The exhibition also featured some of Geetanjali’s watercolour and digital paintings. A unique thing about Joshi’s section of art was that every single painting was inspired by a literary book, a novel or a poem. (L) Ambuli Mishra (R) Angad Verma (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Ambuli Mishra (R) Angad Verma (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) "Generally when people think of art, they think about a paper, brush and pen. Digital art form however, is a very new and innovative concept, yet already in demand. Honestly, even I’m a traditional artist and I’ve never done digital art. This is my first experience as well. Through this, I want to see the nuances of digital painting. The idea behind this exhibition is to bridge the gap between technology and art," said Geetanjali. (L) Apoorva Trivedi (R) Ayedid Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Apoorva Trivedi (R) Ayedid Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The guest of honours included Dr Bhupesh C Little and Dr Bharat Sah, Director, National Institute of Fashion Technology, Raebareli. "It’s a good platform to encourage students. I believe more students should participate," said Dr Bharat. (L) Bharat Shah (R) Dr Geetanjali Joshi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Bharat Shah (R) Dr Geetanjali Joshi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The event saw a huge turnout of art lovers, art communities and students from various art colleges along with private art institutions. Naisha, a recent graduate, said, "One unique thing about digital art is that you can get several reprints of the same piece, which I think is amazing." — Yashi Agarwal (L) Esha Rao (R) Ravi Joshi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Esha Rao (R) Ravi Joshi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Neha Srivastava and Raghvendra Singh (C) Pulkit Sahani (R) Sandeepan Sharma (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Neha Srivastava and Raghvendra Singh (C) Pulkit Sahani (R) Sandeepan Sharma (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: 'YouTube uploads of Bhojpuri artist inflammatory'
column3: LUCKNOW: A Bhojpuri singer Varun Upadhyay alias Varun Bahar and three of his associates were arrested on Friday for releasing a song on YouTube titled “Jo Na Bole Jai Shri Ram, Usko Bhejo Kabristan” (Those who refuse to chant Jai Sri Ram should be sent to the graveyard). Others arrested include Mukesh Pandey, who assisted in making of the song, lyricist Santosh Yadav and Rajesh Verma, who owns the studio where the song was recorded. All four were booked for hurting religious sentiments (Section 298 IPC) and promoting enmity on grounds of race and religion (Section 153 (A) of IPC). They were later produced before chief judicial magistrate (CJM) who remanded them to judicial custody. Police said a case was registered at the Hazratganj police station as the song had the potential to disturb communal harmony and was tracked by the surveillance cell of the Lucknow crime branch. Two other lyrics of Bhojpuri singer had rabid slant: PoliceNEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Probing the origin of the YouTube upload, investigators found it was recorded at Janta Music Company owned by Rajesh Verma of Aliganj, who too was arrested. On basis of information by Rajesh, a police team raided locations at Mankapur in Gonda and arrested the singer, Varun Upadhaya and lyricist Santosh Yadav. During investigations, it also surfaced their associate Mukesh Pandey also released song with equally objectionable lyrics and he was also picked up. Investigators identified two more songs recorded and uploaded by the group that had an inflammatory slant. “We will incorporate these details and retrieve these songs which they claim to have deleted,” in charge of Hazratganj police station Inspector Radhaman Singh said. There were reports that 44 FIRs have been lodged at various police stations across India against the songs. Lucknow Police was trying to collect details of these FIRs. ManishSee All CommentsAdd commentTalking to TOI, singer Varun Upadhyay’s father Kuldeep said the songs were spontaneous and did not have malice against any religion, class, or sect.  “My son has been singing since class 6. His recent song on Pulwama attack earned 50 lakh views,” he said. However, SSP, Lucknow, Kalanidhi Naithani, said, “The uploaded songs were offensive and could disturb harmony.”

column2: 18 pre-primary schools for differently abled children to come up in UP soon
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh will soon have 18 new pre-primary schools exclusively for the differently abled in various parts of the state. This has been planned to make educational institutes accessible to differently abled children, keeping in mind their population in the state. The state government has also decided to start 12 new “inclusive” schools where disabled children will study along with others to address the psychological issues of differently abled children. Four of these schools will begin functioning from the next academic session. The government also plans to provide financial support to children undergoing cochlear implant surgery to counter rising cases of sensory-neural hearing loss. Special unique disability identity (UDID) cards will also be issued to all such persons, to be used nationally. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Till now, disability certificates were issued by chief medical officers, which were recognised only within the state, depriving them of availing facilities in other states. UP has about 43L disabled people“According to the 2011 census, Uttar Pradesh has a high number of differently abled—nearly 43 lakh, which is 16% of the total 2.68-crore population of differently abled in the country,” said additional chief secretary Mahesh Gupta, who heads the department of disability prevention. “The 2011 census also reveals that three states—Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra and Bihar—together constitute for 50% of differently abled children (0-6 years) of the country, and 29% of these children do not have access to schools,” said Gupta. The UP government has increased the monthly pension of the disabled from Rs 300 a month to Rs 500, ensured free travel in UPSRTC buses and increased financial support to them for surgeries to correct their disability and in providing artificial limbs and equipment. “Barring a few who come from well-to-do families, majority of the differently abled suffer at social-economic level and many are perceived as a liability by their families. The new strategy is to get them into the mainstream and turn them into assets by government’s intervention right from childhood,” said Gupta.

column2: Properties not selling, GDA considers slashing rates
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) is considering waiving or reducing supervisory and administrative charges on properties that it offers for sale. The agency has been forced to think of sweeteners because GDA properties have failed to attract buyers for some time now. “A committee was formed under the GDA secretary to find the reasons why our properties were not finding buyers in auctions,” said Kanchan Verma, vice-chairperson, GDA. SkipIt was found that in comparison with private developers, GDA levies supervisory and administrative charges that together amounts to 30% of the total cost of property. “For the sake of attracting buyers, we’ll either forgo supervisory and administrative charges completely or will slash it because, on both heads, GDA charges 15% of total cost of property,” said Verma. GDA has housing units in Indirapuram, Swarnjayantipuram, Vaishali, Nandgram, Indraprasth and Madhuban Bapudham. In these areas, if a GDA property — say a 2BHK flat — costs Rs 30 lakh, inclusive of supervisory and administrative charges, the price charged by a private developer would be around Rs 25 lakh. Cumulatively, GDA properties worth about Rs 500 crore have gone unsold in auctions. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.GDA is also proposing to give buyers relief on corner shops on levels other than the ground floor. “GDA charges an additional 10% of the total cost on corner shops (because of its advantages) but the committee has suggested that though corner shops on the ground floor have some advantage, those on the first or second floors don’t and hence that charge should be abolished,” said Verma. There are at least 60 such shops in Indirapuram and Raj Nagar District Centre which have gone unsold. Verma also said property rates were not in consonance with circle rates, which are almost double, in some areas. “The circle rates in some areas for the last 11 years has remained high which is the reason why we have failed to attract buyers so we plan to bring parity in the rates,” said Verma. Latest CommentStrangely never heard about these flats or shops on sale in Ghaziabad! GDA should focus on smart designs, Vastu compliance & built quality & online - booking/auction. Rest all will fall in place....Chirag JainSee All CommentsAdd commentAnother suggestion put forth by the committee, which the GDA is also planning to implement, is making land rates in Indirapuram and Vaishali uniform. “These rates are already on the higher side so new rates will be decided which will be compatible with market rates. The decision will be taken at GDA’s board meeting,” said the official. The rethink on rates reflected earlier this week in the Noida administration’s decision to slash circle rates for commercial properties by more than 21%, citing a stagnation in sales.

column2: Lucknow: Rs 65,000 crore projects set for mega launch
column3: LUCKNOW: In a mega event on Sunday, Union home minister Amit Shah will launch 292 projects worth more than Rs 65,000 crore in the second ground breaking ceremony in Lucknow. The major chunk of investment this time is in the field of electronic manufacturing, which is getting 31% of the total investments being flagged off on Sunday. However, the pattern of investment has not changed over years with the quantum of investment dropping as one moves from west to east. Around 54% of the projects to be launched are located in Pashchimanchal or west UP. Madhyanchal or central UP will be getting 19% of the investment, followed by 13% in Purvanchal and 4% in Bundelkhand. The remaining 10% of the investment are either open for any location in UP or are coming up in multiple regions. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Shah will preside over the inaugural ceremony in the morning where industry leaders will also speak about the investment potential of UP. These include Aditya Birla Group chairman Kumaramangalam Birla, Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani, Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd chairman Anand Mahindra, ITC Ltd’s CEO Sanjiv Puri, Tata Sons’s chairman N Chandrashekharan, Samsung India president SC Hang, Toronto Group’s chairman Sudhir Mehta, Medanta chairman Naresh Trehan and PepsiCo India Holding’s Ahmed ElSheikh. Latest CommentHope at least 50% of same will be actually goes till ground.. nothing but only government has changedAshishSee All CommentsAdd commentThis will be followed by six sessions which will cover the food processing industry, defence and aerospace manufacturing, electronics manufacturing, tourism and films, electric mobility, and power and renewable energy. The first ground breaking ceremony held in 2018 was inaugurated by PM Narendra Modi where 81 projects worth about Rs 62,000 crore were launched.

column2: Rains expected in Lucknow till Tuesday
column3: LUCKNOW: Lucknowites are likely to witness rainfall in the city till Tuesday, predicts Met department. Intermittent showers kept mercury levels below normal in the city for the second consecutive day on Friday, although rain was not widespread and heavy as predicted by the state Met department. Similar conditions are expected till Tuesday. The Met department had on Tuesday predicted moderate rain till next week. However, though Wednesday saw heavy downpour, Thursday was generally dry and scattered rain was witnessed on Friday. While the state Met observatory at Amausi recorded 33.6 mm rain from morning till evening, total rainfall at Lucknow University weather monitoring cell in the heart of the city measured only 3.4mm. Even within the city, there was variation in rain pattern. While areas like Mahanagar, Jankipuram, Aliganj and Indiranagar received several showers during the day, Hazratganj, Aminabad, Husainganj and University road were generally dry. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.On Saturday, sky would be partly cloudy with possibilities of a few spells of showers and thundershowers in some areas, while maximum and minimum temperatures are expected to be around 32 and 23 degrees Celsius, respectively. State Met director JP Gupta said the monsoon trough - a stream of cyclonic circulations formed due to low pressure - is passing from over UP. There is also a cyclonic circulation over South UP. Together the two systems will keep rainfall activity alive in the state till Tuesday.

column2: Yamuna Expressway accident: Driver was fit to drive, says Suresh Khanna
column3: LUCKNOW: More than a fortnight after a bus fell into a gorge on Yamuna Expressway killing 29 people, the state government on Friday told UP assembly that the bus driver was fit and was given the job as per the transport department guidelines. The incident had happened on the intervening night of July 7 and 8 when a UPSRTC bus rammed through a crash barrier and fell into a culvert killing 29 and injuring several others. The three-member committee, constituted by chief minister Yogi Adityanath, had held the driver, who also died in the accident, responsible for the tragedy. BSP legislator Sukhdeo Rajbhar sought to know if the transport department was following the rules in deploying drivers on long routes and whether they were given training. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Driver had joined after 3-day leaveReplying to this, urban development minister Suresh Khanna told the house that the driver of the bus had returned after a three-day leave and was fit to drive. “The postmortem examination report has said that the driver died of drowning in the culvert. Nobody knows what exactly happened on the fateful night when the bus got dragged for around 50 metres, crashed through the barrier and fell into the culvert,” Khanna said. “It could not be concluded if the driver slept or fell unconscious due to one reason or the other,” he said. The parliamentary affairs minister said every UPSRTC driver was deployed for duty that should not exceed eight hours. “The drivers are given rest for half an hour after driving for five hours,” he said. Responding to Khanna’s reply, BSP legislator Sushma Patel said transport department drivers were often not checked if they were drunken. “There department should impart even better training to drivers to prevent such accidents,” she said.

column2: Lucknow: School vans and cops blind to DM's order
column3: LUCKNOW: Two days have lapsed since district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma directed traffic ASP Purnendu Singh to deploy police to stop violations of one-way rule by school vans at Gomti Barrage in the morning, cops continue to keep their eyes wide shut. On Friday, TOI found school vehicles flouting the one-way rule with impunity, putting lives of children at risk. No policeman was seen on the accident-prone stretch in the morning. TimesViewAfter the July 15 accident in which four children were injured due to their van driver’s negligence, the administration had announced a slew of measures to ensure safe transport for schoolchildren. From penalising vehicle owners and drivers to holding parents responsible for overloaded vans, a lot was promised. However, the administration is yet to do anything about traffic officials not doing their jobs. Their negligence explains why even DM’s specific orders have not been implemented.TOI caught on camera 17 school vehicles violating the one-way rule between 6.05am and 7.10am. Many of these were not painted in the mandatory yellow, had no grilles on windows, driver and owner information was missing as were fire extinguishers and school bag carriers. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Ugrasen Shukla, a morning walker, said heavy vehicles posed a greater threat to school vans, as they too entered the barrage from the wrong side in top gear. Nimisha Pandey of Gomtinagar said most of these school vans had no seatbelts. Jitendra Gupta, a retired government official, added that it was high time police acted against gross violation of road safety. On July 15, four children had been injured at Samtamulak crossing near the barrage when a school van in the wrong lane hit a roadways bus. The driver was also found to be lacking in required experience. Traffic ASP did not respond to calls from TOI.

column2: LDA to moot green belt around homes
column3: LUCKNOW: Making provision for a green belt around your new housing unit may get you a discount of 10% on the map approval fee and other charges levied by Lucknow Development Authority (LDA). Officials said a proposal on the same would be tabled in the annual budget of LDA on July 30. If cleared, both individuals and developers will have to make provisions in the building map for an open area to plant saplings. The parameters of plantation will be decided at the meeting. “Developers coming for approval of building plans should make provision for planting saplings. They can do balcony or terrace gardening; vacant space for gardening in front of a housing unit will also be approved. In the process, they can earn a 10% discount on processing fees if the proposal gets a nod,” an official said. LDA officials will take around Rs 2 lakh from the developer as refundable security money during map approval. After construction of housing units, a reality check will be done to find out if the developer has planted saplings or not. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: High court summons LDA VC for contempt
column3: LUCKNOW: The high court on Friday found LDA vice-chairman PN Singh guilty of contempt of court in a case related to a retired employee. The court has summoned him on August 16 for framing charges. A bench of Justice DK Singh passed the order on the contempt petition moved by Suraiya Begum. The petitioner's lawyer BK Singh had submitted that the husband of the petitioner had retired in 2013. Before being regularised in 2010, he was a work charge employee. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.On a petition, the HC had on August 29, 2018, directed LDA to consider the services of her husband performed as work charge employee but that was not done, the petitioner stated. This was defiance of the court order, the high court said.

column2: DU professor booked for threatening Ghaziabad corporation officials
column3: GHAZIABAD: A Delhi University professor living in Vaishali has been booked for allegedly misbehaving with the chief engineer and threatening officials of the Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation (GMC). His grouse, police said, was that corporation officials had dumped garbage from a drain in front of his house. The man, identified as Ashutosh Gupta, is a resident of JJ Colony in Sector 9 of Vaishali. According to a complaint by Mahendra Pratap, a GMC official, around 12 noon on Wednesday, Gupta barged into the office and told officials that since several days, garbage had been lying unattended in front of his house, which was taken out from a drain by Moiniddin, chief engineer in the corporation. He also claimed that he was a professor in Delhi University. Top CommentBUT have the police looked into the matter... any person will do something like that only if filth is dumped outside his house and not removed for days.... if what the professor says is true... compl...Read MoreVinooSee All CommentsAdd comment“The professor also made a threatening statement that he will not spare any person if the official failed to clean the garbage lying in front of his house,” the FIR said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Umesh Bahadur Singh, SHO of Sihani Gate police station, said that on the basis of the official’s complaint, an FIR has been registered under IPC section 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace) and 353 (assault or criminal force to deter a public servant from discharge of duty).

column2: Ghaziabad man offers MNC job to woman, rapes her
column3: GHAZIABAD: A man allegedly raped a 22-year-old woman in Ghaziabad on the pretext of giving her a job on Thursday evening. The rape survivor said she met the person, identified as Ankur Tyagi, through her friend. Ankur from Ghaziabad had promised her a job at a multinational company in Noida, she alleged. Ankur is also a functionary of a political outfit, police said. “The woman, originally from Bulandshahr, lives in a rented accommodation in Sihani gate area with her cousin,” an officer said. According to the complaint, the man had called her to a hotel in Ghaziabad’s Sihani Gate area for a meeting, the cops said, adding that he made her consume a drink laced with sedatives. After she fell unconscious, the accused raped her. “I gained consciousness after almost four hours and found myself lying on the bed without clothes. I then approached police and filed a complaint against Ankur,” the survivor told TOI. The woman said, a month ago, she had quit her job in a private company in Noida. “I was looking for a job in Delhi-NCR, when a friend gave me Ankur’s mobile number saying he would help me. He then offered me a lucrative job in a Noida-based multinational firm and asked me to meet him on Thursday when the incident happened. He offered me a soft drink, which I had and fell unconscious,” she added. Based on the complaint filed by the woman, an FIR has been registered against the accused under Section 376 (punishment of rape) of the IPC, said SP (city) Shlok Kumar. “Police are investigating the matter and CCTV footage of the hotel has been obtained. No arrest has been made so far,” Kumar added.

column2: Two corridors to ease traffic flow in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) will take up two corridors to ease congestion as part of a traffic mobility plan suggested by the Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) in a report. “The CRRI had suggested amendments on five most congested corridors. After inspection, we plan to work on two such corridors, including the 5-km Hapur road, which will extend from the GDA office in Navyug Market to NDRF office, and the 3-km GT Road stretch from Thakurdwara to Opulent Mall through Choudhary Mor (junction),” said V N Singh, chief engineer, GDA.
