column2: UPSRTC bus rams railing on UP highway and topples over, 30 hurt
column3: KANPUR: Nearly 30 people were injured on Friday after Kannauj-bound UPSRTC bus hit the railing on the state highway and fell into a culvert near Arjunpur pulia under Indergarh police station in Kannauj on Friday morning. The bus was heading to Tirwa area of Kannauj from Delhi. The driver, who was allegedly overspeeding, lost control of the vehicle following which the mishap occured. The injured have been admitted to Tirwa medical college in Kannauj. “Nearly 45 passengers were travelling in the UPSRTC bus of Azad Nagar depot, which was heading towards Tirwa from Delhi. Thirty passengers were injured while 11 among them sustained serious injuries. The incident occurred at around 5.30 am. As soon as the local police received information about the accident, teams were rushed to the spot for rescue operation. The injured are undergoing treatment at Tirwa medical college,” said SDM, Mahendra Kumar Singh. According to the passengers, the mishap occurred as the driver was overspeeding. "We will ask the investigators to book the driver if he was at fault, the SDM added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Sloth bear surprise for experts in Mirzapur forests
column3: LUCKNOW: It was a delightful surprise for wildlife enthusiasts after a camera trap survey found the presence of sloth bears in Mirzapur forest division, a discovery that exceeded their expectations. The first-of-its-kind camera trap survey was done by an environment and wildlife research foundation based in the region. The sloth bear is endemic to the Indian subcontinent and is protected under Schedule (I) of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972. This means the bear has absolute protection and any offence will invite the highest penalty. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Vindhyan Ecology and Natural History Foundation (VENHF), that put up 15 cameras at about 50 points in three forest ranges, found at least 24 other wildlife species in the region. Many of these were protected animals not recorded in Mirzapur before this. These included leopard, Asiatic wild cat, rusty spotted cat, Indian wolf, Indian gazelle, blackbuck, peafowl, Bengal monitor lizard and mugger crocodile. Other important species recorded were striped hyena, jungle cat, red fox, golden jackal, ruddy mongoose and red jungle fowl.The survey was done from May to July in 2018. Now, the group has proposed to the forest department that a conservation reserve for sloth bear be declared in Mirzapur. “We have submitted our report, which we published this month, to the state forest and wildlife department. Through our report we also propose a conservation reserve in Mirzapur for sloth bear,” said Debadityo Sinha, one of the lead authors. The report has been co-authored by DFO, Mirzapur, Rakesh Chaudhary. The camera trap survey was done mainly in four of the eight ranges of Mirzapur forest division: Marihan, Sukrit, Chunar and some parts of Lalganj. “We are proposing the conservation reserve in these ranges. The total area of the reserve is about 408 sq km,” said Sinha. The National Bear Conservation and Welfare Action Plan, published by the Union ministry of environment and forests in 2012, has already recognized Mirzapur forest division as an important sloth bear habitat. The report highlighted a threat to the species because of mining and increasing anthropogenic pressures. It also showed the sloth bear population to be declining in the region. Wildlife census by the state forest department from time to time confirms the same. Wildlife estimates for 2011 and 2013 showed at least 46% decline. “Many of these animals are elusive and nocturnal. They may not have been recorded in the census because of their nature and behaviour,” said Sinha.

column2: When women took centre stage in Lucknow
column3: A play titled Ghazab Teri Adaa was recently staged at Bhartendu Natya Akademi. The play, written and directed by Prof Waman Kendre was inspired by the Aristophanes’ play Lysistrata in which women were shown opposing the war. The thought of doing this play came several times in the director’s mind in the last 32 years, but it only remained an aspiration for him. The recent global scenario of multiple wars though did not affect him directly, this insensitivity saddened him greatly. The two-hour-long play was performed by actors of the NSD Repertory Company and was a complete treat for theatre lovers in the city. A scene from the play Ghazab Teri Adaa staged at BNA recently (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) A scene from the play Ghazab Teri Adaa staged at BNA recently (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The plot of the play revolved around wives and mothers of a kingdom who sent their husbands and sons for wars despite knowing the consequences. The women in the play opposed the war after observing the cons of the war. They play concluded with all the women successfully persuading the king to not send his soldiers on the battlefield and that the war should end. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Dr Anil Rastogi (R) Faisal Siddiqui (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Dr Anil Rastogi (R) Faisal Siddiqui (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) "It’s a very good thing that such good plays are staged in the city, performed by artists from NSD Repertory Company," said theatre veteran, Dr Anil Rastogi. Theatre actor Shashank Awasthi, said, "I completely enjoyed the play. I wish more plays like these would be staged in the city." — Saad Abbasi (L) KK Agarwal (R) Mridula Bhardwaj (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) KK Agarwal (R) Mridula Bhardwaj (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Prof Suresh Sharma (R) Ravi Shankar Khare (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Prof Suresh Sharma (R) Ravi Shankar Khare (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shashank Awasthi (R) Shubhangi Gupta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shashank Awasthi (R) Shubhangi Gupta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shivam and Avijit (R) Dr Sima Modi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Shivam and Avijit (R) Dr Sima Modi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Basant Mishra (C) Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (R) Sukumar Tudu (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Basant Mishra (C) Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (R) Sukumar Tudu (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: Lucknow: Harassment FIR against paper leak whistleblower
column3: LUCKNOW: A senior resident of King George’s Medical University (KGMU) has lodged an FIR accusing the head of oral pathology and microbiology department of harassing her and her two colleagues. She has also lodged a complaint with the KGMU vice-chancellor who has constituted a committee to probe the charges. The harassment FIR was lodged on July 24, a day after HoD professor Shaleen Chandra submitted a complaint with the university administration accusing dean, faculty of dental sciences, professor Shadab Mohammad of leaking the question paper of an exam for selection of residents in his department. But, reporters came to know about it on Saturday when a committee formed by the varsity to probe the harassment called senior residents and the HoD to record their statements. The exam in question was held on July 21, but later cancelled after HoD Chandra lodged his complaint on July 23. He claimed that the paper was leaked on WhatsApp by the dean after procuring it from a teacher of his department. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The FIR lodged by the purported victim of harassment says that she, along with two colleagues, were in the residents’ room on July 24 when Chandra barged in around 9.30am, closed the doors, grabbed her hand and snatched her mobile phone. “He did the same with the others as well. He also snatched our laptops and other belongings. He used foul language when we refused to give passwords to our mobile phones,” it said. Speaking to TOI, the senior resident said Chandra told them that these things were being taken as evidence in the paper leak probe. “We went to the vice-chancellor who allowed us to take back our phones. Our other belongings are being kept in a sealed room,” she said. Her colleague said Chandra had hit her in August last year, but later apologised when she threatened to lodge a police complaint. The HoD rubbished the allegations and said they had been levelled because he exposed the paper leak. He said the residents submitted phones and other belongings voluntarily. “I have never misbehaved with any woman in my life,” he added. Dean Shadab, on the other hand, denied the charge of paper leak and said it was an attempt to malign his image. A five-member committee is probing the harassment charges while another five-member team is investigating the leak. Latest Commentit looks like residents are lying because one(hod)  has to be eccentric to behave that way with ladies . hod could easily confisicated their equipment without being physical or abusive.    blame the ...Read MoreModernSee All CommentsAdd commentKGMU proctor professor RAS Kushwaha said action would be taken against HoD Chandra if he was found guilty by the panel. If residents have made false charges, they’ll be punished too. Similarly, he said, action will be taken if charges of paper leak are established. Chowk SHO Pankaj Kumar Singh said they had recorded the statement of the three KGMU residents. “We are scanning CCTV camera footage to verify the charges,” he added.

column2: UP pushes 372 reforms to improve ease of doing business
column3: LUCKNOW: The foundation of the second groundbreaking ceremony that will kick off on Sunday was laid by 20 state departments, which worked in tandem to push through 372 policy reforms for improving ease of doing business in Uttar Pradesh. The reforms set the stage for launching 292 projects of Rs 65,000 crore as the ease of doing business index rose from 84.52% in 2017 to 92.89%. SkipSpeaking to TOI, chief secretary Anup Chandra Pandey said this would help the state to rise to PM Narendra Modi’s challenge of turning UP into a trillion-dollar economy. While inaugurating UP investors’ summit on February 21, 2018, Modi had asked UP and Maharashtra to compete for emerging as the country’s first $1-trillion economy. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Union home minister Amit Shah will be the chief guest at the event that will witness a star-studded gathering of top industrialists and investors. Most industrialists arrived on Saturday and attended a dinner hosted by CM Yogi Adityanath where he assured them full state support for investments in the state. Speaking to TOI, chief secretary Anup Chandra Pandey, who is also Infrastructure and Industrial Development Commissioner, said the ceremony is another step to power PM’s New India dream while justifying the motto ‘UP Powering New India’. With the second groundbreaking, nearly 25% of the leads generated investors summit will be launched, Pandey said. Around 1,025 MoUs worth over Rs 4.28 lakh crore were signed in February 2018. Even as UP has 14.2% share in national MSME sector, the proposed defence industrial corridor (DIC) in Bundelkhand region will mobilise the strength of large MSMEs, he said. “The government has already acquired 3,000 hectares of the total 5,000 hectares required to shape up the defence corridor. The defence corridor will spur economic activity in Bundelkhand and consequently boost UP’s gross state domestic product,” he added. A rigorous follow-up mechanism, including an online MoU tracker, was also put in place as one of the many initiatives for turning the MoUs signed at investors summit into reality, Pandey claimed. Meanwhile, Lucknow MP and defence minister, Rajnath Singh will be conspicuous by his absence as he is scheduled to leave for his Mozambique visit.

column2: Dengue patient count 10 in July, Lucknow civic body takes a nap
column3: LUCKNOW: Dengue has started taking the city in its grip this monsoon, but the civic body seems to be waiting for it to turn into a health crisis. The city has reported 10 dengue cases in July. However, fogging by the Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) is yet to pick up pace. Though officials claimed to have covered all eight zones in the past week, a TOI reality check found mosquito breeding grounds at many places. Residents also countered LMC's claims, saying no anti-mosquito drive had taken place so far. TimesViewLucknow Municipal Corporation needs to realise that prevention is better than cure. Rather than waiting for outbreak of the vector-borne disease, the civic body should proactively check mosquito population from rising by ensuring regular anti-larvae spray and fogging across the city. Senior officials should also take feedback from the residents to find out whether the plan to check mosquito menace is being executed properly or not.The civic committee, constituted on HC order after the dengue outbreak in 2016, had asked LMC to complete fogging of the entire city before monsoon. On July 9, municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi had said 16 vehicles - two each for eight zones - had been deployed for fogging and the entire city would be covered in a week. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.However, TOI found that garbage piles had choked drains and puddles formed after rain were serving as breeding grounds for mosquitos. Residents in many areas, including Indiranagar, Gomtinagar, Mahanagar, Niralanagar, Nishatganj, Daliganj, Chowk, Balaganj, Thakurganj and Husainganj, complained that no fogging had taken place. Triloki Narayan, a resident of Mahanagar's Sector A, said, "At least 15 people suffered from dengue in my area last year. LMC is waiting for it to turn into a health crisis this year too." Dileep Kumar of Niralanagar said fogging had not been done in their area. Siddhartha Shah, who lives in Paper Mill Colony in Nishatganj, said the LMC had not cleaned drains. "As a result, mosquitoes are breeding in puddles formed on the roadside. I lodged three complaints this month, but in vain. LMC health officer SK Rawat admitted that they had not been able to cover the entire city, as there was incessant rain in early July. "After that, the temperature was above 35°C when fogging is not advisable," Rawat said, seeking 15 days to control the menace.

column2: 3 minor Bengal girls rescued at Shahganj, abducters held
column3: LUCKNOW: Three minor girls kidnapped from West Bengal were rescued at Shahganj railway station in Farakka Express on Saturday. Two suspected traffickers were also arrested by RPF and handed over to GRP. Senior divisional security commissioner of Northern Railway, Lucknow division, Abhishek Kumar said he got a call from additional superintendent of police Dinajpur, Bengal, about the kidnapping of three minor girls who were being taken to Delhi by train. While Bengal police knew that the train had gone towards UP, the name of the train was not confirmed. Kumar immediately alerted his teams in Varanasi, Jaunpur and Shahganj, where trains from Bengal enter from. Around 50 trains were checked. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Railway official Sandeep Yadav in Shahganj traced the girls in the general coach of Farakka Express. The three were sitting together clutching their bags. The two ‘kidnappers’, Pappu Sarkar (22) and Pranav Sarkar (27), were seated next to them. The girls told RPF that they belong to different villages in North Dinajpur. They have been taken to a shelter home in Jaunpur. Additional SP of Dinajpur told RPF he would reach Jaunpur on Sunday. The team will then go to Lucknow for further proceedings. Deputy IG VP Srivastava said, “After the information, we alerted teams at major stations. After one hour of inspection, RPF recovered the minor girls. The men have been arrested by GRP.”

column2: 11 projects on cards for Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: The second ground breaking ceremony comes with a promise of an investment of Rs 2,041 crore for Lucknow. A government spokesperson said that 11 projects would be inaugurated for Lucknow which would provide employment to 1,970 people. SkipGarv Buildtech is investing Rs 700 crore and will generate 500 jobs. Companies of the Shalimar Group are investing Rs 569 crore in three projects and will generate 300 jobs. Pintail Company will invest Rs 350 crore and is expected to employ 350 people. Other projects include UP Hotel Ltd, Hotel Pradeep, and Concorde Control System. In the first ground breaking ceremony in 2018, seven projects were launched in Lucknow with a total investment of Rs 1,417.74 crore which created 5,240 jobs, a government spokesman said. These included PTC Industries which invested the highest amount of Rs 205 crore providing employment to 500 people. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Upload details of tax defaulters, says Ghaziabad district magistrate
column3: GHAZIABAD: The district magistrate has directed officials at sub-divisional level to compile and upload details of tax defaulters and the action taken against them by August 10. All tehsildars and the chief revenue accountants (CRA) will have to give an affidavit to the effect that no recovery certificate (RC) is pending. DM Ajay Shankar Pandey has decided to initiate departmental action against officials who do not comply with the order and fail to upload RCs. In case, RCs are found pending after August 10, officials may even face suspension, Pandey said. The initiative is aimed at recovering taxes from individuals who have been evading payment of taxes for many years altogether in connivance with departmental staff. It is being done to bring in transparency and curb malpractices. An inquiry by the DM revealed that in several cases wrong addresses were mentioned on the RCs to unduly favour the defaulters, while in other cases officials did not take any action after issuing RCs. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The data will have to be uploaded on computers at tehsil-level, but the cumulative information about the defaulters will be stored with CRA at district level. The DM said the data will be subsequently uploaded on the state government’s website. Officials will have to provide details of the defaulters like the date when RC was issued, tax amount, when it was received by the defaulter, name of the revenue clerk with whom the file is pending and the final action taken against the non-payer. A tehsildar said RCs are issued when dues of electricity, excise, entertainment, stamp, bank and others are not paid. An RC is also issued when a penalty imposed by a court is not recovered. Pandey said a list of all RCs where wrong addresses were mentioned is being prepared and it would be sent to the heads of the departments concerned.

column2: Woman comes to lodge FIR, Kanpur cop hears her relaxing in bed
column3: KANPUR: Kanpur police found themselves in an embarrassing situation after another video of a cop listening to the grievance of a woman while lying on a bed surfaced on social media. Senior officials told TOI that the video was one-and-a-half-month old and the sub-inspector in question was unwell on that particular day. In the video, sub-inspector Brijesh Shukla, posted at Panki Road police outpost, is seen listening to a woman's complaint while lying, making the complainant uncomfortable. Soon after the video came to light, circle officer, Kalyanpur, Ajay Kumar ordered a probe into the matter following which the cop was identified. "We have conducted initial probe and questioned S-I Brijesh Shukla. All other police officials seen in the video have also been identified. Investigations, however, revealed that the video was about one-and-a-half month old and the sub-inspector in question was taking rest as he had severe stomach ache on that day," CO Ajay Kumar said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A few days ago, another video of a police officer shaming a victim of molestation for wearing ornaments while going out was circulated on social media. Latest CommentMannerless Government Servants should be transferred or suspended.Abhay Kumar PradhanSee All CommentsAdd commentThe victim, along with her parents, had gone to file a complaint at Nazirabad police station of Kanpur. Read this story in Bengali

column2: IIT-Kanpur mulls super-speciality hospital & medical college
column3: KANPUR: After pioneering science and engineering, IIT-Kanpur is now set to become a leader in imparting medical education to students. This will be the first time in Uttar Pradesh that an IIT will be imparting medical education and conduct research in medical science besides offering courses in science and engineering. The IIT-K administration has proposed to set up a 500-bed super-speciality hospital and a medical college and has an estimated budget outlay of Rs 800 crore.  The institute’s authorities are preparing a detailed project report (DPR) which will be sent to the central government for approval. IIT-K authorities are hopeful that they would receive green signal from the government. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Deputy director, IIT-K, Prof Manindra Agarwal said, “A 500-bed hospital will be set up near Shivli end of the institute’s campus. The hospital will cater to the residents of Kanpur as well as the members of IIT-K community. The hospital will be set up on 20-acre land.” Prof Agarwal said that the students would be able to pursue courses such as MBBS, MD and MS. Once the project gets government nod and the hospital comes up on IIT-K campus, it would be one of the largest hospitals in the city equipped with modern medical facilities. The health centre at IIT-K provides medical facilities to the campus community but for major ailments or complications, they have to seek treatment at private hospitals in the city.

column2: Rain relief costs Kanpur power cuts, waterlogged streets
column3: KANPUR: With Kanpur receiving 435mm rainfall till now during the monsoon season, Saturday’s showers ended the city’s rain deficit. With just a couple of days left in July, the rain gauge is expected to record a higher reading. The average rainfall recorded in July in Kanpur is 365 mm. Chandra Shekhar University of Agriculture and Technology’s (CSUAT) meteorological department was earlier apprehensive that the city might receive scanty rainfall this year, but weather gods have been kind so far. Till Saturday 3pm, the rain gauge recorded a reading of 66.2mm In the month of July, Kanpur received its heaviest rainfall on July 6 at 79.4 mm. At 54.8mm, the city recorded its second highest level of rainfall on July 10. The rainy spell after July 20, commenced from July 24 when the rain gauge recorded was 21.6mm. On July 25 and 26, the rain gauge was 20.6 mm and 30.2 mm respectively. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Saturday’s downpour also led to waterlogging in and power outtage in several areas. Lanes in prominent areas like Swaroopnagar, Aryanagar and Civil Lines were flooded after the intermittent rains. The district administration said that rain had also taken a toll on the ongoing road repair work in the city and that the construction would resume only after the monsoon season concluded. The delay is likely to add to commuters’ problems, who are already struggling with pothole-ridden roads. Snapping electric wires led to marathon power cuts throughout the day. It took Kanpur Electricity Supply Company hours to restore the power supply. Weather experts predicted that rain is likely on Sunday too.

column2: GDA asks Vaishali societies to share renovation charges
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) has offered the RWAs of Mandakini and Alaknanda towers in Vaishali, which were declared ‘unfit to inhabit’ by Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation last year, to jointly fund renovation of the two dilapidated buildings. As per GDA, the cost of renovation of each nine-storey building will be about Rs 3.5 crore. As of now, 62 flats are occupied in Alknanda and 48 in Mandakini, of 79 apartments in each of the towers. The GDA says if both the RWAs agree, then it is also ready to construct new towers on the model of Tulsi Niketan. “The retro-fitting cost of each towers have been estimated at Rs 3.5 crore and we have suggested that the two RWAs and GDA bear the cost proportionately,” said VN Singh, chief engineer, GDA. “If this proposal is not accepted to RWAs, then we have suggested ‘Tulsi Niketan’ model under which that the two apartment buildings will be handed over to private builders who in turn will construct new ones after demolishing them, and in the intervening time, the occupants will be shifted elsewhere only to return after construction,” he added. GDA’s proposals, however, has found no takers in the two RWAs. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“In 2011, when GDA had given the possession there was no RWA, and it came into being only in 2015,” said Amit Kumar, treasurer of Alakhnanda RWA. “The entire handover process was botched up as GDA at that time had not fulfilled the basic facilities necessary for complete handover. GDA is wrong in bringing forth the argument that it is RWAs responsibility to maintain apartment.” Latest CommentGDA /its corrupt officers responsible for poor quality must bear the cost. Residents have already paid huge money towards its cost. Therefore it is responsibility of GDA to renovate.ASee All CommentsAdd commentUdyan Giri, RWA member of Mandakini Tower, demanded that GDA build new apartments on its own after demolishing the existing ones. “We do not subscribe to Jamia Milia Islamia report which says the buildings are ‘structurally sound’, we know that it is beyond repair and GDA needs to build new apartments or else we will go to court,” he said. During a safety audit conducted by Jamia Milia Islamia, it was found that the buildings were structurally strong “but required retro fitting and maintenance”.

column2: Government allows farm land lease for solar power plant, agriculture industry
column3: LUCKNOW: In a major push to boost investment and production as well as setting up of solar power projects in the state ahead of the ground breaking ceremony on Sunday, the UP government has made it possible to lease out agricultural land, so far prohibited, for agricultural purpose or for setting up solar plants. The new law permits lease of agricultural land for agricultural purposes for up to 15 years and for a solar project for up to 30 years. SkipThe change in rules will be highly beneficial for Bundelkhand where acres of land has been lying fallow as leasing was not permitted, said an official. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“It is not as if people were not leasing their land, but we have now formalised the system for financing and investment, and given a huge boost to solar projects,” the official said on the eve of second ground breaking where 292 projects worth about Rs 65,000 crore will be launched. The UP Revenue Code (Amendment) Bill, 2019, which has replaced an ordinance, was cleared by both Houses on Friday. The Bill could not be tabled in last Assembly session for some reason and had lapsed, forcing the government to bring an ordinance on March 10, 2019, an official said. The bill also eases the process of converting agricultural land to non-agricultural vide an amendment to section 80 which deals with land use conversion and has introduced a regularisation penalty in case someone purchases more than 12.5 acre agricultural land without prior permission from government. Till now, banks did not finance projects if the land use wasn’t changed while the revenue department refused to allow change of land use till work started. The amendment will allow application for land use change with minimum work carried out at the site. The other key development is introduction of a 5% regularisation penalty for purchase of more than 12.5 acre agricultural land for non-agricultural use. One cannot hold more than 12.5 acre land for agricultural purposes.

column2: Twin bins every 2.5km from August
column3: LUCKNOW: Come August, every neighbourhood in the city will have twin dustbin sets for segregation of wet and dry garbage, with Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) deciding to install around 5,000 new ones and replace 3,000 old or broken ones by the first of next month. The project, under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, is an extension of the programme started in January 2019 and will cost around Rs 2 crore. People will find the twin bins every 2.5km. Latest CommentDoes providing twin bins every 2.5 km will solve the waste problem?????? Has LMC also planned to ensure timely cleaning of these twin bins?????? There are twin bins installed just around 10 m from my...Read MoreHimanshu VermaSee All CommentsAdd commentThe decision to cover the entire city with dustbins under the door-to-door garbage collection programme was taken after the LMC performed poorly in the Swachch Bharat ranking. Among 404 cities in the country, Lucknow ranked 141. The city lost valuable points owing to negative marking for poor garbage management. According to LMC officials, under Swachh Bharat parameters, the city must have 9,000 twin bins. "Our attempt is to install 10,000," said an official. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Mulayam Singh Yadav daughter-in-law calls for apology
column3: LUCKNOW: SP patriarch Mulayam Singh Yadav’s daughter-in-law Aparna Yadav on Saturday disapproved of Azam Khan’s remarks on BJP MP Rama Devi during Lok Sabha proceedings recently and said he should tender an unconditional apology. “I just fail to understand why a politician of Azam Khan’s stature said what he said in the Parliament. There was neither any provocation nor there can be any reason whatsoever for a man of his oratory skills to say what he did,” Aparna said talking to TOI. “As a senior politican he is well aware of how one has to conduct himself in Parliament. Such statements do not go down well with his status and seniority,” she said.

column2: Sidharth Malhotra and Parineeti Chopra’s food trail in Lucknow
column3: Itishree.Misra@timesgroup.com  and Akash.Wadhwa@timesgroup.com A complete foodie at heart, actress Parineeti Chopra, who was in Lucknow on Saturday to promote her latest film with co-actor Sidharth Malhotra, had to literally control herself to not eat too much. When the two in fact, sat down for an exclusive tasting, arranged by Lucknow Times, of the several dishes prepared with famous Lakhnawi Dussehri mangoes, they did not waste time in tasting the wonderful dishes even while lamenting that their calorie count for the day was going for a toss. “It looks like a mango fest, what is this!” exclaimed Parineeti while eyeing the mango dishes. “So I am actually going to eat each and every dish made of mango! Seeing all these dishes only makes me so happy. Itne dinon se grilled veggies jo main kha rahi hoon, I actually want to try all these dishes. This mango drink looks like a martini...so cool. It is party time for us!” she said excitedly while Sidharth wanted to know all about the dishes and what they were and bombarded the hotel chef to tell him about them. “This spread looks amazing. Main toh aaj aam jaisa lag bhi raha hoon. But seriously, we shot in Malihabad but couldn’t have magoes then, thankfully ab khane ko mila gaya hai.” Having lost oodles of weight, Parineeti says she now doesn’t obsess over food as much as she used to. “I used to be a complete foodie but not any more. I eyed the food laid here and then I moved on. I think this comes with growing up. Most of my life I have actually not given my health or my body the respect that I should have. And I think that was one weakness that I needed to work on the most. Today I respect myself and fitness much more. Yes, you should have a cheat day but the lifestyle change should also come. Earlier I used to only look at taste, but now I look at tasty and healthy options. The wake up call for me was when I didn’t have the stamina to even shoot for four hours. I really became unhealthy. But I still have miles to go...”she says. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Jabariya Jodi is the third film Parineeti shot for in Lucknow. Ask her about the experience of shooting in the city so many times and she says, “I have such a huge sense of familiarity now with this city. My first ever solo film, Ishaqzaade was shot here. So obviously that instant bonding happens with the people and the place that you shoot at. To come back to Lucknow for Dawat-e-Ishq and then coming back again for Jabariya Jodi, has made Lucknow the Indian city which I have traveled to the most. After Mumbai, this is my most favourite city. There is a reason why so many films are being shot in Lucknow, because it is really-really Bollywood friendly. It really supports film shootings and so we actors also love coming back here. Even if we are shooting outdoors in Lucknow, we are fine because the crowd is always in control. I always know now that shooting in Lucknow is going to be a good experience. Even food wise, every time I come to Lucknow to shoot or to promote my film, I enjoy a lot of good Lakhnawi food.” Sidharth and Parineeti also feasted on baati-chokha in Lucknow (BCCL/ Pics: Aditya Yadav) Sidharth and Parineeti also feasted on baati-chokha in Lucknow (BCCL/ Pics: Aditya Yadav) For Siddharth, however, it was his first experience of shooting a film here. “It was my first time in shooting here and Lucknow gives you such a lovely texture of heartland India. We had shot for the film in different parts of the city and on different streets. So we pretty much utilised every part of the city in our film even though Jabariya Jodi is based in Patna. But because our producers found it very easy to shoot here, we shot in this city. And there are so many films being shot here. With this speed Lucknow will soon become the new Mumbai,” shared Sidharth. Parineeti Chopra in Lucknow(BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Parineeti Chopra in Lucknow(BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Recalling how she explored the city before the release of Ishaqzaade, Parineti says, “At that time I remember Ladies Versus Ricky Bahl hadn’t released and nobody really knew me. So after pack-up, I used to go out and roam around Lucknow. I have visited the Bada and Chhota Imambara, the malls, I used to go to Rumi Gate and have ice creams, I would just do all those normal things as a regular tourist. I have such amazing memories and pictures of that time. But now everything has changed. We are talking about all this seven years later. I have not really experienced Lucknow like that again. Now it is always going out in Lucknow as an actor with the security. I also remember shooting a lot in Residency where the people who work there knew me because we have spent so much time together,” she says, adding, “Lucknow is a really modern yet old city. It still has proof of all the Indian culture that was once there. The beautiful Indian monuments are still standing. It is amazing to see a city like Lucknow which has a blend of both the worlds.” Having shot three films in the city, Parineeti rues that she hasn’t got to play a proper Lakhnawi girl. “In Ishaqzaade, I never got to play a proper Lucknowite as it was a very modern character with a different accent, in Dawat-e-Ishq, I had a Hyderabadi accent, and in Jabariya..., I play a Bihari, so now I really wish to play a Lucknowite with a proper accent of this city.” Sidharth Malhotra in Lucknow (BCCL/ Pics: Aditya Yadav) Sidharth Malhotra in Lucknow (BCCL/ Pics: Aditya Yadav) Even Sidharth wishes to come back to the city soon. “Kudos to the state government for making Lucknow so shoot friendly. Even today we got to know that several actors are shooting for different films here. So it wouldn’t be a surprise if I came back here soon for another film. In fact, I’m sure I will,” shares Sidharth. Recalling the days spent shooting for the film in Lucknow Sidharth says, “Actually, I feel lucky about getting a chance to shoot in Lucknow, in this wonderful city. I’m really happy that we shot here in Lucknow. I missed Lucknow when I got back to Mumbai,” he adds. Several girl fans of Sidhrath came to meet him and also brought him gifts (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  The two shares that they have encountered several fan moments while shooting in Lucknow. “I remember how several fans used to wait outside our hotel for days till we met them as we used to leave for the shoot early in the morning and come back late in the night,” shares Parineeti, adding, “They would always try to catch us out side the hotel. So when one day, I wasn’t shooting while Sid was, I made it a point to meet them and sit with them for sometime. Lucknow fans showered us with so much of love,” smiles Parineeti, while Sidharth agrees with her. “I remember when we were shooting here there was this group of girls from the city who brought me a cake and had made collage of my pics. As an actor, that’s what you want. People’s love and appreciation and that we got a lot of from the people of Lucknow. Later, the actors visited a restaurant to have baati-chokha, the famous Eastern UP and Bihari dish. “This is so yum!” said Parineeti as she helped herself to one while Sidharth remembered how he had the dish when he bgean shooting for the film. “That was the first time in my life I had had litti-chokha and I had loved it then.” The two actors then met a few fans and had pictures clicked with them. Leaving behind and taking some good memories from Lucknow both Parineeti and Sidharth hoped that they would be back in Lucknow soon. — Itishree.Misra@timesgroup.com and Akash.Wadhwa@timesgroup.com

column2: Communal violence: Eminent persons must strive for harmony before writing letters
column3: In the first war of independence, or sepoy mutiny of 1857, Hindus and Muslims fought shoulder to shoulder against colonial forces. In the next 90 years, undivided India witnessed growing hostilities between Hindu and Muslim communities. It got bloodier after the 1920s. Communal riots in Nagpur and Mumbai in 1927-29 saw mobs lynch innocents. Communal lynching took a grotesque dimension in 1946. Muslim League's Direct Action Day state-sponsored lynching in Calcutta in August-September, followed by the bloody Noakhali carnage in October-November and a retaliation in Bihar. Over 15,000 people were lynched in these three incidents. The worst was reserved for 1947 when vivisection of the country resulted in displacement of 15 million. Frenzied communal mobs lynched a million, scars of which never healed. Since independence, both communities seldom spared an opportunity to bait, berate and engage in violence against each other at the slightest provocation, at the behest of intellectuals or preachers. Uttar Pradesh has historically been the country's communal cauldron. Intellectuals, who are worried by a spike in communal violence and intolerance today, must read Allahabad High Court's judgment in Mohd Ishaq Ilmi [AIR 1957 All 782]. It narrates how intolerance had already taken root even when the nation was in its infancy. Similar incidents continue to spark violence and further weaken the social fabric. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Ilmi was the printer, publisher and editor of Urdu daily 'Siyasat' in Kanpur when Bharatiya Vidya Bhawan, headed by K M Munshi, who was also then governor of UP, re-published a book written by two American authors titled 'Religious Leaders' in May 1956. It had "objectionable and provocative" passages on Prophet Muhammad. Ilmi started a religion-coated campaign against the book and continued with it even after Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan withdrew the book from circulation and Munshi published regret in newspapers. Continuous incitement by Ilmi's 'Siyasat' incensed Aligarh Muslim University students to hold demonstrations and shout slogans like "Hans ke liya Pakistan, Lar ke Lenge Hindustan' and 'Pakistan Zindabad'. Hindu students took out a protest march against such demonstration by Muslims. The protest march was attacked and a prominent Hindu was stabbed to death. Ilmi was taken into preventive custody to stop him from promoting communal hatred. The present 'Jai Sri Ram' chant appears to have taken a leaf out of Ilmi's Siyasat. Though the HC quashed Ilmi's preventive detention after putting a premium on his free speech and said he did not incite violence, it made a general statement, "It is a notorious fact of which we are justified in taking judicial notice that in cases where communal feelings have been exploited and communal frenzy has been worked up, violence has invariably resulted sooner or later whether such violence was advocated or not." These words still hold good for India and for intellectuals, who only look at the result and not the provocations over the years. Provocative statements leading to violence and counter-violence have become a way of life in India and part of right to free speech. Comments by the American authors about the Prophet led to communal violence in many places in UP in 1956. Salman Rushdie's 'Satanic Verses' got banned by the government to placate Muslims without caring for the author's free speech. When MF Hussain painted a nude woman, as a mimic of India's shape, and it was christened 'Bharat Mata', it catered to the secular thoughts of elites and evoked inviolability of right to free speech in judicial minds. Hussain fled India fearing reprisal. The SC came to his rescue on September 7, 2008, and termed the painting a "work of art". It had said, "Paintings are like a sculptures. None gets scandalised by looking at erotic sculptures." Can anyone explain the difference between the three cases - Ilmi, Rushdie and Hussain? A commoner, whose passion get easily aroused through provocative statements, will never understand. In Masood Alam [1973 AIR 897], the SC dealt with a case of a Muslim theologist who went to Pakistan in 1971 and returned home three days before the India-Pakistan war to launch a campaign against Aligarh Muslim University Bill and set up 'Youth Majlis' for training youth to use knives. Upholding his preventive detention, the SC had said, "It has to be borne in mind that when a person professing to be learned in religious theology encourages defiance of law in the name of religion, then ignorant and credulous people are more likely to be misled and swayed by religious passions and sentiments. Such activities naturally have greater potentiality for prejudicially threatening maintenance of public order." The SC has mostly blamed governments for the communal situation remaining in a state of boil. While dealing with the 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots, the SC in Mohd Haroon case [2014 (5) SCC 252] narrated how eve-teasing of girls of one community led to violence and counter-violence. Top CommentWith names like Unity, Peace these "intellectuals" have lobbied for the Nehru-Gandhi Dynasty since Independence. Fooled the Nation by pretending to fight for just causes all the time strent...Read MoreKrishan Kumar TotlaniSee All CommentsAdd commentIt had said, "Had central and state intelligence agencies smelt these problems in advance and alerted the district administration, the unfortunate incidents could have been prevented. Thus, we hold the state government responsible for being negligent at initial stages in not anticipating the communal violence and for not taking necessary steps for its prevention." Did any intellectual blame the then SP government headed by Akhilesh Yadav? In Tehseen S Poonawala judgment [2018 (6) SCC 72], the SC said, "There can be no shadow of doubt that the authorities which are conferred with the responsibility to maintain law and order in the states have the principal obligation to see that vigilantism, be it cow vigilantism or any other vigilantism of any perception, does not take place. When any core group with some kind of idea take the law into their own hands, it ushers in anarchy, chaos, disorder and, eventually, there is an emergency of a violent society." So, when 49 eminent persons, settled in various parts of India, seamlessly coordinate to produce a common letter conveying to the PM their fears over rising intolerance, a commoner would have expected them to make similar coordinated efforts to promote communal harmony. The same applies to the 62 other eminent people who authored a counter-letter. It is for all of us, especially those who make a lot of noise on social media on tolerance, to travel to the nooks and corners of the country and spread harmony to dispel hatred.

column2: Amit Shah hails Yogi Adityanath as CM at launch of 250 projects worth Rs 65,000 crore
column3: LUCKNOW: Hailing Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath as an able administrator who unshackled bureaucracy from political subservience, Union home minister and BJP chief Amit Shah on Sunday said the path to India's $5 trillion economy dream was being paved by its most populous state. " UP ke andar prashashan ka rajneetikaran itna zyada hua tha ki pardarshita kahin door dur tak nahi thi. Prashashan rajnetaon ko khush karne mein laga rehta tha-...Main kisi ka naam nahi lena chahta (There was no transparency in the UP administration due to politicisation of the bureaucracy. The focus was on keeping politicians in good humour. I won't take anyone's name)," Shah said at the launch of 250 projects worth Rs 65,000 crore, including investments by Vivo, Torrent Gas Pvt Ltd and Oppo Mobiles India. "I come from Gujarat, which has been holding investor summits successfully. But the speed with which the UP government has translated investment pledges has surprised me," Shah told an audience of industrialists that included Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani, Tata Sons' chairman N Chandrasekaran, Samsung India president HC Hang, Torrent chairperson Sudhir Mehta, Medanta chairman Naresh Trehan, HCL chairperson Shiv Nadar and PepsiCo India Holding's Ahmed ElSheikh. PepsiCo, Adani Group and Medanta announced their intention to start new projects in the state. "Just like the road to the prime minister's chair passes through UP, the goal of achieving a $5 trillion economy also passes through UP," the home minister said.

column2: Owners away on Rajasthan vacation, burglars strike at Chinhat home
column3: LUCKNOW: A group of burglars struck at a railway clerk's house and made off with jewellery worth Rs 7.5 lakh in Malhaur, under Chinhat police station, late Saturday night. Police said that the burgled home belonged to Deepesh Kumar (37) and he was posted as a senior clerk at Charbagh railway station. Deepesh and his family had left for Rajasthan on July 23. His brother-in-law Sandeep Verma, who lived in the same street, used to sleep in the former's house at night while the family was away. Police said when Sandeep reached Deepesh's home around 11pm on Saturday, he found that the lock on the main door was broken. Deepesh and his family were on their way back when they were told about the burglary. They reached Lucknow around 4am. In his absence, Sandeep lodged a complaint on Sunday. Deepesh told TOI, "The burglars decamped with silver and gold jewellery worth Rs 7.5 lakh along with an LED television. There is a CCTV camera installed in my neighbour's house and the footage showed a man loitering around my home several times over the days." He added that when Sandeep was passing by his home around 8.30pm on Saturday, he too saw the man standing behind the house. "However, he fled when he saw Sandeep coming," he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Sub-inspector (Chinhat) Amit Kumar Singh said, "An FIR has been lodged and we are scanning the CCTV footage from the area to."

column2: Kanpur woman, lover held for killing husband in Mumbai
column3: KANPUR: A 22-year-old woman from Kanpur Dehat took her husband of two months to Navi Mumbai on the pretext of a better job and killed him with the help of her childhood sweetheart. Preeti Rathore and her lover, Gaurav Singh (22), also a native of Kanpur Dehat, were caught red-handed on July 22 after they smothered Hari Om (27) with a pillow and slashed his throat at a rented chawl room in Panvel. The two have confessed to the crime and are currently in judicial custody. Kanpur Dehat police are likely to seek their transit remand. Preeti married Hari on May 6. “The marriage was against her wishes and she hatched a plot with her lover to kill my brother,” said Shiv Om , Hari’s brother. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Kanpur Dehat ASP Anoop Kumar said Preeti had been in a relationship with Gaurav since schooldays. As Gaurav belonged to a different caste, Preeti was afraid to tell her family. “The lovers plotted the murder in Kanpur and executed it in Mumbai. The plan was simple: eliminate Hari and elope.” Preeti had fights with her in-laws after marriage and she convinced her husband that they needed to move out of Kanpur. On July 20, she introduced Hari to Gaurav, saying the latter was her friend’s brother and worked in Navi Mumbai. The trio reached Panvel on July 22 morning and Gaurav helped the couple find a room. When Hari was enjoying a siesta that day, Preeti pressed a pillow against his face while Gaurav slit his throat with a kitchen knife borrowed from a neighbour. Hari’s muffled cries before he succumbed to the wound alerted a few neighbours who stopped the lovers from fleeing and alerted the police control room. Gaurav, initially, tried to cook up a suicide story but broke down during interrogation. He and Preeti were arrested by night.

column2: Kanwar yatra: Restrictions for vehicles from Noida to Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: With hundreds of kanwar pilgrims thronging the roads, the Ghaziabad traffic police have suspended the entry of vehicles from Noida to Ghaziabad on one of the lanes of New Link Road that connects to GT Road. “However, the opposite lane of this stretch is open for commuters,” superintendent of police (traffic) S N Singh told TOI. Singh said that the traffic diversion will be applicable from Monday (July 29) to Wednesday (July 31) and if the movement of kanwariyas increases in the next few days, the traffic police will ban vehicular movement on the other lane too and reserve it for the yatris. “This step has been taken for the safety of kanwariyas. The diversion is in place to reduce the chances of an accident,” he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The officer said commuters coming from Noida and heading towards Ghaziabad can also take other routes like the elevated road via NH-9. This road can be taken for those going towards Raj Nagar Extension or Meerut, he added. Top CommentMost of these are hooligans and criminal who resort to violence and abuse common man. They violate traffic rules, smoke weed and drink in the name of God. Only 10% of them are actually Kawariya. Who ...Read Morecontact ChaudharySee All CommentsAdd commentCommuters, meanwhile, have been facing trouble due to several diversions that have been put in place for the kanwar season. Rakesh Singh, who is from Raj Nagar Extension, said there are snarls on the NH-9 route. “Heavy vehicles moving from Delhi towards Bulandshahr and Haridwar have been diverted to NH-9 via UP Gate. Now, another diversion will increase congestion. Also, there is traffic due to the construction work going on at NH-9 going on since last year,” he added. Massive security and traffic arrangements have been put in place in Delhi for the movement of kanwariyas. An advisory has been issued on vehicle movements at Apsara border, Shahdara flyover, Seelampur T point, ISBT flyover, Boulevard Road, Rani Jhansi Road, Faiz Road, Upper Ridge Road, Dhaula Kuan and NH 8.

column2: Rae Bareli mishap: Akhilesh Yadav demands CBI probe, alleges conspiracy to murder Unnao rape victim
column3: LUCKNOW: Samajwadi Party national president Akhilesh Yadav on Sunday demanded a CBI probe into the Rae Bareli road accident alleging that it could be an attempt to kill the Unnao rape survivor. The statement came hours after the accident in which the rape victim and her lawyer, Mahendra Singh, were critically injured while her aunt and another woman relative were killed when a truck crashed into their car on NH-31. "There is a strong possibility of conspiracy to murder the victim due to which the investigation of the murder should be handed over to the CBI. This is an another example of jungle raj in the state and only a central agency should be entrusted with the task of probing the accident case," he said. "We offer our condolences to the grieving family. We want the government to provide proper treatment and round-the-clock security to injured victim,” he said. column2: Yogi Adityanath ended politicization of bureaucracy, says Amit Shah
column3: LUCKNOW: In a big push to the UP government's industrialisation effort, 290 projects of Rs 65,000 crore were launched by Union home minister Amit Shah at the second groundbreaking ceremony in the state capital on Sunday. The government also said projects of Rs 62,499 crore are in the pipeline. Shah hailed CM Yogi Adityanath as an able administrator, who ended politicization of bureaucracy that marred development of the state before BJP came to power in 2017 The mega event saw participation of noted industrialists, including Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani, Tata Sons' chairman N Chandrasekaran, Samsung India president HC Hong, Torrent Group chairman Sudhir Mehta, Medanta CMD Naresh Trehan, HCL founder-chairman Shiv Nadar and PepsiCo India Holding's Ahmed ElSheikh. While all congratulated the state government for providing a conducive environment for industry, PepsiCo, Adani Group and Medanta expressed intent to set up new projects in the state. The second groundbreaking saw Vivo, Torrent Gas Pvt Ltd, Oppo Mobiles India kick off projects in state. This time, majority projects, 31% of the total investments, are focused on electronics manufacturing. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.‘New policies to boost data centre, retail trade’Vivo, for instance, has a project worth Rs 7,429 crore while Oppo is investing Rs 2,000 crore. More than 50% projects launched on Sunday will be coming up in west UP. Latest CommentThese include policies on electric mobility, data centre investment and retail trade.“When we came to power, we had to battle pre-conceived notions about UP. In these two years, we have wo...Read MoreS Palraj PalrajSee All CommentsAdd commentCongratulating CM Yogi Adityanath for his efforts at pushing industrial growth in the state, Shah said, “It’s believed the road to the Prime Minister’s chair passes through Uttar Pradesh. Now, the road to making India a $5 trillion economy also goes through UP. The state will become the first $1 trillion economy state in the country.” CM Yogi announced the government had already issued 16 sector specific policies to promote industries and three more are in the pipeline. These include policies on electric mobility, data centre investment and retail trade. “When we came to power, we had to battle pre-conceived notions about UP. In these two years, we have worked towards improving UP’s image. We have not just changed the law and order situation in the state, but provided facilities like 24x7 power supply. Industries that were about to leave when we came to power have stayed back and are keen to invest more. In 2018-19, UP’s exports grew by 28.18%,” the CM said. With the conclusion of the second groundbreaking, almost 25% of the MoUs inked at Investors’ Summit have been converted into projects on the ground. The summit saw around 1,025 MoUs worth over Rs 4.28 lakh crore being signed. In the first groundbreaking ceremony, held in July 2018, 81 units with a combined investment of Rs 61,847 crore were launched, generating about 2.13 lakh jobs.

column2: Building catches fire, 40 spend 2 hours on terrace
column3: GHAZIABAD: A short-circuit in electric meters installed in the basement of a four-storey building charred 18 cars and bikes and forced around 40 residents to spend tense two hours on the terrace. Four cars, two Bullets and 12 others bikes were charred by the time fire fighters reached Ambuj City around 1.30am on Sunday. The building has 15 flats, of which 12 are occupied. Among the residents who were stuck on the terrace was a two-month-old girl. Some, however, jumped to the terrace of the adjacent building. Latest CommentWell, keep ignoring how your RWAs loot your maintenance money and keep accumulating illegal wealth. As residents you should go and question what is done with firefighting system and ask them for at l...Read MoreSurinder GujjarSee All CommentsAdd commentResidents alleged that the fire brigade reached the spot almost an hour after the blaze had started. Sunil Kumar Singh, the chief fire officer of Ghaziabad, said they got information around 1am on Sunday. Three fire tenders rushed to the spot and douse the flames within two hours. JJ Pathak, a resident, said the fire started around midnight. “I got up and found that the house was full of smoke. Flames had engulfed the entire building and all the residents were going to the terrace. I took my two-month-old daughter to a private hospital as she could not breathe properly in the smoke. She is stable now,” he added. column2: UP beat Gujarat in turning MoUs to projects: Amit Shah
column3: LUCKNOW: Union home minister and BJP chief Amit Shah hailed UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath as an able administrator, who eliminated politicization of bureaucracy that marred development of country’s most populous states before BJP came to power in 2017. He also said the road to turn India’s $5 trillion economy passes through UP.“UP ke andar prashashan ka rajneetikaran itna zyada hua tha ki pardarshita kahin door dur tak nahi thi. Focus hi prashashan tha. Prashashan rajnetaon ko khush karne mein laga rehta tha...Main kisi ka naam nahi lena chahta (There was no transparency due to politicization of bureaucracy. Focus was on administration which was busy keeping politicians in good humour. I won’t take anyone’s name),” said Shah, while speaking at the second groundbreaking ceremony of 250 projects of Rs 65,000 crore. Shah said the Yogi government has turned bureaucrats into ‘janta ke sewak’ (helper of people), rather than ‘rajnetaon ke sewak’ (helpers of politicians). SkipShah said Yogi Adityanath has improved law and order situation, which was the biggest hurdle in investments in the state. “It’s not until law and order is improved that investments would come,” he said. He said before the 2022 assembly election, UP would become the No.1 state in the country in terms of infrastructure and development. “I can guarantee the state government’s focus has been on a host of sectors, particularly small-scale industries,” he said. “I come from Gujarat which has been holding investors’ summits successfully. But the speed with which UP government has grounded investment pledges has surprised me,” Shah told the host of industry captains. Shah said the Centre has set an aim of turning India into a $5 trillion economy, for which UP will have to play a crucial role. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Just like the road to prime minister’s chair passes through UP, the goal of achieving $5 trillion economy also passes through UP,” the home minister said. “We have already laid the foundation to achieve this target,” he said. Recalling the Vajpayee era, Shah said the country was 11th in global economy ratings. The situation did not improve during the UPA government. In last five years, the India has moved to 6th position, he said. Shah said when BJP came to power in 2014 then PM Narendra Modi began concentrating on a host of sectors. “Modi ji ne kaha tha pehle jo sarkarein aayi thi woh sarkar chalane ke liye aayi thi..hum desh ko badalne ke liye sarkar chalayenge (Earlier, political parties would form a government for the sake of running a government. We formed government to change the country and the people’s perception about it,” Shah said.

column2: Industry honchos vow investments and projects in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government’s attempts to bolster the investment potential of Uttar Pradesh received a boost when several industrialists pledged new projects during the second ground breaking ceremony on Sunday. CEO of PepsiCo India Ahmed ElSheikh said the company would like to invest Rs 514 crore in the state over the next three years. The new investment plan is in line with PepsiCo’s goal to double its snacks business in the country by 2022. The company is expected to help create over 1,500 direct and indirect jobs,” he said. The plant is set to come up in Mathura and will be ready by 2021. Torrent Group chairman Sudhir Mehta announced that his company was keen on investing more than Rs 3,000 crore in establishing gas pipelines and CNG stations across the state. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Meanwhile, Tata Sons is on the verge of signing a final agreement with the state government for setting up a 30,000-people TCS centre. Its chairperson N Chandrasekaran recalled the time when the company was about to exit UP, the news of which got chief minister Yogi Adityanath really “worked up”. “At that time, we made a commitment to him to not leave and have since continued expanding in the state,” he said. Medanta Group CMD Dr Naresh Trehan also announced his plan for setting up three new hospitals in Gorakhpur, Varanasi and Allahabad. The company will be inaugurating a 1,000-bed hospital in Lucknow on October 15 which will generate about 13,000-15,000 jobs. Its 700-bed facility in Noida was part of the ground breaking ceremony. “As soon as work on it starts, I will return for permissions for other three hospitals,” Trehan said. Flipkart Group’s chief executive officer Kalyan Krishnamurthy did not offer details of the company’s proposed investment in the state but said that UP would play a crucial role as the company sought to bring in 200-300 million customers within its network. “We want to connect lakhs of MSME suppliers, small farmers and farmer-producer organisations to marketplace while creating lakhs of new livelihood opportunities,” he said. Rajneesh Kumar, Flipkart’s chief corporate affairs officer, said the company was keen on promoting MSMEs and one-district-one-product (ODOP). Samsung India president HC Hong spoke about the world’s largest mobile manufacturing factory it opened up in Noida in 2018 and said it would aim at making 10 million phones by 2020. “We want to make Noida factory an export hub,” he said.

column2: Industry honchos vow investments and projects in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: The state government’s attempts to bolster the investment potential of Uttar Pradesh received a boost when several industrialists pledged new projects during the second ground breaking ceremony on Sunday. CEO of PepsiCo India Ahmed ElSheikh said the company would like to invest Rs 514 crore in the state over the next three years. “The company plans to set up a greenfield snacks manufacturing plant in Uttar Pradesh. The new investment plan is in line with PepsiCo’s goal to double its snacks business in the country by 2022. The company is expected to help create over 1,500 direct and indirect jobs,” he said. The plant is set to come up in Mathura and will be ready by 2021. Torrent Group chairman Sudhir Mehta announced that his company was keen on investing more than Rs 3,000 crore in establishing gas pipelines and CNG stations across the state. The company had signed MoUs worth Rs 6,000 crore during the 2018 investors’ summit and has already rolled out projects for half that amount.
